Chapter One: Waiting for a new period of reform and the resumption and re-establishment of the correct route 
I. Birth of political reconciliation atmosphere in hesitant progress 
During the transition from 1976 to 1978, the political reconciliation atmosphere was mainly realized through the restoration of Deng Xiaoping's leadership, the resumption of college entrance examination system, and the reversal of Tiananmen incident.
1. Restoration of Deng Xiaoping's leadership and reversal of Tiananmen incident 
After the disintegration of "Gang of Four", although the political forces supporting the "Cultural Revolution" were overthrown from the highest level of the central government, the party and national leadership that was related to the future and fate of China after the "Cultural Revolution" did not yet achieve decisive progress.
Before Mao Zedong's death, Hua Guofeng was appointed to succeed him, and subsequently served as Chairman of the Communist Party of China, Chairman of the Central Military Commission, and Premier of the State Council. Relying on the Central Politburo, he executed the will of the people and took decisive measures to crush the "Gang of Four," thereby ending the "Cultural Revolution." During the process of crushing the "Gang of Four," Hua Guofeng played a significant role, given his position in the central leadership core. The masses were thrilled and celebrated together.
At the outset of the decimation of the "Gang of Four," Hua Guofeng took steps to reveal and criticize the "Gang of Four" in order to solve problems and stabilize the situation, earning the support of the Party and the public. The nation began to thoroughly investigate the "Gang of Four" and their factions in various regions, restoring normal production and work orders, and working to revitalize the national economy, which yielded noticeable results. However, there was a conflicting issue that was not resolved very well at the time: on one hand, they were exposing and criticizing the "Gang of Four," and on the other hand, they were keen on limiting the rectification of the damage caused by the radical left line of the "Gang of Four," especially not allowing to touch on Mao's late-year mistakes. This effectively slowed the rectification of miscarriages of justice during the "Cultural Revolution," and some major issues were obstructed.
As early as October 26, 1976, Hua Guofeng spoke to heads of central propaganda departments, stressing that all Mao's teachings and remarks should not be criticized. On November 18, Wang Dongxing mentioned at the Central Propaganda Work Conference that Mao had already made a decision on the issue with Deng Xiaoping, and that anything Mao had discussed and indicated could not be wrong. On February 7, 1977, the editorial "Learning Documents Well and Grasping Essentials" indicated the two guidelines to follow: adhere to any decision made by Chairman Mao and follow any instruction given by him. Furthermore, there were strong calls for Deng Xiaoping to return to his work and for the April 5th Movement, in which the public mourned for Zhou Enlai and denounced the "Gang of Four," to be rehabilitated. Given the public sentiment, Hua Guofeng declared that "Deng Xiaoping will resume his work at the right time." In July 1977, the Tenth Central Committee of the Communist Party decided to restore Deng Xiaoping's work and position. 
The April 5th Movement needed to be redressed after Deng Xiaoping's reinstatement. However, the political status of the participants of the April 5th Movement in Tiananmen Square, who were suppressed with Deng Xiaoping, remained unclear. Thus, there was a spontaneous movement among the public to rectify the Tiananmen Incident. The efforts of the society led to the eventual rectification of the Tiananmen Incident. 
Until November 14, 1978, with the approval of the CPC Central Committee, the expanded meeting of the CPC Beijing Municipal Committee officially passed the decision to rehabilitate the Tiananmen incident, and it was announced in the Beijing Daily on the 15th: "On the Qingming Festival in 1976, the masses went to Tiananmen Square to mourn our beloved Premier Zhou, entirely due to their boundless love, nostalgia, and deep sadness for Premier Zhou, fully reflecting their deep hatred for the heinous crimes of the 'Gang of Four'. It reflects the aspirations of hundreds of millions of people in the country, and is entirely a revolutionary action. Those comrades persecuted because of this should be vindicated and their reputations restored." However, such a nationwide incident merely publishing the rehabilitation decision in local newspapers is clearly not enough.
Zeng Tao, president of Xinhua News Agency, Hu Jiwei, editor-in-chief of People's Daily, and Yang Xiguang, editor-in-chief of Guangming Daily, sharply noticed this report, extracted this paragraph from the article and released it as a separate news story, with the headline "CPC Beijing Municipal Committee announces 'Tiananmen incident' is a revolutionary action", which instantly elevated the significance of the news. It is worth mentioning that when Xinhua issued this news, it did not seek approval from the Central Politburo or report to any of its standing members. Afterwards, even Hu Yaobang said to Hu Jiwei: "You didn't notify me about such an important matter?" Zeng Tao and others at the time thought it was better not to ask for instructions and let Xinhua take responsibility. Everyone appreciated Zeng Tao’s courage and determination.
After the discussion by the Standing Committee of the Central Committee, Hua Guofeng announced at the Central Working Conference then in session on behalf of the Central Committee: "The Tiananmen incident is a completely revolutionary mass movement and should fully and openly redress the Tiananmen incident." Since then, the "Tiananmen incident" has finally been vindicated.
2. Beginning to Redress Individual Miscarriages of Justice
During the "Cultural Revolution" period, it led to a large number of miscarriages of justice, involving a considerable social group within and outside the party nationwide who were wronged but denied justice, whose basic political rights, working rights and basic livelihoods were not guaranteed. Therefore, after the downfall of the "Gang of Four", the most direct and urgent call of the whole society was to quickly redress the miscarriages of justice. This became a fervent hope and strong desire for all social strata including the heavily persecuted leaders at all levels.
In July 1977, the Third Plenary Session of the Tenth CPC Central Committee decided to restore Deng Xiaoping's leadership, indicating an obvious political rationality. The political report at the Eleventh Party Congress in August pointed out: "Remaining issues from past cadre reviews should be handled seriously and promptly. Those who are able to work but haven't been assigned jobs should be offered work without delay. Older and weaker members unable to work should also be well taken care of. For the minority who need conclusions from the review, it should be done as soon as possible. The slanders imposed by the 'Gang of Four' should be debunked." These important signals marked the starting point for further historical clarifications. In the hearts of those unliberated, the light of hope for their own, or familial and kinship, fate and future began to ignite, and it burned brighter and brighter.
Hu Yaobang, then the standing deputy principal of the CCP Central Party School, had been pondering on how to speed up the redress of miscarriages of justice and implement cadre policies. On October 7, 1977, the People's Daily published an article titled "The cadre line reversed by the 'Gang of Four' should be corrected", which was written with the support of Hu Yaobang. The article pointed out that some comrades, especially those working as cadres, due to the influence of the "Gang of Four", have not been effective in implementing the party's cadre policy, a major issue. As a result, some cadres who are aware of the line and capable of working have not been assigned jobs, many cadres under review have not received correct conclusions, and some bad elements mixed in the cadre team have not been dealt with. These all indicate that implementing the party's cadre policy is still a serious battle task.
The article emphasizes the courage to break through resistances and overthrow the slanderous words and incorrect conclusions imposed by the "Gang of Four" on many cadres. This article has caused widespread social resonance, and the central relevant departments received more than 10,000 letters from cadres and the masses within more than a month, all expressing agreement with the viewpoints and measures proposed in the article. The People's Daily also continued to publish commentaries on the implementation of cadre policies, excerpted some letters from the masses, and reported on the implementation of cadre policies in some areas. This further stirred people's emotions to rehabilitate grievances, and they strived to resolve the issue as soon as possible through various forms such as petitions and appeal letters.
However, the implementation of cadre policies and the work of redressing unjust, false and wrong cases still encounter significant resistance. On the one hand, in the organization departments of the central and some regional units, there are people from the "Gang of Four" or those influenced by them who always find various excuses to shirk and fail to seriously implement the party's cadre policy. On the other hand, many people are still fearful and worried that addressing the lingering issues in the review of cadres, especially correcting those wrong cases, will negate the achievements of the "Cultural Revolution". A typical example is former Shandong Provincial Party Secretary Shu Tong went to the Central Organization Department to request the implementation of policies and job allocation, but was blocked by the head of the Organization Department at the time, who even refused to let him stay at the Organization Department's guest house. There were more than 6,000 cadres like Shu Tong who were "hung up" and "sidelined" in central and national organs. They kept petitioning, but all to no avail.
This incident greatly affected Hu Yaobang, and it reaffirmed his determination to push for the implementation of cadre policies. "If we don't go to hell, who will", borrowing a line from Dante's Divine Comedy, Hu Yaobang said: "Our saying is: If we don't go into the frying pan, who will!" We are at a crucial moment of resisting a new force of typhoon. Since we have taken a firm step, we will never retreat and strive to expand the breakthrough that has been opened. Hu Yaobang analyzed that it seems that to really solve the cadre problem, we still have to go through many difficulties, and we need to make up our minds and break through one after another. He organized Comrades from the Central Party School to write the second manifesto: "Chairman Mao's Cadre Policy Must Be Seriously Implemented", condemning behaviors similar to stubbornly adhering to the wrong organizational line.
At this time, veteran comrades like Ye Jianying, Deng Xiaoping, and Chen Yun also believed that the leadership of the organization department must be strengthened, some organization departments must be adjusted and replenished, and they strongly recommended Hu Yaobang to serve as the head of the Central Organization Department.
Hu Yaobang took office at the Central Organization Department on December 15, 1977. At 8 o'clock in the morning, the crowd in the courtyard of the Organization Department was excited, firecrackers were launched, and all the staff sincerely welcomed the arrival of the new minister. This lively scene reflects the strong desire of the vast number of cadres and the masses to completely redress unjust, false and wrong cases. Afterwards, the number of visits and letters to the Organization Department increased daily. In January 1978, there were up to several hundred visitors a day, and appeal letters up to six sacks. Some letters even directly wrote Hu Yaobang's name.
With the support of veteran comrades such as Deng Xiaoping and Chen Yun, Hu Yaobang, who joined the Chinese Workers' and Peasants' Red Army at the age of 14, bravely broke through the various restrictions and taboos set by the "two whatevers", and vigorously organized and led the Central Organization Department to implement cadre policies and redress a series of urgent tasks of unjust, false and wrong cases.
At the first work meeting after joining the Central Organization Department, Hu Yaobang proposed that it is the inescapable responsibility of the organization department to redress wrongful cases and implement cadre policies. He said: Only during the "Cultural Revolution", major cases such as the Tiananmen Incident, the "61 people" issue, the Peng Dehuai Case, the Tao Zhu Case, the Wang Renzhong Case, the Inner Mongolia "Inner Party" issue, northeast's so-called "Traitor Group" issue, Xinjiang Ma Mingfang and other "Traitor Group" issues, the supposed "counter-revolutionary" cases of pleading for Liu Shaoqi and "viciously attacking the great leader", "viciously attacking Deputy Commander Lin", were beheaded, and it was unclear how many victims were involved. Before the "Cultural Revolution", there were successive political movements, and some wrongful cases before the founding of the New China, including wrongful cases in the Central Soviet Area in the 1930s, were referred to as "a mountain of accumulated cases", and the current situation of the Organization Department is "difficult to step forward".
Hu Yaobang clearly stated that to clear up and implement policies for the wrongful cases since the founding of New China and during the "Cultural Revolution" is the primary task of the organizational department. As for the historical issues left over before the founding of New China, whether they were not resolved or not completely resolved due to historical conditions or the impact of war, we should also resolve them completely. No matter how difficult it is, we must have the determination to "surmount the top". He also greeted the people present: If old comrades who have suffered injustices come to me in the future, I will meet and talk with them, please do not stop anyone; all envelopes written with "Hu Yaobang", please send them to me in time, if there is no expression from me, I hope no one will take the initiative to handle it, and even less withhold it.
According to statistics, the Organization Department of the Central Committee received 391,363 cases in 1730 volumes at that time, and 669 senior cadres were examined. Among them, 320 people were identified as having serious problems or contradictions between us and the enemy, accounting for 47.8% of the total number of people who were re-examined. Among these people, 213 were deputy ministerial level cadres, 71 were members and alternate members of the Central Committee, 10 were members of the Central Politburo, 10 were members of the Central Secretariat, and 7 were deputy premiers.
From March to April 1978, Hu Yaobang organized and instructed the Organization Department to hold workshops on difficult cases in the central, state organs and some provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the Central government. He personally participated in the discussion or made a speech, proposed handling opinions on hundreds of long dragging and unresolved difficult cases, divided policy boundaries, and proposed four standards for implementing cadre policies: (1) those without conclusions, Make conclusions as soon as possible, if the conclusions are incorrect, they should be realistically corrected; (2) those who have not been assigned work should be properly assigned work, and those who are old and invalid should be properly arranged; (3) those who have passed away should make realistic conclusions and do a good job of carrying out the aftermath; (4) Resolve the family members and children who are implicated. The overall policy is to seek truth from facts, and the method is the mass line.
Under the leadership of Hu Yaobang, the Organization Department has issued more than forty guiding documents and published more than a dozen articles in newspapers to liberate cadres and redress wrongful cases. It has published nearly 100,000 words of policy reviews in more than 30 issues on the "Organization Work Newsletter". During his days in the Organization Department of the Central Committee, Hu Yaobang was busy dealing with all kinds of incoming letters almost every day. On average, he dealt with 33 appeal letters from deputy hall and county committee secretary-level cadres every day, and the most one-day processed 200 letters. According to a cadre in the Organization Department, in this year alone, Hu Yaobang approved 902 letters for the Cadre Review Bureau to handle. Thanks to the unremitting efforts and meticulous work of Hu Yaobang and his comrades in the Organization Department, a considerable number of middle and high-level cadres' issues have been resolved and arrangements have been made for their work and life.
As Hu Yaobang said: "One justified wrongful case, the people are overjoyed." By July 1978, 5,344 cadres in the central and state organs had been assigned and arranged according to policy, accounting for 87.2% of the original awaiting distribution in the 53 units of the central and state organs, playing a leading role in liberating thinking and rectifying chaos. By August, among the principal leaders of 20 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities, 9 were found to have connections with the "Gang of Four" and were removed from office. This represents approximately a third of all primary leaders in these areas. The central government also made major changes to the leadership teams of 14 provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities, and 23 ministry-level executive departments. These changes played a crucial role in ensuring the stability of the situation, the recovery and development of the national economy, and the promotion of the struggle to expose, criticize, and investigate malpractice. 
3. Reinstatement of College Entrance Examination (Gaokao) providing equal development opportunities for the Youth 
On October 21, 1977, The People's Daily published news about the resumption of the college entrance examination under the eye-catching headline "Admission to University Is the Hope of the All People". The reinstatement of the "Gaokao" marked the beginning of the reform and development of Chinese education in a new historical era, and was also the prelude to the magnificent opening up reforms in the 1980s. By the end of that year, tens of thousands of educated youth took part in the examination. They carried years of accumulated knowledge from grassroots labor and had only prepared by briefly and hurriedly reviewing. Hearts filled with anxious excitement, they participated in and witnessed the first Gaokao after the "Cultural Revolution" that would change the era and the fate of a generation. That year, a total of 5.7 million people nationwide registered for the Gaokao, with an unprecedented age range from 37 down to 13. However, only around 272,000 were admitted. It was the most competitive year for the Gaokao since the founding of the People's Republic of China.
At the end of the year, many people, due to personal, family, or societal considerations, missed the opportunity of the first resumption of the Gaokao. Fortunately, the Gaokao was only partly resumed in 1977. In 1978, college admissions restored a unified nationwide exam, organized by the Ministry of Education, with provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities organizing examinations, grading, and admission work at local universities. As per Deng Xiaoping’s instruction, "The examination results of all candidates are to be announced at the same time as the list of those undergoing physical examination. The method of announcement is to be communicated to each individual by the admissions committee of the county (district)." Announcing the examination results was a crucial measure to increase the openness and transparency of the examination process. It played an important role in changing societal norms, eliminating the tendency to pull strings and show favoritism, and discourage corrupt behavior.
Because regular college admissions had been interrupted for a decade, more than 30 million youths and students across the country were eligible to apply. With colleges just recovering from the destruction of the "Cultural Revolution" and the availability of limited faculty and facilities for schooling, it was impossible to accommodate numerous students. In 1978, the Ministry of Education decided to restore and add 60 key colleges and 55 ordinary colleges and required all colleges to expand their enrollments by all possible means. As a result, in 1978, 6.1 million people nationwide took the Gaokao. 402,000 were admitted. Its unprecedented scale remains memorable for many people to this day. 
The once-suppressed tide of talent surged in an instant. More than 670,000 people were fortunate to step into the realm of higher education, and more than 11 million young people subsequently registered to take the Gaokao. This touched countless families, units, and social concerns, causing broad social impact.
With the abolition of the "Cultural Revolution" recruitment model for university students from workers, farmers, and soldiers, which was centered on power and origin, and adopted the method of "mass recommendation and leadership approval", the principle of unified examinations and admission on merits was implemented. They expanded the enrollment to recent high school graduates and young people from all walks of life who, in the past, could never even imagine having any opportunities. As a result of their own struggle, many of these people have transformed their lives. The phenomenon of "Blank Page Heroes" from the "Cultural Revolution" has vanished forever. The restoration of the college entrance examination has motivated a generation of young people to learn and instigated a mechanism for fair competition.
Though the revolt against the chaos was not fully carried out in 1977, many candidates were not admitted due to family issues. Candidates and parents, however, no longer remained silent and gave up. Instead, they went around to appeal for their rights, to fight for justice, which led to some problems being resolved. In response, the People's Daily published an editorial titled "The political review of college entrance examination must resolutely implement the party's policy", criticizing the inclination in the review of college students to focus primarily on their family and relatives' political history instead of the students' political performance. It pointed out that such biased and irresponsible practices were extremely harmful and seriously interfered with the implementation of the party's policy. With the deepening of the rectification of chaos in guiding ideology, the issue of overemphasizing the so-called "class line" in college admissions work has been resolved.
After the downfall of the "Gang of Four," there was a significant change in society - a climate of societal reconciliation was starting to form. This change was largely due to the gradual resolution of China's long-standing tense political relations. Not only was the college entrance examination fully restored, but at the National Science Conference in March 1978, Deng Xiaoping made the critical point that "Science and technology are not only productive forces but also a grand revolutionary force driving historical progress," reaffirming that the vast majority of intellectuals are already part of the working class. This overturned many years of "left-leaning" policies towards intellectuals. A "spring" that respected knowledge and talent had arrived, greatly inspiring intellectuals in every sector, including science, education, and arts. People commonly perceived a long-missed atmosphere of "reconciliation," accelerating the restoration and rebuilding of normal social order and lived routines, filling the society with vigor and vitality.
II. Theoretical Understanding and Breaking through Intellectual Resistance
The "Cultural Revolution" caused severe damage to the national economy and a significant disturbance in the field of ideology and theory. However, as the nation started to recover and build up the economy in 1977, economic theorists began to gradually clarify various erroneous ideas spread during the "Cultural Revolution" by criticizing the Gang of Four's fallacies on economic theory, gradually restoring the correct Marxist economic theory and the party's realistic thinking and correct standard for testing the truth, and correctly employing them in the process of socialist construction.
1. Major discussion on the issues of commodities, distribution, and distribution according to work in the economic theory community
Stalin's model of a planned economy is a highly centralized model. As a result, the commodity economy has always been in an awkward position in China. For many years, the commodity economy was seen as a capitalist phenomenon, even the most basic commodity exchange in rural markets was deemed as capitalism. Under this ideological guidance, the development of China's commodity economy was very restricted; the degree of commercialization of agricultural products was very low; industrial products could hardly meet the people's daily needs and couldn't provide enough machinery, fertilizers, and pesticides for agricultural development. The commodity distribution channel was singular; desired commodities were often obtained through a "supply" model, and some scarce commodities were acquired by means of a "coupon" model. This was a characteristic of a shortage economy under undeveloped commodity economic conditions. After the "Gang of Four" was smashed, in order to rid the dilemma of shortage economy, the first issue raised was to develop the commodity economy. In fact, to promote economic construction, it is necessary to develop a commodity economy. This requires stripping off the "capitalistic" shell attached to commodity production and distribution. 
On December 5, 1977, the State Council issued a "Notice on Holding a National Urban and Rural Commercial Dazhai Conference", which pointed out: the socialist commodity production and distribution have essential differences from that of capitalism. Our country is not producing too much, but too little. Under the coexistence of public ownership and collective ownership, socialist commodity production needs to be greatly developed. Only in this way can we strengthen the economic power of socialism, prevent capitalistic activities in towns and villages, and strengthen the material basis of proletarian dictatorship. We need to promote socialist production and the development of socialist commodity distribution righteously. Although this announcement carries the language characteristics of the time, like discussing the importance of commodity production and distribution from the perspective of "eliminating the activities of capitalism in urban and rural areas", it pointed out the essential differences between socialist commodity economy and capitalist commodity economy and proposed to boldly develop the commodity economy, which was of great significance at that time.
On July 7, 1978, Hua Guofeng delivered a speech at the National Financial and Trade Dazhai Conference. This speech, drafted by several comrades in theoretical circles and revised many times by Hu Qiaomu, analysed the relationship between economic development and supplying guarantees, essentially the mutual relationship of production, exchange, distribution, and consumption, which cannot be done without any. Production is the determining factor in the total production process, but exchange, distribution, and consumption also play a significant role in production, and the development of commerce was emphasized as a "powerful promoter" of agricultural and industrial production development. The speech had a great impact after it was published.
To promote the development of commodity production and circulation, the theoretical group of the State Council's Economic and Trade Group drafted a paper entitled "Refuting the 'Gang of Four's' Reactionary Fallacies Denigrating Socialist Productive Commodities", which clarified the proper understanding of socialist commodity production. The article pointed out that commodity production in socialist society must be allowed to exist and must be utilized to establish close connections between urban and rural areas. Only by vigorously developing commodity production and circulation can the varied needs of national construction and people's lives be satisfied. The vigorous development of the socialist commodity economy is a need for the mutual promotion between agriculture and industry. Although these arguments were still somewhat lacking, it was a significant step forward compared to previous absurd theories that viewed the commodity economy as a breeding ground for capitalism and that raising three ducks by rural members was socialist, whilst raising five was capitalist. 
After some progress in re-understanding the issues of commodity production and exchange, attempts to clarify the "leftist" influence on distribution according to work encountered many obstacles, because this involved Mao Zedong. As early as 1958, Mao Zedong saw wage systems, bonuses, etc., as the "bourgeois right" and believed these were a regression from the communist lifestyle in wartime, having attempted to restore the supply system. In 1974, when Mao Zedong met with Danish Prime Minister Poul Hartling, he said, "In summary, China is a socialist country. Before the liberation, it was not much different from capitalism. Now it still implements an eight-grade wage system, distribution according to work. These are not much different from the old society, the difference is that the ownership has changed." Regarding this, it can "only be restrained under the dictatorship of the proletariat".
The "Gang of Four" have greatly exaggerated the phrase "the distribution according to work has not much difference with the old society", and it has developed to the extreme. In 1975, Zhang Chunqiao and Yao Wenyuan separately published two articles, "On the Complete Dictatorship of the Bourgeoisie" and "On the Social Basis of the Lin Biao Anti-Party Group". They claimed that the distribution according to work is the bourgeoisie right, which is an important economic foundation for the emergence of new bourgeois elements, and can "only be restrained under the dictatorship of the proletariat." Because the article used Mao Zedong's speech, "breaking the bourgeoisie's right" seemed to have become a Marxist classic interpretation of the socialist distribution issue. At that time, all kinds of newspapers greatly publicized it, and the distribution according to work and the principle of material interest were thoroughly negated, which not only caused great confusion in theory but also brought many troubles to practice.
In January 1977, someone criticized Zhang Chunqiao and Yao Wenyuan by name. However, Wang Dongxing, who was in charge of propaganda work at the time, disagreed, arguing that these two articles had been read by Chairman Mao, so they could not be thoroughly negated, and could only criticize the wrong views in the article anonymously. This actually set a forbidden area for re-understanding the issue of distribution according to work. However, this did not prevent the discussion of the issue of distribution according to work from being carried out in depth. In February 1977, the Economic Research Institute of the National Planning Commission took the initiative, together with the Economic Research Institute of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, the National Labor Bureau, Peking University, and other units, to decide to hold a national economic theory discussion conference, starting with the criticism of the "Gang of Four" for their fallacies on the issue of distribution according to work. In April, the first discussion had the participation of over a hundred theorists from more than thirty units in Beijing. In June, the second discussion was attended by four hundred theorists from nearly a hundred units in Beijing.
In July, soon after Deng Xiaoping returned, he responded to the discussion in the economic circle. He said that the articles on distribution according to work are generally not bad, but he felt dissatisfied and did not dare to speak up. On August 3, Deng Xiaoping talked about the articles on the distribution according to work with Yu Guangyuan and others, saying that they were basically well written and valid, but a bit hesitant, and could be revised after discussion. He pointed out that there should be appropriate material rewards; those who work less get less, those who work more get more, make it clear. On August 8, Deng Xiaoping pointed out at a symposium on scientific education: talking about distribution according to work, it is nothing more than the more you work, the more you get, the less you work, the less you get, if you don't work, you don't get. From theory to practice, there are many specific issues to be studied and resolved. This is not only a question for the scientific and educational circles but also an issue for the whole nation.
"Work more, gain more; work less, get less; if you don't work, you get nothing" Deng Xiaoping, with his unique language, promoted the liberation of thought in the world of economics. On August 9, the People's Daily published an article refuting Yao Wenyuan's fallacy that distribution according to work produces bourgeoisie, and criticised Yao Wenyuan's article by name. From the end of October to the beginning of November, the economic circle held the third discussion on the issue of distribution according to work. In addition to more than 500 theorists from Beijing-based units, more than 300 theorists from 23 provinces, municipalities, and autonomous regions also attended, and more than 100 people gave speeches. The scale of the conference got bigger and bigger. Articles published in "People's Daily", "Guangming Daily", "Economic Research" and other newspapers are increasing day by day, and discussions in the economics field are gradually extending into the society.
From February 6 to March 5, 1978, the first session of the Fifth National People's Congress was held. The government work report clearly affirmed that "Throughout the entire socialist historical stage, the principles of 'He who does not work, neither shall he eat', and 'to each according to their labor' must be adhered to." It pointed out: In distribution, we should both avoid extreme disparities and oppose egalitarianism, implementing the practice of more work more gain, less work less gain. All the social teams must carefully implement the quota management and labor score system, enforcing equal pay for equal work regardless of gender. State-owned enterprise workers' wages implement a system that mainly relies on timing, supplemented by piecework, plus rewards. And for jobs with high labor intensity and poor working conditions, a post allowance is implemented. And the principle of distribution according to labor was incorporated into the constitution amendment approved by the conference.
According to Deng Xiaoping's opinions, the State Council Research Office organized the writing of an article on distribution according to labor. On March 28, Deng Xiaoping met with Hu Qiaomu, Deng Liqun, Yu Guangyuan and other leaders of the research office and said about the draft of the article: "I read this article, it is well written, it explains that the nature of distribution according to labor is socialist, not capitalist. Some places still need to be changed, connecting with the actual problems existing in the current distribution according to labor."
How to connect with the actual problems? Deng Xiaoping expressed some views that he formed through thinking:
According to the principle of distribution based on the quantity and quality of labor, when assessing the wage level of workers, the main factors to consider are their work performance, technical skills and contributions. The distribution problem can only be handled according to labor, not politics or qualifications. We implement a low-wage policy, which is a long-term policy. At present, the highest wage level for Class Eight workers is one hundred and several yuan. With the development of production in the future, wages should be gradually increased, the wage amounts for all levels should be increased. The wages of primary school teachers are too low now. A good primary school teacher, his labor is quite heavy, their wages should be increased. In the future, some primary school teachers who teach very well, their salaries can be rated as special class. Special classes should be set up in all walks of life to encourage people to engage in their own professions for their entire life.
An assessment system should be implemented. The assessment must be strict, comprehensive, and regular. All walks of life should do this. Rewards and punishments should be clear. Different remunerations should be given to those who perform well and those who perform poorly after the assessment. The bonus system should also be restored. Bonuses should be given to inventors and creators, as well as those who have made special contributions. Scientists who have made significant achievements can not only be rewarded for their inventions, but their salary level can also be increased. The fee system should also be restored and revised according to the new situation. There are many things to do in order to implement the principle of distribution according to work. Some problems need to be solved gradually through research and investigation. Some systems need to be restored and established. The overall purpose is to encourage everyone to make progress.
On May 5, after the personal review of Deng Xiaoping and Li Xiannian, The People's Daily published this article titled "Implementing the Socialist Principle of Distribution According to Work". The article comprehensively proved the socialist nature of the distribution according to work, elaborated on various types of labor compensation under the distribution according to work, and systematically cleaned up theoretical errors and confusion on the issue of distribution according to work. The article has aroused widespread social response. At the same time, it was also criticized by the leaders who advocated for "two whatevers". Wang Dongxing criticized this article at a small meeting, saying that it "actually points the finger at Chairman's thought". Deng Xiaoping believed that this was a Marxist article. He also told the person in charge of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences: We cannot give in on the theory, as appeasement will lose our principles.
In August, institutes such as the Economic Research Institute of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences held a special discussion on implementing the principle of distribution according to work in rural areas. Comrades from 17 provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities directly under the Central Government, and relevant departments of the Central Committee attended. The participants generally believed that the main trend in the distribution of current agriculture is egalitarianism. Some comrades urged that in order to manage well, we must adhere to the principle of material interest and let people care about their labor results from material interests. This principle, which could not be talked about in the past, must now be emphasized and applied in actual work. We should proceed from reality and not bind our minds to certain concepts. Some economists pointed out that over the past twenty years of cooperation, although the state has invested a lot in agriculture, agricultural production has not developed correspondingly, and this must be due to the production relations. To boost agriculture, it is necessary to strengthen the material foundation of agricultural production, but it is even more important to seriously implement the policies of equal exchange and distribution according to work.
From October 25 to November 2, at the fourth discussion on distribution according to work, the focus was on whether the combination of distribution according to work, commodity production, and money exchange can lead to the emergence of a new bourgeoisie. Most of the participants believed that socialism's distribution according to work, commodity production, and money exchange will neither lead to capitalism nor form a new bourgeoisie. Regarding this, some participants also explained with systematic social investigation that there isn't a new bourgeoisie that is produced by distribution according to work.
The discussion on the issue of distribution according to work at this stage is large-scale and long-lasting, mainly clarifying the following issues: (1) Distribution according to work is the distribution principle of socialism, and it is by no means a factor of capitalism. (2) The right to exchange equal labor in the distribution according to work is both an equal right and an unequal right. There is no hierarchy in the distribution according to work. Distribution according to work will not give rise to capitalism and bourgeoisie. (3) Bonuses and piece-rate wages are not revisionist things and should be restored. In the situation of rectifying chaos, the great discussion on the issue of distribution according to work has played a positive role in clarifying people's fuzzy understanding.
At the same time, the theoretical circle also criticized the "Gang of Four" for slandering the development of production as "solely focusing on productivity". A few consensuses have been reached through discussions: (1) Genuine socialism should be a higher mode of production than capitalism, and should create higher productivity than capitalism. Socialism is incompatible with poverty, and poverty is not the essential requirement of the socialist system. (2) Our country is building socialism in a relatively backward country in terms of productivity, and must take the road from poverty to wealth, making our country quickly prosperous and becoming a modern strong country of socialism. To achieve this goal, we can only rely on the development of productivity. (3) The real contradiction that China currently faces is still the contradiction between productivity and productive relationships. This contradiction is mainly manifested in the presence of many factors in the productive relationships and the superstructure that hinder the development of productivity, which contradict and conflict with the requirements of productivity development. The resolution of this contradiction must rely on the development of social productivity. (4) The production relationship must suit the nature of productivity. In accordance with this rule, on the one hand, we need to change the backward production relationships, open the way for the development of productivity, and at the same time prevent the over-exaggeration of the counter-effects of production relationships. If the changes in production relationships are too rapid and too fast, surpassing the level of productivity development, it will also hinder the development of productivity, and even destroy productivity.
On this issue, Deng Xiaoping also expressed his opinion. In October 1977, he said when meeting with Canadian guests: "The Gang of Four" denies the importance of productivity. Whoever proposes to develop productivity is said to be "being focused solely on productivity". This is one of our major debates with the "Gang of Four". If the productivity doesn't develop to the point of being extremely rich in material, how can we realize distribution according to demand, and how can we enter communism? Marxism-Leninism doesn't have the term "solely focusing on productivity", this term is unscientific. In December, he said when meeting guests from Australia: How can we reflect the superiority of socialism that Lenin talked about? What is the superiority? Is not working and not studying considered superiority? Is the decline in people's living standards instead of improving considered superiority? If this is called the superiority of socialism, we can also reject this kind of socialism.
In addition, the theoretical circle has also carried out a theoretical analysis on the era when the "left" mistakes prevailed, where conducting affairs according to economic rules was regarded as something opposed to the emphasis on politics. The representative article at the time was "Conducting Affairs According to Economic Rules and Accelerating the Realization of Four Modernizations" which was drafted by Hu Qiaomu, Yu Guangyuan, and Ma Hong. This article was first spoken by Hu Qiaomu at the State Council's virtual meeting, and then published in People's Daily on October 6, 1977. The article discusses the following points: Economic law is objective and is not subject to people's will; although economic law is objective, it cannot automatically ensure that people act according to the objective economic law. This must be studied and consciously complied with its law. Acting in accordance with the economic law, we must first improve scientific management and expand the role of economic organizations and economic means. Specifically, one is to promote the contractual system, the second is to develop professional companies, the third is to strengthen the role of banks, and the fourth is to develop economic legislation and economic justice. These discussions hit the nail on the head and provide directional guidance for solving problems in practical economic life. Some effective economic management methods have been initiated, such as quality-based compensation, piece-rate wages, etc. have been reintroduced.
2. Historical reflection in the literary and artistic world
After the crushing of the "Gang of Four", with the so-called "literary and artistic black line dictatorship thesis" being completely overthrown, a large number of films, dramas, and other excellent Chinese and foreign literary and artistic works that have been banned for a long time have been liberated. Mass organizations such as the United Front and the Writers Association have resumed their work, various literary and artistic creations have gradually become active, and some literary works that have initially reflected on the damage of the "Cultural Revolution" have soon appeared. After experiencing the situation of a "cultural desert" for ten years, simply recovering the works that were available before the "Cultural Revolution" is far from meeting social needs. It is still difficult to change the situation where the flowers of literature and art are withered without new works reflecting the fate of ordinary people in past ages from a new height. In such a period of transition from old to new, reportage literature, which is very realistic, has emerged first.
The form of reportage literature is most close to people's real life and can show readers the survival status and the truth of related events of the protagonists they are not familiar with but want to learn about. After crushing the "Gang of Four", the field of science education was the first to release a little "spring mood". The always sensitive writers captured the spring breeze. The stories of Chinese scientists who remained unmoved in the decade of turmoil and insisted on scientific research at the cost of life are very vivid and moving. Even without deliberate carving, it is enough to shock people's hearts.
The old-generation writer Xu Chi was the first to pick up the pen, recording the life journeys of scientists who have been submerged by the enthusiastic ignorant political atmosphere but have been tirelessly working hard to rejuvenate China's science and technology. He passionately sings of scientists who are willing to be lonely and selflessly dedicated in a difficult time. He wrote "Light of Geology", "Goldbach's Conjecture", and "The Tree of Life Remains Green" one after another. The emergence of these works injected vitality into the literary and art forms that were ravaged and distorted during the decade of turmoil, and burst into life.
The "Goldbach's Conjecture" published in the first issue of "People's Literature" in 1978, with fresh and gorgeous, philosophical yet poetic strokes, vividly depicts mathematician Chen Jingrun's persistent and unyielding tenacity in conquering world-class mathematical difficulties, his heartfelt desire for the motherland's scientific cause and his noble quality of not succumbing to evil forces and being shaken by temptation in the face of political storms. It truly reproduces the feelings of a generation of intellectuals in the new China who are obsessed with scientific exploration. People's Daily reprinted this piece of reportage literature in two full pages, which is rare in the history of the People's Daily.
Subsequently, a batch of realistic works praising Chinese scientists have emerged. Readers recognize the names of leading figures and young and middle-aged scientific research elites in the Chinese science and technology community from the deep historical sense of the pen, they are: geologist Li Siguang, biologist Tong Dizhou, quantum chemist Tang Auqing, physicist Xie Xide, mathematician Chen Jingrun, botanist Cai Xitao, engineering physicist Wu Zhonghua, hydrologist Zhang Guangdou, mathematician Hua Luogeng, science and technology ironman Chen Zhen, cotton planting model Wu Jichang, etc. People marvel at these groups of scientists who have distinct personalities yet share common ideals. Despite facing extremely sparse material conditions, and interruptions from the "leftist" political tendencies of past eras, they have still attained world-leading scientific achievements and have earned respect from society. The intellectual, emotional, and value-related impacts brought about by these reportage literature works have instigated and ignited the flame of rational thinking in society, thereby creating a sweeping momentum.
Before and after this, literary works revealing the trauma of the "Cultural Revolution" - termed "Scar Literature" - also began to emerge. People's Literature in 1977 published a short story called "Class Monitor" by Beijing writer Liu Xinwu, which is regarded as the foundational work of "Scar Literature". In his narrative, the author painstakingly portrays two typical middle school students - the small thug Song Baoqi and the Youth League Branch Secretary Xie Huimin. Although the imprint of the "Cultural Revolution" seems to be vastly different onto these two individuals, the depths of their souls have both been seared with the indelible scars inflicted by ultra-leftist currents.
Following the publication of the story, it aroused strong reactions amongst readers. A number of reflective works considering the pain inflicted by the Cultural Revolution gradually began to appear in newspapers and magazines. Among these works, a notable one is the short story "Scar", published in Wen Hui Bao on August 1, 1978. This narrative uncovers the life hardships and soul "injuries" inflicted upon Chinese society and particularly young people, by the ultra-leftist trend and "Theory of Bloodline". A highly stimulating theme that directly touches upon the hidden pains of real-life society instigates thoughts of people reflecting on their past and projecting into their future, and has significant influence throughout the nation.
The reason why the novel "Scar" sparked an enormous reaction in society and resonated with a considerable portion of people was mainly because it was able to articulate the inexplicable pain felt in people's hearts at the time. Indeed, with regards to the topic and ideas reflected in the work, there was a plethora of mixed opinions and it was a controversial piece. Some symposiums held in both Shanghai and Beijing including some debates. However, whether in agreement or disagreement, these types of literature quickly created a trend, later to be known as "Scar Literature". In reality, this phenomenon was a necessary form of historical reflection for people returning to rationality after China had just endured a period of great societal upheaval. Although this reflection is still primary and superficial, it has prompted more people to deeply and rationally consider the errors of the "Leftist" dominance in the past.
The historical reflection triggered by "Scar Literature" will become the eternal proposition of rational thinking during the transition from tradition to modernity: Throughout the decades of China's development, the entire humanistic condition has ruptured. This rupture, fed by the long-term influences of the May Fourth Movement, has essentially negated the broad consensus of pre-Qin philosophers; and the Cultural Revolution, which subverted the May Fourth tradition of Democracy and Science. The consequence is that the humanistic spirit cultivated by modern China was sacrificed during turbulent times, and the long-standing core values passed down by the Chinese nation have been severed. Post-severance, these values can be recovered, but the scars from the wounds cannot be reverted to their original state. In the ten years of upheaval during the "Cultural Revolution", human problems, societal problems, and ideological issues have slowly emerged over the next two or three decades. Among various populations and classes, due to various new and old reasons, these problems are everywhere - which is the truly grave problem. Only with the return of the rationality of societal values, and when the economic and social development and national prosperity reach a certain level after the reform and opening up, will we return to the issue of "humanity". The humanistic condition of a civilized society is always undeniable.
Literature played a leading role in opening rational thinking in the cultural realm of the time, but drama played a more unique role in mobilizing people's thoughts and emotions. In March 1978, the Beijing People's Art Theatre staged the drama "Danxin Pu" created by Su Shuyang. This was the first political drama performed by the theatre after its restoration. The play describes a thrilling struggle between a group of medical workers, represented by the elderly intellectual Fang Lingxuan, who are researching a new treatment for coronary heart disease on Prime Minister Zhou Enlai's orders, and the minions of the "Gang of Four". It deeply exposes the profound "inner injuries" caused by the "Gang of Four's" rampant actions on people's souls, praises Fang Lingxuan's persistent pursuit of the scientific enterprise, and powerfully condemns the despicable behavior of those who sided with the "Gang of Four" such as Fang Jisheng. The performance of the play, and the performance of "In a Silent Place", a four-act drama written by Shanghai worker Zong Fuxian, both received rave reviews and were highly sought after.
As the People's Daily commented at the time, it was "using the form of literature and art to turn over the history that the 'Gang of Four' had turned upside down, expressing what billions of people wanted to say in their hearts, and expressing the strong feelings deep in the hearts of the people". The exposure and criticism of the "Gang of Four" in China's art and literature circles was the start of historical reflection on the "Cultural Revolution" in various artistic forms and expressive language, which powerfully propelled the wave of liberation of thought at that time.
3. The Great Debate on the Criterion of Truth
The discussions in the economic theory circles and historical reflections in the literature and art circles took the lead in breaking the "forbidden zones", playing a role of "letting in light by drilling through the wall". However, under the rigid shell of "two whatevers", it was still difficult to thoroughly clarify the rights and wrongs before and during the "Cultural Revolution". In the words of Hu Yaobang: since we have firmly and forcefully taken the first step, we will never retreat and strive to expand the opening we have already made. Therefore, critical weapons must be raised against the "two whatevers".
The older generation of revolutionaries of the Chinese Communist Party, with both high political prestige and rich experience of long-term struggle, first brought forward the ideological weapon of seeking truth from facts.
On September 5, 1977, Nie Rongzhen published an article titled "Restoring and Carrying Forward the Party's Fine Style" in the 9th issue of "Red Flag" magazine. Nie Rongzhen proposed: The thought of seeking truth from facts is the most valuable theoretical legacy Mao Zedong has left us. "To uphold the style of seeking truth from facts, we must treat Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought with the right attitude. In studying and applying Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought, we must grasp the spiritual essence, learn its standpoints, viewpoints, and methods, use the basic principles as action guidelines, and firmly oppose treating certain phrases of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought as dogmas divorced from time, place, and conditions." "All right thoughts are subject to time, place, and conditions, otherwise they become metaphysics." "We must never forget for a moment to seek truth from facts, to divide one into two, and to base everything on time, place, and conditions, otherwise we are deviating from the most fundamental aspect of Mao Zedong Thought."
On September 19, Xu Xiangqian, in his article "Always Adhere to the Principle of Party Commanding the Gun," emphasized the importance of sticking to the principle of seeking truth from facts through discussing the party's struggle with Zhang Guozhu and the "Gang of Four" on military issues. He pointed out: "We must never act like some people, running after whoever has greater power without considering the correctness of the way. This is very dangerous. Of course, it is not easy to distinguish between the correct and wrong path." Therefore, it is necessary to "fully and accurately understand and master Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought."
On September 28, Chen Yun, in his article "Stick to the Revolutionary Style of Seeking Truth from Facts", severely criticized the rampant idealism and metaphysics when the "Gang of Four" ran rampant. He pointed out: "The 'Gang of Four' and their followers tell lies, fabricate cases, and play double-faced anti-revolutionaries, which has become a common thing. They have twisted, split, tampered with, and forged Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought to an extreme extent, using quotes from Marxist classics as a talisman to oppress, harm people, harm the Party, and harm the country. They have seriously destroyed the good tradition and style of our Party that Chairman Mao has cultivated for a long time. They not only greatly damaged the Party's way of seeking truth from facts, but also brazenly constructed a "theoretical" basis for their subjective idealism system. They vigorously promote the "anti-empiricism" guideline, which actually denies practical experience as the basis of cognition, denies all correct principles that start from practice, and denies Chairman Mao's principle of seeking truth from facts.
Chen Yun profoundly pointed out: "Seeking truth from facts is not an ordinary style issue, it is a fundamental ideological route issue of Marxist materialism. We must adhere to Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought, so we must adhere to seeking truth from facts. If we deviate from the revolutionary style of seeking truth from facts, then we will deviate from Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought and become idealists who are out of touch with reality, and then, our revolutionary work will fail. Therefore, whether to maintain the revolutionary style of seeking truth from facts is actually one of the fundamental signs to distinguish between genuine and counterfeit Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought."
The older generation of revolutionaries emphasized adhering to the fundamental ideological route of seeking truth from facts, opposing the use of some phrases or use of a few words by Mao Zedong to split Mao Zedong Thought. On this issue, the "Two Whatevers" is exactly meant to uphold everything of Mao Zedong, including his erroneous theories and practices in his later years. In response to this difficult problem, in July 1977, shortly after the resumption of his work at the third plenary session of the tenth central committee, Deng Xiaoping immediately put forward the need to accurately and completely understand Mao Zedong Thought, adhere to the scientific system of Mao Zedong Thought; and actively advocated to maintain Mao Zedong's basic view of seeking truth from facts in order to guide people to treat Mao Zedong Thought and Mao Zedong with the correct attitude.
However, just after Mao's death, with the deep influence of the long-term personal worship of Mao within the party, it would be extremely difficult to be "complete and accurate". This requires an objective standard that puts all people and things under it. Otherwise, it will be impossible to break free from the shackles of the "Two Whatevers", and the guiding principle of emancipating the mind and seeking truth from facts will be hard to reestablish. This will inevitably affect the in-depth development of rectifying chaos, and the hesitation in various tasks will be difficult to reverse. Hence, the standard of testing truth was proposed.
At the end of 1977, more than 800 mid-to-high-level cadres who were studying at the Central Party School held concentrated discussions on the history of the Party since the "Cultural Revolution". A prominent problem encountered during the discussion is what standards should be used to understand and judge the right and wrong of history. For this, Hu Yaobang, who was then in charge of the routine work of the Central Party School and Vice President, guided the theoretical workers of the Party School to amend several times, and wrote a document guiding the study of the Party's history, clearly proposing two guiding principles: one is to fully and accurately use the basic principles of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought; the second is to use practice as the standard for testing truth and distinguishing right from wrong. Under the guidance of these two principles, some theoretical workers of the Party School began to write articles on the issue of the standard of truth, in response to the influence of "whatevers".
In March 1978, in response to the confusion concerning the standard of truth, the editorial department of the People's Daily published a thought-provoking commentary titled "There is Only One Standard", clearly stating: "The standard of truth is only one, which is social practice." After the article was published, it met with some opposition from people who believed that Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought were the standards for testing truth. Therefore, the editorial department decided to continue organizing articles to further clarify this issue.
In early April, the Guangming Daily was preparing to publish an article titled "Practice is the Standard of Testing Truth", by Hu Fukang, a teacher of the Philosophy Department of Nanjing University, on its "Philosophy Special Issue". Yang Xiguang, the new editor-in-chief who had just returned from studying at the Central Party School, keenly felt the weight of the issues discussed in the article on China's political and intellectual circles at the time, and thus decided to remove the article from the "Philosophy Special Issue", add some realistic targetivity, and then publish it on the first page. At this time, the original author Hu Fukang came to Beijing to participate in the theoretical discussion, and the newspaper invited him to discuss modifications with the Central Party School's theoretical research room. After modification, the manuscript was processed twice by newspaper editors, and then sent to the Central Party School's theoretical research room for further modification and polishing before the final draft was confirmed.
The article "Practice is the Only Standard of Testing Truth", after being personally approved by Hu Yaobang, was first published in the "Theoretical Trends" of the Central Party School on May 10, 1978; the Guangming Daily published it in the form of a special commentator's article the next day. On the 12th, the People's Daily and the Liberation Army Daily reprinted the full text, and Xinhua News Agency also released a communiqué. Many provincial and municipal party newspapers also reprinted it one after the other.
The article, which contains the collective wisdom of the theoretical circle at the time, explains with a large amount of facts that practice is not only the standard for testing truth, but also the only standard, and all theories must continuously accept the test of practice. Marxism is recognized as truth because it has been confirmed by the long-term practice of hundreds of millions of people. The dialectical and materialistic epistemology of practice standards, which is the absolute and relative dialectical unity of viewpoints, are the views that any thought, any theory must without exception, always, and continuously accept the test of practice, which is also the view of the development of truth. In testing truth with practice, our revolutionary mentors have set an example for us.
In connection with the then state of affairs in the field of thought and politics, the article emphasizes: the "Gang of Four" and its gang system has now been destroyed, but the mental shackles of the "Gang of Four" imposed on people have not been completely shattered. The tendency that Mao Zedong once criticized, "only what is recorded in the Bible is right", still exists. Whether in theory or in practical work, the "Gang of Four" have set up many "forbidden areas" that confine people's thoughts. For these "forbidden areas", we should dare to touch and distinguish right from wrong. Science has no forbidden areas. Where there is a "forbidden area" that goes beyond practice and self-claims to be absolute, there is no science, there is no real Marxism, no Mao Zedong Thought, only obscurantism, idealism, and cultural despotism.
The article finally states: To us, there are still many places that are the inevitable kingdom yet to be recognized in socialism. In order to complete this great task, we are faced with many new problems, which we need to understand and study. Lying on the pre-existing provisions of Marxism and Mao Zedong Thought, and even using ready-made formulas to restrict, dissect, and trim the ever-enriching, rapidly evolving revolutionary practice, this attitude is incorrect. We need to bear the responsibility and courage of a Communist and dare to study vivid real-life situations, to investigate the exact realities, and to explore new issues brought up in new practices. Only in this way can we adopt a correct attitude towards Marxism and gradually progress from the kingdom of necessity to the kingdom of freedom, successfully embarking upon a new, great Long March.
In fact, the article "Practice is the sole criterion for testing truth" repeatedly proves a common-sense philosophical proposition of Marxism, and in itself has no special theoretical innovations. However, under the specific historical conditions where the "Cultural Revolution" had just ended, and "two whatever" still restrained people's thoughts, its distinctive tendency, strong pertinence, exerted infinite power. As soon as the article was published, it immediately caused different responses from all walks of society, and set off a huge wave inside and outside the Party. The nationwide discussion on the standard of truth thus began.
On May 12th, the very day when the "People’s Daily" republished the article "Practice is the sole criterion for testing truth," a responsible person of the newspaper received a phone call accusing the article of making a "directional error."
On May 17th, Wang Dongxing, then Vice Chairman of the CPC Central Committee, criticized by name the articles "Practice is the sole criterion for testing truth" and "Implementing the socialist principle of distribution according to labor" published by the "People’s Daily" on May 5th, saying that they had not read these two articles, and that the endless discussion inside and outside the Party was in fact aimed at the Chairman's thoughts. Our party's newspaper should not do this. He questioned, "Whose idea within the Central Committee is this?"  and stated that we should "investigate and learn a lesson, unify our understanding, and not repeat it," and requested the Central Propaganda Department to "guard."
On May 18th, at the discussion meeting held by the Propaganda Department for National Education Work Conference and provincial and city cultural and educational secretaries and propaganda directors, Zhang Pinghua, Minister of the Propaganda Department, asked everyone to "discuss and express different opinions" on the article "Practice is the Only Criterion for Testing Truth." And he said, "Don't believe that it is a final decision just because the 'People's Daily' has published it or the Xinhua News Agency has disseminated it." "Chairman Mao once told the heads of provinces and cities that no matter where it comes from, including the Central Committee, smell it first, and see whether it smells good or bad. Don’t follow the wind."
On June 15th, Wang Dongxing convened a meeting with heads of the Central Propaganda Department, central directly affiliated agencies and related news units. At the meeting, he criticized "Practice is the Sole Criterion of truth" and a few other articles again, named Hu Yaobang, and reminded him to pay attention when writing articles for the newspaper. He particularly mentioned that some articles by commissioned commentators should be noted as a few were not very appropriate. We should not seek temporary satisfaction. He believes that shortcomings in propaganda will be exploited by enemies at home and abroad. Soviet and American hegemons and reactionaries will all take advantage, sow discord. They will stir up relationships among Politburo Standing Committee members, Party Committee members, between Chairman Mao and Chairman Hua, and between workers and farmers. If the propaganda gate is not tightened, it would be a terrible thing if it gets exploited by the enemy.
In July, the Central leaders in charge of propaganda work visited Shandong Province for an inspection. In Jinan, they talked to the leading comrades of the Shandong Provincial Committee, during which the topic of the standard of truth was brought up. The summary can be encapsulated in three sentences: One, do not surrender our flag; two, do not abandon our weapons, and three, do not make a 180-degree u-turn. 
Under such political circumstances, many publications eagerly participate, yet the "Red Flag" magazine maintains a long silence. Of course, silence is also a stand. When the person in charge of the magazine reflected that the attitude of the "Red Flag" was under criticism from both inside and outside the party, Wang Dongxing said: "Don’t be afraid of being isolated. What are you afraid of! Don’t be afraid. The 'Red Flag' will not participate in this discussion."
When the discussion of the criterion of truth was being suppressed and hardly bearable for a time, Deng Xiaoping and other older-generation revolutionaries stood out and gave strong support. On May 30th, in a conversation with several leaders, Deng Xiaoping pointedly said: "As long as what you say is different from what Chairman Mao said, it is not acceptable. What Chairman Mao and Chairman Hua did not say, you said, is also unacceptable. You have to copy exactly what Chairman Mao and Chairman Hua said, and only if you copy all of it will it be ok. This is not a phenomenon of isolation; it is a reflection of the current trend of thought." He emphasized, "The most fundamental and most important thing in Mao Zedong's thought is seeking truth from facts. Now, even practice as a test of truth has become a problem, which is simply inexplicable."
On June 2nd, at the All-Army Political Work Conference, Deng Xiaoping once again talked about this issue and criticized: "We also have some comrades who talk about Mao Zedong's thoughts every day, but often forget, abandon, or even oppose Comrade Mao Zedong’s principle of seeking truth from facts, starting from reality, and integrating theory with practice. This fundamental Marxist viewpoint and method are not only abandoned; some people think that if anyone insists on seeking truth from facts, starting from reality, and integrating theory with practice, they have committed a horrendous crime. Their views essentially advocate for copying Marx, Lenin, and Comrade Mao Zedong verbatim, as long as you copy, it is enough. Otherwise, they would say that this is a violation of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought, and a violation of the spirit of the Central Committee. The problem they raised is not a small one; it is about how to view Marxism, Leninism, and Mao Zedong Thought."
On July 21st, Deng Xiaoping specifically found Zhang Pinghua, the Minister of the Central Propaganda Department, to talk and asked him "no more bans or restricted areas, do not pull back the lively political situation that has just begun".
On August 19th, Deng Xiaoping, in a conversation with the person in charge of the Ministry of Culture, also said: "I have said that the article 'Practice is the Sole Criterion for Testing Truth' is Marxist and is undeniable. I agree with the views of this article."
On September 16th, Deng Xiaoping, while listening to the work report of the Standing Committee of the Jilin Provincial Committee, said more directly: "Now inside and outside the party, at home and abroad, many people advocate raising the banner of Mao Zedong Thought. What is it called to raise it? How to raise it? As we all know, there is a kind of discussion called 'two whatevers', which is quite famous? Documents reviewed by Comrade Mao Zedong cannot be touched, and things done and said by Comrade Mao Zedong cannot be touched. Is this called raising the banner of Mao Zedong Thought? No! If this continues, it will harm Mao Zedong's thought ..." The basic point of Mao Zedong Thought is seeking truth from facts, which is the combination of the universal principles of Marxism-Leninism with the specific practice of the Chinese revolution."
On September 9, Li Xiannian also expressed support for the discussion on the standard of truth in his speech at the State Council. He said that the destruction of Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" had messed up many theoretical issues, including the relationship between theory and practice, causing ideological confusion that needs to be clarified. He emphasized the role of practice as the only standard for testing truth, indicating that things proven to be in line with objective laws and in the interests of the majority through long-term social practice should be resolutely pursued. All our policy plans and measures, whether correct or not, should be evaluated by whether they can benefit the people.
In commemoration of the 85th birthday of Mao Zedong, "Hongqi" Magazine invited Tan Zhenlin to write an article recalling Mao Zedong's leadership in the Jinggangshan struggle. After the article was written, the editors found that in addition to recalling history, it also discussed the issue about practice being the standard of truth. This was in contradiction with the attitude of "Hongqi" not being involved, and the author was unwilling to make amendments. As a last resort, it had to be submitted to the Standing Committee for judgment. Hua Guofeng, Deng Xiaoping, Li Xiannian and others agreed on publishing this article.
Deng Xiaoping and Li Xiannian also criticized "Hongqi" Magazine in their comments. Deng Xiaoping wrote: "I think this article is good, at least there are no errors." "If 'Hongqi' is reluctant to publish it, it can be transferred to 'People's Daily'. Why isn't 'Hongqi' involved? It should be. Different opinions can be published. It seems that not being involved may be being involved after all." Li Xiannian commented: "After reading this article, I believe what Comrade Tan Zhenlin is saying is historical fact, it should be published. 'Hongqi' is too passive if it's not published, it has already been very passive."
When the central high-level leadership further engaged the "Whatever Faction" in the debate about the standard of truth, the theoretical, academic and journalistic worlds followed suit. Inspired by the concern and support of the older generation of revolutionaries, they withstood the various pressures from the "Whatever Faction", continued to write articles, hold discussions, and further deepen the already initiated debate.
As for the claim that practice is the standard for testing truth, most people expressed support, but some questioned whether practice is the "only standard". They believe that practice is indeed the standard of truth, but Marxism should also be the standard for testing truth. This was a common cognitive issue at that time. In response to this situation, Xing Bensi of the Institute of Philosophy of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences published an article entitled "On the Issue of the Standard of Truth" in response to an invitation from the People's Daily, specifically addressing the aforementioned question. The article argued that advocating both practice and Marxism as the standards of truth violates the monism of dialectical materialism and could cause theoretical confusion. In terms of cognition, this confuses the issues of truth and the standard of truth. Marxism is the truth, but just as any truth cannot prove itself, Marxism also cannot prove itself, it needs to be proven by practice. At the same time, Marxism cannot be used as a standard to test other truths. Another confusion is that Marxism is the pointer of revolutionary practice, which is confused with Marxism being the standard of truth. These are two different questions. Philosophically, while acknowledging the reflective effect of theoretical knowledge on practice, one must not deny the fundamental determinant role of practice, nor should one use this reflection as a substitute for the question of practice being the standard of testing truth.
In the face of various criticisms that practice is the only standard for testing truth, theorists have given persuasive responses and refutations. The most systematic, sharp, and pungent of these is the article "A Basic Principle of Marxism" published on June 24th by the Liberation Army Daily in the name of a special commentator. The article clearly points out: "The most powerful refutation of agnosticism, skepticism, and other strange philosophical theories is practice. This is a famous saying by Engels when he criticized Hume and Kant's agnosticism and skepticism, and it is still meaningful for us to quote it today." "Marxist epistemology recognizes practice as the true authority.   In the world, it is only because there is no established objective standard for judging truth (practice) that agnosticism and skepticism have a market.
