To implement the spirit of the Fifth Plenary Session, the Central Organization Department forwarded on April 18, 1980, the Guizhou Provincial Party Committee's "Notice on Rehabilitation and Correction of the Unjust, False, and Wrong Cases Caused by the Issue of Liu Shaoqi, and Well-Committing the Party's Policy," asking all local and departmental cases that were implicated due to Liu Shaoqi's unjust case and other unjust, false, and wrong cases during the "Cultural Revolution," to be completed in the first half of that year. On May 17, a memorial ceremony for Liu Shaoqi was grandly held in Beijing. More than 10,000 representatives of party and state leaders and various aspects of the capital attended the memorial ceremony. Liu Shaoqi's rehabilitation cleared the case, and tens of thousands of people across the country involved in Liu Shaoqi's unjust case were completely rehabilitated. Through the rehabilitation of this unjust case with the greatest impact in the country, the thoughts of the broad masses of cadres were further liberated, and the rehabilitation work of other unjust, false, and wrong cases was promoted.
⑧ Rehabilitation of comrades implicated by the so-called nationwide "First Big Character Poster"..



At the beginning of the "Cultural Revolution", Nie Yuanzi, secretary of the Party branch of Peking University's Philosophy Department, along with others, unjustly accused and attacked the Peking University Party Committee, Lu Ping (Secretary of the Peking University Party Committee), Song Shuo (Deputy Director of the University Science Department of the Beijing Committee), and Peng Peiyun (Deputy Secretary of Peking University Party Committee), which was greatly praised by Mao Zedong. Many, including Lin Biao, Jiang Qing, Kang Sheng, Chen Boda, took this opportunity to fabricate charges against Lu Ping, Song Shuo, and Peng Peiyun and persecute them. Not only was the poster publicized on the radio, but also the People's Daily commentators praised it greatly, causing a very negative impact nationwide. This was a major wrongful accusation in the early stages of the "Cultural Revolution". In February 1979, the Beijing Municipal Committee of the Communist Party of China decided to completely rehabilitate the Peking University Party Committee, Lu Ping, Song Shuo, and Peng Peiyun. In August 1980, the Central Organization Department forwarded the Beijing Municipal Committee's notice on rehabilitating comrades who were framed by the so-called "first big-character poster", and this wrongful case was completely redressed.

The so-called "black party", "fake party" issue was rehabilitated. During the "Cultural Revolution", under the influence of Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four'" extreme left-wing line, the 38th Army underground party organization led by Yang Hucheng was falsely accused of being a "black party", "fake party". Many old comrades in this organization were slandered as "real nationalists, fake communists", and labeled as "traitors" and "spies", and they suffered brutal persecution. After the dissolution of the "Gang of Four", after the investigation by the Shaanxi Provincial Committee, the so-called "black party" and "fake party" issues were completely unfounded. With the approval of the central government, in February 1981, the Central Organization Department forwarded the Shaanxi Provincial Committee's request for the Yang Hucheng's 38th Army underground party organization to be rehabilitated from being accused of being a "black party", "fake party" and for those who were persecuted because of this case to be completely rehabilitated, falsities were refuted, and post-event work was handled well.

Rehabilitation of the so-called "Red Flag Party" issue. During the Yan'an rectification movement in 1943, Kang Sheng forced confessions and fabricated the so-called "Red Flag Party" case. Underground parties in Gansu, Henan, Shaanxi, Sichuan, Hunan, Hubei, Yunnan, Guizhou, Zhejiang, Guangxi and other places were falsely accused of being a "Red Flag Party", and many underground party members were labeled as "spies", "traitors", "insiders". In the later stage of the Yan'an rectification, the central government found that the so-called "Red Flag Party" case fabricated by Kang Sheng was a pure fake case and promptly corrected it. However, a comprehensive conclusion was not made due to the historical conditions at that time. During the "Cultural Revolution", this historical issue was revived, and many comrades were again falsely accused and brutally struggled, some were even persecuted to disability and death. In order to fully solve the lingering issue of the so-called "Red Flag Party", and to eliminate the adverse effects caused by Kang Sheng's fabrication of this fake case, in September 1981, the General Office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued a notice, announcing that the central government decided to officially rehabilitate the underground party organizations in several provinces (autonomous regions) wrongfully accused as the "Red Flag Party", refuted all these false accusations made against these underground party organizations, and completely rehabilitate the comrades who were persecuted because of this case. 

Rehabilitation and restoration of Pan Han-nian's reputation. Pan Han-nian was an old member of our party, who had held important leadership positions inside and outside the party. He made significant contributions to the party's cultural work, united front work, especially in carrying out covert struggle against the enemy, and was highly meritorious. After 1955, due to serious neglect of the peculiarity of covert struggle against the enemy, and confusion of right and wrong boundaries and enemy and self boundaries, Pan Han-nian was erroneously defined as a "spy". He was arrested, examined, and later convicted and sentenced, and expelled from the party; Until he died of illness in 1977, he suffered from wrongful accusation and humiliation for more than 20 years.



The issues involved with Pan Hanyuan have implicated many comrades who worked with him in the past, causing them to suffer long-term injustice. In March 1981, the Central Committee of the Party ordered the Central Discipline Inspection Committee to re-investigate the Pan case. The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection examined and studied various materials for this purpose, and interviewed dozens of comrades who had worked with Pan Hanyuan in the past. The re-investigation showed that the original verdict that Pan Hanyuan was a "traitor" could not be substantiated and ought to be rejected. This was a major wrongful case since the establishment of New China. On August 23, 1982, the Central Committee issued a document to formally declare to the Party: to rehabilitate Pan Hanyuan and restore his honor; anyone who was wrongly implicated in the Pan case should also undergo a fact-based review and rehabilitation, with proper handling of follow-up matters.

(3) Rehabilitation was conducted for a group of party and national leaders, hundreds of provincial and ministerial level officials and many well-known figures from all walks of life.

During the "Cultural Revolution," a large number of the Party and country's important leaders were attacked and persecuted. After the Third Plenary Session, the Central Committee of the Party successively rehabilitated Liu Shaoqi, Peng Dehuai, He Long, Tao Zhu, Peng Zhen, Bo Yibo, Yang Shangkun, Zhang Wentian, Lu Dingyi, Tan Zhenlin, Xi Zhongxun, Huang Kecheng, Wang Renzhong, Song Renqiong, Luo Ruiqing and other party, government, and military leaders. Rehabilitation was also carried out for Qu Qiubai, an early leader of our Party.

Before the "Cultural Revolution", there were a total of 1,253 officials at the deputy provincial and deputy ministerial levels across the country. 1,011 of them, accounting for 81% of the officials at the same levels, suffered setbacks during the "Cultural Revolution". Among them, 453 were framed as "traitors", "spies", "counter-revolutionary revisionists", "agents of the bourgeois headquarters", "executors of the revisionist line", accounting for 36% of the total number (excluding those directly reviewed by the original Central Special Case Group). The so-called reviews of these officials were mostly based on concocted and framed charges or they were exaggerated and mislabeled, leading to serious mental and physical suffering. 40 comrades died with grievances during the "review" period and some became permanently disabled.

After the overthrow of the "Gang of Four", the Central Organization Department, commissioned by the Central Committee, reviewed and adjudicated from 1978 to the end of 1980 the cases of 453 officials at the deputy provincial and deputy ministerial levels.

During the "Cultural Revolution", 85 people who were defined as enemies were all rehabilitated and their honor was restored. Those who had historical problems in the past and were further scapegoated during the "Cultural Revolution" were mostly maintained with the verdict before the "Cultural Revolution". After implementing policies, those comrades who were in good health and capable were put back into leadership positions. Those who were not in good health were properly settled. Those who died innocently were vindicated. For the comrades and their families who were implicated due to the wrongdoing, work was done to eliminate the impact.

(4) Rehabilitation for several central departments that were criticized wrongly or slandered during the "Cultural Revolution". This primarily included: overturning the erroneous verdict on the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China's Foreign Liaison Department implementing "three reductions and one elimination"; completely vindicating the so-called "Yama Palace of the Central Propaganda Department"; removing the hat of "executing the capitulationist line" for the National United Front, Ethnic, Religious Work Department; completely vindicating the wrongful case of calling the former Ministry of Culture a "Ministry of Emperors and Generals, Talents and Beauties, Foreign Dead Persons"; completely vindicating the injustice of the General Political Department of the People's Liberation Army being slandered as "Yama Palace", and revoking the Minutes of the Symposium on Troop Cultural and Artistic Work in February 1966. The forced so-called "execution of revisionist line" verdict on the educational frontline was overturned, and the Summary of the National Education Work Conference in 1971 was revoked; and so on.

After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, party organizations at all levels continued to review and vindicate a number of renowned figures from the artistic, sports, scientific, medical, and various other fields.

Second, properly handling historical legacy issues.



Proper handling of historical legacy issues is a vital part of restoring order from chaos and an arduous task in rectifying wrongful cases and implementing cadre policies. Due to the influence of "left" errors in previous political movements and some work mistakes, complicated issues were not timely addressed under the special historical circumstances of the war years, along with other various reasons, creating numerous unresolved issues. According to incomplete statistics, cases left over from the time prior to the "Cultural Revolution" across the country reached as many as millions, involving millions of people and affecting tens of million lives.

With the restoration and promotion of the party's principle of seeking truth from facts, the rectification of wrongful cases, the deep implementation of cadre policies, the demand to resolve issues left over from the history before the "Cultural Revolution" has been increasing, and the call for this has been growing stronger. This is not only the inevitable requirements for the party to liberate its thoughts, seek truth from facts, correct wrongful cases and deeply implement cadre policies, but also directly related to the rectification of wrongful cases during the "Cultural Revolution". Many wrongful cases from the "Cultural Revolution" were in fact deliberately stirred up again by Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" from issues that had been dealt with in history, causing indefinite escalation. Therefore, the deepening development of rectifying wrongful cases and implementing cadre policies will inevitably involve many issues leftover from history. If these issues are not handled properly, it will be hard to mobilize and give full play to the enthusiasm of these cadres and the masses, the environment of stability and unity will be hard to strengthen and develop, and the principle of seeking truth from facts by the party will not be thoroughly restored and promoted.

Soon after the work to rectify wrongful cases and implement cadre policies began, the issues left over from the "anti-rightist" and "Four Cleanups" movement were already brought to the agenda for review and correction. The Central Committee issued related documents, defined relevant policy regulations, and began to review, correct and resolve legacy issues before the "Cultural Revolution".

After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, especially after the principal task of rectifying wrongful cases from the "Cultural Revolution" was basically completed, the focus of rectification of wrongful cases and the implementation of cadre policies shifted to properly handling historical legacy issues. Major legacy issues such as the "anti-rightist", "anti-rightist deviation", "Four Clean-ups", "underground party", "intelligence operatives", "wrongful killings during anti-counterrevolutionary purges in the Soviet area", "Huxi Trotskyist Incident", and the "Central Plains Breakout" were reviewed and handled one after another. This work was basically completed by the time of the Thirteenth National Congress in 1987.

How to actively and properly handle legacy issues relates to whether the rectification of wrongful cases and the implementation of cadre policies can be carried out steadily and healthily, and to whether the general situation of stability and unity can remain stable. For this reason, the Central Organization Department and relevant departments of the central state authorities have taken two main measures in macro-guidance:
1. Endeavor to remove all obstacles and disruptions. In the early stages of handling these legacy issues, the primary resistance and disruption came from the "left". Some people continued to view these issues through a "left" lens, refusing to correct those that were wrongly judged.

After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, another problem arose in the process of reviewing and handling: some people took a negate-all attitude and demanded a total overhaul of issues from all political movements since the establishment of New China along with pre-existing historical issues. The calls for this grew louder and the number of letters and visitors increased dramatically, even changing things that should not have been changed. To address these issues, in June 1979, the Central Organization Department convened a "Work Symposium on Implementing Cadre Policy". At the meeting, the leaders of the Central Organization Department made it clear that the wrongful cases from the "Cultural Revolution" and those before the "Cultural Revolution" were different. For the old cases before the "Cultural Revolution", it is necessary to solve them based on the principle of dialectical materialism, historical materialism, the principle of seeking truth from facts, and the principle of correcting mistakes when they occur.



In essence, problems of the time should be treated in the light of the prevailing circumstances, conditions, and policies. A strategy and principle for dealing with historical issues left over from the "Cultural Revolution" were proposed. After the conference, with the approval of the Central Committee, the Organization Department of the Central Committee issued the "Notice on the handling of some cases before the 'Cultural Revolution'". The document stipulates that apart from the correction of wrongful rightists, the rectification of wrongful cases in the anti-right-leaning struggles since 1959, and the review of wrongful cases in the "Four Cleanup" campaign, which were already stipulated by the Central Committee, the remainder of the cases could be handled individually according to the normal scope of work. This was significantly different from the numerous injustices, fraudulent cases, and wrongful cases caused by the serious interference and destruction by Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" during the "Cultural Revolution". If these old cases were not analyzed historically and tousled up once again, guided by today's policy perspective, a comprehensive review and handling would undoubtedly lead to a confusion between right and wrong. This would lead to unnecessary ideological confusion that could affect stability and unity, and drive a wedge between the party and the masses. Certain old cases should be handled cautiously in light of the different circumstances they were in. 

In January 1983, to further improve the review of historical legacy issues, the Organization Department of the Central Committee organized a symposium in Yichang, Hubei, which was attended by comrades from the Organization Departments of seventeen provinces and municipalities, as well as some central and national authorities. They exchanged experiences on this work, studied difficult problems encountered in the work, put forward suggestions and measures to solve problems, and further defined the policy and tasks of this work. Afterward, the Organization Department of the Central Committee issued a notice, promulgating "Minutes of the Symposium on the Review of Unjust, False and Mistaken Cases of the 'Cultural Revolution'", pointing out that the nature of the unjust, false and mistaken cases that occurred before the "Cultural Revolution", mainly due to the limitations of cognition and work mistakes at the time, is different from the large-scale unjust, false and mistaken cases intentionally created by Lin Biao and Jiang Qing's anti-revolutionary group under the specific historical conditions of the "Cultural Revolution". 

To rectify and correct the unjust, false, and mistaken cases before the "Cultural Revolution" and solve the remaining problems of history, we must comply with the spirit of the Party's Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee and the relevant policy provisions of the Organization Department of the Central Committee approved by the Central Committee, "Notices on Some Case Processing Opinions before the 'Cultural Revolution'", in view of the situation at that time, to be historical and comprehensive. It is necessary to analyze specific cases in detail, adhere to truth-seeking and error-correcting, and actively and cautiously correct all the yet unresolved injustices step by step. 

In the work, attention should be paid to preventing two biases: one is to continue to view historical cases from the "left" perspective, not correcting the wrong characterizations, and even if the cases handled and approved by oneself are obviously wrong, they should not be rectified; the other is to deny everything, changing even those that should not be changed. For cases before the "Cultural Revolution", whether they have appealed or not, if the organization finds that there may be mistakes, they should be reviewed, focusing on major cases, important cases, public cases, cases wrongly defined as contradictory to the enemy, cases wrongly expelled from the party, and cases wrongly dismissed from public office. Cases should be handled based on facts and in accordance with the Party's policies. If the main basis of the original conclusion is false, a thorough rehabilitation should be carried out; if the characterization is wrong, correction should be applied; if the facts are clear, the evidence is solid, and the conclusion is correct, or if there is no major discrepancy with the primary evidence and the characterization is basically appropriate, albeit a bit severe, it can remain unchanged, and considerations can be given in terms of their usage and life.



After the rectification of wrongful convictions, it is crucial to resolve issues from a political perspective and do a good job in ideological work, while properly handling the aftermath according to relevant regulations. The two meetings and the documents issued after them have effectively promoted and driven the in-depth development of addressing historical legacy issues.

2. Formulating correct guidelines and policies for dealing with historical legacy issues

Dealing with historical legacy issues bears significant responsibility and policy implications, directly relevant to the recognition, assessment of revolutionaries who made supreme sacrifices for the revolution, and the political destiny of some comrades, which can't be taken lightly. A strict adherence to the central government's guidelines and policies is a must. Therefore, formulating correct guidelines and policies is extremely important.

Under the careful guidance of the central leadership and the older generation of revolutionaries, the Central Party Committee and relevant departments of the Central State organs have successively formulated a series of policies and regulations on handling historical issues, such as the "Notice on Fully Removing the Label of Rightists", "Implementation Plan for Fully Removing the Label of Rightists", "Notice on Rectification and Correction for Those Designated as Right-deviationist", and others. These documents clearly stipulate the principles, guidelines, and policy boundaries for dealing with the historical issues of the Cultural Revolution, strictly specifying the scope, key points, and approval authority of the review process. Practice has proven these policies play an important role in guiding and addressing the historical residue of the Cultural Revolution.

In this work, there were major historical issues directly reviewed and handled by the Central Party Committee, relevant departments of the Central State organs, and certain provinces and cities commissioned by the Central Committee, including the following cases:

(1) The review and rectification of false cases during the "Anti-Rightist" movement. During the 1957 party-wide rectification process, a small number of bourgeois right-wing elements took the opportunity to brag about "letting a hundred flowers bloom", launching reckless attacks on the party and the newly established socialist system, attempting to replace the leadership of the Communist Party. Under such circumstances, the Central Committee decided to counterattack against the right-wing. This was necessary and correct. But the 'Anti-Rightist' movement was severely inflated, and a large number of intellectuals, patriots, and cadres were mistakenly labeled as 'rightists', which had unfortunate consequences. As Deng Xiaoping pointed out, "The problem lies in that as the movement evolved, it was inflated, the scope of the attack was too wide, and the severity was too extreme. Many people were indeed improperly handled, their treatment was too severe, they were wronged for many years, they could not demonstrate their talents and wisdom for the people, which is not only a loss for them personally, but also for the entire country."

In 1959, the Central Committee issued instructions on gradually removing the label of 'rightists' in separate stages and batches. By 1964, the label of 'rightists' had been removed for most of the people who were mistakenly labeled.

After the "Gang of Four" was crushed, the issues of removing the 'rightist' label and correcting mistakes were raised again during the work of redressing wrongful cases and implementing cadre policies. At that time, because the 'left' thought restriction hadn't been broken and the "Cultural Revolution" hadn't been thoroughly negated, it was challenging to deal with this issue properly – there was great resistance, many disputes, and an extremely difficult situation.

In the spring of 1978, relevant departments of the Central State organs held a meeting in Yantai, Shandong, to discuss how to properly deal with the historical issues of the "Anti-Rightist" movement. At the meeting, there was a consensus on the issue of 'removing the hat', but opinions on correcting the wrongful labeling of 'rightists' were not unanimous. After the meeting, the United Front Work Department of the Central Committee and the Ministry of Public Security drafted a "Request Report to the Central Committee on Fully Removing the Label of Rightists".



After research and approval, in April 1978, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued the "Notice on Completely Removing the Labels of Rightists," and decided to remove the labels of all remaining rightists.

Later, at the insistence of Hu Yaobang, the Central Organization Department reported to the Central Committee, suggesting to rectify the mistakenly labeled rightists according to the principles of seeking truth from facts and correcting mistakes. To this end, in August 1978, the relevant departments of the central government convened a meeting again to study the issue of rightists' rectification. At the meeting, some people still insisted on only "removing the label" and not rectifying. Some believed that past right and wrong is a thing of the past, and there is no need to clear accounts anymore, just to remove the labels and treat everyone as one of us. Some thought that each place and each department should leave some "models" no matter what, and not all should be changed. Some even said, if hundreds of thousands of rightists were rectified, wouldn’t it mess up the entire party? Comrades who insist on both "removing the label" and rectifying, believe that we must adhere to the principles of seeking the truth from facts and correcting mistakes, and pointed out that only by rectifying all wrong cases can we distinguish right from wrong, enhance unity, and promote the development of our cause. After a heated debate, the latter view was approved by the vast majority of comrades present.

In September 1978, the Central Committee adopted the "Implementation Plan for the Central Decision on Removing All Rightist Labels" drafted by the Central Organization Department, the Central Propaganda Department, the Central United Front Department, the Ministry of Civil Affairs, and the Ministry of Public Security based on principles of seeking truth from facts, punishing any rebellion, and correcting any mistakes. The plan set the direction and established basic policies and methods to correctly handle the aftermath of the Anti-Rightist Campaign.

In order to carry out the work of "removing the label" and rectification of the rightists, the "Label Removing" office was jointly established by the Central Organization Department, the Central Propaganda Department, the Central United Front Department, the Ministry of Public Security, and the Ministry of Civil Affairs. The Central Organization Department set up a Rightist Rectification Office to be specifically responsible for this work. Speaking under pressure and overcoming obstacles, the old generation of revolutionaries, represented by Deng Xiaoping, gave great support to this work. Deng Xiaoping emphasized: "Completely removing the label of rightists, correcting most people's handling, and assigning them proper work is a very necessary and major political measure."

Under the correct leadership of the Central Party Committee, with the firm support of the old generation of revolutionaries, and the joint efforts of the relevant departments of the central government, through hard and meticulous work, the ice was finally broken which was preventing the removal of all labels of rightists and the rectification of mislabeled rightists.

In February 1979, the Central Organization Department and the Central United Front Department jointly held a national experience exchange conference on the review and rectification of rightists. Units like the Central Party School, the Ministry of Public Security, and the Henan Yongcheng County Committee shared their experiences on rectifying and reviewing the past with liberated thoughts. The leaders of the Central Organization Department and the Central United Front Department also spoke at the meeting, elaborating on the great significance of handling historical legacy issues in a pragmatic way in accordance with the spirit of the Third Plenum of the Eleventh Central Committee. For the first time, they raised the issue that "the anti-rightist struggle in 1957 made the mistake of overreaching." They emphasized that "correcting the mislabeled rightists is to correct our mistakes in the 'anti-rightist' struggle," and "no matter which level of organization or individual approved the case, any mistake should be corrected." This was not only an experience exchange meeting but also a meeting for thought liberation. Subsequently, similar meetings were held in each province, autonomous region, and municipality, and even counties.



Subsequently, the party central committee issued a notice on the policy issues of the aftermath work such as the resettlement after the correction of the wrong denomination of the rightists, in response to the new situations and prominent contradictions that emerged in this work. This resolved more thoroughly the issues left over from the "anti-rightist" struggle in terms of policy stipulations. By the first half of 1981, this work was successfully concluded, with the rightist issues of over 540,000 people being rectified nationwide, representing more than 98% of the original total of 550,000 rightists. For the 270,000 people who lost their public offices, their offices were reinstated, work was arranged again or their lives were settled, and those who were improperly arranged for work were adjusted. In addition, policies were implemented for over 315,000 "middle-rightists" and "anti-socialist elements" and their family members affected by genetic discrimination. The successful completion of this work not only "liberated" hundreds of thousands of comrades who were wrongly designated as rightists, but also alleviated the pain of countless family members and friends affected by genetic discrimination, inspiring their enthusiasm for the construction of socialism.

(2) Review and rectify wrongful cases in the "anti-rightist" struggle. From July 2 to August 16, 1959, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China successively held expanded Politburo meetings and the eighth plenary session of the eighth Central Committee in Lushan, Jiangxi, the so-called "Lushan Meeting". In the later stage of the "Lushan Meeting", a wrongful criticism of Peng Dehuai was initiated, which led to a wrongful "anti-rightist" struggle across the party. The resolution of the eighth plenary session of the Eighth Central Committee on the so-called "anti-party group of Peng Dehuai, Huang Kecheng, Zhang Wentian, Zhou Xiaozhou" was completely erroneous. The resolution proposed to transfer comrades such as Peng Dehuai from work posts such as the Ministry of National Defense while retaining their roles as members of the Political Bureau, to observe the effects. The conference also passed a resolution "To Defend the Party's General Line and Struggle Against Rightist Opportunism". The resolution believed that "rightist opportunism has become the main danger in the party at present. Uniting the whole party and the people of the whole country, defending the general line, and repelling the attack of rightist opportunism has become the current main task of the party." As a result, the "anti-rightist" struggle was extended to the whole party. In the "anti-rightist" struggle, a large number of party members and cadres were erroneously criticized and handled, and some comrades were wrongly categorized as rightist opportunists. During the "Cultural Revolution", under the influence of the extreme left trend, these comrades were again subjected to persecution, criticism, and various punishments.

The "anti-rightist" struggle was a major error in the political life of our party since the founding of New China. It seriously damaged the democratic life within the party from the central to grassroots level, wrongly attacked a large number of comrades who dared to seek truth from facts, reflect the actual situation to the party, and proposed critical opinions, supported exaggeration and lying tendencies, and fostered the development of personality cult within the party.

Although after the conference of 7,000 people in 1961 and 1962, the central government decided to distinguish those who have been identified as rightist opportunists (or rightist opportunism errors) since 1959, a large amount of work has been carried out, and many people have been redressed and corrected. However, since the "left" error at the time was not fundamentally rectified, the rectification was not thorough. Later, after the tenth plenary session of the eighth congress, due to the proposal to oppose the wind of rightist reversal of verdicts, this work essentially came to a halt. In the "Four Cleanups" campaign and the "Cultural Revolution" campaign, under the influence of the extreme left trend, many places re-labelled people who were redressed and corrected in 1961 and 1962 as rightist opportunists or rightist opportunism errors, and subjected them to criticism and struggle. For those who have not been redressed and corrected, they are therefore subjected to harassments, parades, or disciplinary sanctions, and many people are subjected to various penalties such as expulsion from the party, demotion, pay cuts, re-education through labor, and dismissal from public office.

After crushing the "Gang of Four", at the beginning of redressing wrongful cases and implementing cadre policy, some old comrades proposed suggestions and requests to redress comrades who were wrongfully criticised in the "anti-rightist" struggle. The third plenary session of the eleventh CCP Central Committee redressed Peng Dehuai. In July 1979, the central government officially issued the "Notice on the Rectification and Redress of Rightist Opportunists".



The notice emphasizes that, since the "anti-rightist" struggle of 1959, those who have been labelled as rightist opportunists or made errors due to reflecting the actual situation or expressing different opinions within the party, should be rehabilitated and corrected across the board. Policies regarding both political and livelihood treatment should be properly implemented.

After the document was issued, per the Central Committee's plan, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection was responsible for, and assisted by the Central Organization Department, promptly and properly handling the lingering issues from the "anti-rightist" movement.

(3) Review and correct the wrongful cases during the "Four Clean-ups" campaign. The "Four Clean-ups" campaign was a large-scale mass movement led by the party. The central working conference in February 1963 decided to conduct a socialist education movement with the "Four Clean-ups" (cleaning up accounts, inventory, finances, and work points) as the main content in rural areas; and the "Five Anti's" (against corruption, speculation, waste, decentralization, and bureaucracy) movement in cities. The central working conference from late 1964 to early 1965, under the leadership of Mao Zedong, discussed and established some issues on the "Twenty-Three Points" in the rural socialist education campaign. This document also defined "Four Clean-ups" as cleaning politics, economics, organizations, thoughts. It emphasized that the nature of this movement was to resolve "contradictions between socialism and capitalism," suggesting the focus was to rectify "those in power within the party who are on the capitalist road," and other even "more left" perspectives. Although the "Four Clean-ups" campaign played a certain role in resolving issues such as the official style and economic management, it categorized different types of problems as class struggles or reflections of class struggle within the party, resulting in numerous grassroots officials being wrongfully implicated. During the "Cultural Revolution," Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" took advantage of the situation to create chaos, further exacerbating the problem.

In May 1978, Li Jingquan, the first secretary of the former Southwest Bureau, submitted a report to the central government titled "About the Remaining Issues during the 'Four Clean-ups' Campaign in Guiyang City." Deng Xiaoping instructed, "Agree with this report, this issue seems suitable for the Organization Department to discuss a handling policy and method with the Provincial Committee and report to the Central Committee." The Guizhou Provincial Committee submitted to the central government "Request for the Situation and Treatment Opinions on the Remaining Issues during the 'Four Clean-ups' Campaign in Guiyang City" in July of that year. In August of the same year, the Communist Party of China Central Committee replied agreeing to the Guizhou Provincial Committee's report. The Central Committee pointed out: In the "Four Clean-ups" campaign in Guiyang City, some comrades were wrongly characterized and handled redundantly, confusing two different types of problems and hurting some comrades. Now, it is very necessary to correct these matters pragmatically, which is beneficial to restore and carry forward the good traditions of the party, implement party policies, motivate the activity of cadres and party members, and enhance unity. Work with comrades who participated in the "Four Clean-ups" work and comrades who were criticized or punished during the "Four Clean-ups" should be well done. They should not pursue personal responsibility and should not care about personal grievances.

A proactive and cautious approach must always be adopted to rectify wrongful cases in the "Four Clean-ups," both to resolve issues and stabilize the situation. Emphasis should be placed on solving problems politically, promoting stability and unity, and developing a great situation. After that, the Central Organization Department proposed some specific regulations and work requirements for re-checking and redressing wrongful cases in the "Four Clean-ups" campaign. In accordance with the spirit of the Central Committee, various regions and departments across the country began to review and correct wrongful cases in the "Four Clean-ups".



Given the great disparity between the "Four Clean-ups" campaign in Guizhou in 1964 and the rest of the country, and its unique nature, in December 1983, the Guizhou Provincial Party Committee once again submitted a "Request Report on Thoroughly Solving Guizhou's 'Four Clean-ups' Issues" to the Central Organization Department, asking for approval from the Central Committee again. Entrusted by the Central Committee, the Central Organization Department drafted a reply to the Guizhou Provincial Party Committee, "Response to the Solution of Guizhou's 'Four Clean-ups' Issue (Draft Opinion)", which, after approval by the central government, was formally replied to the Guizhou Provincial Committee in the name of the CPC Central Committee in June 1984. The response pointed out: "The 'Four Clean-ups' campaign in Guizhou in 1964 was carried out under the guidance of 'left-leaning' erroneous thinking. The assessment and analysis at that time that the Provincial Committee had committed mistakes of a right-leaning opportunist line, and 'Guiyang Municipal Committee has formed a reactionary two-faced regime', was completely wrong. Based on this, the wrongful cases created are completely correct to be thoroughly reversed." According to the spirit of the relevant central regulations, "The erroneous conclusions and telegrams concerning Guizhou's 'Four Clean-ups' issue have all become invalid on their own." "The Central Committee believes that the leaders of the Guizhou Provincial Committee, Guiyang Municipal Committee, and other places where the 'Four Clean-ups' campaign was launched are all good comrades, and the two thousand cadres selected by the Central Committee to participate in the 'Four Clean-ups' in Guizhou at that time are also good comrades. Currently, strengthening unity among cadres is of utmost importance for starting a new situation in Guizhou's work." From then on, all provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the Central Government, in accordance with the spirit of the central government, carried out comprehensive and thorough reviews and corrections of wrongful cases in the "Four Clean-ups" campaign. A total of more than 630,000 wrongful cases in the "Four Clean-ups" campaign were reviewed and corrected nationwide.

(4) Properly handling the legacy issues of the underground party. At the beginning of the establishment of New China, during the general cleanup of underground party organizations, some places, due to insufficient understanding of the complexity of underground struggle, lack of understanding of the historical environment and characteristics of underground struggle, and errors in their work, wronged some underground party comrades and treated them unfairly, creating many legacy issues. In the "Cultural Revolution", some underground party comrades were also slandered and persecuted. In July 1981, Hu Yaobang endorsed a letter saying, "We should handle the historical legacy issues of the underground party well and solve them fairly and squarely. Please start with Fujian first." The Central Organization Department sent letters to Fujian and other relevant provincial party committees, conveying Hu Yaobang's instructions. The Fujian Provincial Party Committee attached great importance to this issue. Under the responsibility of the Provincial Party Secretary, it took more than three years to thoroughly investigate and properly handle the legacy issues of the Fujian underground party.

The Yunnan Provincial Party Committee also immediately set about solving the legacy issues in Yunnan's cleanup of underground party work, following the spirit of the instructions. In March 1982, the Central Organization Department issued the Yunnan Provincial Party Committee's "Report on Solving the Historical Legacy Issues of Yunnan's Underground Party and 'Border Verticals'" and "Report on Restoring the Political Reputation of Comrade Zheng Boke", both approved by the Central Committee. All slanders against the Yunnan underground party and "Border Verticals" imposed by the provincial military control committee and the provincial revolutionary committee during the "Cultural Revolution" were completely overturned, and a large number of wrongful cases were thoroughly redressed. At the same time, they also resolved the inappropriate conclusions made against the Yunnan underground party and the "Border Verticals" in several political movements before the "Cultural Revolution", and resolved the erroneous criticism of Zheng Boke, the main person in charge of the Yunnan underground party by the Provincial Party Committee in the 1950s. It fully affirmed the Yunnan underground party and "Border Verticals" for their hard work, a lot of work done, significant achievements made, and contributions to the liberation of Yunnan in the remote multi-ethnic border areas far from the central government. In August 1982, the Central Organization Department also approved the release of the Shaanxi Provincial Party Committee Organization Department's "Report on the Situation of the Northwestern United University Underground Party Organization and Opinions on Handling the Party Membership of Related Personnel".



Based on the careful summary of the experiences in properly handling the historical problems left over by the underground party in the above areas, in December 1984, the Central Organization Department convened a symposium on handling the historical issues of the underground party in 16 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the Central Government to conduct serious research and deployment of the work. After the meeting, with the approval of the Central Secretariat, the Central Organization Department issued a notice on the issuance of "Summary of the Symposium on Handling the Historical Problems of the Underground Party" (referred to as "Summary"). The "Summary" affirmed that the underground party organizations and the guerrilla forces led by the underground party across the country bravely fought in the white terror for a long time and made due contributions to China's liberation cause. 

It pointed out that the historical problems left over by the underground party mainly referred to the underground party organizations established before the local liberation or the guerrilla forces led by the underground party, secret peripheral organizations and their members, which were formed due to wrongful treatment, presenting false, wrongful cases, and remaining party membership issues. To handle these issues, we must follow the "Resolution on Several Historical Issues of the Party Since the Founding of the Nation" and the spirit of central related policies and instructions, adhere to the principle of "seeking truth from facts, correcting mistakes when found," and resolve them with fairness and integrity. It emphasises the importance of defining right from wrong, solving problems, fostering stability, and unity. No individual responsibility will be pursued. Emphasize solving politically, for comrades who have been wronged for a long time, appropriate remedies should be made in terms of political and living conditions. 

The "Summary" also proposed opinions on several issues in the work of dealing with the historical issues of the underground party. Afterward, this work was widely unfolded across the country. In November 1985, the Central Organization Department issued a "Notice on Urgently Handling the Historical Issues of the Underground Party", requiring local organization departments to continue to handle the historical issues of the underground party based on the central spirit of basically completing policy implementation before the Thirteenth Party Congress. Also, it answered the questions about the living allowances related to the comrades of the underground party who have been wronged for a long time. 

Under the correct leadership of the Central Committee and the concerted efforts of the related provinces and cities, this work basically ended before the Thirteenth Congress, and the historical issues of the underground party were properly handled, restoring the revolutionary image of the underground party, clarifying right from wrong, and strengthening party unity. 

(5) Serious implementation of the policy about intelligence and investigation personnel. This is an important task in the later stages of the work of rectifying wrongful cases and implementing cadre policies. The Party's intelligence and investigation work, whether in the war years or the construction years, played an important role in revolution and construction. However, since the founding of New China, in various political movements, especially during the "Cultural Revolution", due to the "leftist" thought influence and work mistakes, the special circumstances of intelligence and investigation work were neglected, causing many intelligence and investigation personnel as well as leading cadres to be wrongly handled, resulting in a lot of wrongful cases. 

Since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Party, local party organizations have corrected some wrongful cases among intelligence and investigation personnel in the work of rectifying wrongful cases and implementing cadre policies, especially the significant impact of the Central Committee's rectification for Pan Han-nian, who suffered from injustices for many years. However, the historical issues left over by intelligence and investigation personnel are relatively complex. Some areas and departments, due to a lack of understanding of the Party's policies, practices, and features of intelligence and investigation work, and a lack of policy basis to handle the problems that intelligence and investigation personnel experienced under specific conditions, hence some wrongly handled intelligence and investigation personnel's issues and aftermath work have not been resolved, or were not thoroughly resolved. 

To this end, the party group of the State Security Department and the Central Organization Department submitted a "Request Report on Seriously Implementing the Intelligence Investigation Personnel Policy" to the Central Secretariat in April 1986. The Central Secretariat instructed that implementing the policy for intelligence and investigation personnel is a serious political task that all parts and relevant departments should seriously implement. In implementing the policy, the special nature of intelligence work should be fully taken into account. According to the policies and strategies of our party's struggle against the enemy at different times, closely combined with the historical environment and actual situation at that time, we should comprehensively analyze and investigate in a realistic manner..




Specific issues should be handled in the spirit of 'preferred simplicity over complexity' and 'leniency over severity'. In May of the same year, with the consent of the Central Committee, the General Office of the Communist Party of China (CPC) Central Committee forwarded this request report. In July, the National Security Department and the Central Organization Department jointly held a symposium in Beijing on the implementation of the policy for intelligence officers in provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the Central Government. The symposium focused on implementing the central directive for intelligence officers and the notification from the General Office of the CPC Central Committee. It further deepened the understanding of the importance of this work, clarified the guiding ideology and measures for the work, and made relevant work arrangements. After the meeting, the implementation of the policy for intelligence personnel was launched in 24 provinces, municipalities, and districts nationwide, and the relevant ministries of the central state organs.

Each province, municipality, and district attaches great importance to this work. Some provinces have even established special organizations to carry out this task. However, due to the uniqueness, complexity, and difficulty of implementing the policy for intelligence officers, this work was not completely finished until the early 1990s. Nationwide, many cases of injustice were righted, and policies for intelligence officers were implemented for thousands of people, achieving remarkable results.

The nationwide rectification of unjust cases and the implementation of policies for intelligence officers is unprecedented in the history of intelligence work and has achieved significant results. This fully reflects the party's care for intelligence officers and the spirit of thorough responsibility, relieving the comrades and their families who had been wrongly dealt with of their years-long burdens. This has played a positive role in winning over friends, consolidating comrades, stimulating enthusiasm among comrades in the intelligence front, enhancing cohesion, and promoting the development of national security work.

(6) Exoneration for the novel "Liu Zhidan." At the Central Working Conference in Beidaihe in 1962 and at the Tenth Plenary Session of the Eighth Central Committee, the unpublished novel "Liu Zhidan" was criticized due to the instigation of Kang Sheng. After the meeting, the writing of this novel was communicated as an anti-party event within the party, and long-term special case examinations were carried out on the novel itself, the novel's author Li Jiantong, Xi Zhongxun, Liu Jingfan who reviewed the manuscript, and comrades from the Worker Publishing House who organized the creation of the novel. The special case examination had not ended by the time the "Cultural Revolution" began, and no formal conclusion was made. During the "Cultural Revolution," Kang Sheng, in collaboration with Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four," launched a larger scale of political persecution on the issue of the novel "Liu Zhidan." Yao Wenyuan published an article declaring "Liu Zhidan" an anti-party novel and stating that the author and the comrades who supported the book were anti-party elements. Subsequently, the comrades who had been under special case examination suffered even more serious devastation, and the number of people implicated increased. Those who had read the manuscript and supported the creation of the novel, including a group of old cadres and party members from the original Shaan-Gan revolutionary base area, and even some comrades who had participated in the special case examination, suffered varying degrees of persecution, and some were persecuted to death. Li Jiantong was identified as a "key member of the anti-revolutionary group active in anti-party activities by using the novel, induced by Xi Zhongxun." Until May 1977, a review conclusion given to Liu Jingfan by the Central Special Case Group still claimed that Liu Jingfan "threw out the anti-Party novel 'Liu Zhidan' in collusion with Xi Zhongxun, intending to overthrow Gao Gang."

In 1979, the Central Organization Department reviewed the case, and the facts showed that novel "Liu Zhidan" (submitted for review) was not an anti-party novel but a relatively good novel praising the older generation of proletarian revolutionaries and depicting the history of revolutionary struggle. Xi Zhongxun and other comrades' attention to the creation of this novel and their suggestions on how to improve it were completely legitimate and cannot be said to be activities of any anti-party plot group. Looking at the entire case, the so-called use of writing novel "Liu Zhidan" for anti-party activities case was a major wrongdoing created by Kang Sheng and was a modern literary prison case caused by Kang Sheng, in collaboration with Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" during the "Cultural Revolution," which implicated many people. Therefore, in August 1979, the Central Committee endorsed the report from the Central Organization Department on the exoneration of the novel "Liu Zhidan."



By publishing articles in newspapers to clarify right from wrong, comrades who have been unjustly accused are vindicated, and follow-up work is done, this major wrongful case has been justly resolved, greatly touching the hearts of the public. 
(7) The so-called "Peng, Gao, Xi Anti-Party Group" was rectified. The so-called "Peng Dehuai, Gao Gang, Xi Zhongxun Anti-Party Group" was fabricated by Kang Sheng after the 10th plenary session of the 8th CCP Central Committee in the special case review of Xi Zhongxun. He abused his power, issued "instructions", made false accusations, and launched a series of activities to denounce the "Peng, Gao, Xi Anti-Party Group." In 1965, the "Outline for Xi Zhongxun's Anti-Party Issue" approved by Kang Sheng was distributed and communicated among leaders at all levels, with the so-called "thorough purge of the evil influence of Peng, Gao, and Xi." As a result, not only were Peng Dehuai and Xi Zhongxun slandered and persecuted, but also a group of comrades who had worked with them were implicated.

During the "Cultural Revolution", Kang Sheng, Lin Biao, the "Gang of Four" and their proxies in Shaanxi, further played up the so-called "Peng, Gao, Xi Anti-Party Group" issue, claiming that the "enemy situation in Shaanxi was serious", and that "Peng Dehuai, Gao Gang, and Xi Zhongxun used Xi'an, Shaanxi as their rear base". Under the name of "cleaning up the team", they conducted actions like "checking the dark line", "digging up the dark root", painted the original Northwest Bureau, the Shaanxi Provincial Party Committee, Shaanxi People's Committee, Xi'an Municipal Committee, and the Municipal People's Committee as "five black nests", treating them as the "old forces" of Peng, Gao, and Xi and "thoroughly smashed" them. Many of the members of the four standing committees of the Provincial Party Committee since the founding of New China were branded by them as "traitors", "spies", and the "die-hard followers of Peng, Gao, and Xi." They put more than fifty leading cadres of the Northwest Bureau, Shaanxi Provincial Committee, and Xi'an Municipal Committee into prison, fabricated crimes and persecuted them in a fascist manner.

In 1979, after reexamination by the Shaanxi Provincial Party Committee, the so-called "Peng, Gao, Xi Anti-Party Group" was extremely absurd and purely defamatory, causing many wrongful cases and causing significant harm and impact on the work in Shaanxi. Although Peng Dehuai has been exonerated by the Central Committee, and the issue of Xi Zhongxun has also been resolved, given the wide-ranging implications of the so-called "Peng, Gao, Xi Anti-Party Group" issue in Shaanxi and the strong public reaction, the CPC Shaanxi Provincial Committee believes that it is still necessary to solemnly announce the complete exoneration of this false case. In January 1980, with the approval of the CPC Central Committee, the Organization Department of the CPC Central Committee forwarded the "Proposal Report on the Complete Rectification of the so-called 'Peng, Gao, Xi Anti-Party Group' Issue" from the CPC Shaanxi Provincial Committee, to completely and thoroughly rectify this false case.

(8) Properly dealing with the issue of innocent victims in the purge in Soviet areas. The issue of innocent victims during the purge in Soviet areas is a major historical issue that has wide implications and involves many people. From 1930 to 1935, under the influence of the "left-leaning" erroneous line, several major Soviet areas, including the Central Soviet Area, West Hunan-Hubei, Hubei-Henan-Anhui, West Fujian, Sichuan-Shaanxi, and Shaanxi-Gansu, launched campaigns to purge "8th Regiment", "Reorganization Faction", "Social Democratic Party", "Third Party", and "Cancellation Faction". Many comrades were wrongly jailed and killed. The resolution on certain historical issues at the 7th Plenary Session of the 6th Party Congress in 1945 explicitly stated:
"Due to the mingling of erroneous anti-spionage policies and sectarianism in cadre policies, a large number of excellent comrades have been wrongfully dealt with and framed, resulting in extremely regrettable losses within the Party." "All comrades who have been unjustly treated and framed after investigation should be exonerated, party membership should be restored, and they should be memorialized by comrades." But due to historical limitations, this problem was not able to be resolved before the founding of New China.



After the establishment of New China, in 1954, the central government proposed suggestions on how to properly address this issue. The internal department of the central people's government issued "Notice on the Handling of Wrongfully Executed Persons and Their Relatives in the Period of the Second Domestic Revolutionary War". Following the spirit of the notice, the provinces of Jiangxi, Fujian, Hubei, and others have exonerated nearly 20,000 people. Other provinces have also exonerated wrongly executed party, political, and military leaders. However, the issue regarding the majority of the people has not yet been resolved. After the third plenary session of the 11th Central Committee of the Communist Party, many relatives of the wrongfully executed individuals and some elderly comrades repeatedly demanded a thorough solution to this historical issue. Leading comrades in the central government directed the central organization department and the Ministry of Civil Affairs to propose handling methods. In March and June of 1983, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council approved two opinions on handling these wrongly executed individuals. The State Council transferred the Ministry of Civil Affairs' "Notice on the Handling of Wrongly Executed Persons During the Period of the Second Domestic Revolutionary War". The organizational departments and civil affairs departments of The provinces Hu'bei, An'hui, He'nan, Fu'jian, Jiang'xi, Si'chuan, Shan'xi, and others, worked closely together to conduct thorough reviews.

Under the leadership of the Central Committee and the efforts of the relevant provinces and cities, after three years of hard work, the wrongful cases were finally cleared in Soviet former territories' anti-counter revolution campaign. Those wrongly executed or improperly treated, and their widows were adequately compensated. This major historical issue that had been dragging on for decades was thoroughly resolved.

In June 1979, Ji Pengfei, Li Da, Hu'ang Zhen, Wang Youping, Yuan Xuezu, Su Jin, and other 12 elderly comrades wrote to the central government. They reflected that the famous generals Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue of the Ningdu Uprising, who were part of the former Red Army's 5th Corps, had been wrongly executed in 1934 and suggested their names be cleared. In accordance with instructions of leading comrades in the central government, the Central Organization Department sent personnel to investigate, consulting with more than 70 elderly comrades and reviewing relevant archives. Ji Zhentong was originally one of Nationalist Party's 26th Route's 25th Division 74th Brigade, and Huang Zhongyue was a regiment commander. On December 14, 1931, they took part in the nationwide shaking “Ningdu Uprising” led by Communist Party member Zhao Bosheng and other key commanders. After their uprising, the ten thousand soldiers were organized into the Red 5th Army, and Ji Zhentong was inducted into the Communist Party as a special member, taking up the position of army commander. Huang Zhongyue was the commander of the 15th Army. In the spring of 1932, the National Security Bureau found that the faction led by Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue intended to abscond with the troops, branding them as counter-revolutionaries and later, under the influence of Wang Ming's "Leftist", they were executed on the eve of the Long March. 

For this case, comrade Ye Jianying remarked: "I heard Chairman Mao say (probably in Yan'an) that killing Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue was a mistake, and now I think this wrongful case should be cleared." From the Central Organization Department’s review, Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue made significant contributions to the Ningdu Uprising and had a substantial impact, and so should be recognized. He Yingqin once sent people to get in contact with Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue to cause defection, but although Ji and Huang did not report this contact to the organization, the enemy's attempt at defection was unsuccessful. Their execution was unjustified and should be redressed and their reputations restored. In August 1981, the Central Secretariat approved and agreed to the "Request for the Redress of Comrades Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue of the Former Red Army's 5th Corps by the Central Organization Department". They also decided to properly evaluate Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue's contributions to the uprising, thus resolving the wrongful case, which had been a miscarriage of justice for nearly half a century, in a fair and reasonable manner.



(10) To fully redress the "Suto Incident" in Huxi. The Huxi "Suto Incident" occurred between August and November 1939, starting from the lakeside regional committee and then spreading to the entire Sulu Yu border region. A large number of officials were arrested and killed in this incident, causing severe losses. In November 1939, Luo Ronghuan and Guo Hongtao, the heads of the Shandong branch of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), rushed to Huxi and took emergency measures to stop the development of this event. From 1940 to 1945, the central government and the Shandong branch made several reviews and confirmed that Wang Xuren, the former Minister of Organization of the lakeside regional committee, was the prime culprit who was of unknown origin and created the "Suto Incident". However, due to the historical conditions at that time, no definite conclusion was made about the nature of the incident, resulting in many legacy issues being inadequately addressed. Some relatives of the wronged comrades were tagged as "anti-relatives" during the "Cultural Revolution". The Shandong Provincial Committee rechecked this historical injustice according to the spirit of the Central Government's instructions on redressing wrong cases. In May 1983, the CCP Shandong Provincial Committee submitted a report to the Central Committee on "Suggestions for handling the remaining issues of the Huxi 'Suto Incident'", pointing out that this was not an exaggerated issue. The "Suto Movement" in 1939 aimed to purge "Trotskyite members" and "Trotskyite organizations" without any factual basis. The seven so-called "true Trotskyist bandits" were found to be false one by one. This was a major false and wrong case that should be fully redressed. For those comrades who were wrongfully killed or handled improperly, they are to be completely rehabilitated and vindicated. The family members and children of those affected should also be completely rehabilitated and their reputations cleared. Approved by the central government, the Organisation Department of the Central Committee forwarded the report of the CCP Shandong Provincial Committee on "Suggestions for handling the remaining issues of the Huxi 'Suto Incident'" in December 1983, enabling this long-standing wrong case to be fully redressed.

(11) To redress the so-called "Trotskyite case" of the Fourth Division of the New Fourth Army and the Huabei and Huanan bases in 1941. In October 1984, the Organization Department of the CCP Central Committee and the General Political Department of the People's Liberation Army made a "decision on the complete redress of the so-called Trotskyite case of the Fourth Division of the New Fourth Army and the Huabei and Huanan bases in 1941". The decision pointed out that the CCP branch of the Guangxi Student Army, from its establishment in May 1938 to its withdrawal to Huabei and Huanan bases in March 1940, under the direct leadership of the Anhui Provincial Work Committee, the Party Committee of the Eyuwan area and the Lihuang City Committee, did good work in mobilizing and organizing the masses, insisting on resistance behind enemy lines, propagating the party's Anti-Japanese National United Front policy and Anti-Japanese political advocacy, and shielding underground party leadership organs. Communist members and progressive masses in the Guangxi Student Army made positive contributions to the Anti-Japanese armed struggle and base construction after arriving at the New Fourth Army and the Huabei and Huanan bases. In the past, defaming the CCP branch of the Guangxi Student Army as a "Trotskyite organization" and reviewing dozens of comrades for "Trotskyite issues" was groundless. The so-called Trotskyite case was completely unjustified. To eliminate the impact of this historical injustice, it was decided to completely vindicate the Guangxi Student Army CCP branch and all comrades who were wrongly reviewed, wrongfully executed in this case, and restore their reputations. The relevant regional and unit party organizations shall, in accordance with relevant central provisions, carefully sort out archival materials and do a good job of follow-up work.

(12) Proper handling of the historical legacy of the "Central Plains Breakout". In August 1980, Zheng Shaowen, Zhang Zhiyi, and others wrote to the Party Central Committee requesting that the remaining issues of the "Central Plains Breakout" be resolved realistically and properly. Hu Yaobang made an important instruction on the letter, asking the relevant departments to handle it properly.
In 1946, our troops in the Central Plains and the party and government organs in the liberated areas of the Central Plains, under the heavy siege of 300,000 troops of the Kuomintang, carried out a strategic shift - breakout. Due to the extremely urgent situation, in order to preserve forces, the original Central Plains Bureau of our party formulated some special policies, mobilized a large number of comrades who could not break out with the army to be demobilized and to go undercover. During the breakout process, many comrades were scattered and lost.



Some of them, due to reasons such as demobilization, concealment, and falling behind, did not get proper resolutions to issues such as party memberships, experience in revolutionary work, and historical problems, but were also treated unjustly. On May 29, 1957, Zheng Wei San, the former secretary of the Central Plains Bureau, and Chen Shao Min, the minister of the organization department, both wrote a special letter to the Central Organization Department detailing the situation. The letter stated that, before the breakout from the Central Plains in 1946, the situation was already very urgent, and a large number of local work cadres were unable to mobilize with the army. In order to conserve strength, we had made the following decision: try as much as possible to disguise themselves and go to other liberated areas using social connections; those who couldn't disguise themselves should use social connections to hide; if found by the enemy and unable to hide, they could surrender to the enemy as New Fourth Army soldiers or agricultural association members, as long as they did not reveal their party memberships or surrender as party members; future return to the ranks would not be treated as surrender; if they surrender as party members, they would be dealt with separately. This decision, made under very difficult circumstances, was our responsibility if wrong. The Central Organization Department forwarded this letter to the provincial committees of Hubei and Henan for handling, asking them to pay attention to the conditions discussed in the letter while dealing with the surrender of party members in the Central Plains liberated area. However, it did not receive the attention it deserved at the time. In the early days of the founding of the People's Republic of China, when dealing with the historical issues left over from the "Central Plains Breakout", some comrades were judged too harshly due to insufficient consideration of the historical context and a lack of detailed analysis. Especially during the "Cultural Revolution", some comrades were purged and the judgement escalated.

According to the instructions of the Central leadership, the Organization Department of the Hubei Provincial Committee and the Party Group of the Provincial Civil Affairs Department conducted a serious investigation into the historical issues left over from the "Central Plains Breakout" and put forward "Opinions on Handling the Historical Issues Left Over from the Demobilized, Concealed, and Fallen Behind Personnel during the Central Plains Breakout", pointing out that the remaining issues of the demobilized, concealed, and fallen behind personnel during the Central Plains Breakout should be handled in accordance with the basic spirit of the letter from Zheng Wei San and Chen Shao Min, which was forwarded by the Central Organization Department on June 6, 1957, and the Central Organization Department's "Opinions on Thoroughly Redressing Wrong and False Cases and Further Doing a Good Job in Implementing Cadre Policies" on February 19, 1981. Based on the principle of "seeking truth from facts and correcting mistakes", their issues should be carefully sorted out and resolved properly and cautiously; the past conclusions on issues such as party membership, work arrangement, retirement, and calculation of time in work, and issues related to honoring the demobilized soldiers and martyrs, should be adjusted if they were wrong. In July 1981, the Central Organization Department forwarded the "Opinions on Handling the Historical Issues Left Over from the Central Plains Breakout" from the Organization Department of the Hubei Provincial Committee and the Party Group of the Provincial Civil Affairs Department. The relevant provinces, cities, and departments quickly organized the review and correction. Through the review and correction, more than 50,000 cases of demobilized, concealed, and fallen behind personnel were resolved, correcting the wrongly handled cases in the early days of the founding of the People's Republic of China, and this historical issue was properly resolved.

(13) The legacy issue of properly handling the personnel killed in the "Sino-US Cooperation Office" prison on the eve of the liberation of Chongqing. After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, the Central Organization Department of the Communist Party of China entrusted the Organization Department of the Sichuan Provincial Committee to re-investigate and verify the martyrs who were killed in the "Sino-US Cooperation Office" prison on the eve of the liberation of Chongqing. After an in-depth investigation by the Organization Department of the Sichuan Provincial Committee, 83 issues were clarified. The Party organization made objective and fact-based conclusions about them. Among them, 64 people, including Xi Maozhao and Zhang Luping, insisted on the noble character of the Communist Party members, bravely fought, remained unyielding, and calmly sacrificed themselves in prison, demonstrating heroic deeds worth singing and crying about and sufficient to be a role model for future generations, and were posthumously recognized as revolutionary martyrs. This historical issue, which had been delayed for more than thirty years, was finally resolved properly. On November 20, 1986, Xinhua News Agency even made a special report on this matter.

By dealing with the above major historical issues, it promoted the progress of properly handling historical issues nationwide.



Each province, city, autonomous region, and department has reviewed and cleaned up the historical issues left over in their region and department. A large number of historical issues in their region and department have been properly handled. According to incomplete statistics, during the process of properly handling historical issues, nearly two million historical cases from before the "Cultural Revolution" were re-examined and handled nationwide. Before the Thirteenth Congress in 1987, the nationwide work of properly handling historical issues was basically completed. By properly handling historical issues, the enthusiasm of the vast majority of cadres and the masses was greatly mobilized, contributing to social stability and unity, promoting the rectification of wrong cases, implementing cadre policy work, and ensuring that this work was completed victoriously before the Thirteenth Congress.

III. Reasonably Adjusting Social Relations under the New Situation
While rectifying wrong cases on a large scale, the Central Committee of the Party also studied and dealt with some historical issues in a practical manner, adjusted social relations, and implemented policies in various aspects.
1. Fully implement the intellectual policy and solve the practical problems of intellectuals
Implementing the intellectual policy is an important part of rectifying wrong cases and implementing cadre policy work. This spans the entire process of rectifying wrong cases and implementing cadre policies, from 1978 until its victorious completion before the Thirteenth Congress in 1987.
Our intellectuals have a fine tradition of patriotism. After years of education by the Party, the vast majority of intellectuals support the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party and love their socialist motherland. However, due to a "left" bias and discrimination against intellectuals that had formed over a long period, many intellectuals were impacted to varying degrees during each political movement. During the "Cultural Revolution", many intellectuals were once again severely persecuted.
After the smashing of the "Gang of Four", in March 1978, Deng Xiaoping delivered an important speech at the National Science Conference. He clarified the basic Marxist principles on the position and role of science and technology in social development. He pointed out that the intellectual workers serving socialism are part of the working people and stressed the necessity of creating a larger force of science and technology in our country. Deng Xiaoping's discussion on intellectuals being part of the working class greatly inspired the intellectuals to love the party and build the socialist motherland. At the same time, it also cleared the obstacles for the large-scale implementation of intellectual policies and pointed out the direction.
From October to November 1978, the Central Organization Department of the Communist Party of China held a symposium on implementing the intellectual policy. The meeting believed that the situation of the intellectual team had undergone profound changes. The guidelines for the "unity, education, and transformation" of intellectuals put forward at the beginning of the founding of the country are no longer applicable to the current situation. It is imperative to properly implement the intellectual policy. On November 3, the Organization Department issued a notice on "Several Opinions on Implementing the Party's Intellectual Policy", proposing six requirements for the implementation of intellectual policy: First, there should be a correct estimate of the intellectual team. Second, continue to do a good job of reviewing and rectifying wrongful cases. Third, fully trust, let go, and ensure that there are positions, power, and responsibilities. Fourth, adjust the use of non-professional talents, and make the best use of talents. Fifth, strive to improve working and living conditions. Sixth, strengthen leadership and improve style. After the document was issued, the large-scale implementation of intellectual policy gradually unfolded nationwide, and respect for knowledge and talent gradually gained traction in society.



Hu Yaobang paid great attention to this work and put in a lot of effort. He made many important notes on the problems encountered in implementing the policy for intellectuals. In accordance with Hu Yaobang's series of instructions and the Central Committee's proposal to complete the reversal of wrongful cases before the Thirteenth Congress, the Central Organization Department worked with relevant departments to seriously implement inspections and follow-up work on the policy for intellectuals. This was one of the focal points of the Central Organization Department during this period.

In May 1985, the Central Organization Department and the Central United Front Department jointly held a national seminar on the implementation of policies for intellectuals, specifically studying how to complete the task set by the Central Committee before the Thirteenth Congress. They focused on the establishment of a responsibility system divided by departments and levels. Leadership at all levels, especially colleagues in the organization departments, were asked to personally go to the grassroots to supervise and help solve difficult problems, and solidly carry out the work of implementing policies for intellectuals.
