In September 1986, with the approval of central leaders, the Organization Department of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued a "Notice on the Inspection of the Implementation of the Intellectual Policy", which pointed out that the task of implementing the intellectual policy and solving historical legacy issues had been substantially completed in some regions and departments. The majority of regions and departments planned to complete it in the second half of the year. In order to ensure the quality of the work, the units were asked for a careful inspection. Specific requirements were put forward for the scope and content of the inspection, organization, leadership, and step-by-step methods. In November, the Organization Department of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China held experience exchange meetings in Dalian, Wuhan, and Beijing. According to statistics from 25 provinces (regions, cities), more than 7.1 million people (items) had their various issues resolved in the implementation of policies for intellectuals.

The above measures greatly promoted and propelled the deep development of the implementation of policies for intellectuals. Under the caring concern of the central leadership and the collective efforts of all regions and departments, this arduous task was basically completed before the Thirteenth Congress of the Party.

2. Cap Removing and Problem-Solving for Offsprings of Landlords and Wealthy Peasants

On January 11, 1979, in accordance with the principles passed at the Third Plenary Session of the 11th CPC Central Committee, the CPC Central Committee made the "Decision on the Issue of Cap Removal for Landlords and Wealthy Peasants and the Component Issue of Landlord and Wealthy Peasants' Offspring" (hereinafter referred to as the "Decision"). The "Decision" announced that all landlords and wealthy peasants, as well as counter-revolutionaries and bad elements who had obeyed the laws and regulations of the government for many years, worked honestly, and did not do evil, would all have their "hats" removed upon approval by the county revolutionary committee through a mass review, and they would be treated as members of the rural people's commune. The offspring of landlords and wealthy peasants, as well as former capitalists and laborers, would automatically become commune members and enjoy the same treatment as other commune members. From then on, they should be mainly judged by their political performance in aspects such as entering school, recruitment, joining the army, joining group or party, and job allocation, and they should not be discriminated against. The "Decision" also required thorough learning of the party's policies from within and outside the party, and thorough ideological education work.

This decision paved the way for at least 20 million people to end their political discrimination, to enjoy the rights they should have as citizens, and to start a new political life. According to Xinhua News Agency, by November 1984, the last batch of "Four Categories" had their "hats" removed smoothly nationwide. The "hats" of those who were mistakenly categorized into the "Four Categories" were also corrected. All of the "Four Categories" who had already left the country or their residences had their "hats" removed, and their families were notified.

3. Restoring the Status of Original Workers and Businessmen



On November 12, 1979, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China approved the request report from six departments, including the United Front Work Department of the Central Committee, on the issue of distinguishing the workers from the original industrial and commercial workers. The report clearly pointed out that in 1956, when private enterprises were combined with public-private partnerships, a large number of small merchants, peddlers, small-scale craftsmen, and other laborers were brought into the partnership, and they were uniformly referred to as private personnel, treated as bourgeois industrial and commercial workers, which was improper. They should be distinguished from the original bourgeois industrial and commercial workers and their original labor composition should be clarified. In accordance with the spirit of this document, after more than a year of work, a total of over 700,000 small merchants, peddlers, small-scale craftsmen, and other laborers were distinguished from the original industrial and commercial workers, the constituent of the workers was restored, thus effectively solving this historical issue left over from socialist transformation and correcting the errors at that time. In the process of carrying out this work, according to the Central's regulations on several specific policies of the former industrial and commercial workers, the hat of the capitalist or capitalist agent was also removed from the former industrial and commercial workers.

4. Resolution of issues relating to historical restrictions on some cadres

During the later stage of the work to redress unjust, false and wrong cases and implement cadre policies, the Central Organization Department also systematically cleaned up some special documents on cadre review issued since the founding of New China, modified or abolished those influenced by "leftist" thinking or no longer applicable due to changes in circumstances. For cadres who were wrongly treated, a review was given for correction. It solved a batch of problems that had been left over for many years, such as some cadres having historical restrictions.   

Restricting the use of some cadres was a special method adopted by our party to suit the war era and special environment in the use of cadres. In the war era and the early days of New China, due to objective constraints, it was difficult to clarify the political history or social relations of some cadres for a while, and it was impossible to make an affirmative or negative conclusion. Therefore, in their service, the party organization placed them in secondary work positions, controlled them appropriately, and continued to inspect them. Adopting this temporary measure was necessary at that time. But for a long time after the establishment of New China, this method was not timely changed, but continued. During the "Cultural Revolution", some places and units abused this method, arbitrarily made restrictive conclusions for some comrades, severely dampened the enthusiasm of some cadres and the public. On February 1, 1979, the 38th issue of "Organization Work Communication" published an article "We Cannot Randomly Conclude the 'Control of Use' for Cadres". The article pointed out that it has been nearly thirty years since the national liberation, and after multiple political movements and organization reviews, some comrades have been cleared and found to be unquestionable, or although there are some issues, but they have consistently shown good performance after a long period of examination. The organization should lift the past doubts, cancel the conclusion of "controlling use", give political trust, and boldly use them according to the conditions of virtue and talent. It clearly states that the cadre will generally not be "controlled" in the future. Only for a very few people who are very likely to harm the socialist cause if they are not controlled, it is necessary to control them in use. But before the problems with them are completely cleared up, those with special skills should pay attention to their role based on the situation, and continue to educate and inspect them in the process of use. With the deepening of redress cases and the implementation of cadre policies, in October 1983, with the approval of the Central Secretariat, the Central Organization Department issued the "Opinions on Resolving Some Problems of Historical Restrictions on Cadres". The document pointed out that before and after the establishment of New China, in the cadre review and anti-corruption campaigns, the Central and the Central Organization Department had regulations to restrict the use of cadres with political history and other issues. These regulations were necessary under historical conditions. But these cadres, who have been used restrictively, have undergone long-term revolutionary struggle and training, and most of them have shown good or better behavior. Some comrades have also made important contributions to the party and the people. In order to use cadres reasonably and fully exert their active role in the four modernizations, the original regulations should be changed. 
To do this work well, in September 1984, the Organization Department of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China forwarded the pilot work report of the cadre review office of Changchun Municipal Committee and Nongan County Committee on resolving some issues regarding historical restrictions on cadres.



In September 1986, the Organization Department of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China submitted a request to the Central Party regarding "Changing the Use Restrictions of Forty-One Cadres Above Deputy Department Level" and, with agreement from central leaders, this was approved. The document pointed out that based on the relevant provisions of the Central Organization Department's "Opinions on Changing the Restricted Use of Cadres who Made Mistakes after Being Arrested and Captured" approved by the Central Party in July 1981 and "Opinions on Lifting Some Cadres' Historical Restrictions on Use" in October 1983, it was proposed that the original restrictions on the use of 41 comrades would be revoked, canceled and removed. Provinces, Autonomous Regions, Municipalities, and ministries of the Central State Organ responded positively and carried out this work in a steady manner based on their managerial authority and Central's recommendation. The efforts to lift historical use restrictions on some cadres ended before the 13th National Congress.

5. Implementing the Party's Ethnic and Religious Policies

Between 1980 and 1981, the Secretariat of the Communist Party of China held conferences in regions like Tibet, Yunnan, Xinjiang, and Inner Mongolia to earnestly solve issues regarding the implementation of the party's ethnic policies. The "hats" of comrades who were labeled "local ethnic nationalists" were removed by the Central and certain local party committees.

In March 1982, the Secretariat of the Communist Party of China issued a document on religious issues during socialism, clarifying the Party's basic views and policies on religion. Before and after this, the activities of patriotic religious groups were restored, temples were gradually renovated and opened, and the party's religious policies were implemented.

6. Implementing Policies for Foreign Experts and Friends Working in China

In September 1981, a foreign expert working in China wrote a letter to central leaders, requesting a revision of the review conclusion. The leaders of the Central Organization Department proposed an overall review of the policy implementation issues of foreign expert friends, and suggested a solution to the Central Secretariat. The central leaders agreed and commented that this foreign expert's "request was reasonable and should be thoroughly rectified without leaving any residue. A comprehensive review and disposition of the policy implementation issues of foreign friends is completely necessary."

Following the leaders' instructions, the Central Organization Department and Ministry of Public Security reviewed the conclusions regarding this foreign expert and others who were working in China, such as Epstein and his wife Qiu Molly who worked in the Foreign Literature Bureau, British expert Chapinoh who worked for Xinhua News Agency, and British expert Kruk who worked in the Foreign Language Institute, and implemented the policy. They also understood the status of policy implementation for foreign experts from units such as the National Foreign Experts Bureau. According to investigations, most foreign experts affected during the "Cultural Revolution" have been exonerated, their reputation restored, wages replenished, and they have been re-assigned to their jobs. Nevertheless, many issues still exist and need to be carefully resolved.

Therefore, the Central Organization Department and Party Group of Ministry of Public Security submitted a "Report on the Policy Implementation Situation for Foreign Expert Friends" to the Central Party, affirming the significant contributions made by foreign experts in China's revolution and construction, underscoring that they should be respected by our Party and people, and requesting relevant units to carry out comprehensive checks and clean ups on policy implementation for foreign expert friends. Any discovered issues should be promptly resolved to eliminate adverse effects. For experts hurt during the "Cultural Revolution", political rehabilitation should be thorough, their lives well cared for, and work enthusiastically supported. Our Party's series of guidelines and policies on cadre policy implementation should be fully implemented among foreign expert friends. In addition, their characteristics should be taken into consideration, and preferential treatment given. In March 1982, the Central Committee of the Communist Party endorsed the report of the Central Organization Department and Party Group of the Ministry of Public Security. After the document was issued, comprehensive clarifications were made on policy implementation issues for foreign experts working in China and they were promptly and appropriately handled. This eliminated adverse effects, allowing foreign experts and friends working in China to serve China's socialist modernization faithfully and restoring our international reputation.



This nationwide rectification of wrongful cases, adjustment of social relations, and implementation of various policies, unlike anything in the history of our Party, in terms of its length of time, broadness of content, and massive scale, thoroughly solves problems. The resolution of the above-mentioned historical issues and the implementation of the Party's policies effectively mobilized the enthusiasm of all strata of society, consolidated and developed the patriotic united front, and greatly promoted the ideological liberation of the whole Party, the rectification of organizational lines, the consolidation and development of a stable, united political situation, the assurance of socialist modernization, and the unification of the motherland. 

IV. Restoration of the Party's Nationality and Religious Policies

During the "Cultural Revolution", like other fronts, work on nationality and religion was seriously harmed and restricted by the "leftist" guiding ideology. The institutions for nationality and religion work were cancelled, and the nationality and religion work was falsely accused. After smashing the "Gang of Four", the urgent task in the field of nationality and religion work was to heal the trauma brought by the ten years of turmoil to the nationality and religion work, adjust the nationality and religion relations, reaffirm and restore the Party's nationality and religious policies, formulate guidelines to guide the nationality and religion work under new conditions, and carry out groundbreaking work.

1. Restoration of the party's nationality policy

To reaffirm and adhere to the party's nationality policy, and implement the party's nationality policy, we need an organization and people to do this important work. The first session of the Fifth National People's Congress in 1978 decided to restore the State Ethnic Affairs Commission of the People's Republic of China and appointed Yang Jingren as the director. The second session of the Fifth National People's Congress in 1979 decided to restore the Ethnic Affairs Committee of the National People's Congress and appointed Vice Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, Apa Awang Jinmei, as concurrent chairman. Other nationality work institutions and ethnic affairs work institutions at all levels across the country were also restored.

Shortly after the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Party, in April 1979, the Central Government hosted the National Frontier Work Conference. This conference is of great historical significance for consolidating the national frontier, promoting national unity, and rectifying the chaos in national work. One of the main contents of the meeting was to discuss the tasks of national work in the new era. Because most of the border areas of China are minority areas, to build a solid defense, maintain national unity, develop a stable and united situation, it is necessary to do a good job in national work, promote national unity and common development and prosperity. The meeting reaffirmed a series of national policies, religious policies, united front policies that have been proven correct by practice, against the damages of Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" to national policy and national work, focusing on the practice of national work since the founding of New China, summarizing the lessons and experiences: First, we must adhere to the principle of linking theory with practice, and starting from reality. The situation in border minority areas is complicated, and the implementation of the party's line, guidelines, and policies, and the realization of the overall tasks of the new era must be well combined with the national characteristics and regional characteristics of the border minority areas. Second, we must insist on the long-term existence of the national question. The socialist stage is a period where all nationalities develop and prosper together. Throughout the socialist historical stage, the task of national work is arduous, we must pay attention to national issues, seriously implement the party's national policy, and truly respect the equal rights and autonomous rights of minority nationalities. Third, we must adhere to the proletarian view of nationality and continually strengthen the great unity of the people of all nationalities based on the solid alliance of workers and farmers. The consolidation of national unity and the unity of all nationalities in the country is the fundamental guarantee for accelerating the realization of the overall tasks of the new era. Fourth, we must persist in the policy of combining state support with self-reliance, and accelerate the economic and cultural construction of the frontier minority areas.



Practice has proven that developing the economic and cultural construct in minority areas of the frontier relies on the tough struggle and self-reliance of the local people of all ethnic groups. Concurrently, the state must actively support and pay particular attention to these areas while earnestly aiding their economic and cultural development. This is a major task for the state in terms of its ethnic work. The Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) approved the conference report, urging the whole party to attach great importance to ethnic work, carry out reeducation of ethnic policies and solve existing problems by checking the implementation of these policies.

In September 1979, the CPC Central Committee approved the document of the National United Front Work Conference titled "Guidelines and Missions of the United Front in the New Historical Period". As for strengthening ethnic work, it asked for reeducation on ethnic policies to be carried out widely and thoroughly among the entire party and all ethnic groups, and to solve problems related to ethnic relations and eliminate any factors that could harm unity. It urged education for cadres and people of all ethnic groups, particularly Han Chinese, to comprehend the importance of strengthening ethnic unity and improving their awareness of implementing ethnic policies. It stressed respecting minorities' equal rights, self-rule rights, native language, customs, and religious beliefs, as well as implementing the party's freedom of religious belief policy entirely.

Implementing the party's ethnic policy should not only regard the areas inhabited by the ethnic minorities but also consider mixed and dispersed living areas. In October 1979, a report entitled "About Doing a Good Job in Ethnic Work in Mixed and Scattered Areas of Ethnic Minorities" was approved by the CPC Central Committee and the State Council where they pointed out that although the criticism of Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" had triumphed, some areas had not applied ethnic and religious policies thoroughly and some cases of injustice had not been redressed. Suggesting that it was necessary to earnestly safeguard their equal rights, actively help minorities develop economically and culturally, fully respect their customs and implement the freedom of religious beliefs policy.

In response to the dilution of people's concept of ethnic policy caused by the ten years of turmoil, the CPC Central Committee Propaganda Department, the United Front Work Department, and the State Nationalities Commission held a symposium on ethnic policy propaganda work in December 1979, making arrangements for reeducation on ethnic policies, and deciding to conduct a widespread propaganda education on ethnic policies and ethnic unity for a period of time. In January 1980, the three departments approved the meeting minutes, stating that it is very important to conduct ethnic policy education. The focus of the reeducation should be on overcoming Han chauvinism, which is the key to adjusting ethnic relations and promoting ethnic unity at the moment, while also preventing and overcoming major ethnic nationalism and local ethnic nationalism. Both the Han and the ethnic minorities should be educated, mainly focusing on educating the Han. The reeducation should be combined with the inspection of the implementation of ethnic policies to solve practical problems. From central to local levels, some outstanding issues related to ethnic relations were solved by carrying out reeducation on ethnic policies and inspecting the implementation of ethnic policies, religious policies, and united front policies. The understanding of ethnic policies and the awareness of maintaining ethnic unity among the vast number of cadres and the masses have been raised, and ethnic relations have improved initially.



For example, in the Xinjiang Uighur Autonomous Region, there is a concentrated effort to enact ethnic policies and promote ethnic unity through education. The region has issued and implemented the "Ethnic Unity Code", formulated the "Ethnic Unity Convention", and broadly held commendations for progress in ethnic unity across the entire autonomous region, carrying out activities supporting ethnic unity and progress. The General Office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China forwarded documents from the Party Committee of the Xinjiang Uighur Autonomous Region, pointing out that diligently implementing the party’s ethnic policy, and continuously strengthening ethnic unity, is a very important task for every party committee in ethnic autonomous regions and areas where various ethnic groups live together. Concrete measures should be formulated and enforced to strengthen ethnic policy education and promote substantial progress in ethnic unity.

Restoring and adhering to the party's ethnic policy principally involves adhering to and implementing the policy of ethnic regional autonomy. This includes first restoring the structure of ethnic regional autonomy, followed by training officials from ethnic minorities. In 1979, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council decided to restore the original administrative divisions of the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, which had been previously allocated to Liaoning, Jilin, Heilongjiang, Gansu, and Ningxia during the Cultural Revolution. Work related to ethnic regional autonomy that had been forced to stop due to the ten years of turbulence was restarted. At the same time, a number of new ethnic autonomous regions were established. From 1979 to the end of 1988, a total of 53 new ethnic autonomous regions were established nationwide. Implementing the policy of ethnic regional autonomy allows autonomous ethnic groups to truly manage their own affairs, and training of officials from ethnic minorities is crucial. The Constitution of the People's Republic of China promulgated in 1982 restored and developed some important principles concerning ethnic regional autonomy from the 1954 constitution. It also made a series of important amendments and supplements based on changes in state affairs during the new period of socialist construction, expanding even further the autonomous rights of ethnic autonomous organizations. After the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Party, a large number of ethnic minority officials returned to their job through the "correction of chaos" and retrials of cases where injustice had been done, gradually increasing the intensity of this work at all levels from central to local, adopting a number of effective measures, and rapidly growing the ethnic cadre to 1.84 million by 1988.

2. A New Policy for the Work in Tibet

Among China's relations with its various ethnic groups, Tibet bears a unique sensitivity. Work resolving historical issues in Tibet commenced in 1977 and this included the retroactive exoneration and re-examination of cadre who had been allocated full-time positions for trial and investigation pre-Cultural Revolution and during the Cultural Revolution. After the Central Work Conference was held in November 1978, Deng Xiaoping conveyed a willingness for reconciliation with the Dalai Lama to the West within a week. Three months later, Deng Xiaoping personally met representatives sent by the Dalai Lama in Beijing, publically expressing "Welcome back, Dalai, welcome more people to come back and visit."

In February 1980, Hu Yaobang, who was elected General Secretary of the Central Committee, first focused on the issue of Tibet. From March 14th to 15th, 1980, he presided over a symposium on Tibet work, listening to reports from officials responsible for the Party Committee of the Tibetan Autonomous Region. Hu Yaobang emphasized in the meeting that in order to accelerate the construction in Tibet, we must further liberate thinking, implement policies, decisively cleanse the remaining toxins of the "leftist" line, correct the "leftist" economic policies, boldly train and promote Tibetan officials, and gradually make Tibetan officials the main body in party and government agencies above the county level.



It must be prudent in dealing with Lamaism in religion, urgently handle the historical problems such as the expansion of rebellion and the misjudgment of the rich peasants, and strengthen the work on the Dalai group and the relatives of the Tibetans living in the territory, mobilize all positive factors, and consolidate the stable and united situation. On April 7, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China forwarded the minutes of this meeting and issued a notice. In late May, Hu Yaobang, Wan Li and the leaders of the relevant central departments formed a delegation of over ten people to inspect Tibet. On May 29, Hu Yaobang made a report at the Tibet Autonomous Region cadre conference at the county level and above, proposing that Tibet should do well in six major tasks, including decisively implementing the policy of rest and recuperation, implementing more flexible economic policies than the mainland, and restoring and developing Tibetan culture and science. The most important ones are the following two: one is to grant Tibet a "full and independent autonomy", and the policy of the central government can not be implemented or can be implemented flexibly if it does not fit the Tibetan situation, and if it is not conducive to national unity or the development of productivity, it can not be implemented. The second is to emphasize the strengthening of the unity between Han and Tibetan cadres, and the method is to gradually withdraw Han cadres and replace them with Tibetan cadres, so that Tibetan cadres account for more than two-thirds of the national cadre out of production within two or three years. For the cadres who go to Tibet to work, Hu Yaobang both encourages and criticizes, thinking that "Han cadres working in Tibet have completed their historical tasks", proposing that 80% of Han people withdraw from Tibet. According to Hu Yaobang's opinion, the Tibet Autonomous Region submitted a report to the central government on the "Request Report for the Large-scale Transfer Back of Cadres and Workers", proposing that the majority of people entering Tibet be transferred back to work in the mainland or retired in phases and batches, except for a part of the leadership cadres and technical backbone. On August 6, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council forwarded this report. From 1980 to the end of 1981, a total of more than 20,000 cadres have been transferred in two batches, most of whom are the "old Tibetans" who entered Tibet in the 1950s and 1960s. It decided to call back another 17,000 cadres and workers who went to Tibet (including those who retired) in 1986.
The central policy on Tibet had a great impact on ethnic regions such as Inner Mongolia, Xinjiang, Yunnan, Qinghai, Ningxia, and Gansu. On May 31, 1980, during his brief stopover in Ge’ermu, Hu Yaobang told the leaders of Qinghai Province, "The six points we made at the cadre meeting in the Tibet Autonomous Region basically conform to the situation in Qinghai, and you can refer to it for study and implementation." Hu Yaobang and Wan Li both emphasized that the policy should be relaxed a little bit more, and the autonomous rights of ethnic regional autonomy should be fully exercised. The purpose was to apply the policy guidelines for solving Tibet to other ethnic regions. Subsequently, Gansu, Inner Mongolia, Ningxia, Guangxi and other provinces and autonomous regions held meetings to study the central party committee's instructions on work in Tibet and Hu Yaobang's speech in Tibet, and decided to solve local problems in accordance with the central instructions on work in Tibet. Since then, the Central Secretariat of the Communist Party of China has discussed the work of Yunnan, Xinjiang, and Inner Mongolia, leading to the formation of the minutes on the work of the ethnic groups in Yunnan, Xinjiang, and Inner Mongolia.
In the early 1980s, the Party began to adjust its ethnic policy, with the aim of improving ethnic relations. However, the state-compiled "Contemporary Tibet in China" pointed out that a large number of Han people and Han cadres withdrew from Tibet, which was done rather "roughly", causing a group of urgently needed talents in Tibet to be transferred away and causing great impact on various work in Tibet, especially in science and technology, education, medical and health, financial and financial departments. Deng Liqun also raised sharper criticisms from a political perspective on the large-scale withdrawal of cadres entering Tibet. Some domestic scholars also opposed the decision to withdraw cadres from Tibet for national security considerations.
3. Restoration and Adjustment of Religious Policy
After 1957, the "left" mistakes in the party's religious work gradually grew, and further developed in the mid-1960s.



Especially during the "Cultural Revolution," Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" maliciously manipulated the "leftist" errors, wantonly trampled on the scientific theories of Marx-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought on religious issues, entirely negated the correct policy of the Party on religious issues since the founding of the People's Republic of China, and completely ceased the Party's religious work. They forcibly prohibited the religious life of religious believers, treated patriotic religious figures and even ordinary religious believers as "objects of dictatorship," and fabricated numerous false cases in the religious community. They also regarded certain customs of certain ethnic minorities as religious superstitions and forcibly prohibited them. In some places, they even suppressed religious believers and undermined national unity. They used violence on religious issues, but as a result, religious activities somewhat developed in secrecy and disarray. A few bad elements took advantage of these conditions to carry out illegal and destructive activities under the guise of religious activities.

After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Party, the Party's correct policies on religious affairs gradually resumed. The core of the policy adjustment at that time was to allow religious freedom to a certain extent. On December 1, 1978, the United Front Work Department of the Central Committee convened a national seminar on religious work. The primary task of religious work in the future was proposed: to seriously implement the policy of freedom of religious belief, to properly arrange religious activities, and to unite the majority of religious believers to participate in the construction of socialism. It proposed to restore and improve the institutions of religious work and the activities of patriotic religious groups. The Central Committee of the Communist Party of China circulated the minutes of this meeting.

In 1979, nationwide religious groups and local religious organizations successively resumed activities. Various religious clergy members gradually returned to temples and churches to preside over religious affairs again. Some ethnic religious festivals, which had been banned for many years, gradually resumed.

On January 25, 1980, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China approved the report by the United Front Work Department on convening a national conference of religious groups. That year, national conferences of the Islamic Association of China, Taoist Association of China, Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association, Chinese Christian "Three-Self" Patriotic Movement Committee and Buddhist Association of China were successively held. Leaders of each religious group were elected, and they drafted activity constitutions, resumed work, and restored and established 164 provincial religious groups and more than 2000 county-level religious groups. On July 16, the State Council approved the report from the Bureau of Religious Affairs and the National Building Commission, returning all property rights of religious group buildings to the groups, and compensating at discounted prices where return was not possible.

In some larger and medium-sized cities, places where religious activities were historically prevalent and where believers congregated, especially in ethnic minority areas, a number of temples, Taoist temples, and churches were gradually restored in a planned and step-by-step manner. On April 1, 1983, the State Council approved the reopening of 163 key Buddhist and Taoist temples in Han areas. The government provided financial assistance for the restoration of some temples and Taoist temples. According to incomplete statistics, from 1980 to 1991, the central government contributed more than 140 million yuan for the renovation of temples, Taoist temples, and churches. By 1992, more than 60,000 religious sites nationwide had reopened.

Since 1980, China has gradually restored and newly established the Chinese Buddhist Academy, Chinese Islamic University, Chinese Christian Nanjing Jinling Union Theological Seminary, Chinese Catholic Holy Philosophy College, Chinese Taoist College and Chinese Tibetan Advanced Buddhist Institute, and 41 other local religious schools. In March 1982, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China put forward "The Basic Views and Policies on Religious Issues during the Socialist Period of our Country," emphasizing the long-term nature of religious issues under socialist conditions and criticizing attempts to eliminate religion through administrative orders or other coercive measures. It reiterated the policy of respecting and protecting religious freedom, but did not allow religion to interfere with national politics.




From August 29 to September 7, 1979, a Chinese religious delegation, led by Zhao Puchu, the deputy chairman of the China Buddhist Association, and Ding Guangxun, the vice chairman of the China Christian "Three-Self" Patriotic Movement Committee, participated in the Third World Conference on Religion and Peace (WCRP) held in Princeton, New Jersey, USA. In October, the Chinese Muslim Hajj group was allowed to go to Mecca for Hajj for the first time after the "Cultural Revolution", indicating that the Communist Party of China is willing to conditionally restore international exchanges within the domestic religious community. However, they maintained a high vigilance against the infiltration of foreign churches into domestic religions. On March 4, 1980, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council transferred the report from the Religious Affairs Bureau and other departments on the issue of resisting the religious infiltration by foreign churches, pointing out that the harm of foreign religious infiltration should be fully estimated, and efforts should be made to prevent and limit its influence as much as possible.

Looking over the basic situation of religious work during this period, it can be clearly seen that the basic task of the party and government for religious work is to firmly implement the policy of freedom of religious belief, to consolidate and expand the patriotic political alliance of the religious community of all ethnic groups, to strengthen their patriotism and socialist education, to mobilize their positive factors, and to strive together to build a modernized socialist power, to achieve the great cause of unification of the motherland, and to oppose hegemonism and maintain world peace. Under the leadership of the basic tasks, all party members, party committees at all levels, especially the departments in charge of religious work at all levels, seriously summarize and absorb the historical experience of the party's religious work since the founding of New China, further understand and master the objective laws of the occurrence, development and elimination of religion, overcome all difficulties and resistances, and firmly put the party's religious policy on the scientific track of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought.

4. Implementing the united front policy and developing the patriotic united front

After the "Gang of Four" was smashed, the organizations and activities of the various democratic parties gradually recovered. After the third Plenary Session of the 11th CPC Central Committee, with the comprehensive launch of rectification and reform and opening up, the party's united front work was fully restored. The various democratic parties began to play their roles in political consultation and democratic supervision in the country's political life once again, and the party's theory on the united front was also enriched and developed.

In June 1979, Deng Xiaoping, in his opening speech at the second session of the fifth session of the CPPCC National Committee, analyzed the situation of the various classes in China and clearly pointed out the new tasks and changes faced by the united front in the new period, using the two concepts of "socialist workers and patriotic supporters of socialism". He pointed out: "Our country's united front has become a broad alliance led by the working class, based on the alliance of workers and peasants, of socialist workers and patriotic supporters of socialism. The tasks of the united front in the new period and the CPPCC are to mobilize all positive factors, strive to turn negative factors into positive ones, unite all forces that can be united, have the same heart and the same virtue, pool wisdom and strength, maintain and develop a stable and united political situation, and strive to build our country into a modernized socialist power." Soon after, the Central Committee of the Party further proposed that "the greatest united front can be revolutionary and patriotic, now the biggest united front is the return of Taiwan to the motherland, the issue of unification of the motherland". According to this directive, the 14th National United Front Work Conference held in August 1979 used the term "revolutionary patriotic united front". The meeting believed that in the new period, within the united front, although there are such and such contradictions between socialist workers, peasants, intellectuals and other patriotic supporters of socialism, there are no fundamental conflicts of interest.



The basic policy and method of the revolutionary patriotic united front must start from the practical transformation of the main contradictions within the country, strictly distinguish two types of contradictions of different nature, regard the correct handling of contradictions among the people as the general subject, strictly abide by socialist democracy and socialist legal system, correctly handle various contradictions within the united front, actively help non-party people from all walks of life to make new progress and contributions in achieving the four modernizations. For all those who love the motherland, "as long as they agree to the reunification of the motherland, even if they do not approve of the socialist system, we must unite with them."

In October of the same year, the central committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) submitted the guiding tasks of the united front in the new historical period at the national united front work meeting. This document made a realistic analysis of the fundamental changes in social class situation in the 30 years since the founding of New China, and gave a clear explanation of the nature, policy, and tasks of the united front in the new period. It pointed out: the foundation of China's united front - the worker-peasant alliance, has entered a new stage centered on achieving socialist modernization. The vast majority of intellectuals, including old intellectuals from the old society, are now part of the working class and are an important backbone force for modernization. All ethnic groups in China have formed new socialist relations of unity, friendship, mutual assistance, and cooperation. In the process of modernization, the socialist consistency of all ethnic groups will further develop, and patriotic people of different religions also have great progress. The capitalist class in China no longer exists as a class. They have undergone various tests on the path of socialist transformation and in the struggle with Lin Biao, and the "Gang of Four". The vast majority of them support the leadership of the party and the socialist system. Now, they are contributing to the four modernization efforts either through their own labor or as national cadres. All democratic parties in China have become a political alliance of a part of socialist workers and a part of socialist patriots connected to them, all serving socialism under the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party. A part of people who used to be on the enemy side, such as pardoned war criminals and KMT county-level officials who were pardoned, have turned to the people's side after long-term transformation. The class struggle is no longer the main contradiction in our society. With the strategic shift of the whole Party's work focus, and according to the fundamental changes in domestic class situation, the United Front in the new period should be called the Revolutionary Patriotic United Front. It is a broad alliance of all socialist workers and all patriots. In the new historical period, the task of the united front is: to unite all the forces that can be united, mobilize all positive factors at home and abroad, strive to turn negative factors into positive ones, strive to maintain and develop a stable and united political situation, and work together for the construction of a modern socialist powerful country, the return of Taiwan to the motherland and the great cause of national unification. This document not only has the effect of clearing up the impact of "left" errors in the united front work, but also promotes the implementation of various party policies.

Soon after, the CPC Central Committee proposed the concept of "Patriotic United Front". This is because the concept of the Revolutionary Patriotic United Front has made great strides compared with the past, but this concept still cannot cover a wider range of united front objects and fully adapt to the tasks and requirements of the new historical conditions. In June 1981, the Party's 11th Plenum of the Sixth Plenum of the CPC Central Committee passed the "Resolution on Certain Historical Issues of the Party since the Founding of the People's Republic of China", which clearly stated, "We must unwaveringly unite all the forces that can be united, consolidate and expand the Patriotic United Front."

From December 1981 to January 1982, the 15th National United Front Work Conference further clarified the "Patriotic United Front", emphasizing that the United Front in the new period is still a great weapon of the Party. The meeting believed that for a long time, due to the influence of "left" thinking, there has been a tendency to ignore or even abandon the united front. Recognizing the importance and permanence of the united front is the prerequisite for doing a good job in united front work.



Hu Yaobang said in his speech: "In the new historical period, in the long historical period in the future, the united front will still be necessary, important, and still have strong vitality, and it is still a great weapon of our party." The meeting further clarified the scope and target of the patriotic united front in the new era, proposing that there are two united fronts in the new era, one is the international anti-aggression and expansion united front, and the other is the national patriotic united front. The patriotic united front within the scope of the nation is the widest united front of all socialist workers, patriots who support socialism, and patriots who support national unity. Over a long period of time in the future, the targets of united front work aren't getting fewer and fewer, but more and more; the range of united front activities are not becoming narrower and narrower, but wider and wider. The targets of the united front work within the scope of the country alone can involve ten aspects: 

1. Democratic parties; 
2. Non-party celebrities, mainly patriots; 
3. Non-party intellectual cadres; 
4. Uprising and surrendering former Kuomintang military and political personnel; 
5. Former rich businessmen;  
6. Top figures of ethnic minorities; 
7. Patriotic religious leaders; 
8. Family and friends of those returning to Taiwan and remaining on the mainland; 
9. Taiwanese and Hong Kong and Macao compatriots; 
10. Returning overseas Chinese and overseas Chinese.

The concept of the "Patriotic United Front" reflects the development of the party's united front theory. This understanding accurately expresses the historical features of the united front in the new era. Transitioning from the "Revolutionary Patriotic United Front" to the "Patriotic United Front," this change advances the party's united front theory while also making the united front policy more in line with the social reality of our country in the new era. As for the patriotism in the Patriotic United Front, it is "essentially socialist patriotism, but it has a broader range than socialism, including patriots who support national unity but do not necessarily favor socialism or have doubts about socialism. Proposing the Patriotic United Front is a combination of principle and flexibility."

Regarding the relationship between the Communist Party and the various democratic parties and other non-party patriotic democrats in the United Front, Mao Zedong proposed the eight-character guideline of "long-term coexistence, mutual supervision" as early as April 1956. This guideline reflects the history and reality of the Chinese revolution, representing both the Chinese Communist Party's advocacy for long-term coexistence with various democratic parties and the equal status of various democratic parties. However, from the late 1950s to the end of the "Cultural Revolution," this correct guideline for handling the relationship between the Chinese Communist Party and the various democratic parties was not well implemented, especially during the "Cultural Revolution," when the work and activities of the democratic parties were forced to stop. After the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Party, the Chinese Communist Party reaffirmed its policy of "long-term coexistence, mutual supervision" with various democratic parties. Deng Xiaoping also clearly stated, "This is a long-term unchanging guideline."

Entering the new period of reform and opening up, with the profound changes in the class relations in our country, the class color of the various democratic parties in our country has gradually faded, and they have essentially become a part of the socialist workers' party. To adapt to this change, the Chinese Communist Party developed the "eight-character guideline" guiding the relationship between the democratic parties into the "sixteen-character guideline." Hu Yaobang pointed out at the 15th National United Front Work Conference in January 1982: "Our comrades should "make friends with all non-party people, and then turn the widespread acquaintance into true friends, and then reach a relationship of sharing weal and woe"; "We should clearly tell the party comrades and non-party friends that in the new historical period, we must establish a true weal-and-woe relationship with non-party friends". This is the first time the Chinese Communist Party has proposed the eight-character phrase "sharing weal and woe" in united front work.



In September of the same year, Hu Yaobang, in his report at the 12th Congress of the Party, combined the two eight-character slogans of "long-term coexistence, mutual supervision" and "share weal and woe" for the first time, putting forward the principle that our Party should continue to adhere to "long-term coexistence, mutual supervision, sharing weal and woe", and strengthen cooperation with various democratic parties, non-party democrats, ethnic minority figures, and patriotic figures in religious circles. In November of the same year, Deng Xiaoping also emphasized the 16-character principle of "long-term coexistence, mutual supervision, sharing weal and woe" in his speech at the opening of the Fifth Session of the Fifth National Committee of the Political Consultative Conference, thus formally establishing these 16 characters as the fundamental guiding principle for the relationship between the Communist Party of China and the various democratic parties in the new era. The proposal of the 16-character principle is in line with the objective realities of the new era of reform, opening up and socialist modernization, benefitting the role of democratic parties and democrats, encouraging them to participate in the common management of national affairs, long-term cooperation, and making the unity between the CPC and the various democratic parties even closer.

After the 12th National Congress of the Party, with the full unfolding of reform and opening up and the implementation of the "one country, two systems" principle, the united front has further taken on the dual tasks of serving socialist modernization and the reunification of the motherland, with a wider scope and richer content. In this context, the 16th National United Front Work Conference held from the end of November to December 1986 proposed the idea of "Two Alliances". One is the alliance of all workers and patriots on the mainland, based on socialism; the other includes compatriots in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macao, and overseas Chinese, based on patriotism and support for the reunification of the motherland. These two alliances not only constitute the whole of the united front in the new era, but also constitute an important new feature of socialism with Chinese characteristics.

Chapter Three: Strengthening the Party's Leadership in the Field of Thought and Culture and Scientific Evaluation of Mao Zedong's Historical Position

I. Denial of Class Struggle as Guideline & Reaffirming the Four Fundamental Principles.

After a thorough debate on the criterion of truth, especially after the central work meeting and the third plenary session, the error of "all of which" was severely criticized, and the party's ideological line of seeking truth from facts was reestablished. However, the disagreements and debates on the ideological line within the Party have not been completely eliminated. Not only that, but two erroneous tendencies emerged within the Party and society. One group influenced by the '"leftist" errors is still petrified or semi-petrified, doubting or even resisting the lines and policies of the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee. The other group among some people denies socialism and the leadership of the Party.  To ensure the shift in the party's focus for work and to promote modernization under the new situation, the Central Committee explicitly proposed the adherence to the Four Fundamental Principles.

1. Proposal of the thought of a political foundation for modernization in the new situation

In the climax of ideological liberation, China entered 1979. On the first day of the New Year, Deng Xiaoping highly assessed the new political situation and social atmosphere at a symposium held by the National Committee of the Political Consultative Conference, and for the first time, he raised the issue of the political foundation for modernization. 

Deng Xiaoping stated that Chairman Mao's political situation in 1957, characterized by concentration and democracy, discipline and freedom, unified will and personal sentiment, lively and vivid, gradually formed last year. This kind of atmosphere and situation, generally speaking, is called a lively and vivid political scene. It is necessary to uphold and develop this atmosphere and situation across the country, and uphold and develop it in the Party, government, military, and people. This is the political foundation for realizing the Four Modernizations. Without such a political scene, the Four Modernizations cannot be realized. For a long time in the past, we did not do well on the relationship between democracy and concentration, with less emphasis on democracy. Therefore, we should promote democracy more.

Deng Xiaoping's speech represents the central spirit and is the consensus of the Party Central Leadership Collective.



On January 2, Hua Guofeng emphasized in his report to Hu Yaobang on the national political and ideological situation that we must firmly establish the democratic life of our party and national. This is a political guideline decided at the Third Plenary Session and is unswerving. We must properly guide party members and leaders. Party committees at all levels and newspapers are to guide our democratization process in a healthy and orderly manner to avoid detours.

After experiencing a major change, especially for China, which has just passed the "Cultural Revolution" and is emerging from the shadow of the "Two Whatevers", re-examination and establishment of the political basis for China's modernization is one of the historical meanings of this transformation. Therefore, once the issue of political basis was raised, it immediately triggered a wide social response. Major media outlets such as the People's Daily and the Liberation Army Daily continuously published editorials, signed articles, and investigative reports to further elaborate on the political basis of modernization. Within less than a month, People's Daily published successive articles such as "People's Representatives Must Be Elected by the People", "Democracy and Rule of Law are Political Guarantees for Achieving the Four Modernizations", "Promoting Democracy and Achieving the Four Modernizations", "There Must Be a Sound Democratic Life Within the Party", and "Proletarian Democracy and Proletarian Dictatorship". They emphasized, "Achieving socialist modernization is inseparable from the great promotion of socialist democracy. The four modernizations must be accompanied by democratization in politics," urging "to expand this democratic style to the entire party, the entire military, and all ethnic groups across the country as required by the Third Plenary Session".

In such a social atmosphere, the preparatory work for Theoretical Work Club began.

The Theoretical Work Club was originally proposed by Ye Jianying. As for when this suggestion was specifically made, the authoritative biography of Ye Jianying's lifetime activities, "Ye Jianying Chronicle," does not record it, but Hu Yaobang's speech at the Theoretical Work Club and the "Deng Xiaoping Chronicle" provides an important corroboration.

Hu Yaobang pointed out in the "Preface to the Theoretical Work Club" that: Last May, an important development on the ideological and theoretical front was the beginning of the discussion about practice being the only criterion for testing truth, which caused a storm on China's ideological and theoretical front. In September of last year, the editors of the Hongqi Magazine wrote a long article called "Revisiting the 'Theory of Practice-Preamble on Practice as the Basis of Marxist Epistemology'". The article reached the Standing Committee. Comrade Ye Jianying suggested that the Central Committee hold a Theoretical Work Club, where different opinions are put forward, and after a full democratic discussion, everyone can reach a unified understanding and resolve this issue.

On October 14th, 1978, Deng Xiaoping also mentioned in a conversation with Wei Guoqing: Ye Jianying proposed a Theoretical Work Club, so to speak, to avoid talking behind the back, this is good.

Subsequently, Hua Guofeng officially proposed in his speech at the closing ceremony of the Central Work Conference that: At this conference, comrades have put forward many situations about the issue that "practice is the only standard for testing truth", and have raised many questions, and gave many critical comments to some comrades, which created favorable conditions for the convening of the Theoretical Work Club. Because the central work conference has many topics and limited time, it is impossible to spend a lot of time solving these problems. The comrades of the Central Political Bureau still follow Marshal Ye's proposal and convene a Theoretical Work Club after the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee to further resolve this issue.

The preparation for the Theoretical Work Club was chaired by Hu Yaobang.

On January 7, 1979, Hu Yaobang wrote to the Standing Committee of the Central Political Bureau, submitting the draft of the "Preface" and conference notice, which were to serve as the opening remarks for the Theoretical Work Club. The letter said: I have considered a preliminary idea for launching the Theoretical Work Club: first invite about two hundred theoretical workers in Beijing to attend the conference in late January or early February, lasting about twenty days. Then take a few days off and report to the central government.




We kindly invite approximately 200 theorists from all parts of the country, aggregating to around 400 participants, to attend a ten-day conference. The first phase of the assembly mainly focuses on group discussions, group talks, and combined conference speeches, encouraging an open exchange of ideas and free speech. In the second phase, we have invited Comrade Kingdom Peak, Comrade Jian Ying, and Comrade Xiao Ping to guide everyone in focused discussions, aiming to address some important issues urgently needing resolution on the ideological and theoretical front. By fostering democracy first, and then concentration, we seek to unify thoughts, thereby bettering theoretical work following a shift in the focus of the entire party's work.

After the issuance of Hu Yaobang's preface to "The Working-Theoretical Work Meeting" and the accompanying letter, approval was quickly received from the Standing Committee members of Central Politburo. Hua Guofeng was the first to voice his approval.

On January 9th, Hu Yaobang presided over the Ministry of Publicity departmental meeting, officially setting the specific agenda for the Theoretical Work Meeting: 
(1) The meeting begins on January 18th. 
(2) Locations: Friendship Hotel, Jingxi Hotel. 
(3) The meeting is divided into two phases: the first phase, spanning 20 days (ten days before and after the Spring Festival), hosts 200 participants, mainly from Beijing, with one representative sent from each province, municipality, and autonomous region, with group meetings as the primary focus; the second phase, lasting ten days, hosts 400 participants (200 from Beijing and 200 from other regions), convened in the name of the Communist Party Central Committee, inviting the Central Chairman and Vice Chairman to speak at the conference, with the main conference as the main feature. Both phases are separated by a one-week break. 
(4) Members of the Theoretical Work Meeting Steering Committee: Hu Yaobang, Hu Qiaomu, Huang Zhen, Zhu Muzhi, Hu Jiwei, Yu Guangyuan, Zhou Yang, Tong Dalin, Wu Lengxi, Wu Jiang, Hu Sheng. 
(5) Drafting group members for conference documents: Hu Yaobang, Hu Qiaomu, Yu Guangyuan, Wu Jiang, Ruan Ming, Lin Jianqing, Lee Honglin.

Although the conference later greatly exceeded the original schedule in terms of time, and adjustments were made in procedures and content, under Hu Yaobang's meticulous preparation, the Theoretical Work Meeting officially commenced on January 18th.

2. The Hosting of the Theoretical Work Meeting
Hu Yaobang presided over the opening ceremony. At the beginning of the meeting, he announced the names of the conference Steering Committee, and concurrently revealed the names of the five group conveners. 

The group conveners also served as the heads and deputy heads of their respective groups. In addition to these, there were 20 specially invited attendees, all veteran comrades, taking their health and work into consideration, they were notified that they could freely attend, and documents and newsletters were distributed accordingly.

At the opening ceremony, Hu Yaobang delivered a speech, the main content of which was the preface to "The Working-Theoretical Work Meeting."

During his speech, Hu Yaobang highly praised the achievements made in rectifying the chaos in the ideological and theoretical circles since 1977. He deemed the ideological and theoretical work accomplished over the past two years as the most outstanding and fruitful since the establishment of the New China in terms of scale, combat utility, and its contribution to the elevation of the entire Party's theoretical level, and can be regarded as the finest and most fruitful work in theory after the Yan'an Rectification campaign. He commended theorists as vanguard fighters on the ideological and theoretical frontlines, asserting that the emergence of a group of excellent pioneers has bolstered the strength of our Marxist theoretical contingent, and was an impressive achievement. He noted that it's a rarity in history for theoretical work to become a truly mass activity as it is today. Looking at the world, not many nations – like the Chinese people - show such concern for theoretical issues or have such theoretical interest – a treasure of our national spirit.



On the issue of how theoretical propaganda work adapts to changes in the key focuses of the Party and the country, Hu Yaobang proposed an overall guiding principle in his speech. He said that the fundamental task of theoretical propaganda work after the shift in the Party's main work can be summarized as follows: closely combining the universal truths of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought with the great practice of achieving four modernizations, studying new issues, solving new problems, making our theoretical work as advanced as possible, continuously enriching and developing Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought in practice, and guiding us to win the victory in the new Long March. 

The meeting was conducted in groups from the second day. On January 22, Hu Yaobang specially conveyed Deng Xiaoping's views on the theoretical work conference to the congress. Deng Xiaoping emphasized the need for open-minded discussions. There are still many truths to talk about and it should be quicker. Many theoretical problems have not been clarified yet, for example: democracy, law issues, economic management problems. The "Cultural Revolution" can also be discussed. The issues of continuing revolution under the proletarian dictatorship can also be discussed. In the future, don't mention "raising the banner of Chairman Mao", we should mention "upholding the banner of Mao Zedong Thought". Following Deng Xiaoping's instructions and the preliminary discussions of the groups after the beginning of the meeting, Hu Yaobang gave another speech, summarizing several major issues for the congress to study deeply. These issues include: how to discuss the truth standard issue in depth; the class struggle during the socialist period, how the party's basic theory came about; the experiences and lessons of theoretical work since the founding of New China; the evaluation of the "Cultural Revolution", the nature, requirements, lessons, etc. of the "Cultural Revolution"; the issue of socialist democracy; the outstanding issue of personal propaganda; and so on.

Subsequently, the meeting discussion was heatedly unfolded. Each group's speech was sent to the congress secretariat, which printed and distributed detailed briefings to each participant. Therefore, the situation was exchanged very timely. During this stage, a total of 262 briefings were sent out. Despite the fact that Hu Yaobang had clearly requested that the conference materials and discussion content should not be spread outside, the range of briefings sent out was quite wide, resulting in many readers and the quick spread of the conference's impact in society.

Almost at the same time as the central theoretical work conference was being held, Shandong, Shanghai, Fujian, Guangdong, Liaoning, Hunan, Jiangsu and other provinces and cities also spontaneously held meetings with the same content before the Spring Festival, with about fifty to sixty attendees, and up to three hundred in Shanghai.

The first stage of the theoretical work conference ended in mid-February 1979, and the second stage began in late March. During the second stage, four or five hundred people were invited to attend, including not only members of the original central units, but also comrades from various provinces and cities (mainly secretaries and ministers of propaganda who are responsible for ideological and propaganda work in the party committee), and the theoretical work conference continued until April 3 before it ended.

Judging from the progress of the first stage of the conference, the theoretical work conference adhered to the democratic atmosphere restored by the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Party, insisted on the principles and direction of liberating thought, not only continued to critically review the erroneous guiding thinking of "whatever", but also challenged the so-called "forbidden zones", conducted in-depth discussions on many important theoretical issues, such as some statements about the class struggle during the socialist period, the theory of continuing revolution under the proletarian dictatorship, the reflection of the social class struggle in the party struggle, the stage of socialism in China, the opposition to personal superstition, socialist democracy, economic theory and practical problems, etc. It provided decision-making references for the central government, many of which were very valuable. Many of the issues raised at the meeting that needed to be discussed, through subsequent research and practice, were gradually resolved, promoting and facilitating the formation and development of the theory and undertakings of socialism with Chinese characteristics.

However, at this conference, due to a lack of comprehensive analysis of the situation after the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Party, and a lack of systematic analysis and research on the rapidly changing ideological situation, inadequate theoretical preparation, some speeches by representatives also had apparent erroneous tendencies and vague understandings.




And this situation is intertwined with the complex social environment, presenting new challenges for the emerging new situation of socialist construction.

3. Presentation of Social Instability Factors under the New Situation

Prior to the theoretical work conference, some areas had produced societal contradictions due to various problems left over from the "Cultural Revolution". Some people took the opportunity to cause trouble, making various demands that were not feasible or outright unreasonable under the current circumstances. They incited the masses to strike at party and government institutions, occupy offices, stage sit-in hunger strikes, and disrupt traffic. Most seriously, agitation by these people had risen into a wave of unrest in many places, severely damaging working, production, and social order. During this process, there was a trend of doubt or even denial of the Communist Party's leadership, the socialist system, the dictatorship of the proletariat, and Mao Zedong Thought. Starting from late October 1978, the "Xidan Democracy Wall" became the main front for these propagandas and activities.

On January 6, 1979, Ren Huo village and six others posted a mimeographed flyer titled "Chinese Human Rights Declaration", announcing the establishment of the so-called "Chinese Human Rights Alliance", proposing a 12-point program, and delivered it to foreign journalists, claiming "Our alliance asks for support from human rights organizations and the public around the world", asking the President of the United States to "care" about China's human rights.

A female worker in Beijing, along with some petitioners, organized a "Citizen's Petition Group". With the support of some organizations, they paraded and demonstrated in Tiananmen Square under the banner of "anti-hunger, anti-persecution, for human rights, for democracy", and petitioned at the gate of Xinhua. Tens of thousands of onlooking crowds caused serious traffic obstruction. On January 18, the Beijing city detained this female worker, the "Chinese Human Rights Alliance" and the other six organizations, and mimeographed publication, i.e. "United Statement", which were planning to hold a mass accusatory meeting at the Xidan Democracy Wall and then petition at Zhongnanhai.

At the time, along with the activities at Xidan Democracy Wall, there were also emerging some grassroots organizations and publications. The attention to Wei Jingsheng and his "Probe" started around this time.

Wei Jingsheng was a worker at Beijing Park Service Management Bureau, and the chief editor of the mimeographed publication "Probe". Between December 1978 and March 1979, he consistently wrote articles and distributed publications, accusing Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought as "nothing more than slightly more refined elixirs of charlatans" and slandering the state system of proletarian dictatorship as being "feudalist monarchy cloaked in the garments of socialism". He incited the masses, saying "Don't believe in the 'stability and unity' of the dictator anymore", "Focus the fury on the evil system that creates the tragic plight of people", and agitated to "Seize power from these Lords". Some of his articles were posted on the Xidan Wall, some were published on "Probe". This publication had been widely posted, distributed, and sold in Beijing and Tianjin.

In addition to that, eight workers in Guiyang initiated the establishment of the "Enlightenment Society", with the main branch in Guiyang,and a branch in Beijing, growing to more than 30 people. They propagated the concepts of "democracy", "freedom", "human rights" in the capitalist world. In March 1979, the main individuals responsible for the "Enlightenment Society" set up the "Thaw Society" in Beijing, declaring that they want to "abolish class struggle, violent revolution, and all forms of dictatorship".

Similar organizations and publications had also cropped up in Guangzhou, Wuhan, Shanghai, and other places.

As for how to understand and assess these new occurrences in the ideological theoretical realm, there were differing perspectives within the party and the theory community, with some people having sympathetic or even supporting attitudes towards these new social trends and social problems.

At the Theory Work conference, someone suggested that "The central government should express support for the Democracy Wall." Someone said, "Even under the conditions of socialism, democracy is achieved through the people rising up and striving for it. This can only be achieved by breaking the resistance of bureaucrats and opportunists, and the suppression by overly concentrated bureaucratic power."



"Democracy can never depend on anyone's gift," one person says. "The main issue now is that democracy is not prevailing enough, rather than too much, it is not about correcting deviations." Another person claims, "what we should be vigilant about now is not the tendency of liberation of thought or democracy to go too far, and we should not have a new anti-right wave. The 'left' aspects have not been criticized enough, if the anti-right side is brought up, it will hinder criticism of the 'left', affect the liberation of thought, and may even go backwards. The so-called 'right' can never be regarded as a critical tendency to oppose. As for isolated cases, they can be guided through practical work. For such issues, one should stay alert intellectually, but there is no need to publicly oppose it as a tendency in theoretical propaganda." Some people suggested setting up a "Democratic Wall" column in the newspaper for posting large-character posters. Some even say: "Mao Zedong's thought should also be divided into two parts, seeing it that it contains some errors; it is going too far to say 'without Chairman Mao there would be no new China’ and ‘Chairman Mao's contribution is never overestimated’". These conversations and discussions clearly show that theoretical work has deviated in facing new situations and problems.
4. The Initial Response to New Erroneous Tendencies
Various new situations inside and outside the Party and both domestically and internationally, particularly the content of the discussions at the Party's academic research session, alerted Deng Xiaoping. He keenly perceived the gravity of these issues and therefore, from March 1979 onwards, he issued multiple speeches and talks, clearly advocating the importance of adhering to the four fundamental principles.
On March 16, 1979, at the report meeting on the Sino-Vietnamese border dispute held by the Central Committee of the CCP, Deng Xiaoping very explicitly pointed out the necessity to uphold the great banner of Chairman Mao. He held, to negate Mao is to negate the People's Republic of China and the entire history of the Party. Without Mao, there would be no new China. This is history. It implies that without the guidance of Mao Zedong Thought, we might still be struggling in darkness. When we write articles, we must pay attention to uphold the great banner of Chairman Mao and never hurt this banner in any way. Domestic and foreign class enemies want us to fall into chaos on such important matters. We need to tell the members of the Communist Party and the people not to fall into it. The key is to maintain stability and unity now. Dealing with left-over issues is for the sake of focusing on the future. He seriously indicated to the over-enthusiastic behavior of some educated young people demanding resettlement, that we must tell them, what would be the result of all these commotions and breaking into governmental organizations? Wasn't the past lesson enough? Once everything collapses, what hope is there for the Four Modernizations? What about stability and unity? All leadership bodies are engaging energy in dealing with these issues, leaving no energy for the Four Modernizations. What hope can there be for the improvement of people's livelihood and the development of the national economy? We should speak of the local and whole, the immediate and far-reaching issues. These issues need to be communicated to all the people. He stated, why are some people so envious of the foreign human rights movement and why don't they organize a rebuttal? To those supporting Carter’s human rights in the "Democratic Wall" letters, what human rights do imperialists have! Imperialism has killed so many people, and it has helped Chiang Kai-shek kill so many people in China. Imperialists have no qualification to talk about human rights. Why don't we use these living facts to educate the people? He severely pointed out, it is absolutely correct to arrest those instigators of trouble according to the law. Deng Xiaoping's talk first raised alarm among high-ranking party officials, which then conveyed to party officials at the county and league levels, indicating the stance of the Central Committee. 
On March 27, Deng Xiaoping discussed with Hu Yaobang and Hu Qiaomu some of the main points and ideas he planned to elaborate on at a Party academic research session. He said, the four persists, persisting in the socialist path, proletarian dictatorship, the party's leadership, and the fundamental principles of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought, should be discussed now.



Deng Xiaoping said, whether socialism's public ownership is good, or capitalism's private ownership is good? As long as our work is done well, and construction is carried out according to economic laws, it is certain that socialism's public ownership is better than capitalism's private ownership, and socialism is better than capitalism. Speaking of the party leadership, we should talk about history. Without the Communist Party, there would be no new China, without the Communist Party, there would be no socialism. Which difficult hurdle we encountered was not overcome under the leadership of the party? The evaluation of Chairman Mao must be discussed. The current speeches are not prominent enough, the weight is not enough. With the October Revolution and the acceptance of Marxism-Leninism, the Chinese Communist Party was established and a new China emerged. All of these cannot be separated from Chairman Mao. Only by proposing the theory of the division of the three worlds, Chairman Mao enabled us to break away from the state of international isolation. It is not possible without the dictatorship of the proletariat. Regarding the actual conditions at home and abroad, we still need to prevent the restoration of capitalism. 

Deng Xiaoping said: The issues of democracy and legal system need to be fully discussed. We need to discuss the relationship between democracy and centralization, the immediate interests and long-term interests, and the relationship between personal interests and national interests.
