With this, all preparations for the Twelfth CPC National Congress were successfully completed.

2. The Twelfth National Congress of the Communist Party of China was held
From September 1 to 11, 1982, the Twelfth National Congress of the Communist Party of China solemnly took place in Beijing. A total of 1545 official delegates and 145 alternate delegates attended the congress, representing more than 39 million members of the party. The congress had three major agenda items: 
(1) to review and approve the report of the Central Committee and to set the program for opening up a new situation in socialist modernization; 
(2) to review and approve the new Constitution of the Communist Party of China; 
(3) to elect in accordance with the new party constitution, a new Central Committee, a new Central Advisory Commission, and a new Central Discipline Inspection Committee.

The congress was conducted by the Presidium and the Standing Committee of the Presidium. The opening ceremony of the congress invited representatives of various democratic parties and non-party democrats. The executive chairman of congress, Deng Xiaoping, made his opening speech. 

In this opening speech, Deng Xiaoping reviewed the history of the Party since the seventh congress and explained the significant historical position of the Indian congress. He said: "In 1945, the Communist Party of China's 7th National Congress was convened under the leadership of comrade Mao Zedong, and it marked the most important congress of our Party since its foundation during the democratic revolution. It summarized the twisty history of China's democratic revolution for over 20 years, adopted the correct programme and strategy, overcame the incorrect ideologies within the Party, and united the whole Party's understanding on the basis of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought, achieving unprecedented unity in the party, which laid the foundation for the victory of the new democratic revolution across the country." "Since the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, we have restored correct policies in economics, politics, culture and other aspects, studied new situations and experiences, and set a series of new correct policies. Compared with the eight congress, our Party now has a much deeper understanding on the law of socialist construction in our country, a lot more experiences, and a much stronger willingness and determination to implement our correct policies. We have a solid reason to believe that the correct program set by this congress will be able to fully open up a new situation for socialist modernization, making our Party prosperous and strong, our socialist cause prosperous and strong, and our nation and country prosperous and strong."

In the speech, Deng Xiaoping also summed up historic experiences of the Party, and introduced the guiding doctrine of following the path of socialism with Chinese characteristics. He said, “Our modernization construction must be based on the actual conditions in China. Whether during revolution or construction, it is important to learn and draw from foreign experiences. However, success will never come by mechanically copying or imitating others’ experience or model. We have learned much from our past. To integrate the universal truth of Marxism with China's specific conditions, to tread our own path, to build socialism with Chinese characteristics, is the fundamental conclusion we have drawn from long-term historical experience.” This fundamental conclusion is the CPC's correct understanding and application of the objective law of socialist construction in our country, and also a concentrated reflection of the will, wish, and demand of people of all ethnic groups in our country. Our country's reform, opening-up and modernization construction have achieved great success under this ideological guide.



In his opening remarks, Deng Xiaoping evaluated the situation and far-sightedly proposed the three major tasks faced by our nation's people in the 1980s, namely: accelerating the construction of socialist modernization, striving for the realization of reunification involving Taiwan, opposing hegemony, and maintaining world peace. Among these three tasks, the core is economic construction, which is the foundation to solve international and domestic issues. He emphasized that for a long period to come, at least until the end of the 20th century, we need to focus on four tasks: implement organizational reforms and economic system reforms, achieve the revolutionization, rejuvenation, intellectualization, and specialization of the cadres; build socialist spiritual civilization; crack down on criminal activities that undermine socialism in the economic and other fields; regulate the party's style and organization based on seriously studying the new party chapter. 

At the 12th Party Congress, Hu Yaobang, on behalf of the 11th Central Committee, made a political report titled "Comprehensively Create a New Situation for Socialist Modernization Construction". The report is divided into six parts: (1) historical changes and new grand tasks; (2) promote the overall boom of the socialist economy; (3) strive to build high-level socialist spiritual civilization; (4) strive to build high-level socialist democracy; (5) adhere to an independent foreign policy; (6) build the party into a strong core that leads socialist modernization.

In the report, he reviewed the party's journey and the huge achievements made on all fronts since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, and proposed the party's overall task in the new historical period: uniting all ethnic groups in the country for self-reliance, hard work, gradual realization of modernization in industry, agriculture, national defense, and science and technology, and building our country into a highly civilized and democratic socialist country. From this congress to the next, within five years, we must vigorously promote the construction of socialist material and spiritual civilization according to the requirements of the overall task, continue to improve socialist democracy and law, seriously regulate the party's style and organization, strive to fundamentally improve the national financial and economic situation. Also, we should work together with all patriotic people including Taiwanese, Hong Kong, Macau compatriots, and overseas Chinese, and strive to promote the reunification of the motherland. Furthermore, we must continue to fight against imperialism, hegemony, and maintain world peace with all people in the world. 

Based on the actual situation in China, the report focused on the overall tasks, devising strategic goals, key points, and a series of policy guidelines for economic construction. The report pointed out that among the tasks of opening up a new situation, the most important task is to push forward the economic construction of socialist modernization. From 1981 to the end of the 20th century, the overall goal of China's economic construction is to strive to double the annual total output value while continuously improving economic benefits, increasing from 710 billion in 1980 to about 2.8 trillion in 2000. Important tactical points like addressing agriculture, energy, transportation, education, and science can stimulate a rapid increase in production, drive the development of industries, and ensure the improvement of people's lives. 

To achieve the 20-year goal, it should be divided into two stages in strategic deployment: laying a strong foundation for the first ten years, and entering a new period of economic revival in the next ten years. This is an important decision made by the Central Committee of the Party after a comprehensive analysis of China's economic situation and development trends. During the sixth five-year plan from 1981 to 1985, we need to continue to firmly implement the guidelines of adjustment, reform, rectification, and improvement, practice austerity, oppose waste, and shift all economic work to the track centered on economic benefits.



We must focus our efforts on adjusting the economic structure in various aspects, consolidating and improving the preliminary reforms that have been implemented in the economic management system, and urgently formulate an overall plan and implementation steps for reform. During the seventh five-year plan period from 1986 to 1990, we should widely carry out enterprise technology reform, and gradually carry out the reform of economic management system. At the same time, we should complete the rationalization of the enterprise organizational structure and various aspects of the economic structure. In the 1980s, we still need to carry out a series of necessary basic construction in energy, transportation and other areas and "tackle" series of major scientific and technological projects. As long as we do the above work well, we can solve the problems left over from history well, and lay a solid foundation for economic growth in the next decade. By the 1990s, China's economic growth rate will definitely be much faster than the 1980s, and China's economy will fully enter a period of high growth.

The report highly praised the significance and role of building socialist spiritual civilization, and proposed that we must strive to build socialist spiritual civilization. The report points out that we must strive to build a high-level socialist spiritual civilization while building a highly material civilization. This is a strategic policy issue in building socialism. The historical experience of socialism and the current reality of our country tell us whether to adhere to such a policy, relates to the rise and fall of socialism and its success or failure. The relationship between physical civilization and spiritual civilization in socialist construction is very close, the construction of material civilization is the indispensable foundation for the construction of socialist spiritual civilization, and socialist spiritual civilization not only greatly promotes the construction of material civilization but also ensures its correct development direction. The construction of the two civilizations, each being a condition and a goal of the other. The report pointed out that building a socialist spiritual civilization is not an easy task, especially today. We must make the greatest efforts to adapt to the new conditions and circumstances of the construction period, do a good job in building a socialist spiritual civilization and inspire the great enthusiasm of the masses to build socialism with revolutionary thoughts and spirits.

The report also pointed out that building a high level of socialist democracy is one of our fundamental goals and tasks. The report emphasizes that we must continue to reform and improve the country's political system and leadership system in accordance with the principle of democratic centralism, expand socialist democracy to all aspects of political, economic, cultural and social life. Develop democratic management in various enterprises and institutions, develop grassroots social mass self-government, and closely combine the construction of socialist democracy with the construction of a socialist legal system to legalize and institutionalize the socialist democracy.

Regarding China's foreign policy, the report pointed out that combination of patriotism and internationalism has always been the fundamental starting point for dealing with foreign relations. We insist on implementing independent foreign policy. China's foreign policy is based on the scientific theory of Marxism-Leninism, Mao Zedong Thought, and is from the fundamental interests of Chinese people and people all over the world. It has a long-term strategic basis and never yields to any temporary incidents, is not subject to anyone's instigation, and we will never seek hegemony under any circumstances. At the same time, the report also pointed out that our party insists on the basis of Marxism, develops relations with communist parties and other working-class parties of various countries in accordance with the principles of independence, equality, mutual respect, and non-interference, all parties should respect each other and help one another. China should make a great contribution to the world.

The report emphasized the importance of building the party into a strong core leading socialist modernization. In order to strengthen the building of the party in the new era, the Twelfth National Congress of the Communist Party of China made many fundamentally significant amendments to the eleventh party constitution. The general principle of amending party constitution is to adapt to the characteristics and needs of the new era, put forward stricter requirements for party members, enhance the combat effectiveness of party organizations, and maintain and improve the leadership of the party. The new constitution eliminated the "left" errors in the eleventh party constitution and inherited and expanded the advantages of the party constitutions of the Seventh and Eighth National Congresses of the Communist Party of China.



The report states that in order to build the party as the core force leading the cause of socialist modernization, at present, it is necessary to improve the party's system of democratic centralism, improve the system of leadership institutions and cadre, realize the revolutionization, youthfulness, intellectualization, and professionalism of the cadre team, and at the same time strengthen the party's work among workers, peasants, and intellectuals. Close the connection between the party and the masses, and carry out party rectification in a planned and stepped manner over a period of three years, so that the style of the party can be fundamentally improved.

Hu Yaobang's report revolves around the goal of building socialism with Chinese characteristics and outlines a blueprint for achieving this ambitious goal from various aspects such as politics, economy, culture, diplomacy, and party building. It solves a series of major problems in China's socialist revolution and construction from the combination of theory and practice and has caused strong responses from all sides. From September 2nd to 4th, the delegates attending the 12th congress spent three days for a heated discussion on the report. Everyone spoke freely, felt comfortable, and the meeting atmosphere was very active.

On the afternoon of September 5th, the Presidium of the Congress held a meeting. Vice Secretary-General Hu Qiaomu explained the amendments to the 11th Central Committee's report and the draft of the Constitution of the Communist Party of China based on the suggestions and opinions put forward by the representatives in group discussions. The meeting passed the draft resolutions on the report of the 11th Central Committee and the Constitution of the Chinese Communist Party and decided to submit these two draft resolutions to the Congress for approval. The meeting also decided to submit the candidate list for the Central Committee, the Central Advisory Committee, and the Central Discipline Inspection Committee proposed by the Presidium to the full congress for discussion, and passed the election methods for the three committees and submitted them to the Congress for review.

On the afternoon of September 6, a plenary meeting was held. The Congress adopted the resolution on the report of the 12th Central Committee and approved the report made by Hu Yaobang on behalf of the 11th Central Committee. The resolution of the congress stated: "The lines, principles, and policies since the third plenary session of the 11th Central Committee are correct and the work is effective." "The correct program and a series of guiding principles and policies that are proposed in the report to comprehensively open up a new situation of socialist modernization construction should become the basic basis for all future work of the party." The congress also passed the Constitution of the Chinese Communist Party proposed by the 11th Central Committee and the resolution about this constitution. The resolution calls for the entire Party to carefully organize the study of the Party Charter, strive to make all party members truly understand the preamble and various provisions of the party charter, and enable the understanding of all party members, especially all leading cadres, to be improved, so as to be fully prepared for the thorough improvement of the party's style and the party's organization and make the party a strong core leading the socialist modernization.

On the 6th, Ye Jianying and Chen Yun gave speeches, expressing their approval of Deng Xiaoping's opening speech and Hu Yaobang's political report and the Charter of the Chinese Communist Party, and focused on the issue of new and old cadre cooperation and rotation. Ye Jianying said: "Our Party is a vibrant party. Through this congress, a group of vigorous comrades will come to the central leadership and other leadership positions, which is an important sign of the prosperity of the party's cause. Our older comrades feel very pleased to see this happening." At the same time, he quoted the Tang Dynasty poet Li Shangyin's verse "The juvenile phoenix is clearer than the old phoenix" to praise the young comrades, and sincerely "hope that the young comrades who are new to work, cooperate closely with the old comrades, take up the heavy burden, and bravely move forward," and later come up and surpass the old comrades; hope that the old comrades who retire have not retired in thought and should write their own history in their later years with actual actions, always thinking about the interests of the party and the people, and continue to do what they can.

Chen Yun analyzed the condition of the party's caucus team and explained the significance and policy of the cooperation and alternation of old and new cadres.



He said, "Solving the operational handover problem of our cadre team is an important task facing the entire party. To solve this problem, veteran cadres must step down from leadership positions gradually. Those remaining temporarily on the front line should guard against major issues and ensure proper mentorship." He also emphasized the need to promote thousands of middle-aged and young cadres to various leadership teams. He stressed: "Promotions must be made in the thousands, not just promoting tens, or hundreds." Only in this way, there can be enough cadres to succeed the veteran cadres' work, however, "those who made their careers by rebelling against Lin Biao and Jiang Qing during the Cultural Revolution, those with serious factionalism, and those who involved in violent actions, cannot be promoted. On the contrary, they must be resolutely removed from the leadership team." He said that we should be bold in promoting, while also being cautious about politics. When comparing morality and talent, we should focus more on morality, which is to say, indeed, promote those with strong party principles, upright style, and dare to uphold principles. He believed that as long as the cadre handover issue is well-handled, there will be successors for our party mission.

On the morning of September 9, the presidium of the congress held a meeting. According to the preliminary election results, it established the official candidate list for three committees and also passed the draft resolution regarding the work report of the Central Discipline Inspection Committee. In the afternoon, various delegations held group meetings to review the list of candidates proposed by the presidium.

From the morning of October 10 to 11, a plenary meeting was held to elect members of the Central Committee and the Central Advisory Committee. After thorough preparation, the Congress democratically elected 210 members of the Central Committee and 138 alternate members, forming a new Central Committee. Among these 348 members and alternate members, 211 were newly elected, accounting for 65% of the total number. 171 of them were under 60 years old, accounting for 49.1% of the total. 122 of them had college degrees, accounting for 35.1% of the total. There was a significant improvement in terms of knowledge and specialization from the previous Central Committee. The Central Committee also reserved eight honorable revolutionary elders, including Ye Jianying, Deng Xiaoping, Li Xiannian, Chen Yun, Xu Xiangqian, Nie Rongzhen, Peng Zhen, and Deng Yingchao. At the same time, a Central Advisory Committee, which never existed before in the history of the Party, was newly established, with 172 members elected. They all had more than 40 years of Party membership, made significant contributions to the Party, and had rich leadership experience. 133 members were also elected to the Central Discipline Inspection Committee.

The establishment of these three committees embodied Deng Xiaoping's "Reform of the Party and State Leadership System" in setting up three committees, further implementing the principle of cadre alternation between the old and the new. This ensured a strong and improved leadership for the Party and a long-lasting domestic peace for the country, provided a reliable organizational guarantee for the full development of socialist construction.

On September 11, the Twelfth Congress came to a close, and Li Xiannian delivered the closing speech. He highly praised Hu Yaobang's report and the new Party constitution, as well as the achievements of the congress. He called for the extensive and in-depth publicity, study of the spirit of the Twelfth Congress, implementing practical measures, and striving to achieve our great goals step by step.

From September 12 to 13, the first plenary session of the Twelfth Central Committee of the Party was held. Hu Yaobang and Zhao Ziyang presided over the meeting. The plenary session elected Wan Li, Xi Zhongxun, Wang Zhen, Wei Guoqing, Ulanhu, Fang Yi, Deng Xiaoping, Deng Yingchao, Ye Jianying, Li Xiannian, Li Desheng, Yang Shangkun, Yang Dezhi, Yu Qiuli, Song Renqiong, Zhang Tingfa, Chen Yun, Zhao Ziyang, Hu Qiaomu, Hu Yaobang, Nie Rongzhen, Ni Zhifu, Xu Xiangqian, Peng Zhen, Liao Chengzhi as members of the Central Political Bureau, and elected Yao Yilin, Qin Jiwei, Chen Muhua as alternate members of the Central Political Bureau.

Hu Yaobang, Ye Jianying, Deng Xiaoping, Zhao Ziyang, Li Xiannian, Chen Yun were elected as members of the Standing Committee of the Central Political Bureau.



Hu Yaobang was elected as the Secretary General of the Central Committee, Wan Li, Xi Zhongxun, Deng Liqun, Yang Yong, Yu Qiuli, Gu Mu, Chen Pixian, Hu Qili, and Yao Yilin as Secretaries of the Central Secretariat, with Qiao Shi and Hao Jianxiu as alternate secretaries.
The plenary meeting decided on Deng Xiaoping as Chairman of the Central Military Commission, with Ye Jianying, Xu Xiangqian, and Nie Rongzhen as Vice Chairmen, and Yang Shangkun as the standing Vice Chairman.
The plenary session approved Deng Xiaoping as the Chairman of the Central Advisory Commission, with Bo Yibo, Xu Shiyou, Tan Zhenlin, and Li Weihan as Vice Chairmen, and Wang Ping and another 23 people as standing members. Chen Yun was approved as the First Secretary of the Central Discipline Inspection Commission, with Huang Kecheng as the Second Secretary, Wang Heshou as the Standing Secretary, Wang Congwu, Han Guang, Li Chang, Ma Guorui, Han Tianshi as Secretaries, and Ma Guorui, Han Tianshi and another 11 people as standing members.
The Twelfth National Congress of the Party was a very important meeting, which holds a significant historical achievement and position in the history of the party and in the history of socialism construction in our country.
3. Main contributions and historical status of the Twelfth Congress
This congress explicitly proposed the proposition of "Socialism with Chinese Characteristics". The theory of Deng Xiaoping on the socialist road with Chinese characteristics has provided great guidance for reform and opening up and socialist modernization in our country.
First, the Twelfth Congress smoothly achieved the turnover of old and new leaders. One of the main topics of the Twelfth Congress was to solve the turnover of new and old cadres and to realize the revolutionization, youthization, intellectualization, and specialization of cadres as soon as possible. In the history of the international communist movement, the turnover of high-level leadership of the party is always a matter that relates to the fate of the party and the state, but also a problem that has not been solved very well and has had painful lessons. The Twelfth Congress made an active and effective exploration of this issue.
Second, the congress formulated and passed a new "Party Constitution". The "Party Constitution" is the fundamental law of the party, and all past party congresses have attached great importance to the revision and formulation of the "Party Constitution". The Twelfth Congress of the Party, in order to build the party into a strong core leading the cause of socialist modernization, to greatly improve the political quality of the whole party, to enhance the fighting strength of the party, formulated a very distinctive new "Party Constitution". Its characteristics are: It has a rather substantial "General Principles", which succinctly summarizes the nature and overall task of the party, and on how the party correctly plays a leading role in national life, it has made Marxist provisions; for the requirements of party members and party officials in thought, politics, and organization, they are stricter than the provisions of past Party Constitutions; based on historical experience and lessons, the new Party Constitution emphasizes that organizations at all levels from the central to the grassroots must strictly abide by the principles of democratic centralism and collective leadership, and clearly stipulates: "Any form of personal worship is prohibited." It has made many new provisions for improving the system of the party's central and local organizations, for strengthening the party's discipline and disciplinary inspection organs, for strengthening the construction of grassroots organizations of the party. The new Party Constitution adopted by the Twelfth Congress was formulated with the wisdom of the whole party and the accumulation of its historical experience.
Third, the Twelfth Congress also enriched and developed Marxism on some theoretical issues. On the issue of the basic characteristics of socialism, the report of the Twelfth Congress proposed a new content in the characteristics of socialism, i.e., socialist spiritual civilization and high socialism democracy. In this way, the basic characteristics of socialism include both the relations of production and productive forces, as well as the superstructure and ideology, and therefore appear even more comprehensive and complete. On the issue of the structure of socialist ownership, the report of the Twelfth Congress pointed out that the socialist state economy occupies a dominant position in the whole national economy, but there is a need for coexistence of multiple forms over a long period of time. On the issue of socialist planning and market, past discussions often emphasized planning and excluded the market, the Twelfth Congress proposed the principle of planned economy as the main, supplemented by market regulation, and under this principle, the boundaries and limits of directive plans, indicative plans, and market regulation should be correctly divided.



On the issue of class struggle during the socialist era, the Twelfth Congress report proposes that, after the exploiting class has been eliminated as a class, most of the contradictions existing in our society do not have the nature of class struggle. While class struggle is no longer the main contradiction in our society, it will continue to exist within a certain range in our society for a long time, and under certain conditions, it may even intensify. Additionally, the Twelfth Congress report also has new expressions on issues such as the construction of spiritual civilization and the construction of the Party. These new understandings enrich and develop the Marxist theoretical treasure trove.

Fourth, the Twelfth Party Congress scientifically summarized the historical experience of the Party. According to the current actual situation in our country, it set forth the ambitious goals of creating a new situation of socialist construction and a more complete series of correct guidelines, policies, and measures. It proposed the overall task and general line of the Party in the new historical period. It ranked economic construction, political construction, and ideological and cultural construction simultaneously as goals of socialist construction, which was the first instance in the history of socialist construction in our country and was also a first in the international communist movement. The Twelfth Congress fully initiated a new situation in the modernization of socialism in our country. After the Twelfth Congress, China's reform and opening up and the cause of socialist modernization entered a period of vigorous development.

Part II: The formulation of the economic system reform program and the comprehensive implementation of reform and opening up

With the advancement of rural and urban economic reforms, the content of the reforms has greatly exceeded the originally envisaged realm of developing commodity production and commodity exchange, revealing more and more tendencies towards the development of a commodity economy and market regulation. This further touched on the core command plan system of the planned economy, exposing deeper contradictions and problems, and thereby triggering fierce debates. The focus of the debate was whether or not the economy at the current stage in China is a commodity economy, and whether or not we needed to establish an economic system that is compatible with the commodity economy.

1. Theoretical confrontation on "Socialist Commodity Economy"

At that time, quite a few people believed that the socialist economy is a planned economy, not a commodity economy. Since it is a planned economy, the economic system should naturally be adapted to the planned economy. This opinion is easily morally high, because in the eyes of many people, there are many discussions in the classic works of Marxism. As long as the speech of the "ancestors" is quoted, there are sharp theoretical weapons, the so-called "socialism is a commodity economy" argument is irreparable.

However, both before and after the third plenary session of the eleventh central committee, many economists have insisted on the idea of "commodity economy". Going back a bit farther, as early as in 1959, Wang Xuewen and Qi Qi jointly published an article in "Economic Research", proposing "planned development of the commodity economy". After the third plenary session of the 11th Central Committee, veteran Guangdong economist Zhuo Jing wrote a paper in the spring of 1979, unequivocally proposing: break the product economy and develop the commodity economy. Also, in the same year, at the socialist economic value law discussion meeting held in Wuxi, Professor Hu Zhaopei of Xiamen University explicitly put forth the argument that "the socialist economy is a planned commodity economy based on public ownership". In 1979, Deng Liqun, the vice president of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, published an article in "Finance and Trade Economics" Issue 11, arguing that the current stage of socialist economy is a commodity economy.

In October 1979, the "Preliminary Opinions on the General Idea of Economic System Reform" issued by the Economic System Reform Group of the State Council Financial and Economic Committee, straightforwardly wrote: The current stage of socialist economy in China is a commodity economy where public ownership of production materials predominates, and various economic elements coexist. It is necessary to establish an economic system that fits with it. Despite the two qualifiers at the beginning, it clearly set the establishment of an economic system adapted to the commodity economy as the goal of reform. According to Professor Yang Qixian, who participated in the draft, this sentence was added by Xue Muqiao.

During this period, Chen Yun was also thinking about how to reform the planned economic system.



In March 1979, he summarized in the research proposal of "Planning and Market Issues": "For sixty years, the major disadvantage that has emerged in the planning work system of the Soviet Union or China is only 'planned proportionally.' There is no need for market regulation under the socialist system. The so-called market regulation is to regulate according to the law of value, and in some aspects of economic life, we can use the 'anarchic', 'blind' production method for regulation." This was the earliest mention within the party of the need for market regulation under the planned economic system. Therefore, throughout the 1980s, plans and markets, and their relationship and proportion, became the mainstream discourse within the party and the theoretical world. In 1981, Chen Yun summarized this statement as "the planned economy is supported by market regulation."

Concerning whether it is a planned economy or a commodity economy, the economic and ideological world has been exploring this through arguments; however, in 1982, a momentous change occurred. In early May of that year, the National Office for Economic Reform (reorganized as the Economic System Reform Commission in 1983) and the State Council Economic Center jointly held a large-scale discussion on the theoretical issues of economic reform. The seminar was divided into eight groups, with more than two hundred participants. The keynote of this seminar affirmed the planned economy, holding that the planned economy is a socialist economic system. Although some scholars pointed out that commodity economy is the basic content of commodity production and commodity exchange in theory, they have no essential difference. Still, the dominant opinion believes that the existence of commodity production and commodity exchange in socialist societies cannot be said to constitute a commodity economy.

Due to the lack of theoretical progress, the political report at the Twelfth National Congress of the Communist Party of China held in September 1982 emphasized the principle of "prioritize planned economy and supplement with market regulation”, pointing out: "China implements a planned economy based on public ownership. Planned production and circulation are the main body of China's national economy. As for the production and distribution of production materials and consumer materials, particularly backbone enterprises affecting the overall economy in the state-owned economy, it must implement directive planning... For the collective ownership economy, some directive indicators should also be given as needed."

The Twelfth Congress confirmed that China still implements a planned economy and maintaine directive plans and directive indicators. This was an inevitable understanding during the initial stage of China's reform of “crossing the river by feeling the stones”. Under these circumstances, the "Commodity Economics Theory" naturally fell into an awkward situation. In 1982 and 1983, criticism of the expressions "socialist commodity economy" and "planned commodity economy" in newspapers gradually heated up.

Some scholars believe that: "The key feature of the socialist economy should be the planned economy, not the commodity economy. The foothold of planned commodity economy is still the commodity economy— 'planned' is abstracted. If the planned economy no longer exists, where does 'planned' come from?"

Other scholars believe: "If we summarize our economy as a commodity economy, it will blur the essential difference between the socialist economy and the capitalist economy. The essential characteristic of the socialist economy can only be the planned economy... Downgrading the socialist economy to a 'commodity economy' can only be a historical regression. In fact, without a planned economy, there will be no socialism."

Of course, some scholars believe that it is correct to draw the line between socialist planned economies and capitalist market economies by whether there is a directive plan.

For a time, newspapers and public opinion were full of righteous denunciations of the "Commodity Economics Theory". Xue Muqiao, who advocated the "Commodity Economics Theory", was even criticized for "having the weaknesses of intellectuals."




After this intense criticism, Xue Muqiao finally made a concession, proposing that "the most important feature of the socialist economy is not the commodity economy, but the planned economy which is based on the public ownership of the means of production, and in which commodity production and exchange exist".
On September 6, 1982, Liu Guoguang, an economist at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, published an article titled "Adhering to the Basic Direction of Economic System Reform" in the People's Daily, emphasizing the importance of guiding plans and relatively reducing the scope of directive plans. On September 21, the "People's Daily" published a long article on the front page of the first edition in the name of the newspaper's commentator, indirectly criticizing Liu Guoguang.
The article continually emphasized the importance of directive plans, emphasizing that "the use of the market does not mean regulation by the market," stating that "directive plans are not, as some comrades have determined, only necessary when the national economy is in certain situations of adjustment. They are also necessary for the production and distribution of products related to public welfare and key industries in general conditions. In fact, they are the cornerstone of the principle that the planned economy is the main and market regulation is supplementary". Liu Guoguang's article was sent to the People's Daily before the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China and was published on the eve of the congress, contradicting the spirit of the political report of the congress. From the fall of 1982 to 1983, the forces to defend the directive plan were quite strong. Deng Liqun, who wrote an article advocating "commodity economy" in 1979, also joined in the criticism of commodity economy.
Actually, one important reason why such high-profile criticism of commodity economy emerged in 1982 and 1983 stemmed from a macro explanation of our country's economy after the 12th National Congress. The relationship between market regulation and the planned economy is like the relationship between the bird and the cage. If the bird represents invigorating the economy, the cage represents the national plan. Activating the economy and market regulation can only work within the scope allowed by the plan, and cannot depart from the guidance of the plan. This is equivalent to saying that the ongoing state-owned enterprise reform is a "change within the cage". Another political background was the Anti-Spiritual Pollution Campaign in 1983. At that time, some people took the advocacy of "commodity economy" as a target of "spiritual pollution" for criticism. Fortunately, this deviation was quickly corrected by the central government. The process of Chinese reform always creates new opportunities in the midst of "mountains and rivers in doubt". In the climax of criticism of the commodity economy, a new change is brewing.
2. The divergence and breakthrough of the Planned Management System Reform
In 1983, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council were ready to advance the "macro first change" strategy on a global scale. Where to start with macro first change? They chose the "directive planning system of the product planning economy" - that is, the planning management system. The planning management system controls the overall situation of the planned economy, so the first step in advancing the macro first change strategy on a global scale was to reform the planning management system.
From August to December 1983, the Planned Management System Reform Leading Group was established under the leadership of the Secretariat of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, and the Planned Management System Reform Working Group was set up. The main members of the working group came from the State Planning Commission and the State Council's Reform Office, with the office located in the South District Guard Building of Zhongnanhai. The task of the Planning Management System Reform Working Group was to propose a reform plan. This work from August to December 1983, due to differing views in discussion and large gaps between different views, most of the time was spent on debate.
There were two representative views during the debate:



The first opinion suggests that state-owned enterprises should expand their autonomy in production and operation, broaden the scope of market regulation, and take responsibility for their profits and losses. This requires narrowing the scope of directive planning and correspondingly reducing the range of state-priced products. 

The second opinion emphasizes two points: (1) Any important product related to the national economy, whether it is in short supply or surplus, should have directive planning. The scope of directive planning cannot and should not be reduced. (2) State-owned enterprises cannot operate under a profit-and-loss responsibility system nor a relative profit-and-loss responsibility system. The reason is that if state-owned enterprises apply a profit and loss system, they won't be willing to accept low-price directive production plans and product allocation plans.

The debate was intense and in-depth. The economist Wang Zhuo, who participated in this discussion, specifically recalled several events that occurred during the discussion:

The first event, Neresh, who is known as the father of Hungarian reform, visited China. When he visited the National Planning Commission, some people asked him: did Hungary really cancel the directive plan? To this, some people present expressed obvious doubts. When Neresh visited the Ministry of Materials and other ministries, some units also raised similar questions, showing skepticism about Hungary's cancellation of directive planning. Neresh was deeply puzzled by this, and when he arrived at the State Council Reform Office, he asked: why did some ministries in your country not believe in Hungary's reform of cancelling directive planning? He expressed regret about this! This event illustrates that at that time, central ministries widely disagreed with the reform of reducing directive planning, and did not approve of the reform of canceling directive planning.

The second event, during a reporting meeting attended by ministry leaders, someone pointedly said that Wang Zhuo had proposed the theory of product production during the discussion. At that time, whoever advocated for the expansion of product production was considered heretical. Wang Zhuo was prepared to respond. Immediately, Liao Jili from the State Council Reform Office protected Wang Zhuo, saying that it was not the case, and blocked the attacking comments from that comrade. Therefore, Wang Zhuo didn't need to reply any further.

The third event, at the same meeting, a somewhat famous economist spoke out against the reform of reducing the scope of directive planning. After the meeting, some comrades were in a lively debate, accusing him of being a verbal reformist who would readily change his original points with the shift in "political wind."

The fourth event, the different opinions initially discussed within the Planning System Reform Working Group were leaked outside of the meeting. Consequently, someone from the CPC Central Committee Policy Research Office wrote a letter to the leading comrades of the CPC Central Committee, stating that some people are now rekindling the debate on directive planning. What was originally a dispute over reform issues was painted with political colors, preventing this beneficial grand debate from achieving the desired results.

After several months of work, the Planning Management System Reform Working Group produced a compromise draft incorporating the two opinions. After more modifications, it did not form a proper document. However, the strategy of macro change did not fail, and the "grand debate" has not concluded.



In 1984, the system reform project in China continued and achieved breakthrough major results. This is "The Decision on Economic System Reform" passed by the Third Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on October 20, 1984. This decision acknowledged for the first time that what China was implementing was a "planned commodity economy".
3. The Drafting and Passage of "The Decision on Economic System Reform"
The drafting team of "The Decision on Economic System Reform" was left over from the drafting team of the government work report for the Sixth National People's Congress. The team includes Yuan Mu, Gao Shangquan, Gui Shipu, Wang Renzhi, Xie Minggan, Yang Qixian etc. It started with Yuan Mu in charge of drafting the outline. The draft was discussed many times and could not break out of the circle of "planning economy as the main and market regulation as the supplement". At that time, some people believed that in order to break out of this circle, there must be a breakthrough in the issue of the commodity economy, that is, to change the reform target model from "planning economy as the main, market regulation as the supplement" to "planned commodity economy". However, the views of the drafting team on this issue were very different.
Between July and August 1984, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China held a meeting in Beidaihe. Under the chairmanship of Hu Yaobang, the drafting team discussed the outline twice. Hu Yaobang was not satisfied with this outline. He emphasized repeatedly that this is a historic document, and it must be well written. He also said that economic issues should listen to Zhao Ziyang's opinions, and proposed to include the development of various economic components. Hu Yaobang strengthened the drafting team and added Lin Jianqing, Lin Zili, Gong Yuzhi, and Zheng Biji. The person in charge was changed from Yuan Mu to Lin Jianqing.
After returning to Beijing from Beidaihe, both Hu Yaobang and Zhao Ziyang hosted discussions respectively. When talking about the relationship between planning and market, Zhao Ziyang said, "I lean towards writing about planned commodity economy.". During this period, many people had given suggestions to Zhao Ziyang. For instance, in August, Dong Fuchu, Tong Dalin, Yu Guangyuan and more than ten economists held a meeting in Baiwanzhuang, Beijing, adamantly advocate for "planned commodity economy". They wrote a conference report to Zhao Ziyang, stating their reasons. Thus, it can be seen that Zhao Ziyang's initial establishment of "planned commodity economy" was based on the opinions of many parties.
Zhao Ziyang convened the drafting team to discuss twice in Zhongnanhai. Besides the drafting team members, Deng Liqun was also invited to the last discussion. Zhao Ziyang asked everyone, "Are there any theoretical problems?" Yang Qixian answered: "It can stand theoretically." Zhao Ziyang asked again: "Is there any contradiction with the constitution?" Zheng Biji answered: "No contradiction..."



"The Constitution doesn't mention 'a planned economy being principal and market adjustment auxiliary,'" Zhao Ziyang announced at the end of the meeting. As everyone stood and prepared to leave, Zhao Ziyang asked Deng Liqun, "Old Deng, what do you think?" Deng Liqun replied, "That's exactly what I proposed in 1979". Sometimes, the details of history can be thought-provoking.

On September 9, Zhao Ziyang wrote a letter to Hu Yaobang, Deng Xiaoping, Li Xianian, and Chen Yun, suggesting that China's economic system should be summed up in the following four points:
1. China practices a planned economy, not a market economy.
2. Spontaneous and blind regulation of production and exchange through the market is limited to small commodities, three types of agricultural and sideline products, and service repair industries, which play an auxiliary role in the national economy.
3. A planned economy does not mean a mainly directive plan. Directive and indicative plans are specific forms of a planned economy ...For a considerable length of time, our policy should be to gradually reduce directive planning and expand indicative planning.
4. Indicative plans mainly use economic means of regulation, while directive plans must also consider the role of economic laws, especially the law of value. The socialist economy is a planned commodity economy based on public ownership. Plans should be implemented through the law of value, and the law of value should be used to serve planning. The description "plans first, law of value second" is not accurate, and should not be continued in the future...

Zhao Ziyang's letter quickly received approval from the four standing members of the Politburo. On September 11, the Central Committee convened approximately 1,500 people, including members of the Central Committee and alternate members in Beijing, members of the Central Advisory Commission, members of the Central Discipline Inspection Commission, main cadres of various central departments, leaders of provinces, cities and regions, big military districts and 26 large enterprises to discuss the draft proposal. Through discussion, attendees strengthened their recognition of the necessity and urgency of economic system reform, especially city system reform, and agreed to incorporate "planned commodity economy" into the "Resolution of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on Economic Structure Reform" (hereafter referred to as "Resolution"). At the same time, the title of the fourth section of the draft "Reforming the planning system, consciously applying the law of value" was changed to "Planning system that consciously applies the law of value, developing socialist commodity economy"

"However, including this in the Resolution does not mean everyone's thoughts are aligned," said Yang Qixian. Due to ongoing controversy, the night before the final draft of the "Resolution" was formally drafted, a sentence was added: "However, under socialist conditions, labor, banks, land, and mines are not commodities." This effectively means that the commodity economy is limited to the production of products, and does not include elements of production, it is not a complete commodity economic system.

The Twelfth Plenary Session of the Third Central Committee passed the decision on economic system reform, clarifying the urgency and necessity of accelerating the economic system reform with a focus on urban areas, and laying out the direction, nature, tasks, and basic policy principles for the reforms.

The most outstanding contribution of this "Resolution" is that it broke the traditional view that equates a planned economy with a commodity economy, affirming that China's socialist economy is a "planned commodity economy based on public ownership." The reforms in China are self-improvement and developments of the socialist system. The basic tasks of the reform are to further implement policies to stimulate the economy domestically, to implement openness externally, and to gradually establish a lively and vibrant socialist economic system with Chinese characteristics that promotes the development of social productivity.



Centered around the basic task of reform, the "Decision" clearly put forward the main problems to be solved, namely, establishing a vibrant socialist economic system; making the enhancement of enterprise vitality the central link of economic system reform; establishing a planning system that consciously applies the law of value, developing a socialist commodity economy; establishing a reasonable pricing system, giving full attention to the role of economic leverage; implementing the separation of government and enterprise responsibilities, and properly playing the role of government institutions in managing the economy; establishing various forms of economic responsibility system, earnestly implementing the principle of distribution according to work; actively developing various forms of economy, further expanding foreign and domestic economic and technical exchanges; using a new generation of people, creating a grand team of socialist economic management cadres; strengthening the leadership of the Party, to ensure the smooth progress of the reform.
This "Decision" has made the direction, task and requirements of our country's reform more clear, and is a programmatic document guiding our country's comprehensive economic system reform. Although it has not proposed the issue of establishing a socialist market economic system in its reform goals, the proposed goal of planned commodity economy on the basis of public ownership has already implied a clear market orientation, which is a major breakthrough in socialist economic theory. Deng Xiaoping gave it high praise, believing it to be "political economy combining Marxist basic principles and Chinese socialist practice."
Practice has proved that the release and implementation of the "Decision on Economic System Reform" of the Third Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee is another liberation of the thoughts of the vast number of cadres and the masses. After this plenary session, the economic system reform focused on urban areas began to unfold around expanding the autonomy of enterprises, piloting shareholding system, reforming ownership structure, changing employment system, implementing the factory director responsibility system and so on.

III. Define the theme of the era and develop foreign relations

After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, when the Party and the state shifted the focus of work to socialist modernization construction centered on economic construction, diplomatic work, like other tasks, serves the center of economic construction and the key point of socialist modernization construction. To adapt to this need, the Party and the country adjusted their diplomatic strategy.

1. Adjustment of International Strategy and Diplomatic Policy

Centered on economic construction, it is necessary to have a good external condition, that is, a peaceful international environment. How to create a peaceful international environment is restricted by various factors. How to correctly analyze and estimate the international situation and adopt the correct foreign strategy and policy is one of the extremely important aspects.

(1) Preliminary adjustment in Chinese leaders' understanding of war and peace. When New China was just established, in order to resist and break the hostility, isolation and blockade of the United States, the Chinese government adopted a "one-sided" foreign policy and formed an alliance with the Soviet Union. This was necessary in the international environment at that time. In the late 1950s, the Soviet Union implemented chauvinism of a big country, forced China to accept its demands damaging China's sovereignty, and pressured China politically, economically, and militarily, leading to a rapid deterioration of Sino-Soviet relations. In the 1970s, one of the two superpowers, the United States, strategically withdrew due to its weakening in the Vietnam War, while the Soviet Union, which was in the stage of military strengthening, took the opportunity to expand massively, seriously threatening world peace and China's security. Under this international situation, the Chinese government adjusted its foreign policy, adopted a "one-line" policy, and implemented a foreign strategy of aligning with the United States against the Soviet Union. The implementation of this strategy not only effectively maintained China's own security but also greatly curbed the global expansion momentum of the Soviet Union.

After the end of the "Cultural Revolution," how to analyze and judge the international situation and formulate a foreign strategy and policy based on this became a major issue in China's foreign relations. In December 1977, the Central Military Commission held a meeting, at which Hua Guofeng, Chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, delivered a speech on the international situation, especially the issues of war and peace, stating that due to the fact that both imperialism and social imperialism are inherently brewing war, the U.S.-Soviet contention would eventually lead to war. Therefore, the outbreak of a world war is inevitable, either sooner or later. We must seize the time and prepare for war.



Compared to the world war triggered by the US-Soviet rivalry, the greatest threat to China's security was still the Soviet Union's invasion of China. The Soviet Union's intention to eliminate us never died, making it our most important and dangerous enemy. In light of this, we need to estimate enough, put our foothold on its attack on us, prepare for its early and severe attack, carry out sudden attacks, and prepared to deal with the most serious situation, never harboring any fluke mentality. The veteran comrades present here should prepare to fight another big war in their lifetime. This recognition, to a certain extent, represented the views of Chinese leaders at the time. This understanding indicated that the sense of inevitable and impending crisis of the war, especially the Soviet Union's invasion of China, was quite strong.

Although the World War and the Soviet Union's invasion of China were seen as inevitable and imminent, Chinese leaders still sought to delay the war, fight for time, carry out construction and strengthen national defense. And there were certain favorable conditions for delaying the outbreak of war: Mao Zedong's theory of the three-world division and the revolutionary diplomatic line could form a good international anti-hegemony united front. In addition, the Soviet Union's global strategy was not ready and the US was defensive globally after the failure in Southeast Asia. So, there was time to fight for a delay in the outbreak of the war. However, because of the serious estimate of the danger of war, it was still challenging to determine exactly how long the war could be delayed. It was likely that the war could be stopped for five years or a little longer, but it could also only be delayed for two, three, or four years.

In the early 1980s, the above basic estimation of the international situation had not changed. China still believed that various contradictions in the world would continue to develop, the international situation would become more turbulent, and the factors of war would continue to increase. However, considering the international political reality of the war not yet broken out and the domestic political reality of China not being ready for war, Chinese leaders still hoped to delay the arrival of the war as much as possible.

In January 1980, Deng Xiaoping expressed at the CPC Central Committee cadre meeting, "We are confident that we can delay the outbreak of war if we do a good job in anti-hegemony struggle and fight for a longer period of peace." His idea of disrupting the US-Soviet strategic deployment through anti-hegemony struggle to delay the outbreak of war was proposed. Deng Xiaoping's sense of imminent war crisis was further alleviated, and the confidence in fighting for a longer period of peace was further strengthened. As the judgment of the danger of war tended to be relaxed, Deng Xiaoping extended the time for delaying the war and fighting for peace, from 5 years or less to 10 years or even 20 years.



We need a relatively long-term peaceful environment for development. Despite the unstable international situation at that time, especially after the Soviet invaders went into Afghanistan at the end of 1979, the global situation became even more turbulent. However, Deng Xiaoping kept prolonging the peace time that could be strived for, which clearly showed a significant and essential change in his views on the world situation, war and peace. He began to shift from highlighting the danger of war to emphasizing striving for a longer period of peace and stressed that we should seize this peaceful time to develop the economy, rather than preparing for war.
(2) A new summary of the theme of the world era. With China's relations with several major countries undergoing major changes, China quickly noticed the positive effect of this change.
In the late 1970s, the international situation was still somewhat unpredictable, and at the end of 1979, the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan occurred. In response to this international situation, our country's foreign relations revolved around the idea of "striving for more time without conflict," "delaying the outbreak of war," and "wanting to seize time" for development.
After China and the United States established diplomatic relations, China strengthened the US-Soviet “one-line” strategy. This was both for considerations of national security and for the need to expedite opening up to the outside world. However, the normal development of Sino-U.S. relations has always faced some obstacles, the most prominent being the issue of Taiwan. Shortly after the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and the United States, the U.S. Congress passed the "Taiwan Relations Act," which damaged Sino-U.S. relations. It was not until August 17, 1982, when the Chinese and U.S. governments issued a joint communique on resolving U.S. arms sales to Taiwan in phases until completely, that Sino-U.S. relations stabilized. However, the U.S. government did not fulfill its promise. In this situation, China began to distance itself from the United States.
In 1982, based on the need to strive for peace, delay war, and establish more balanced foreign relations, the Chinese government began to oppose hegemony and maintain world peace, and strengthen solidarity and cooperation with the third world as the basic foreign policy of our country in the new era. Deng Xiaoping emphasized, "Our proposal to maintain world peace is not empty talk, it is based on our own needs and of course it also meets the needs of the people worldwide, especially the people in the third world. Therefore, opposing hegemony, maintaining peace is our real policy, it is the program of our foreign policy." In September of the same year, Hu Yaobang also publicly stated in the Twelfth Congress Report, "China insists on an independent foreign policy and develops relations with various countries guided by the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence."
Entering the mid-1980s, the international situation clearly began to ease. Not only did US-Soviet relations improve, but Sino-Soviet relations also underwent changes. In response to these new changes, in May 1984, Deng Xiaoping clearly proposed that the "peace issue" and the "north-south issue" had become the two prominent issues around the world. On March 4, 1985, while meeting with Japanese guests, he further made the judgment that "peace and development are the two major issues in the contemporary world." He said: "The real major issues in the world now, the global strategic issues, one is the peace issue, one is the economic issue, or the development issue. The peace issue encompasses the east and the west, the development issue encompasses the south and the north. To sum up, these are four words: east, west, south, and north."



"The introduction of the theme of peace and development laid a crucial theoretical foundation for the transformation of diplomatic strategy in the new era.
(3) Re-establishment of diplomacy based on independence and autonomy. On September 1, 1982, Deng Xiaoping solemnly announced in his opening speech at the 12th National Congress: Independence and self-reliance, self-sustained revitalization, whether in the past, present, or future, are our footholds. The Chinese people cherish their friendship and cooperation with other countries and peoples, and even more cherish the autonomy and independence they have fought for over a long period. No foreign country should expect China to become its vassal, nor should it expect China to swallow the bitter fruit of damage to our national interests. 
It is obvious that Deng Xiaoping's remarks targeted the changes in Sino-US relations at that time, expressing the Chinese government's serious stance and announced the transformation of China's diplomatic strategy.
Furthermore, Deng Xiaoping pointed out in his speech: Accelerate the socialist modernization, strive to achieve the reunification of the motherland, including Taiwan, oppose hegemonism, maintain world peace, these are the three major tasks for our people in the 1980s. Among these three tasks, the core is economic construction, which is the foundation to solve international and domestic issues.
Deng Xiaoping's speech clearly indicated that the goal of China's diplomatic strategy is to create a favorable international environment for the socialist modernization in China, demonstrating the focus of diplomatic work to serve economic construction.
Hu Yaobang, the General Secretary of the CPC Central Committee, comprehensively discussed the issue of China's persistence in its independent foreign policy in his political report at the 12th National Congress. He announced: "China will never be attached to any major powers or national groups, it will never yield to the pressure of any big country". "The five principles of peaceful coexistence apply to all our relations, including socialist countries."
Independence and peaceful coexistence have remained the diplomatic policy of New China since its establishment. However, from the 1950s to the late 1970s, due to the restrictions of the international environment and historical conditions at the time, the tendencies of "leaning to one side" and "drawing a line" with the US and Soviet Union had appeared. To some extent, these affected the implementation of the foreign policy of independence and peaceful coexistence and affected China's relations with some countries friendly to the U.S. or the Soviet Union.
Entering the 1980s, Deng Xiaoping, based on China's long-term diplomacy practice and changes in the international situation, brought new connotations to the diplomatic policy of independence and peaceful coexistence. The new connotation of independence is "non-alignment", not attached to any big powers or national groups. The new connotation of the principle of peaceful coexistence is that relations between countries are not judged by the differences or similarities of their social systems and ideologies; regardless the differences or similarities in social systems and ideologies, they should all be built on the basis of the five principles of peaceful coexistence. Deng Xiaoping believed that the practice of drawing lines or deeming affinity according to social systems or ideologies is unreliable. Only by transcending the differences and similarities in social systems and ideologies and universally implementing the five principles of peaceful coexistence can normal state relations be developed, international cooperation be enhanced, and world peace be maintained.
China upholds a diplomatic policy of independence and non-alignment, widely implements the principle of peaceful coexistence, and has received widespread acclaim and support internationally.
China takes the maintenance of world peace and the promotion of human progress and development as the fundamental purpose of its diplomatic work. To maintain world peace, we must first stop the arms race and implement real disarmament. In order to achieve this, the Chinese government has changed some of its past viewpoints and practices on the disarmament issue, actively participated in various international disarmament activities, and has put forward many new suggestions and propositions on this issue. For example, it proposed that the goal of disarmament should be to completely ban and thoroughly destroy nuclear weapons; the U.S. and the Soviet Union, possessing the world's largest nuclear arsenals, should take the lead in halting the testing, production, and deployment of all types of nuclear weapons, and to significantly reduce the presence of various nuclear weapons both within and outside their borders."



To prevent the outbreak of nuclear war, the Chinese government has proposed that all nuclear countries should undertake not to be the first to use nuclear weapons under any circumstances, especially not to use or threaten to use nuclear weapons against non-nuclear countries and non-nuclear zones. On this basis, an international convention should be concluded with the participation of all nuclear countries to ensure the prohibition of the use of nuclear weapons. At the same time as nuclear disarmament, there should be a substantial reduction in conventional arms; no country should develop, test, and deploy space weapons in any way; an international convention should be concluded as soon as possible to completely ban and thoroughly destroy chemical weapons. In order to ensure the implementation of disarmament, disarmament agreements must specify necessary and effective verification measures.
Considering that the issue of disarmament relates to the security interests of countries around the world, the Chinese government has also proposed that disarmament should not be delegated or monopolized by a few major powers, and their disarmament agreements should not harm the interests of other countries. All countries, regardless of their size or military strength, should enjoy equal rights to participate in discussions and solve the disarmament issue according to fair, reasonable, comprehensive, and balanced principles, and to effective disarmament.
In addition to the above fair and reasonable proposals, the Chinese government has also taken a series of practical actions on the issue of disarmament. For example, in 1985, it reduced the number of troops by 1 million, transferred military production to civilian use, and converted a large number of military facilities for civilian or shared military use. At the same time, defense spending was substantially reduced, and by the early 1990s, China's defense expenditure as a proportion of GDP was the lowest among any country in the world. The Chinese government's rational stance on reducing military equipment and practical actions have earned it widespread compliments from the international community.
The international strategic thinking and diplomatic theories put forward by Deng Xiaoping in the new era, and the adjustments of China's diplomatic policies, have perfected China's independent and peaceful foreign policy, creating a new situation in China's diplomatic work. This has played an important role in China's modernization, safeguarding world peace, developing friendly cooperation with various countries, and promoting common prosperity. It made a huge contribution.
2. Developing Peaceful and Friendly Relations with Major Countries
As Chinese leaders' views on war and peace were changing, China's relations with several major countries were also changing.
(1) The positive development of Sino-Japanese relations. After the Sino-Japanese Peace and Friendship Treaty was concluded in October 1978, both sides began to exhibit a positive development momentum in the political, economic, scientific, and cultural fields. In December 1979, Prime Minister Masayoshi Ito officially visited China. During this visit, both sides agreed that, although China and Japan have different systems, it is necessary to further strengthen dialogue between the governments to promote exchanges at various levels between the two countries. During this visit, the two leaders prominently discussed economic cooperation between China and Japan, and both leaders agreed that it is advisable for China and Japan to further cooperate in resources and energy. The two sides reached an agreement on cooperation to explore and exploit oil in the Bohai Sea and cooperate in the development of resources like coal. Japan also announced that from 1979 to 1983, it will provide JPY 330 billion (about USD 1.5 billion) in loans from the Overseas Economic Cooperation Fund for construction projects prioritized in China's modernization plan. Starting from April 1980, Japan will also offer preferential tariff treatment to Chinese products. The two sides also signed a cultural exchange agreement during Prime Minister Ito’s visit. The visit greatly advanced economic cooperation between the two countries.
1982 marked the 10th anniversary of the normalization of Sino-Japanese diplomatic relations. Chinese Premier Zhao Ziyang and Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone exchanged visits.



At the end of May and beginning of June, 1982, during Zhao Ziyang's visit to Japan, he proposed three principles for the development of Sino-Japanese relations: On the basis of the existing peaceful and friendly relations between the two countries according to the "Sino-Japanese Joint Statement" and "Sino-Japanese Peace and Friendship Treaty", the economic relations between the two countries should be actively developed; Sino-Japanese economic relations should follow the principle of mutual benefit and equality, starting from each other's needs and possibilities, exchanging needs, taking strengths to make up for weaknesses, and continuously developing in new breadth and depth; The development of this type of economic relation serves the fundamental interests of the people of China and Japan and the wish for generations of friendship, and should be long-term and stable, unaffected by international turmoil. The Chinese-proposed three principles of Sino-Japanese relations received an active response from Prime Minister Suzuki and the Japanese government. In September of the same year, Prime Minister Suzuki made a return visit to China. Deng Xiaoping said to Prime Minister Suzuki that, to sum up, Sino-Japanese relations are about generations of friendship between the two peoples, and that is our state policy.

In November 1983, General Secretary Hu Yaobang visited Japan. Prime Minister Nakasone proposed to change the three principles of Sino-Japanese relations to four principles, adding "mutual trust" to the existing "peaceful and friendly, equal mutual benefit, long-term stability". Hu Yaobang agreed. According to the agreement between the two sides during this visit, the "Sino-Japanese Friendship 21st Century Committee" was established in 1984 with representatives from all walks of life in China and Japan, and 3,000 Japanese youths visited China in the same year. The following year, 500 Chinese youths visited Japan.

In March 1984, Prime Minister Nakasone visited China. In April 1985, Chairman Peng Zhen visited Japan. These mutual visits by leaders of the two countries made significant contributions to the establishment of the four principles of Sino-Japanese relations and the promotion of a long-term, stable, friendly, and cooperative relationship between China and Japan. During this period, exchanges and cooperation between the two countries in economic, cultural, and scientific and technological fields became more active. By 1989, the total trade between the two countries reached 18.9 billion USD, which was 2.7 times the total trade in 1979; Japan is China's second-largest trading partner, after the United States. The two countries made progress in capital cooperation and technology transfer. In December 1979, when Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan visited China, he formally announced that the Japanese government would cooperate with China's six major projects, and decided to provide China with the first batch of government loans of 50 billion yen at low interest in 1979, with an annual interest rate of 3%, a repayment period of 30 years, and a grace period of 10 years. This is referred to as government development assistance, or ODA for short. In 1984, a second batch of low-interest loans of 470 billion yen (approximately 2.1 billion USD) was provided. In December 1984, the Japanese side agreed to provide China with a second batch of energy development loans of about 2.4 billion USD. In 1988, Japan proposed a third batch of low-interest loans of 810 billion yen, mainly for the construction of 42 key projects during the "Eighth Five-Year Plan" period. New progress has been made in the Sino-Japanese joint development of offshore oilfields. The two sides signed five contracts, with a total investment by the Japanese side of 800 million USD. To promote and protect the smooth progress of economic cooperation between the two countries, the two governments signed the Sino-Japanese Avoidance of Double Taxation Agreement in 1983. The ever-closer economic cooperation between China and Japan has effectively promoted their own economic development and brought great benefits to both sides.

Of course, while making good progress in bilateral relations, China and Japan have also encountered some problems, such as Japan's infringement of China's sovereignty on the Diaoyu Islands issue in 1979 and 1980; the "textbook issue" in the spring of 1982. At that time, when the Japanese Ministry of Education examined the history textbooks for primary and secondary schools, it distorted the history of Japanese militarist aggression against China, changing "aggression" to "entry", "full-scale aggression" against China to "full-scale attack", and even attributing the cause of the "Nanjing Massacre" to "due to the fierce resistance of the Chinese army, the Japanese army suffered heavy losses and killed many Chinese military and civilians in anger", etc., to exonerate the militarism of its responsibilities. In 1985, there was an incident where the Japanese Prime Minister and other government members officially paid homage to the Yasukuni Shrine, which houses the spirits of war criminals, etc. While these incidents have impacted on the smooth development of Sino-Japanese relations to some extent, overall, the development of relations between the two countries during this period was reasonably good.



(2) China-U.S. relations continue to advance through mutual understanding. China and the U.S. officially established diplomatic relations in 1979. In order to further enhance mutual understanding and promote the development of China-U.S. relations, Deng Xiaoping made an official friendly visit to the United States at the beginning of 1979 at the invitation of President Carter. This was the first visit to the US by a Chinese leader since the founding of the People's Republic of China, and was warmly welcomed by the US government and people. During his visit, Deng Xiaoping exchanged views with President Carter on international situations, particularly on the issue of Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia with the support of the Soviet Union. The two sides also focused on discussions on the Taiwan issue and China-U.S. relations. During the visit, China and the U.S. signed agreements on scientific and technological cooperation and cultural exchange, agreements on cooperation in education, business, and space, and agreements on establishing consular relations and mutual establishment of consulates, and decided to negotiate on signing trade, aviation, and maritime agreements.
