During the visit, Deng Xiaoping had extensive contacts with people from all walks of life in the United States.
The establishment of diplomatic relations between China and the US and Deng Xiaoping's visit to the US have promoted the development of China-US relations in various fields. In August 1980, China and the US signed the China-US Civil Aviation Agreement, China-US Maritime Agreement and China-US Textile Agreement in Washington. Trade between China and the US increased significantly, and cultural exchanges also rapidly developed. However, some of the US's incorrect practices on the Taiwan issue remain a major obstacle to the smooth development of China-US relations.
After the formal establishment of diplomatic relations between China and the United States, US President Carter proposed a "legislative adjustment" bill on US-Taiwan relations to Congress on January 26, 1979, indicating that the US would continue to maintain business, cultural, and other relations with Taiwan on a non-official basis and would establish the "American Institute in Taiwan" to handle related affairs. When the two houses of the U.S. Congress discussed this bill, they proposed a series of amendments that seriously violated the principles of the Sino-US diplomatic communiques and blatantly interfered in China's internal affairs. This could not help but arouse strong opposition from China.
At the end of March 1979, the two houses of the U.S. Congress passed the "Taiwan Relations Act," the basic spirit, and many specific provisions of which violated the Sino-U.S. diplomatic communique and well-recognized principles of international law. This is particularly reflected in the so-called "guarantee of Taiwan's security" issue and the nature of US-Taiwan relations. The Taiwan Relations Act declares: "The President shall promptly inform the Congress whenever the interests of the United States are threatened by any danger to the security or social economic system of the people on Taiwan, and any danger to the interests of the United States resulting therefrom. The President and the Congress should decide on appropriate action in response to any such danger in accordance with constitutional procedures." These provisions actually seek to indirectly restore the U.S.-Taiwan "Mutual Defense Treaty" that the U.S. announced would end in the Sino-U.S. diplomatic communique, blatantly interfering in China's internal affairs.
The "Taiwan Relations Act" also legally establishes that the United States will continue to provide so-called "defense materials" and "defense services" to Taiwan. The law stipulates: Recognizing the People's Republic of China should not in any way affect the tangible or intangible property held by Taiwanese authorities in the United States before the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and the United States. According to international law, after the United States recognized the Government of the People's Republic of China as the only legal government of China, it is obliged to hand over to the People's Republic of China, in a timely manner, the official property of China in the United States formerly occupied by the Taiwanese authorities. Many provisions in the Taiwan Relations Act actually treat Taiwan as an independent political entity and seek to make US-Taiwan relations official.
On April 10, Carter signed the "Taiwan Relations Act," making reservations on only a few issues, indicating that he would exercise the "discretion" given to the President by the law in a manner consistent with the agreement to establish diplomatic relations between China and the United States.



China is outraged by the enactment of the "Taiwan Relations Act". On April 19, Deng Xiaoping pointed out when meeting with the U.S. Senate Foreign Affairs Committee delegation visiting China: The political foundation of the normalization of relations between China and the United States is that there is only one China, and this foundation is now being disrupted; China is dissatisfied with the "Taiwan Relations Act" passed by the U.S. Congress, the most essential issue of this Act, is that it effectively does not recognize that there is only one China. On April 28, the Chinese Foreign Ministry notified the U.S. Embassy in China, pointing out that the "Taiwan Relations Act" was essentially an intentional continuation of treating Taiwan as a "country", treating the Taiwan authorities as "governments", many of its clauses violated the principles of the China-US diplomatic relations communique. On July 6, the U.S. Embassy in China responded: "The United States will comply with all understandings reached with the People's Republic of China on establishing diplomatic relations"; "The final U.S.-Taiwan Relations Act passed by Congress does not meet the government's intentions in every detail, but it provides the President with sufficient discretion powers to fully implement this law in accordance with the method of normalization". But the U.S. Congress eventually passed the bill.

Following the "Taiwan Relations Act" incident, the U.S. increased its arms sales to Taiwan, and after long-term negotiations between China and the U.S., in 1982, the "August 17" communique was reached, which further identified the principles and direction for solving the issue of arms sales to Taiwan. This was an important step in removing obstacles in China-US relations.

In order to promote mutual understanding between China and the U.S., stabilize relations between the two countries, promote China-US friendship, and maintain world peace, in January 1984, Premier Zhao Ziyang visited the U.S. at the invitation of President Reagan, and exchanges views on international situations and major international issues of interest to both sides with Reagan and other leaders of the U.S. government.

In April of the same year, President Reagan paid a return visit to the Chinese leaders visiting the U.S. In July 1985, Chairman Li Xiannian visited the U.S., and in October of the same year, U.S. Vice President Bush visited China. The reciprocal visits of the leaders of the two countries continued to exchange views on bilateral relations and major international issues, one of the core issues being the Taiwan issue. Obviously, only by eliminating the obstacle of the Taiwan issue can a truly reliable foundation be established for the stable and lasting development of China-US relations.

Although there are always obstacles between China and the U.S. on the Taiwan issue, the overall trend of the development in economy, trade, science and technology exchanges and cooperation between the two countries is positive. China-US economic and technological cooperation has gradually developed. By the end of 1986, the total amount of direct investment contracts agreed by the U.S. in China exceeded $2.627 billion. Of this, joint venture investment was $400 million, and offshore oil development cooperation investment was nearly $600 million. A total of 62 approved Sino-US joint ventures accounted for 6% of the total number of Sino-foreign joint ventures in China, and the total investment amount and the number of projects only second to the Hong Kong region, ranking first among all countries. Since the signing of the Science and Technology Cooperation Agreement between the two countries in 1979 till 1986, China and the U.S. have signed 27 official science and technology cooperation protocols, with more than 500 cooperation projects and over 5,000 personnel exchanges.

Trade between the two countries, which was almost zero in 1972, increased to the point where the U.S. became China's third-largest trading partner by 1985. From 1981 to 1986, the accumulated bilateral trade volume exceeded $35.3 billion. Among this, there was $5.9 billion in 1981; $5.28 billion in 1982; there was a decrease to $4 billion in 1983, but it rebound back to $6.1 billion in 1984; it reached $7.4 billion in 1985; and $7.3 billion in 1986.

In May 1983, when U.S. Commerce Department Secretary Baldridge visited China, he informed the Chinese government of President Reagan's new regulations easing technology exports to China, which changed China's classification from the "P" group to the "V" group in the U.S. export control classification, and listed China in the category of friendly non-aligned countries with the U.S. On June 21 of the same year, the U.S. formally announced this provision. In October 1985, the U.S. opened up exports of 27 different equipment categories to China. The U.S. has loosened its technology exports to China.



However, there are many problems in economic, trade, and technological cooperation between China and the United States. The protectionism within the United States has posed a threat to the development of Sino-US economic and trade relations. For example, the United States has repeatedly restricted the import of Chinese textiles. From 1972 to 1986, China's trade deficit with the United States had accumulated to $18.4 billion. The China-US investment protection agreement, due to the United States insisting on stricter conditions than other developed countries, remains unresolved after several years of negotiation. In technology transfer, the United States still has many restrictions on high-tech exports to China, which require the security review of the United States and review by the "Paris Club".

(3) China-Soviet relations developed through "breaking the ice". Beginning in the 1960s, Soviet leaders seriously violated the spirit of the "Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship, Alliance, and Mutual Assistance", leading to a serious deterioration of the relations between the two countries. By the late 1970s, the Soviet Union continued to maintain and strengthen its military pressure on China's northern border, posing a serious threat to China's security. This rendered the "Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship, Alliance, and Mutual Assistance" virtually defunct. Therefore, according to the relevant provisions of the Sino-Soviet Treaty, on April 3, 1979, the seventh meeting of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress decided not to extend the treaty after its expiry. On the same day, Chinese Foreign Minister Huang Hua met with Soviet Ambassador to China, Sherbakov, and handed him a note from the Chinese government to the Soviet government, notifying the Soviet side of the above-mentioned decision of the Standing Committee of the Chinese People's Congress.

In 1982, progress was made in talks between China and the U.S. on weapons sales to Taiwan, giving new impetus to Sino-U.S. relations and having a positive impact on Sino-Soviet relations. On March 24, Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev gave a speech in Tashkent expressing a willingness to improve relations with China. Deng Xiaoping noticed the information passed by the Soviet side and immediately instructed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to respond. On March 26, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs held a press conference and issued a brief statement on Sino-Soviet relations. The following day, the People's Daily published this statement in a prominent position on the front page, causing widespread international response. In the summer, Deng Xiaoping convened several central and foreign ministry leaders to propose a major action to deliver a message to the Soviet Union and strive for a major improvement in Sino-Soviet relations. However, this should be done on certain principles, one condition being that the Soviet Union must take some action, thus proposing that the Soviet Union take the initiative to resolve the "three major obstacles". Subsequently, heads of the ministries of foreign affairs of the two countries made working visits to each other's countries as guests of the ambassadors. On August 10, the head of the Soviet-Europe Department of the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs visited Moscow under the pretext of inspecting embassy work and suggested holding deputy foreign minister-level political consultations. The Soviet side agreed on the 20th to discuss bilateral relations with China at any time, place, and level to "eliminate obstacles to normalizing relations". Given the Soviet side's positive response, Deng Xiaoping, after hearing the report from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, decided to reopen the Sino-Soviet talks. Thereafter, the two sides agreed to establish an official dialogue channel and alternate between Beijing and Moscow to hold deputy foreign minister-level special envoy political consultations on how to normalize the relations between the two countries. In September, Hu Yaobang mentioned in his report to the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China that as long as the Soviet Union takes practical steps to remove the security threat to China, Sino-Soviet relations might be normalized. Regardless of the state of Sino-Soviet relations, China will maintain and develop the friendship between the peoples of the two countries. This positively responded to the statements by Soviet leaders about their policy towards China. In October, the two countries resumed political dialogue and held the first deputy foreign minister-level consultation. China proposed to eliminate the three major obstacles, namely, withdrawal of troops from Mongolia and the Sino-Soviet border, withdrawal from Afghanistan, and urging Vietnam to stop invading Cambodia and withdraw its troops from Cambodia. These are the keys to normalizing Sino-Soviet relations.



Regrettably, the Soviet Union, under the pretext of not damaging the "interests of a third country", adopted an attitude of non-recognition and refusal to discuss the "three big obstacles." Subsequently, when several Soviet leaders passed away one after another, China sent delegations headed by members of the Central Political Bureau, the Foreign Minister and the Secretaries of the Central Secretariat and the Deputy Prime Minister respectively to attend the funerals in the Soviet Union. Through high-level contact opportunities, they acknowledged Soviet Union's socialist construction efforts, expressed hope for improved Sino-Soviet relations, and encouraged the Soviets to take practical actions towards normalizing Sino-Soviet relations. In December 1984, Soviet Deputy Prime Minister Arkhipov visited China. Sino-Soviet bilateral contact was elevated from the level of Deputy Foreign Minister to that of Deputy Prime Minister, setting up economic, trade, and scientific committees, signing economic and technological cooperation agreements about construction and reconstruction of industrial projects in China, as well as the barter and payment agreement from 1986 to 1990. Bilateral trade increased, border trade was resumed, the scope of cooperation expanded, and bilateral relations visibly improved.

In March 1985, Gorbachev assumed the post of the general secretary of the Communist Party Central Committee of the USSR. In October 1985, Deng Xiaoping sent a message to Gorbachev via visiting Romanian leaders: if the Soviet Union could persuade Vietnam to withdraw from Cambodia, he would agree to meet with Gorbachev. In November, the Soviet side stated that the time was ripe for a top-level meeting between China and the Soviet Union, suggesting a meeting either in the Soviet Far East or China to discuss the normalization of Sino-Soviet relations. In July 1986, in Vladivostok, Gorbachev said that the Soviet Union would withdraw six regiments from Afghanistan by the end of 1986, discuss the withdrawal of "a considerable portion of Soviet troops" from Mongolia, that it could divide the boundary line on the Sino-Soviet Boundary River according to the main navigational channel, and was prepared to hold serious talks on establishing a peaceful neighbourhood at any time and level with China. China cautiously welcomed this, and agreed to resume border negotiations. In September, Deng Xiaoping stated that if the Soviet Union could take a significant step towards removing the three obstacles between China and the Soviet Union, particularly in getting Vietnam to end its invasion of Cambodia and to withdraw its troops, he would agree to meet with Gorbachev anywhere in the Soviet Union.

Owing to improving bilateral relations, in February 1987, Sino-Soviet border negotiations formally resumed. After two rounds of negotiations, there was finally progress after many years of stalemate. From August 27 to September 1, 1988, Vice Foreign Minister Tian Zengpei and Soviet Vice Foreign Minister Rogauchy had a meeting in Beijing specifically on the Cambodia issue, reaching an internal understanding. On September 16, Gorbachev gave a talk in Krasnoyarsk, Siberia, proposing that the Soviet Union "intends to start preparing for a high-level Sino-Soviet meeting". Subsequently, on September 28, Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, both attending the 43rd session of the United Nations General Assembly, met in New York. They agreed that discussions on the Cambodia issue should continue. From December 1 to 3, Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen was invited to visit the Soviet Union officially. This was the first official visit of a Chinese Foreign Minister to the Soviet Union since 1957, the main purpose of which was to prepare for a Sino-Soviet summit. From February 1 to 4, 1989, Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze paid a reciprocal visit to China with the same purpose. On February 6, both sides simultaneously announced a statement on the Cambodia issue and the date of Gorbachev's visit to China. The statement pointed out, "Both sides advocate an early, fair, and reasonable political solution to the Cambodia issue, and express their willingness to make efforts to promote the achievement of this goal;" "Both sides believe that Vietnam's withdrawal from Cambodia is an essential part of the political solution to the Cambodia issue."



Both parties noted Vietnam's decision to fully withdraw from Cambodia by the end of September 1989, and hoped that the implementation of this decision would facilitate the negotiation process to resolve other issues related to Cambodia. The two sides also agreed to continue discussions on the resolution of the Cambodian issue. Thus, this resolves one of the "three major obstacles," essentially resolving the Cambodian issue.
The resolution of the other two obstacles among the "three major obstacles" was relatively easy. With regard to the issue of reducing Soviet troops on the Sino-Soviet and Sino-Mongolian borders, in January 1987, the Soviet Union announced that within the next 4 to 6 months, it would withdraw a motorized infantry division and other units from Mongolia. In a speech to the United Nations in December 1988, Gorbachev announced that the Soviet Union would withdraw 75% of its troops from Mongolia within two years. On May 15, 1989, this withdrawal process began. As for the withdrawal from Afghanistan, in a speech in Vladivostok in July 1986, Gorbachev announced that after the Soviet Union withdrew from Afghanistan, it would hold negotiations, under the auspices of the United Nations, with Pakistan, Kabul regime in Afghanistan, and the United States. On April 14, 1988, the four parties signed an agreement on the political solution to the Afghan issue in Geneva. The agreement stated that the Soviet Union would begin to withdraw from Afghanistan on May 15, 1988, and complete the withdrawal within 9 months. Finally, the Soviet troops fully withdrew from Afghanistan before February 15, 1989. Thus, the "three major obstacles" that affected the bilateral relationship were essentially resolved, and the path to Sino-Soviet high-level meetings was eventually cleared.
From May 15 to 18, 1989, at the invitation of Chairman Yang Shangkun, Mikhail Gorbachev, the Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet and the General Secretary of the Central Committee of the CPSU, paid an official visit to China. During this visit, Gorbachev held meetings with several Chinese leaders, including State President Yang Shangkun, General Secretary of the CPC Central Committee Zhao Ziyang, and Premier of the State Council Li Peng, but the most crucial conference was the high-level meeting with Deng Xiaoping held on the morning of May 16.
Prior to the meeting, Deng Xiaoping clarified that the theme of the meeting was "ending the past and opening the future," emphasizing that "the normalization of Sino-Soviet relations is based on the five principles of peaceful coexistence as per normal." Based on this, Deng Xiaoping established the guideline for this meeting: not to avoid differences, not to dwell on past grievances, seek common ground, look to the future, and to explore the establishment of new friendly neighborly relations based on the five principles of peaceful coexistence. Through this high-level meeting, the two neighbouring countries, China and the Soviet Union, finally ended decades of abnormality and re-established normal state relations. On the evening of the 16th, General Secretary of the CPC Central Committee Zhao Ziyang met with Gorbachev, signifying that the relationship between the two parties, China and the Soviet Union, was also normalized.
On May 18th, China and the Soviet Union issued a joint communiqué in Beijing, summarizing the consensus reached in this high-level meeting. The communiqué formally confirmed the principle of diplomatic relations between the two countries agreed upon by the highest leaders of the two countries. It was different from the alliance relationship of the 1950s and the confrontational state of the 60s and 70s. It was a normal state relation that neither aligned nor countered against each other nor targeted third countries but fostered neighborly friendship.
3. Development and Expansion of Peripheral Diplomacy and Multilateral Diplomacy
Since the 1980s, with the adjustment of China's diplomatic strategy, while prioritizing the promotion of major foreign country diplomacy, China has also vigorously developed peripheral and multilateral diplomacy and has achieved positive results. From 1983 to 1987, China established diplomatic relations with 10 more countries, reaching a total number of 135 countries. The principal leaders of the Chinese government and the party made friendly visits to 46 countries. Deputy prime minister-level leaders, special envoys of the government, and foreign ministers visited 77 countries. China hosted state heads, government leaders, vice presidents, deputy prime ministers, and foreign ministers from over 90 countries for visits. The leaders of the Chinese and foreign senior parliaments have exchanged visits 113 times. China has participated in 64 international conventions, signed 12 bilateral consular treaties as well as many other business agreements, laying the foundation for friendly cooperation between China and countries around the world.
It is worth noting that there has been a significant improvement in China's relations with neighboring countries.



From 1984 to 1987, our country’s leaders successively visited countries including Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Myanmar, and Nepal. Trade and friendly interactions with Mongolia increased, and the two countries signed a new consular treaty. Our country negotiated with Laos to normalize relations and the two countries resumed mutual ambassador deployment. After multiple contacts with Indonesia, the relationship improved and direct trade was resumed.
Looking at the overall situation, the development momentum of our country's external relations is good, and the effect is very obvious:
Firstly, in terms of relationships with neighboring countries. China pays attention to properly handling historical issues with neighboring countries and has made certain adjustments to its policies concerning Southeast Asian countries. It places importance on strictly distinguishing party relations from state relations, which has greatly improved bilateral relations with Southeast Asian countries. At the same time, it also put forward a five-point policy for resolving Sino-Indian border issues, helping Sino-Indian relations to restore high-level mutual visits and border negotiations.
Secondly, in terms of relations with the vast number of developing countries. China emphasizes practical cooperation and proposes the four principles of "equality and mutual benefit, focus on practical results, diverse forms, and common development." This has led to various forms of economic cooperation and has provided deeper economic foundations for our country's relationships with developing countries.
Thirdly, in terms of relationships between China and Western European countries. By the late 1970s, except for Andorra, Liechtenstein, Monaco, and the Vatican, China had established diplomatic relations with all Western European countries. China also specifically proposed accelerating the economic cooperation between China and Western European countries through joint ventures, cooperative development, compensation trade, processing of supplied materials, and sample processing, especially through joint development of oil, coal, and non-ferrous metal resources. From the beginning of the 70s to the early 80s, China signed cooperation agreements with many Western European countries in economics, trade, science and technology, culture, civil aviation, shipping, and other fields. In 1978 and 1979, China also signed trade agreements and textile agreements with the European Communities. Starting from 1980, the European Communities granted China the status of general preferential treatment. During this period, total trade between China and Western Europe increased significantly, and there was a promising start to other forms of economic cooperation. China has introduced some more advanced technologies from Western European countries. China has also started to introduce from Western European countries the funds needed for its modernization construction efforts. The common wish to "develop in peace" has laid a solid foundation for the relationships between China and most Western European countries, and has opened up a wide range of prospects.
After 1983, China's trade volume with Western European countries continued to grow, reaching 9.575 billion U.S. dollars in 1985, an increase of 40.7% compared to 1984, and 11.339 billion U.S. dollars in 1986, an increase of 39.3% compared to 1985, although there was a significant trade deficit on the Chinese side.
Fourthly, in international organizations, China, as one of the five permanent members of the United Nations, actively participates in multilateral diplomacy centered around the United Nations, has acceded to 64 international conventions, and has played an important role in promoting world peace and development. In terms of promoting development, China emphasizes that it is part of the developing country block, making efforts to strengthen its relations with developing countries, and playing a proactive role in promoting North-South dialogue, South-South cooperation, and international economic and technical cooperation. In March 1986, in his Government Work Report at the Fourth Session of the Sixth National People's Congress, Zhao Ziyang explicitly made multilateral diplomacy one of the important contents of China's independent and peaceful foreign policy:
"China adheres to the purposes and principles of the United Nations Charter, supports the work carried out by the United Nations in accordance with the spirit of the Charter, and actively participates in activities promoting world peace and development carried out by the United Nations and its specialized agencies."



China actively participates in a variety of international organizations, carries out proactive multilateral diplomatic activities, and strives to enhance cooperation in various fields among nations. By the end of 1986, China had entered almost every important field of intergovernmental multilateral diplomacy, participating in nearly 400 international organizations and ratifying the accession to 13 international conventions. China has established 11 permanent multilateral diplomatic institutions in various countries, including 10 offices of the United Nations and its specialized agencies in China. At the 39th United Nations General Assembly in 1984, renowned Chinese legal scholar Ni Zhengyu was elected as a judge of the International Court of Justice, ending the history of no persons from the People's Republic of China serving in this significant institution. In November 1986, another Chinese legal scholar was elected as a member of the International Law Commission.

In terms of multilateral economic and technical aid, China actively participates and strives to promote cooperation in various fields. By the end of 1986, China had contracted and effective loans totaling $4.15 billion from the World Bank, of which soft loans accounted for $1.6 billion, or 39%; 41 loan projects were mainly used for education, health, agriculture, transport, hydropower, energy and other fields. China borrowed from the IMF's first credit loan twice in 1981 and 1986, totaling $1.048 billion in special drawing rights. UN Development Program, Population Fund, Children's Fund, and other institutions had promised China over $800 million in grant technical assistance in seven years, arranging approximately 600 projects. Meanwhile, China also made pledges to United Nations economic entities; by the end of 1986, it had donated 25.48 million RMB and 25.51 million USD in convertible currencies. These have played an active role in promoting China's economic construction and enhancing international economic and technical cooperation.

In the 10 years since the reform and opening up, after a new round of adjustment of foreign affairs policies, China's diplomacy began to develop in all directions, and an international and surrounding environment conducive to the modernization and reform has begun to take shape.

IV. Proposing the "One Country, Two Systems" concept, starting the peaceful reunification process

After the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Party, the Party leadership, with Deng Xiaoping at its core, creatively proposed the scientific concept of "peaceful unification, one country, two systems" based on major changes in the international and domestic situations and in the fundamental interests of the state and the nation, and eventually made it into a basic national policy of our country.

1. The origin of the "One Country, Two Systems" and the peaceful reunification of the motherland scientific concept.

The "One Country, Two Systems" and peaceful unification of the nation's policy is an inheritance and development of the Chinese Communist Party's Taiwan policy since the founding of the People's Republic of China. In 1949, the People's Liberation Army was sweeping all before them; the slogan "Overthrow Chiang Kai-shek and Liberate All of China" soon became a reality. Chiang Kai-shek fled to Taiwan in despair. From then on, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait were unfortunately separated. Mao Zedong and others, facing the separation of mainland China and Taiwan, had always been tirelessly exploring and seeking ways and approaches to reunify the motherland, and proposed a series of Taiwan policies.

From 1949 to 1955, the Chinese Communist Party's policy towards Taiwan can be summarized as "relying solely on military force" to solve the problem. On December 31, 1949, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued "A Letter to the Frontline Soldiers and All Nationals", pointing out that the reactionary rule of imperialism and Kuomintang had been overthrown forever, and the task of 1950 was to liberate Hainan Island, Taiwan and Tibet, and completely annihilate the last remnants of Chiang Kai-shek's group. By May 1950, apart from Tibet, the Chinese mainland had been fully liberated, and the People's Liberation Army was actively preparing for the cross-sea operation to liberate Taiwan with high morale. However, shortly after, the Korean War broke out, the US Seventh Fleet invaded the Taiwan Strait, and military force was used to prevent China from liberating Taiwan. Subsequently, China sent Volunteers to fight in Korea, and the action to liberate Taiwan was temporarily put on hold. After the end of the Korean War, the Chinese government repeatedly reaffirmed its policy of resolving the Taiwan issue by military force.



In 1955, our army crossed the sea for combat and liberated Yijiangshan Island and Dachen Island.
In May 1955, the policy of the Communist Party of China towards Taiwan underwent a new change. On May 13th, Zhou Enlai first proposed at the 15th meeting of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress: there are two possible ways to liberate Taiwan, namely, by war and by peace. The Chinese people are willing to strive for the liberation of Taiwan in a peaceful way under possible conditions. This is not a child's play, it is a solemn promise approved by Mao Zedong. In April 1956, Mao Zedong proposed the policy of "peace is precious", "one family of patriots", "no distinction between earlier and later patriots". On June 28 of the same year, Zhou Enlai conveyed new information to the world at the third meeting of the First National People's Congress: "Our government has repeatedly pointed out: there are two possible ways for the Chinese people to liberate Taiwan, namely, by war and by peace; The Chinese people are willing to strive for the peaceful liberation of Taiwan under possible conditions. Undoubtedly, if Taiwan can be peaceful, then it will be the most beneficial for our country, for all our Chinese people, and for the peace of Asia and the world... Now, on behalf of the government, I formally state: we are willing to negotiate the specific steps and conditions for the peaceful liberation of Taiwan with the Taiwan authorities, and we hope that the Taiwan authorities will send representatives to Beijing or other appropriate places to start such negotiations when they think it is appropriate."
At the same time, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China also passed a letter to Chiang Kai-shek through Zhan Shizhao in Hong Kong, saying "The tomb of Fenghua remains the same, and the flowers and plants of Xikou are unharmed", hoping to touch Chiang Kai-shek with hometown feelings. On July 16, 1956, Zhou Enlai received Hong Kong reporter Cao Juren in Beijing. This is a mysterious person with a special relationship with the high-level leaders of the Kuomintang and the Communist Party. Zhou Enlai said during the meeting: "The Kuomintang and the Communist Party have cooperated twice. The first cooperation was successful in the Northern Expedition, and the second cooperation was victorious in the anti-Japanese war. These are facts. Why can't we cooperate for a third time? Our relationship with Taiwan is not a surrender, but a dialogue between each other. As long as the political power is unified, everything else can be discussed together."
Mao Zedong personally met with Cao Juren later, which shows Mao Zedong's importance to this matter. During the meeting, Mao Zedong said that if Taiwan unifies with the mainland and lives according to their own lifestyle, the fishes in the water all have regional characteristics. The fish from Maogai cannot survive in other places. Mao Zedong also stated that if Chiang Kai-shek dissolves his relationship with the United States and connects with the mainland, the roots are still his, he can survive, he can do his own thing. His army can be preserved, I do not oppress him to cut troops, do not ask him to simplify the government, let him implement the Three People's Principals. This thinking was summed up by Zhou Enlai as "one principle and four points", that is, Taiwan must unite with the mainland (one principle); after the unification of Taiwan and the mainland, except for the necessity of unifying foreign affairs to the central government, all military and political powers and personnel arrangements are decided by Chiang Kai-shek; All deficiencies in military, political and construction expenses will be allocated by the central government; social reforms in Taiwan can be postponed and resolved through consultation; both parties agree not to send people to disrupt each other's unity (four points). In fact, it also includes the basic idea of "one country, two systems".
However, the Kuomintang did not make a positive response to the peace proposal of the Communist Party of China. On the contrary, it continued to dispatch a large number of troops to Jinmen and Mazu; the United States stepped up its behind-the-scenes activities in an attempt to get the Kuomintang to accept its "cross-strait rule" conspiracy. Under this circumstance, on the one hand, in order to curb the reactionary momentum of the United States and Jiang, and on the other hand, in order to maintain the "contact" between the mainland and Taiwan, Peng, Jin, and Ma through the form of fighting, the Fujian frontline troops of the People's Liberation Army were ordered to "fire all guns" and hit Da, Xiaojinmen and Dadan and Erdan islands in August 1958. But despite this, our government's main policy of liberating by force and striving for peace has not changed. During the "Cultural Revolution", due to the influence of "left" thinking, our government's policy and policy towards Taiwan turned tough, that is, it was in the stage of "continuing to maintain a military confrontation situation and concentrating on waging diplomatic struggles".



2. Preliminary Concept of the Peaceful Unification of the Motherland in the New Era

By the end of the 1970s, due to the relative ease of international tensions, China's diplomacy entered a new phase. China successively normalized relations with the United States and Japan, both of whom acknowledged the People's Republic of China as the only legitimate government of China, and Taiwan as part of China. By 1978, the number of countries that established diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China increased to 116, while only 23 countries and regions maintained diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

On New Year's Day 1979, the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress issued the "Message to Taiwan Compatriots", marking the Chinese government's full commitment to peaceful unification. The Communist Party of China stated in the "Message to Taiwan Compatriots": "Today, the unification of China is the will of the people and the trend of the times. It's universally recognized that China is one, and the People's Republic of China is the only legitimate government of China. The recent signing of the Sino-Japanese Peace and Friendship Treaty, and the normalization of relations between China and the United States, further demonstrate this unstoppable trend. The country is stable and united as never before, and people of all ethnic groups on the mainland are working together to achieve the great goal of modernization. We eagerly hope for Taiwan's early return to the motherland for common development. Our national leaders have expressed determination to respect Taiwan's current state and the views of all walks of life in Taiwan, and to adopt reasonable and suitable policies and measures to ensure the interests of the Taiwanese people are not compromised."

"The Chinese government has ordered the People's Liberation Army to cease fire on Jinmen and other islands from today. There is still a military stalemate in the Taiwan Strait, which can only create artificial tension. In our view, the first step is to end this military confrontation through negotiations between the government of the People's Republic of China and the authorities in Taiwan, in order to create a necessary premise and safe environment for any level of interaction on both sides."

The "Message to Taiwan Compatriots" not only signifies the Chinese government's full commitment to peaceful unification, but also contains the germination of the idea of "one country, two systems". Shortly after the publication of the "Message to Taiwan Compatriots", Deng Xiaoping explained to relevant American parties during his visit to the US that China wanted to resolve the Taiwan issue peacefully and no longer used the term "liberation of Taiwan". As long as China achieved national unification, "we will respect their current reality and existing system". This marked the first public proposal to resolve the Taiwan issue through "one country, two systems".

On December 6 of the same year, Deng Xiaoping elaborated on the concept of "one country, two systems" while meeting with visiting Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira. He said: Regarding Taiwan, our requirements are simple: Taiwan's system, way of life, and civilian relationships with foreign countries, including foreign investments in Taiwan and civilian interactions will remain unchanged. As a local government, Taiwan can have its own defensive and military forces. There is only one condition: Taiwan must be an inseparable part of China. As a local government of China, Taiwan will have full autonomy.

On September 30, 1981, Chairman Ye Jianying of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress stated the nine principles for the peaceful unification of Taiwan.



(1) In order to quickly end the unfortunate situation of the Chinese nation being divided, we suggest that the Chinese Communist Party and the Chinese Nationalist Party hold equal negotiations, implement the third cooperation, and jointly complete the great cause of reunifying the motherland. Both parties can send people to contact each other and fully exchange opinions.
(2) People on both sides of the Taiwan Strait urgently hope for communication, reunion of relatives, expansion of trade, and increased understanding. We propose that both sides jointly facilitate postal service, trade, visits to relatives, tourism, and academic, cultural, and sports exchanges, and reach relevant agreements.
(3) After the country is unified, Taiwan can serve as a special administrative region, enjoy a high degree of autonomy, and retain its army. The central government does not interfere with local affairs in Taiwan.
(4) Taiwan's current social and economic systems remain unchanged, as do its lifestyle and economic and cultural relations with foreign countries. Private property, housing, land, enterprise ownership, legal inheritance rights, and foreign investment are not violated.
(5) Authorities and representatives of all walks of life in Taiwan can assume leadership positions in national political institutions and participate in the management of the country.
(6) When local finances in Taiwan encounter difficulties, the central government can provide discretionary subsidies.
(7) Ethnic people of Taiwan, people from all walks of life who wish to settle in mainland China, are guaranteed proper arrangements, are not discriminated against, and have freedom of movement.
(8) We welcome business people from Taiwan to invest in mainland China, initiate various economic ventures, and protect their legal rights and profits.
(9) Unifying the motherland is everyone's responsibility. We warmly welcome the ethnic people of Taiwan, people from all walks of life, and public groups to provide suggestions through various channels and in various ways to consult on state affairs.
So far, the Chinese Communist Party has in fact outlined the basic content of "one country, two systems".
3. Official proposition of "one country, two systems"
In January 1982, Deng Xiaoping officially proposed the concept of "one country, two systems" in a talk for the first time, pointing out that the nine principles proposed by Ye Jianying are actually "one country, two systems". Later, party and state leaders spoke about "one country, two systems" on different occasions. In September of the same year, Deng Xiaoping said in a conversation with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on the issue of Hong Kong that the issue of returning the sovereignty of Hong Kong could be solved by the "one country, two systems" plan. This shows that the principle of "one country, two systems" to solve the issue of reunification of the motherland has been expanded from Taiwan to Hong Kong and Macau.



In December of the same year, at the Fifth Session of the Fifth National People's Congress, the "Constitution of the People's Republic of China" was amended and passed. Considering the special situations of Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Macao, it legally confirmed the policy to establish special administrative regions and maintain the capitalism system in these regions after the sovereignty of Hong Kong and Macao was returned and the unification with Taiwan was achieved. Article 31 of the "Constitution" stipulates: "The state sets up special administrative regions when necessary. The system implemented in the special administrative regions is regulated by the National People's Congress according to the specific situation." This affirms the idea that two different social systems can be implemented within a unified country.

On June 26, 1983, Deng Xiaoping met with visiting guests from the United States - famous Professor Yang Liyu from the University of East West, New Jersey and others. During the meeting, according to the opinions discussed by the Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee, Deng Xiaoping detailed the essence and specific ideas of the peaceful reunification policy, targeting some doubts of Taiwan authorities. He said, "The core of the problem is national unity. Peaceful reunification has become the common language of both the Communist Party and the Kuomintang. But it's not about 'I eat you, or you eat me,' but to implement two systems within one country. We will adhere to the principle of peaceful reunification. After the reunification of the motherland, the local government of Taiwan can have its own set of internal policies and independence; the judiciary and the final judgment do not need to go to Beijing; the army is independent; the mainland does not send military and political personnel to Taiwan; Taiwan's party, government, and military systems are all managed by Taiwan itself; the central government should leave quotas for Taiwan. Deng also stated that implementing 'one country, two systems' is to complete the great cause of unification which was not achieved by the predecessors. If the Communist Party and the Kuomintang jointly accomplish this, the history of the Chiang father and son will be better written.

For this meeting and Deng's speech, domestic media did not give special attention at that time. A month later, Yang Liyu published an article in the Hong Kong magazine 'Wide-Angle Mirror,' introducing the situation of the meeting and the main content of Deng's speech. Deng's speech immediately caused a strong response in Hong Kong, Macao, and Taiwan and was widely praised as "Deng's Six Points." The announcement of "Deng's Six Points" marked the complete formation of the "one country, two systems" idea. In May 1984, this scientific concept was officially written into the "Government Work Report" passed by the Second Session of the Sixth National People's Congress, becoming a basic national policy with legal protection.

As for what exactly "one country, two systems" is, Deng Xiaoping answered this question on many different occasions for different audiences. Among them, the most easy-to-understand and easy-to-remember was when he met with the Hong Kong Business Representatives and famous Hong Kong figures such as Zhong Shihe on June 22 and 23, 1984, respectively. He said: "Our policy is to implement 'one country, two systems.' Specifically, within the People's Republic of China, the mainland with a population of one billion implements socialism, while Hong Kong and Taiwan implement capitalism."

"One country, two systems" is a complete scientific concept. Here, the premise is one China. Without this premise, there is no basis for unification. One China refers to the People's Republic of China. Any form of "two Chinas," "one country, two governments," "one China, one Taiwan," "two equivalent political entities," "Republic of China in Taiwan," or "Taiwan as an independent sovereign state," etc., are not allowed.



Under the premise of one China, the main body of the country is socialism. Deng Xiaoping pointed out that the mainstay of China must be socialism. On mainland China, we must resolutely uphold the socialist system. After the founding of the People's Republic of China in 1949, through the joint efforts of the people nationwide, socialism has established a firm foundation on the mainland. Practice has proven and will continue to prove that only socialism can save China, only socialism can develop China. Therefore, we must insist on socialism on the mainland. Under the premise of one China, socialism is implemented on the mainland while capitalism is practiced in Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Macao. In these regions, the existing social and economic systems remain unchanged, the lifestyle remains the same, and the existing laws basically remain the same. Taiwan is even allowed to retain an army. This system will remain unchanged for quite a long time.

After the policy of "one country, two systems" was proposed, it caused a strong reaction both at home and abroad. On August 27, 1984, the Hong Kong-based Ming Pao published an editorial stating that "one country, two systems" is the "basic principle of Marxism today". The Americas Overseas Chinese Daily published an editorial titled "Major Events in the History of International Relations" in 1984, which believed that Hong Kong and mainland China's implementation of "one country, two systems" will have a profound impact on China's unification and world affairs. The Taiwan authorities persistently refused to negotiate with the Chinese Communists and said a lot of things against the great righteousness of the nation on the Hong Kong issue, which resulted in Taiwan losing more hearts among people at home and abroad. It is hoped that the Taiwan authorities will change their ways and conform to the trend of history, otherwise, it will be too late to regret.

4. The “one country, two systems” policy initiates the negotiations on the return of Hong Kong and Macao

Although the concept of "one country, two systems" was mainly proposed to solve the Taiwan problem, it was first successfully used to solve the problems of Hong Kong and Macao.

The Hong Kong issue is a historical issue left over from British colonialists invading China. The Hong Kong region includes three parts: Hong Kong Island, Kowloon, and the New Territories, which have always been Chinese territory. After the Opium War in 1840, Britain forced the Qing government to sign the unequal treaties of the Treaty of Nanking, the Treaty of Beijing and the Convention for the Extension of Hong Kong Territory, and occupied the regions of Hong Kong, Kowloon and the New Territories, reducing Hong Kong to British colonial rule. After the Xinhai Revolution, successive Chinese governments did not recognize these unequal treaties and conducted many negotiations with Britain to recover Hong Kong. On the eve of the founding of New China, due to special internal and external conditions, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China led by Mao Zedong decided to "temporarily maintain the status quo in Hong Kong". After the founding of the People's Republic of China in 1949, the Chinese government adopted the policy of "long-term planning and full utilization" with regards to Hong Kong, and did not recognize these three unequal treaties imposed on China by imperialism, but considering historical reasons, it temporarily maintained the status quo and waited for the right timing to peacefully resolve the issue through negotiations.

According to the aforementioned unequal treaties, the "New Territories" which occupies 92% of the total area of Hong Kong, and which houses Hong Kong's main energy and industrial sectors, will expire on June 30, 1997. As the deadline for the lease of the "New Territories" approaches, the question of whether the land contract for the "New Territories" can cross "1997" becomes increasingly pressing, causing investors to hesitate. In order to extend the Hong Kong governance period, in March 1979, the British sent Governor MacLehose to visit Beijing to try to ascertain the Chinese government's attitude towards the Hong Kong issue.



During the meeting, Deng Xiaoping pointed out that we have always believed that the sovereignty of Hong Kong belongs to the People's Republic of China, but Hong Kong also has its special status. The stance of the Chinese government does not affect the investment interests of investors. This is why Hong Kong can practice its capitalism, and we can practice our socialism for a relatively long period in the 20th and early 21st centuries.
At the beginning of 1981, Deng Xiaoping proposed that the Hong Kong issue has been put on the agenda, and we must have a clear guideline and attitude. He then directed the establishment of a special group to discuss countermeasures for the Hong Kong issue. In December of the same year, a meeting of the Central Secretariat made the decision to reclaim the sovereignty of Hong Kong on July 1, 1997. In April 1982, Deng Xiaoping clarified the basic position of the Chinese government on the solution of the Hong Kong issue during a meeting with former British Prime Minister Heath, clearly indicating that it was time to consider dealing with the Hong Kong issue.
In June 1982, Deng Xiaoping publicly announced the basic position and principles of the Chinese government on dealing with the Hong Kong issue when meeting with prominent figures in Hong Kong: First, it must reclaim Hong Kong in 1997, restore the exercise of sovereignty, and it cannot be later; Second, under the premise of restoring the exercise of sovereignty, we must maintain the prosperity and stability of Hong Kong. At the same time, the research group established with the approval of the Central Committee went to Hong Kong and formulated twelve policies to solve the Hong Kong issue with "one country, two systems" as the core through investigation and research. The main spirit is to restore sovereignty, unchanged systems, Hong Kong people ruling Hong Kong, and high autonomy. These policies further concretized the guideline to solve the Hong Kong issue in accordance with "one country, two systems", thereby laying the foundation for Sino-British negotiations to resolve the Hong Kong issue.
On September 24, 1982, Deng Xiaoping clearly elaborated the basic position of the Chinese government on the Hong Kong issue during a meeting with visiting British Prime Minister Thatcher: First, the issue of sovereignty is not a negotiable issue. China has no room for maneuver on this issue. China and Britain are negotiating on this premise, discussing the ways and means to solve the Hong Kong issue. Second, after China reclaims Hong Kong in 1997, it will implement policies suitable for Hong Kong. Hong Kong will still practice capitalism. Third, the governments of China and the United Kingdom need to discuss properly how to prevent major fluctuations in Hong Kong from now until 1997.
Based on the principles proposed by Deng Xiaoping, the Sino-British negotiations on the Hong Kong issue officially began. The whole negotiation lasted for two years, roughly divided into two stages: The first stage was from September 1982 to June 1983, during which the two sides initially consulted on some principle and procedural issues, and the Chinese side finally completed the formulation of policies towards Hong Kong; The second stage was from July 1983 to September 1984, during which the two sides conducted substantive negotiations and formed the text of the Sino-British agreement on the Hong Kong issue based on Chinese policies.
In September 1984, China and Britain reached an agreement. On December 19 of the same year, the heads of state of the two countries formally signed the Sino-British Joint Declaration on the Question of Hong Kong in Beijing, declaring: The Government of the People's Republic of China will restore the exercise of sovereignty over Hong Kong on July 1, 1997, and the British government will return Hong Kong to China on the same day. From the date of the Joint Statement taking effect to June 30, 1997, the British Government is responsible for the administration of Hong Kong, and the Chinese Government gives cooperation. The two-year Sino-British negotiations were thus satisfactorily concluded. On May 27, 1985, the two governments exchanged ratifications of the Sino-British Joint Declaration and its three appendices in Beijing. The Joint Declaration thus came into effect. Hong Kong enters the transition period before China restores the exercise of sovereignty.




After the transition period began in Hong Kong, the Chinese government began to formulate the Basic Law for the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (SAR). On April 10, 1985, during the third session of the Sixth People's Congress, while approving the Sino-British Joint Declaration, it was decided to establish a Drafting Committee for the Basic Law of the Hong Kong SAR responsible for the drafting of the Basic Law. On July 1, the Drafting Committee was formally established and started its work. In February 1990, based on extensive consultations and repeated revisions, the Drafting Committee of the Basic Law of the Hong Kong SAR held its ninth plenary session to review the draft Basic Law and submitted it to the National People's Congress for examination and approval. On April 4, the third plenary session of the Seventh People's Congress reviewed and approved the "Basic Law of the People's Republic of China for the Hong Kong SAR" and three annexes: "The Method for the Formation of the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong SAR", "The Method for the Formation of the Legislative Council and Decision-making Procedures of the Hong Kong SAR" and "National Laws Implemented in the Hong Kong SAR", also the regional flag and emblem of the Hong Kong SAR. The cooperation between China and the UK in solving the Hong Kong problem moved relatively smoothly in the 1980s. 

As the Hong Kong SAR transition started, the issue of Macao's return also came onto the agenda. As early as 1974, the Portuguese government declared its abandonment of all overseas colonies, recognizing Macao as not a colony but Chinese territory. In February 1979, Portugal and China established relations and reached an agreement on the issue of Macao. The Portuguese government recognized Macao as China's territory, and both agreed to resolve the issue at an appropriate time through negotiations between their governments. 

In the fall of 1984, when the governments of China and the UK reached an agreement on the Hong Kong issue, the conditions for resolving the Macao issue through negotiations between China and Portugal matured. On October 6th of the same year, Deng Xiaoping, in meeting with the well-known Macao figure, Ma Wanqi, further articulated the principle for resolving the Macao issue. It would follow the same principle used to solve the Hong Kong issue, known as "One Country, Two Systems", "Macau People Ruling Macau", unchanged for 50 years. In June 1986, the governments of China and Portugal began negotiations on the issue of Macao. On April 13, 1987, the Heads of Government of China and Portugal officially signed the "Sino-Portuguese Joint Declaration on the Question of Macao" in Beijing. The declaration announced that the Macao region is Chinese territory, and the People's Republic of China will resume sovereignty over Macao on December 20, 1999. On January 15, 1988, representatives of the two governments exchanged the ratifications of the joint declaration in Beijing, marking the official transition period for Macao's return. 

Chapter Five: The Theory of the Primary Stage of Socialism, and the Proposition of the "Three-Step" Strategy

1. The Proposition of the Theory of the Primary Stage of Socialism and the Establishment of the Party's Basic Guidelines

Between the 12th National Party Congress and the 13th National Party Congress, under the guidance of the spirit of the 12th Party Congress, the entire Party and all the people of the country strived to create a new situation in modern Socialist construction. The Party's basic guidelines for the primary stage were officially established at the successful 13th Party Congress in 1987, characterized by certain progress and exploration. 

1. The Preparation and Convening of the 13th Party Congress

On October 25, 1987, the 13th National Party Congress of the Communist Party of China was grandly held at the Great Hall of the People. The decision to hold the 13th Party Congress was made on September 1986 during the sixth plenary session of the 12th Party Congress. Afterwards, the Party Central Committee began preparations for the 13th Party Congress. The preparations for the 13th Party Congress were mainly carried out in two areas:

First, the election of delegates to attend the Congress...



According to the resolutions of the sixth Plenary Session of the 12th Central Committee, the number of delegates to the 13th National Congress of the Communist Party is 1950. The Central authorities require that the composition of the delegates be diverse. There should be a reasonable proportion of minority ethnic party members and female party members. Special attention should be given to electing a certain number of young and middle-aged party members who have made outstanding achievements in socialist modernization and various reforms. 
Through democratic elections, 1936 representatives with wide representation were elected. Among them, officials at all levels accounted for 75.7%, personnel in economics, science and technology, cultural education, sports and health accounted for 18.9%, renowned model workers and war heroes accounted for 5.4%. Women accounted for 14.9%. Minorities accounted for 10.8%. Those with a college degree or above accounted for 59.5%. Among the delegates, party members who joined the party from the early stages of the party's founding to the liberation war accounted for a certain proportion, with the majority joining the party after the establishment of the People's Republic of China. The representatives include veteran proletarian revolutionaries as well as vibrant and outstanding young and middle-aged party members, 58.8% of whom are under 55 years old. 
Second is the preparation of conference documents. The Central Party established a drafting group for the political report. The whole drafting work was carried out under the care and guidance of Deng Xiaoping. 
On March 21, 1987, Zhao Ziyang, then head of the drafting group, submitted a written report and request to Deng Xiaoping on the concept of drafting the outline of the 13th Congress report, and proposed a preliminary idea for drafting the political report. The report intends to write seven sections: (1) Discussing the historical changes that have occurred in our country since the Third Plenary Session, including since the 12th Congress. (2) Discuss that the route since the Third Plenary Session is a Marxist route that stems from the national conditions of our country. Emphasizing that our country is in the initial stage of socialism, this is the basic reason why we must adopt such policies and not adopt other policies. (3) The resulting economic development strategy. (4) The resulting task of developing a socialist commodity economy, and the direction of economic system reform in our country. (5) The resulting task of building a socialist democratic politics, and the principles of political system reform in our country. (6) The resulting tasks of strengthening and improving the leadership of the Party, including the leadership system of the ruling party, intra-party democracy, and supervision of the Party's leaders, the Party's cadres, and the Party's atmosphere. (7) The necessity to avoid "left" and right deviations in theoretical and ideological guidance originates from this, emphasizing that the two basic points of the route since the Third Plenary Session are to adhere to the four basic principles and persist in reform and opening up for invigoration, and pointing out that creative theoretical exploration must be carried out in new practices.
The request also proposed that the political report to the 13th National Congress intends to base its argument on the initial stage of socialism. Why take the theory of the initial stage of socialism as the basis for argumentation? The request said: Affirming that China is in the initial stage of socialism, one is to clearly state that we are socialists, we cannot go back to capitalism, and full Westernization is harmful to the country and the people; the second is to clearly point out that we are socialists in the initial stage, we can only progress step by step, and we cannot be impatient for success, nor can we be "impatient for purity".



It seems that based on the argument of the primary stage of socialism, it is possible to clarify the important issue of having to avoid both "left" and right inclinations, and to clarify the nature and basis of our reforms. If this could be done, it would be beneficial to unify our party's internal and external understanding, and it would also be beneficial for foreigners to understand the long-term stability of our policies. The request was made as follows: If you agree, the drafting of the report will be prepared along this line of thinking, and a rough draft is expected to be available in early May, for refinement until July, to be presented for central consideration in Beidaihe. If not, please instruct!
Four days later, Deng Xiaoping note: "This design is good."

On November 16, 1987, Deng Xiaoping said in a meeting with Japanese Socialist Party leader Doi Takako: Our party's 13th congress report is a collective creation that concentrated the wisdom of thousands of people and many contents are not proposed by me. Of course, it also includes my views and opinion, but most of it is the collective’s opinion.

After the draft of the 13th Political Report came out, the CCP Central Committee invited leaders of all democratic parties, related group leaders, some non-partisan patriots, intellectuals outside the party, and people of ethnic religions for a week-long seminar to solicit everyone's opinions on the draft of the 13th Political Report of the CCP. At the meeting, people from all walks of life spoke freely, expressing their own views, and proposed many valuable revision suggestions and suggestions.

On October 20, 1987, the 7th Plenary Session of the 12th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China discussed and passed the report of the Central Committee to the 13th National Congress of the Party, and discussed and passed the "Amendment to Some Articles of the Constitution of the Communist Party of China". They unanimously agreed to submit these two documents for review to the 13th National Congress of the Party.

At this point, the preparations for the 13th National Congress of the Communist Party of China were fully completed.

On the morning of October 25, the 13th National Congress of the Party was opened at the Great Hall of the People.

Carrying the heavy responsibility of the entire party's 46 million members, with red conference badges on themselves, the delegates happily came to the Great Hall of the People to attend the opening ceremony of the conference. They included the older generation of proletarian revolutionaries, and also outstanding middle-aged and young people who have contributed to the reform and opening up. Deputy chairmen of the NPC Standing Committee outside the party, deputy chairpersons of the CPPCC outside the party, and leaders of all democratic parties and the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce and non-party patriots; people from ethnic minorities and the religious community were invited as guests to attend the opening ceremony and seated on the podium. Some members of the 12th Central Committee, members of the Central Advisory Committee, members of the Central Discipline Inspection Commission, some old comrades in the party, and other relevant personnel inside the party attended the meeting.

Deng Xiaoping presided over the conference and announced the opening of the conference. Zhao Ziyang made a political report on behalf of the 12th Central Committee.

The political report is divided into seven parts: (1) Historical achievements and the tasks of this congress; (2) The primary stage of socialism and the party's basic line; (3) On the strategy of economic development; (4) On the reform of the economic system; (5) On the reform of the political system; (6) Strengthening the construction of the party in the reform and opening up; (7) Striving for a new victory of Marxism in China.

The report clearly proposes and explains the theory of the socialist stage, that is: first, our society is already a socialist society...



We must adhere to and not depart from socialism. Secondly, our socialist society is still in its initial stage. We must start from this reality and not surpass this stage. The initial stage of socialism in our country does not broadly refer to the initial stage that every country will experience when entering socialism, but specifically refers to the specific stage that our country must inevitably experience when building socialism under the conditions of lagging productivity and underdeveloped commodity economy. This stage requires at least a hundred years.

The report, based on the theory of the initial stage of socialism, has formulated the party's basic line in this stage, that is, to lead and unite the people of all ethnic groups in the country, focus on economic construction, adhere to the four basic principles, adhere to reform and opening up, self-reliance, and hard work, and strive to build our country into a rich, strong, democratic, and civilized socialist modern country.

The report summarized the 12 basic points of the theory of socialism with Chinese characteristics, namely: free the mind, seek truth from facts, regard practice as the only criterion for testing the truth; the construction of socialism must depend on the national conditions of the country and find its own path; To build socialism under backward economic and cultural conditions, there must be a very long initial stage; the fundamental task of socialist society is to develop productive forces and focus on modernization;

The socialist economy is a planned commodity economy; reform is an important driving force for the development of socialist society, and opening up to the outside world is a necessary condition for achieving socialist modernization; socialist democratic politics and socialist spiritual civilization are important characteristics of socialism; 

The basic complement of adhering to the four basic principles and adhering to the general policy of reform and opening up cannot be lacking; the unification of the country is achieved with "one country, two systems"; the style of the ruling party affects the life and death of the party; the principle of independence, complete equality, mutual respect, and non-interference in internal affairs is for the development of relations with foreign communist parties and other parties;

Peace and development are the themes of the contemporary world. The report officially formulated the "three-step" economic development strategy. The first step is to double the gross national product from 1980 and solve the problem of providing sufficient food and clothing for the people; 

The second step is to double the gross national product again by the end of the 20th century, and the people's living standards will reach a well-off level; the third step is to reach the level of moderately developed countries in terms of per capita gross national product by the mid-21st century, people's lives are relatively affluent, and modernization is basically achieved.

The report also formulated an action program to accelerate economic and political system reforms, and officially put political system reforms on the entire party's agenda. Regarding economic system reform, focusing on the central link of transforming enterprise operating mechanisms, carry out phased reforms of system matching in areas such as planning, investment, prices, finance, banking, and foreign trade, and gradually establish the basic framework of a new system of planned commodity economy. 

The reform of the political system aims to eliminate the disadvantages and build Chinese characteristics of socialist democracy. The long-term goal of the reform is to establish a highly democratic, legally sound, efficient, and vibrant socialist political system. 

The short-term goal of political system reform is to establish a leadership system that is conducive to improving efficiency, enhancing vitality and mobilizing the enthusiasm of all sides. In addition, the report also clearly put forward the productivity standard, that is, whether it is conducive to liberating and developing the social productive forces as the standard for testing reform measures and other party guidelines and policies.

After eight days of tense and orderly work, the 13th National Congress of the Party successfully completed all tasks. The congress elected the 13th Central Committee, the 2nd Central Advisory Committee, and the Central Disciplinary Inspection Committee. The congress passed relevant resolutions and closed in democratic and united atmosphere on November 1.

The congress called on all comrades in the party to adhere to the party's basic line and firmly grasp the "one center and two basic points" stipulated by this basic line under the great banner of socialism with Chinese characteristics and under the leadership of the 13th Central Committee. We must strengthen the unity of the party and strengthen the close ties between the party and the people of the whole country, work with one heart and one mind, boost morale, work hard, forge ahead, and strive to achieve the grand goal of socialist modernization.



The Congress emphasized that the entire Party needs to resolutely implement the basic line of the Party in the primary stage of socialism as set by the Congress, seriously implement all the resolutions passed by the Congress, strive to complete all the tasks put forward by the Congress, and lead people of all ethnic groups to continue to move forward along the path of socialism with Chinese characteristics. During the Congress, many political parties and organizations from other countries sent congratulatory messages to the Congress through calls. Representatives of various domestic democratic parties and non-partisan patriots also extended their congratulations to the Congress. The Presidium of the Congress would like to express their gratitude to them.

On November 2, the first plenary session of the 13th CCP Central Committee was held. The session elected Wan Li, Tian Jiyun, Qiao Shi, Jiang Zemin, Li Peng, Li Tieying, Li Ruihuan, Li Ximing, Yang Rudai, Yang Shangkun, Wu Xueqian, Song Ping, Zhao Ziyang, Hu Qili, Hu Yaobang, Yao Yilin, Qin Jiwei as members of the Central Political Bureau. The Central Political Bureau alternate members elected Ding Guangen. Zhao Ziyang, Li Peng, Qiao Shi, Hu Qili, Yao Yilin were elected as members of the Standing Committee of the Central Political Bureau. Zhao Ziyang was elected as the General Secretary of the Central Committee. The Secretaries of the Central Secretariat were Hu Qili, Qiao Shi, Rui Xingwen, Yan Mingfu, with Wen Jiabao as the alternate secretary. It was decided that Deng Xiaoping would serve as Chairman of the Central Military Commission, Zhao Ziyang as First Vice Chairman, and Yang Shangkun as Standing Vice Chairman. The plenum approved Chen Yun as the director of the Central Advisory Committee, and Qiao Shi as the secretary of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection.  

What is noteworthy is that a large number of relatively young comrades were elected to the new Central Committee, while a group of elderly proletarian revolutionaries with remarkable contributions and high moral esteem bowed out. This is a vivid demonstration of the prosperous development of our party and the succession of talents, a reliable guarantee for the continuous and stable implementation of the correct line of our party.

Compared with the previous central leadership, the average ages of the Central Political Bureau, the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau, and the Central Secretariat have significantly decreased. The average age of the elected members and alternate members of the 12th Central Committee was 59.1 years old, while that of the 13th was 55.2 years old, fully showing the flourishing development of our Party, filled with vitality and succeeding persons. At this Congress, Deng Xiaoping, Li Xiannian, Chen Yun and other old proletarian revolutionaries retired from the Central Committee and the Political Bureau of the Party, playing a very important role in the further rejuvenation of the central leadership and new-old alternation of the leadership.

This Congress was a democratic congress, a united congress, an open congress, and a congress that thoroughly promoted reform and construction career. It was also a congress that made our party more full of vitality and energy.

2. Deepening understanding of the "primary stage of socialism" and its historical significance

The proper understanding of the current historical stage of our society is the primary issue in building socialism with Chinese characteristics and is the fundamental basis for us to formulate and implement the correct line and policy.

To build socialism with Chinese characteristics, the most important issue, of course, is to understand China's national conditions. On this issue, both the Soviet Union and our own China have profound lessons.

The Soviet Union was the first socialist country in the world. Its greatest achievement lies in turning socialism from theory into reality. But in a country like the Soviet Union, how to build socialism did not provide us with ready-made successful experiences. The situation in the Soviet Union at that time was extremely severe. Domestic hostile forces tried to overthrow the Soviet power, and international enemies tried to strangle the unsteady socialist system. Faced with internal and external pressures, the Soviet people, under the leadership of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, overcame various difficulties, and socialism was not only firmly established but also flourished. Lenin, based on practice, put forward: From the point of view of communism, denying the party means skipping from the eve of the capitalist collapse (in Germany) to the highest stage of communism instead of entering its lower and intermediate stages. We, in Russia (three years after the overthrow of the bourgeoisie), just started the transition from capitalism to socialism, which is the initial stage leading towards communism.



Twelve years after Lenin's death, in 1936, Stalin declared: "Our Soviet society has essentially achieved socialism, established the socialist system, that is, realized the system of the first or lower stage of socialism, also known as communism, by Marxists." Three years later, Stalin declared: "We are moving towards communism." This approach was clearly impulsive. After Stalin's death, Khrushchev pushed the impetuous thought of rushing towards communism to the extreme.
