Following the Twenty-First Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, which proposed a comprehensive acceleration of communist construction, Khrushchev proposed at the Twenty-Second Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union in 1961 that the Soviet Union should basically build a communist society within 20 years. The new program passed by the Twenty-Second Congress was: "Our generation will live under the communist system." When boasting of the significance of this program, Khrushchev said, "The three programs of the CPSU are like a three-stage rocket. The first stage took us away from the capitalist world, the second stage elevated it to socialism, and the task of the third stage is to introduce communism."

Twenty years have passed, the plan has completely fallen through, becoming a bubble, which demonstrates that the Soviet Union's estimation of the stages of social development does not correspond to reality. It was not until the 1980s that the Soviet Union and some Eastern European countries began to reassess the stage of social development in which they found themselves.

The Chinese Communist Party also took a detour in understanding the historical stage China is in.

After 28 years of effort, the Chinese Communist Party achieved a great victory in the New Democratic Revolution, and in a relatively short period of time, it achieved the recovery of the national economy and the implementation of socialist reform, establishing a socialist system in China. Mao Zedong analyzed China's national conditions at the Seventh Plenary Session of the Eighth Congress as follows: "The proportion of industry and agriculture in the national economy, on a national scale, before the Anti-Japanese War, was about 10% of modern industry and about 90% of agriculture and handicrafts. This is a reflection of the oppression of China by the imperialist system and the feudal system, and it also represents the economic manifestation of the semi-colonial and semi-feudal social traits of old China. It is also the basic starting point during the Chinese revolution and for a considerable period after the victory of the revolution. From this point, a series of strategic, tactical, and policy issues of our party emerged.”

Based on this analysis, Mao Zedong proposed the major economic policies that our party should implement after the Second Plenary Session of the Seventh Congress. After the founding of new China, during the process of socialist transformation, our party adjusted some of the policies proposed by the Seventh Central Committee's Second Plenary Session according to the new situation, and the basic spirit was implemented. However, after the basic completion of the socialist transformation, we relaxed our investigation and analysis of the new national conditions. As for the stage of development the Chinese society was in at that time, it should have started from the 10% of modern industry and 90% of agriculture and handicrafts, and come to the appropriate conclusion. Unfortunately, we were overexcited by the victory of socialist transformation, got detached from the reality, and took a circuitous route.

The Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee marked a significant turning point in China's history. With the unfolding of the rectifying of past wrongs, the party touched upon the issue of the stage of social development China is in while analyzing the complex path it has taken since the founding of the new China and the reasons for developmental mistakes.  In his speech at the 30th National Day celebration in 1979, Ye Jianying pointed out, "Compared to the capitalist system that has been around for three to four hundred years, socialism is still in its infancy..."



"Our country is still a developing socialist country." This already contains the thought of the primary stage. The Resolution on Certain Historical Issues of the Party Since the Founding of the PRC, adopted at the Sixth Plenum of the Eleventh Central Committee in 1981, for the first time clearly pointed out: Our socialist system is still in its primary stage, but undoubtedly, our country has established the socialist system and has entered socialist society. Any views denying this basic fact are wrong.

The political report of the Twelfth National Congress of the Party in 1982 states: Our socialist society is still in its early stage of development, and our material civilization is not developed.

the Resolution on the Guideline for the Construction of Socialist Spiritual Civilization adopted at the Sixth Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee of the Communist Party of China in 1986 wrote: Our country is still in the primary stage of socialism. We must adopt distribution according to work, develop socialist commodity economy and competition, and for a considerably long period of history, we have to develop various economic components under the premise of public ownership, and under the goal of common prosperity, encourage some people to become rich first.

These three important documents all proposed the significant theoretical proposition that our country is in the "primary stage of socialism", and made clear and scientific elaborations, but they did not elaborate.

The political report of the Thirteenth National Congress of the Party first systematically elaborated this issue of great theoretical and practical significance from a theoretical perspective, and used it as the basis for the entire report. It affirmed that our country is indeed in the primary stage of socialism and clarified two meanings: first, our society is already a socialist society. We must adhere to socialism. Second, our socialist society is still in its primary stage.

The primary stage of socialism in our country does not only refer to the first or earliest stage in the general sense of development sequence, but mainly refers to a special development stage in terms of the maturity of socialist society in a country like ours where the economy and culture are underdeveloped. Its significance has two layers: the first, from the perspective of social nature; our country is already a socialist society, not a transition period, so we must adhere to the socialist direction and path, and we cannot regress to practice capitalism, pursue "full Westernization", supplement "capitalist lessons", and any regression and denial of the socialist path are incompatible with the socialist nature; the second, from the perspective of development level, the maturity of our socialist society is still very low, only in the primary stage, not a higher stage, so we must start from this most basic and important national conditions and objective reality, carry out construction and reform, and cannot make excessive demands, hurry, and rush to success, do things that surpass the stage. The proposition of the primary stage of socialism has drawn a clear line between the transition period and the higher stage of socialism, placing our party's line, principle, and policy on a scientific basis, thus avoiding the "left" error of exceeding the stage in the past.

Our country is in the primary stage of socialism, which is determined by the level of productivity in our country. The political report of the Thirteenth National Congress analyzed this: On the one hand, the socialist economic system based on public ownership of production materials, the socialist political system of people's democratic dictatorship and the guiding position of Marxism in the ideological field have been established; the exploitation system and exploiting classes have been eliminated; the national economic strength has greatly increased; the education, science and culture have made considerable development. On the other hand, we have a large population, a weak foundation, and the per capita GDP still ranks behind in the world. The prominent picture is: over 1 billion people, of which 800 million are in rural areas, basically still using manual means to make a living; a part of modernized industry, coexists with an industry that lags behind the modern level by decades or even hundreds of years; a part of economically developed regions, coexists with areas that are undeveloped and poor; a small amount of science and technology at the world’s advanced level, coexists with a generally low level of science and technology, and illiteracy or semi-illiteracy accounts for nearly one quarter.



The inadequacies in productive forces dictate the state of production relationships; the necessary degree of socialization of production for the development of socialist public ownership is rather low. The economy of goods and the domestic market are far from mature, with natural economies and semi-natural economies occupying a significant proportion, and the socialist economic system is not yet mature. Regarding the superstructure, the socio-economic conditions necessary for creating a highly democratic socialist political structure are heavily insufficient. Feudal, capitalist decadent thinking, and the habits of small scale production still have a widespread influence on society, often infiltrating the ranks of the party and civil servants. This situation indicates that we are still far from surpassing the early stage of socialism.

The early stage of socialism in our country is a relatively long historical phase. As pointed out in the Thirteenth Party Congress report, our country, from the completion of the socialist transformation of private ownership of means of production in the 1950s to finally realizing socialist modernization, will require at least a century. All of this time belongs to the early stage of socialism.

In this phase, the main contradiction we face is between the ever-growing material and cultural needs of people and the lagging social production. Therefore, to resolve this main contradiction, we must prioritize the liberation and development of productive forces while always centering around economic construction.

The early stage of socialism in our country is not a generic term but a specific one. The so-called specific term implies that it's not some initial stage every country goes through after entering a socialist society. Developed capitalist countries and moderately developed capitalist countries don't need to go through this "early stage" when they transition to a socialist society. The specific term refers to the particular historical phase that economically and culturally underdeveloped countries like ours must experience after entering a socialist society, which is the "early stage". Then, what is the early stage of socialism in our country like? The Thirteenth Party Congress report answers:

In general, the early stage of socialism in our country is a phase of gradually eliminating poverty and backwardness. It transforms from an agricultural country, where the majority of the population works in agriculture using manual labor, to a modern industrial nation with a majority non-agricultural population. It transitions from a state with a significant proportion of natural and semi-natural economies to a highly developed commodity economy. It's a phase of reform and exploration, establishing and developing a vibrant socialist system of economy, politics, and culture. It's a stage of achieving the great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation through efforts from the entire population and hard pioneering work.

Starting from the actual conditions of the early stage of socialism, we must concentrate on modernization construction; insist on comprehensive reform; adhere to openness towards the outside world; prioritize public ownership while vigorously developing the commodity economy; build democratic politics based on stability and unity; and develop a civilized society guided by Marxist doctrine.

The Chinese Communist Party's judgment that our country is in the early stage of socialism has profound theoretical and practical importance. Theoretically, it enriches and develops Marxist doctrine on the stages of socialist development, providing a scientific basis for our Party to establish correct policies. Practically, it guides the reform, openness, and construction efforts of our country along the track of scientific socialism, helping us defend against (evade) both "leftist" and rightist errors. If we fail to recognize socialism's presence in our country, we may commit a rightist error. If we don't acknowledge that our country is in the early stage of socialism, we may make a "leftist" error. Both left and right understandings stem from a detachment from reality, disregard for national conditions, and a failure to recognize that our country is in the early stage of socialism.

The 13th Political Report gave a profound explanation of "One Center, Two Basic Points" on the basis that our country is in the early stage of socialism. It proposed the basic line of the Party in the primary stage of socialism, that is, "Leading and uniting the people of all ethnic groups across the country, with economic construction at the center, adhering to the four basic principles, insisting on reform and opening up, self-reliance, hard work, and striving to build our country into a rich, strong, democratic, civilized modern socialist country."



This fundamental route was hard-fought.
The fundamental or general route refers to the party's overall guiding principle in a major historical stage. All other guidelines and policies must be subordinated and serve this fundamental or general route. Because the fundamental route is of great importance, the top leaders of the party attach great importance to its formulation.
During the period of the democratic revolution, the first generation of leadership of the CCP, led by Mao Zedong, formulated the correct general route, that is: "The proletariat-led, people's mass, revolution against imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucratic capitalism."
Under the guidance of this general route, the Communist Party of China led the people of the whole country to drive away the Japanese invaders, defeat Chiang Kai-shek, and establish New China.
The establishment of the People's Republic of China marked the end of the New Democracy Revolution and also marked the beginning of the socialist revolution. During this period, our country was in the transition from new democracy to socialism. The party's general route during the transition period was: "From the founding of the People's Republic of China to the completion of the socialist transformation, this is a transition period. The Party's general line and overall task during this transition period are to gradually achieve the socialist industrialization of the country over a long period of time, and to gradually carry out the socialist transformation of the country's agriculture, handicraft industry and capitalist industry and commerce." Practice has proved that this general route is correct. Through the implementation of this general route, our socialist system has been established and our socialist industrialization has made gratifying strides.
After our country entered socialism, our party proposed the general line of "building socialism with full vigor, striving for the best, and building socialism in a more, faster, better, and more economical way." Regarding this general line, the "Resolution on Certain Historical Issues" passed in 1981 made the following assessment: "The general line of socialist construction and its basic points passed at the Eighth Congress of the Party in 1958 have their merits in reflecting the general desire of the masses to change the backward economic and cultural conditions of our country. Its downside is ignoring the objective economic laws." This assessment is based on actual facts. By implementing this general route, China witnessed the "Great Leap Forward" that was eager to develop productive forces, and the "collectivization of people", which was eager to change production relations and transition. The result was counterproductive and violated economic laws and was punished by the laws. After this, while we made some achievements, we also made mistakes and fell behind, widening our gap with developed countries and affecting the performance of socialism's superiority.
During the "Cultural Revolution", the Ninth Congress of the Party put forward the party's basic line in the entire historical stage of socialism, which is a "left" erroneous line that "takes class struggle as the guideline". It is not a "lifeline" but a "death line" that leads the country to collapse and turmoil.
History serves as a mirror for knowing the rise and fall.



Throughout history, the party has taken several basic or overall lines of direction, learning from both success and failure. In the face of history, the party and its leaders reflect. Why does one path lead to victory while another leads to failure? Where does the cause lie? The results of these reflections undoubtedly have significant implications for the formation of the party’s basic line in the primary stage of socialism. Its direct outcome is to gradually shape the party's basic line in the primary stage of socialism based on the summarization of past historical experience.

18 years before the concept of the "primary stage of socialism" was proposed, Zhou Enlai laid the earliest foundation for this basic line in his December 1964 speech at the first session of the Third National People's Congress, where he proposed achieving four modernizations and adopting a two-step approach. Zhou Enlai pointed out in his report: The primary task for future national economic development, overall, is to turn our country into a modern socialist power with advanced agriculture, industry, national defense and science and technology, catching up with and surpassing the world's advanced level within a not too distant historical period. To accomplish this grand historical mission, China's national economic development can be considered in two steps starting from the third Five-Year Plan: First, establish a relatively complete independent industrial and national economic system. Second, fully modernize agriculture, industry, national defense, and science and technology, making China's economy a world leader.

This idea couldn't be realized due to "left" errors, but its historical status cannot be underestimated. The third plenary session of the 11th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, held at the end of 1978, re-established the correct ideological line, negated the past "left" line that focused on class struggle, insisted on shifting the focus to economic construction, and formulated a basic policy for reform and opening up, paving a solid foundation for the formation of the party's basic line in the primary stage of socialism.

After the third plenary session of the 11th Central Committee, the party emphasized repeatedly the importance of focusing on economic construction, upholding the four basic principles, and implementing reform and opening up. After the task of rectification was successfully completed, the 12th Party Congress proposed the party's overarching mission in the new historical period: uniting people of all ethnic groups across the country, relying on our own efforts, striving hard, gradually modernizing industry, agriculture, national defense and science and technology, and building China into a highly civilized and highly democratic socialist country.

In September 1986, the Sixth Plenary Session of the 12th CPC Central Committee proposed the overall layout for the construction of socialist modernization: focusing on economic construction, unswervingly advancing economic system reform, unswervingly pushing forward political system reform, unswervingly strengthening the construction of spiritual civilization, and making these aspects complement and promote each other. This “overall layout” has incorporated the main content of the basic line summarized by the 13th National Congress, but it's still incomplete.

On January 28, 1987, the CPC Central Committee pointed out in the “Notice on Several Issues in the Current Opposing Bourgeois Liberalization”: The line since the third plenary session of the 11th Central Committee is to build socialism with Chinese characteristics based on China's actual conditions. This line has two fundamentals: one is to adhere to the four basic principles, and the other is to adhere to reform, opening up and invigoration. The proposal for these “two fundamentals” served as the most direct preparation for the final formation of the basic line.

The 13th National Congress of the Party took place under these conditions and, on the basis of proposing the theory of the primary stage of socialism, explicitly proposed and summarized the Party's basic line during the primary stage of socialism.

The key point of the party's basic line in the primary stage of socialism is: "focusing on economic construction, upholding the four basic principles, upholding reform and opening up", namely "one center, two basic points."

"one center, two basic points" are infused with Deng Xiaoping's tireless efforts and encapsulate Deng Xiaoping's strategy for the nation's prosperity.



At the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, under the leadership of Deng Xiaoping, a major shift of the strategic center was implemented, and the basic national policy of reform and opening up was determined. Since then, this propelled the gigantic ship of China towards a new territory and a new era. However, Deng Xiaoping felt that something was still missing. Thus during the theoretical work conference in early 1979, Deng timely proposed to adhere to the Four Basic Principles. Afterwards, Deng Xiaoping always held onto the central link of economic construction without letting go, focusing on two basic points to promote the sustained and healthy development of Chinese society. When someone summarized the party's basic line in the primary stage of socialism as "one central focus, two basic points", Deng Xiaoping expressed appreciation, believing it was a good summary.

"One central focus, two basic points" are interrelated, interdependent and indispensable. 
"Focusing on economic construction" permeates the whole process of fulfilling the fundamental task of socialism and is the redline for the development of social productive forces. It not only reveals and stipulates the central place of economic construction in the party and national work, but also dictates that other tasks must defer and serve the focus on economic construction, to ensure the development of social productive forces. Why must we keep focusing on economic construction? This is because the fundamental task of socialism is to develop productive forces, particularly as our socialist system is not born from advanced capitalist society, nor from societies like Russia where capitalism had a considerable development, but from semi-colonial, semi-feudal societies, with thin foundation and unsatisfactory basis. Even though great achievements have been made in developing productive forces since the founding of New China, it is still far behind developed countries. Hence it is necessary to focus on economic construction, modernize socialism, and focus efforts on developing productive forces. "Stick to reform and opening up" and "adhere to the Four Basic Principles" are two basic points that revolve around the central theme of economic construction, which is also about the central task of developing productive forces. The basic characteristics of the primary stage of socialism are: underdeveloped productive forces, immature relations of production, and imperfect superstructure. Therefore, adherence to reform is essential. Reform and opening up is the only way for China to develop social productive forces and realize socialist modernization. The Four Basic Principles are the fundamental guarantee for the development of social productive forces and socialist modernization. The "two basic points" also uphold the direction of socialism and the perfection and development of the socialist system.

"One central focus, two basic points" also mutually restrict and promote each other. With the objective requirements for the development of productive forces as the benchmark, the center focuses on developing the productive forces, and the "two basic points" act like two wings of a machine, balancing the main body of the machine at the center. The two basic points mutually restrict themselves while being restricted by the "one center".

The basic line of the Party in the primary stage of socialism, not only stipulates "one center, two basic points", but also determines our struggle objective. That is to "struggle to build our country into a prosperous, democratic, civilized socialist modern country". Prosperity, democracy, civilization actually encompass the demands in terms of economics, politics, and ideological culture, which is not only a trinity of modernization goals, but also the three important aspects of socialism with Chinese characteristics.



"Wealth and power" are the goals and requirements in the field of social economy. A socialist society must be affluent, not impoverished. The 13th Congress wrote "wealth and power" into the party's struggle objectives for the first time. 

"Democracy" is the goal and requirement of political construction. Socialist democracy is far superior to capitalist democracy in essence. Socialist democracy requires the broad masses of people to participate in state and social management, truly achieving "being the masters of the house".

"Civilization" refers to spiritual civilization, which is the goal and requirement in the field of social thought and culture. Socialist spiritual civilization is an important characteristic of socialism. In order to build socialism with Chinese characteristics, we must eliminate all kinds of ignorance and backwardness left over from the old society. For a long period in the past, our understanding of socialism was not completely clear. We did not formulate a scientific struggle goal suitable for our national conditions, which was an important manifestation of this lack of clarity.

The integrated struggle objectives of wealth and power, democracy, and civilization vividly reflect our new understanding of socialism. This is a major achievement in our re-understanding of China's national conditions and socialism since the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee.

The Party's basic line in the primary stage of socialism stipulates the forces that rely on achieving the struggle objectives. That is "leading and uniting people of all ethnic groups". Since the basic completion of the socialist transformation of ownership, the exploiting class as a class has been eliminated. Except for a few hostile elements, all ethnic groups across the country under the leadership of the Communist Party are the forces that depend on completing various tasks in the primary stage of socialism.

The Party's basic line in the primary stage of socialism proposes the requirements in terms of mental state for completing various tasks, namely "self-reliance and hard work". What does China rely on to develop? What does China rely on to realize the integrated objectives of wealth, democracy, and civilization? External aid is indeed important. But it is not our base point. Our base point is self-reliance. That is, mainly relying on the strength of the masses themselves and the enthusiasm and creativity of the masses.

The Chinese people have a glorious tradition. They are unyielding in the face of difficulties. It is precisely by relying on this spirit of hard struggle that they have overcome difficulties and won one victory after another.



This spirit was a magic weapon for victory during the revolutionary war years and is equally essential for achieving the integrated goal of prosperity, democracy, and civilization. To accomplish the historical task of realizing the great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation during the initial stage of socialism, it is necessary for people of all ethnic groups in our country to actively participate in the current of reform and construction with a master's attitude. Only in this way can we join the ranks of civilized nations worldwide. 

Second, The Proposal of the "Three-Step" Development Strategy

Starting from 1979, Deng Xiaoping began to design a specific blueprint for China's modernization, which gradually evolved into a "two-step" approach, and by the end of the 20th century, a strategy to "double twice" and achieve a "moderately prosperous level". 

The third plenary session of the 11th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) took on the historic task of shifting the focus of the whole party's work and the attention of the entire nation to socialist modernization, reiterated the aim to realize four modernizations within the 20th century, and proposed to "correctly solve the specific path, policy, method, and measures to achieve the four modernizations". It can be said that the Third Plenary Session has established the overall goal of the economic development strategy of "achieving four modernizations" and put forward the basic principles to achieve this goal. However, what exactly is the blueprint for the "four modernizations"? Through what kind of process and steps should we achieve it? At that time, it was still rather abstract and broad in understanding. 

1. New Thoughts on China's Modernization Development Strategy

After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, the second generation of central leadership with Deng Xiaoping at the core began to seriously contemplate and painstakingly explore how to realize China's modernization. In March 1979, Deng Xiaoping pointed out in his speech on "Upholding Four Basic Principles" that "past democratic revolutions had to suit Chinese conditions and take the path of rural encirclement of cities pioneered by Comrade Mao Zedong. Now in construction, we also need to suit Chinese conditions and carve out a Chinese-style modernization route." He further emphasized that "Chinese-style modernization must start from Chinese characteristics." 

Deng Xiaoping then distilled two crucial features that must be noted for China to realize modernization: one is the thin foundation; the other is the large population and scarce arable land. The two characteristics pointed out by Deng Xiaoping determined that the starting point for China to carry out modernization construction is very low, and hence the time to achieve modernization will be longer. China will have to implement modernization step by step, in phases, based on this low starting point. 

Later, the Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council carried out a discussion and study on how China should precisely realize socialist modernization, stating that "we must start from China's national conditions in our modernization efforts". At a central work meeting in April 1979, the national conditions were analyzed, which indicated that we are a large country with more than 900 million people, over 80% of whom are farmers. Despite winning the revolution thirty years ago, our economy is still very backward, and the people's standard of living is low. Our country is poor, and modernization requires a lot of funds, yet the people also want to improve their living conditions, which is a contradiction. Modernization requires fewer people, but we have a large labor force that needs employment, which is another contradiction. We can only under such contradictions, carry out the "four modernizations." This is the realistic situation and the basic starting point that we must consider when we are drawing up our construction blueprint.

Taking China's actual national conditions as the basic starting point, Deng Xiaoping began to construct a detailed blueprint for China's modernization. This is required for modernization construction, and also a natural result of the development of Deng Xiaoping's cognitive logic. On December 6, 1979, during a meeting with the visiting Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira, Deng Xiaoping discussed how the blueprint for Chinese-style modernization was conceived. He stated: "The four modernizations we aim to realize are Chinese-style four modernizations. Even by the end of this century, although we have reached a certain goal in our four modernizations, our average national income is still very low. To reach the level of slightly wealthier countries in the Third World, such as an average national income of 1,000 US dollars, we also have to make great efforts."



"Even at that level, we are still lagging behind the West. I can only say that China is still in a state of relative comfort," Deng Xiaoping first contextualizes the goal of Four Modernizations to reach a "$1,000 level", entering a moderately prosperous state. The concepts of "$1,000" and "moderate prosperity" were formed in this conversation. More than a month later, Deng Xiaoping, when talking about his answer to Prime Minister Nakasone's question, said, "This answer is of course not accurate, but it is not casually said." Deng Xiaoping analyzed that we now only have a few hundred dollars. If it reaches $1000, it will increase by 3 times. Singapore and Hong Kong are both over $3000. It is not easy for us to reach that level. Because of the vast population and diverse conditions, it is very different. However, it should be said that if our total production value really reaches an average of $1000 per person, our days will be much better than them, better than their $2000.

If Deng Xiaoping's conversation with Prime Minister Nakasone was the first time he talked to a foreign guest about his vision for the next 20 years, then in his speech on "The Current Situation and Tasks" in January 1980, although it was only a retelling of his conversation with Prime Minister Nakasone, it was the first time he presented his idea to the entire party. He pointed out: The realization of the four modernizations in the Chinese style should be completed in two decades. Therefore, the 1980s are crucial and decisive. This decade lays a good foundation, coupled with the next decade, to achieve the Four Modernizations in the Chinese style in the next 20 years, it will be feasible and truly hopeful.

According to Deng Xiaoping's concept, the Sixth Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Party in June 1981 proposed to "achieve the goal of modernization in stages and steps." In November 1981, the Fourth Session of the Fifth National People's Congress defined the "moderately prosperous level" as the prospect of our country's economic development. The conference believes that the speed of economic development during the "Sixth Five-Year Plan" period cannot be rapid, the speed of the "Seventh Five-Year Plan" is expected to be higher than the "Sixth Five", and the speed of the next decade's development is expected to be even higher. The meeting proposed that efforts should be made to double the total output value of industry and agriculture in 20 years and enable the people's life to reach a moderately prosperous level. By the Twelfth National Congress of the Communist Party of China in September 1982, Deng Xiaoping's "moderately prosperous" level was formally proposed and established as a strategic goal for the whole party and people across the country by the end of the 20th century. The report of the Twelfth National Congress pointed out that from 1981 to the end of the 20th century, the overall goal of our country's economic construction is, under the premise of continuously improving economic efficiency, to strive to double the annual total output value of industry and agriculture nationwide, that is, from 710 billion yuan in 1980 to about 2.8 trillion yuan in 2000, and people's material and cultural life reaches a moderately prosperous level. In order to achieve the 20-year struggle goal, two steps must be taken in strategic deployment, the first ten years are mainly to lay a good foundation, accumulate strength, create conditions, and the next ten years should enter a new period of economic revitalization.

After the goal of realizing "moderate prosperity" in "two steps" by the end of the 20th century was proposed, Deng Xiaoping began to further envision China's economic development goals in the mid-21st century from 1984, thus gradually forming a complete "three steps" economic development strategic target.

"2. The Brewing and Elaboration of the 'Three Steps' Development Strategy

The 'three-step' development strategy was brewing before 1984."



The original proposition was to achieve four modernizations by the end of the 20th century. Later on, the party gradually realized that this task could not be completed quickly by the end of the 20th century, hence the phrase "reaching a moderately prosperous level" was adopted. Although sometimes the phrase "realizing the four modernizations by the end of this century" is still used, its meaning has gradually changed and is no longer used in the sense of completion but rather in stages. Under these circumstances, in September 1982, the 12th National Congress of the Party proposed a goal of doubling. Since only a moderately prosperous level can be achieved by the end of the 20th century, it will take some time to reach the level of modernization. In December 1980, Deng Xiaoping stated in his speech "Implementing Adjusted Guidelines, Ensuring Stability and Unity" that, after reaching a moderately prosperous level, "we must continue to advance and gradually reach a higher degree of modernization." In November 1981, the fourth session of the fifth National People's Congress pointed out in the Government Work Report that by the end of the 20th century when people's lives reach a moderately prosperous level, our national economy can start from a new starting point and reach the level of developed countries relatively quickly. It can be seen that at this time the goal of reaching the level of developed countries in a few steps has begun to brew. However, the conditions for proposing the "three steps" development target were not yet in place before 1984, because the realization of the "moderately prosperous" target was still to be tested. Shortly after the end of the 12th Party Congress, on October 14th, 1982, Deng Xiaoping spoke to the comrades responsible for the State Planning Commission, saying: "Can we rely on doubling by the end of the 20th century? The 12th Party Congress said we can rely on it, and I also believe that we can, but whether we can indeed rely on it depends on the work in the future." "We now need to concentrate on making long-term plans. The key to long-term planning is to prepare for the latter ten years in the first ten years." "Preparation has a problem of racing against time and cannot be taken lightly." What Deng Xiaoping was saying here is that without racing against time and taking it seriously, the goal of doubling may be in jeopardy.
After the 12th National Congress of the Party proposed the goal of doubling in 1982, the perennial question in Deng Xiaoping's mind was: "Can our proposed goal of doubling by the end of this century be achieved, or will it fall short?" From 1982 to 1984, China's economy grew rapidly, greatly exceeding the economic growth rate stipulated by the "Sixth Five-Year Plan", major breakthroughs were made in rural reform, China's grain production reached a historical peak in 1984, and urban reform also began, and the national situation was promising. In the early 1983, Deng Xiaoping inspected the south of the Yangtze River. He passed through Jiangsu, Zhejiang and then to Shanghai, he saw the situation was very good along the way, people were beaming, many new houses were being built, the market was rich in materials, and local officials were very confident. Seeing these lively scenes, Deng Xiaoping believed, "it seems there is great hope for the four modernizations." After returning to Beijing, Deng Xiaoping proposed in a discussion with several leading comrades in the center that there should be a more specific overall plan for doubling by the end of the 20th century, and each province, autonomous region, and municipality directly under the central government should also have their own specific plans, so that they have an idea in mind. In March 1984, Deng Xiaoping stating confidently during a conversation with Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, "the target of doubling will not fall short." In June, Deng Xiaoping confidently told the delegation of the Japanese committee of the second Sino-Japanese Civilian Conference that China's economy will continue to develop in the coming years, "the target of doubling by the end of this century will be definitely achieved." On October 1, at the 35th anniversary ceremony of the founding of the People's Republic of China, Deng Xiaoping solemnly declared that the situation in recent years has shown that the grand goal of doubling proposed at the 12th Congress can be achieved.
Considering that the realization of a "moderately prosperous society" by the end of the 20th century has become a realistic goal, Deng Xiaoping began to think across the century for the future and long-term interests of the Chinese nation, designing a grand blueprint for China's development in the 21st century.
On April 18, 1984, Deng Xiaoping met with British Foreign Minister Geoffrey Howe. Before and after this, Deng Xiaoping had made it clear that reaching a moderately prosperous society at the end of the 20th century is the "lowest target" for the four modernizations.



So, how much longer will it take to achieve the "big goals" of four modernizations, i.e., to basically realize modernization? He first proposed this idea while talking with Jeffrey. He said that compared to our big goals, the development of these years is just a beginning. After reaching a moderately prosperous level, we still have to approach the level of developed countries within 30 to 50 years in the 21st century. Deng Xiaoping then repeatedly mentioned this idea. On May 29, Deng Xiaoping said during a meeting with Brazilian President Figueiredo: "China is still very poor, with a per capita GDP of only $300. But we have great ambitions, by the end of the 20th century, we aim to reach $800 per capita. $800 is not much for developed countries, but for China, it is truly great ambition. More importantly, on this basis, after another 30 to 50 years of development, we can approach the level of developed countries." Later, on June 30, October 6, and October 22 of the same year, Deng Xiaoping expressed his ideas in roughly the same language, i.e. achieving a GDP per capita of $800 by the end of the 20th century, not $1000. This is because he took into account the population of China by the end of the 20th century, which was more than 1 billion and approximately controlled to around 1.2 billion. Making GDP double and population growing to 1.2 billion, the GDP per capita would be just over $800. Later, Deng Xiaoping adopted the flexible approach of "$800 to $1000", but sometimes still said "$800" or "$1000". In addition, the goal he proposed at this time was "approaching the level of developed countries", and the time required was "30 to 50 years," which is not quite the same as what he said later.

By 1985, Deng Xiaoping's "three-step" concept had taken a step forward. He pointed out in his speech at the National Scientific and Technological Work Conference on March 7, 1985 that we have been struggling for decades to eliminate poverty. The first step is to reach a moderately prosperous level by the end of the 20th century, that is, not being poor or rich, and living a relatively good life. The second step is to use another 30 to 50 years to approach the level of developed countries economically and make the people's lives relatively affluent. This is the big picture. Deng Xiaoping's words have several new points compared to his conversation in 1984: First, he used the terms "first step" and "second step", preparing for the subsequent summary of the "three-step walk"; Second, he explained the "moderately prosperous level", which means not being poor or rich, having a better life; Third, he paired "making people's lives relatively prosperous" with approaching the level of developed countries as the goal of struggle; Fourth, he pointed out that this is the "big picture" of the entire Party and country. On March 25, 1985, Deng Xiaoping, in his conversation with American journalists and his conversation with Tanzanian Vice President Mwinyi on April 15 of the same year, stated that the first step was to achieve a moderately prosperous level by the end of the 20th century. From the end of 1979 when this goal was put forward to the end of the 20th century, it was 20 years. Based on a GDP reaching 1 trillion dollars, it would take another 30 to 50 years, or more accurately, another 50 years, to possibly reach the level of developed countries and achieve the goal of our second step. It will take 70 years to accomplish this task. In these two conversations, Deng Xiaoping clearly extended the time span of China's economic development strategy from 20 years to 70 years, dividing the development goal in two steps, thereby making strategic goals and strategic deployment clearer and clearer. In September 1985, the Communist Party of China held a national representative meeting. Deng Xiaoping pointed out at the meeting: "Now people say that China has undergone noticeable changes..."



I once told some foreign guests that it was just a small change. Quadrupling and achieving a moderately prosperous standard could be considered a medium change. By the middle of the 21st century, being able to approach the level of developed countries in the world is a big change. Deng Xiaoping used the terms "small change", "medium change" and "big change" here. These "three changes" clearly present the three stages of economic development, which are very similar to his later summarized "three-step" strategy.
By 1987, Deng Xiaoping's "three-step" strategic thinking was completely formed. The good momentum of economic development in 1985 and 1986 showed that most of the major indicators of our country's "Seventh Five-Year" plan could be completed ahead of schedule, which meant that the strategic goal of doubling by 1990 could be realized earlier. This made Deng Xiaoping more confident and his vision for future economic development more clear and explicit. On March 8, 1987, Deng Xiaoping told visiting Tanzanian President Mwinyi that we have gained construction experience and pleasing results over the past eight years. "For the first decade, from 1981 to 1990, it was estimated that there would be no problem doubling the gross national product, and it could be completed ahead of schedule. For the second decade, from 1991 to the end of this century, a second doubling is also reliable from the development trend. Life has improved significantly in the eight years since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Party Committee. By the end of this century, although our per capita GDP of 800 to 1,000 US dollars is not much, the annual GDP will exceed 1 trillion US dollars. With this foundation, it is hopeful to strive to reach the level of moderately developed countries." Here, Deng Xiaoping has actually proposed the strategic concept of "three steps", just without explicitly using the terms "first step", "second step", and "third step". Moreover, here Deng Xiaoping has changed China's development strategic goal for the mid-21st century from "approaching the level of developed countries" to "reaching the level of moderately developed countries". On April 16 of the same year, Deng Xiaoping used the standard of "moderately developed countries" again in his speech when he met with members of the Drafting Committee of the Basic Law of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, and for the first time quantified this goal as "per capita 4,000 dollars" and "Gross national product of 6 trillion yuan", thus making China's strategic goal for the mid-21st century clear and visible. On April 30 of the same year, Deng Xiaoping gave a clear and complete description of the "three-step" economic development strategic goal during his meeting with Spanish Deputy Prime Minister Gracia. Deng Xiaoping pointed out: Our original goal was to double in the 1980s for the first step. Based on 1980, the gross national product per capita was only 250 US dollars at that time, doubling, reaching 500 US dollars. The second step is to double again by the end of the 20th century, reaching a per capita of 1,000 US dollars. Achieving this goal means that we have entered a moderately prosperous society, and have turned poor China into a moderately prosperous one. At that time, the gross national product exceeded 1 trillion dollars, although the per capita number is still very low, but the strength of the country has greatly increased. Our more important goal is the third step, to quadruple in 30 to 50 years in the 21st century, basically reaching a per capita value of 4,000 US dollars. With this step, China will reach a moderately developed level. This is our great ambition.



By this point, Deng Xiaoping's vision of the "three-step" economic development strategy for China's modernization has fully formed.
3. Establishment of the "Three-Step" Economic Development Strategy
According to Deng Xiaoping's concept and the basic national conditions of the primary stage of socialism in China, the 13th National Congress of the Communist Party of China (CPC) officially established the "three-step" economic development strategy for socialist modernization in October 1987. The congress report proposed: "After the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Communist Party of China Central Committee, the strategic deployment of our country's economic construction is generally divided into three steps. The first step is to double the gross national product (GNP) from its 1980 level and solve the problem of people's subsistence. This goal has been basically achieved. The second step is to double the GNP again by the end of the 20th century, and to reach a moderately well-off living standard for the people. The third step is to bring the per capita GNP up to the level of medium-developed countries by the mid-21st century, achieve a relatively affluent living standard for the people, and basically realize modernization. Then, continue to move forward on this basis." The formulation of the "three-step" economic development strategy has resolved significant issues related to the objectives and steps of China's modernization, and will have a lasting and profound impact on China's development for many decades to come.
Compared to China's previous development strategies, the "three-step" economic development strategy for socialist modernization has unique features: First, it is practical. Compared to the goals of "surpass England and catch up with America in fifteen years," and "realize four modernizations by the end of this century," this is a lower target but a practical one. The completion of the first step of the "three-step" well ahead of time is powerful evidence of this. Second, it takes improving people's material and cultural life as its starting point and end goal. Describing the objectives of modernization as "subsistence," "moderately well-off," and "affluent," enables the people to vividly and intuitively understand and personally experience the process of achieving these goals, serving to motivate the public and bolster their confidence. It is in line with the fundamental purpose of socialism. Third, it is clear, concrete, and quantifiable. The goals are quantified as "1000 dollars" and "4000 dollars," making the targets very specific and easy to implement and evaluate. Fourth, it is connected with the global economy. Using "dollars" as the measurement unit, this goal views China's economy in a broader context, making the gap between China and developed countries clear, and positioning China's economy within global economic development. Fifth, it is both an economic objective and a political one. The fundamental task of socialism is to develop productivity; modernization construction is China's paramount political concern, and whether we can achieve the strategic objectives of the "three-step" is tied to the fate and future of socialism. Thus, it is not only an objective for economic development, but also a political goal.
The achievement of the strategic objectives of the "three-step" is of great significance. It is a strategic goal that allows China to gradually escape from poverty and move towards prosperity.



Achieving this strategic goal can not only greatly enhance our country's comprehensive national strength, significantly improve people's lives, and greatly increase China's international influence, make a significant contribution to mankind, but also better reflect the superiority of the socialist system. Deng Xiaoping pointed out, "To prove that socialism is truly superior to capitalism, we have to see the third step, and we are not yet qualified to brag about it." China has a large population. If by the middle of the 21st century, the population reaches 1.5 billion and the per capita is $4000, the annual national output will reach $60 trillion, which is far beyond the U.S.'s GDP of $49.7 trillion in 1987. "This not only provides a way for the third world, which accounts for three-fourths of the world's total population, but more importantly, it demonstrates to mankind that socialism is the only way and socialism is superior to capitalism."

The "Three-Step" economic development strategy is an important part of building socialism with Chinese characteristics theory and is the specific implementation plan and fundamental manifestation of the central task of socialist modernization construction. Some major principles and policies for building socialism with Chinese characteristics revolve around and serve this development strategy. This development strategy points the way for the construction of socialism with Chinese characteristics during the primary stage of socialism. It can be foreseen that as long as we continue to follow the path of socialism with Chinese characteristics, Deng Xiaoping's "Three-step" development strategy for modernization construction will be realized.

3. Further clarification of the goal of political system reform

With the deepening of economic system reform, the task of political system reform is more urgently placed on the party's agenda. The task of political system reform, as early as before and after the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, began to attract people's attention. In 1980, Deng Xiaoping, in his speech on the reform of the party and state leadership system at the expanded meeting of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee, solemnly put forward the major task of political system reform. The central government was prepared to gradually implement political system reform from then onwards, but for various reasons, the political system reform was not fully implemented until 1986.

1. Profound understanding of the importance and urgency of advancing political system reform

With the development of the situation, the reform of the political system inevitably becomes a topic on the agenda again. On June 10, 1986, Deng Xiaoping, while listening to the report on the current economic situation by the central leaders, clearly pointed out: From now on, if we don't reform the political system, we can't adapt to the situation. Reform should include political system reform, and it should be regarded as a symbol of pushing forward reform. Deng Xiaoping also emphasized that all comrades, especially the comrades of the Central Secretariat, should think about the issue of political system reform, find someone to sort it out, and make things clear. He requested that the following be achieved before the 13th National Congress: straighten out the relationship between the party and the government; clarify the content of political system reform, determine the scope of political system reform; and draw up a blueprint for political system reform.

The series of ideas proposed by Deng Xiaoping laid the foundation for the discussion and framework design of political system reform. The Central Committee of the Communist Party of China decided in 1986 to establish a Central Political System Research Group. The group, composed of five people, who are in charge of the Central Secretariat, the Central Advisory Commission, the State Council, and the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, carried out research work under the direct leadership of the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee.



The Central Political System Reform Study Group organized practitioners from relevant departments and theorists from all walks of life, establishing seven special groups to hold focused discussions and demonstrations on topics such as party-government separation, intra-party democracy, institutional reform, cadre and personnel system reform, socialist democracy, socialist legal system construction, and the basic principles of reform. At the same time, the Central Political System Reform Study Group asked the Central Party School to also set up a study group, carrying out in-depth investigations and research in parallel with the aforementioned special groups. They extensively solicited opinions from the CPPCC, mass organizations, and other parties, seriously studied the historical experience of the political system since the founding of new China, particularly the practical experience of reform since the third plenary session of the Eleventh Central Committee, and combined the study of foreign political system structures and operation experience with practical conditions in China, raising reports on each individual topic. 
Based on the reports proposed by the special groups and the absorption of theoretical research results, the Central Political System Reform Study Group gradually formulated a plan for the overall conception of political system reform. This plan, after being generally agreed upon by the Political Bureau of the Central Committee, was submitted to the seventh plenary session of the Twelfth Central Committee in October 1987. After thorough discussion in the plenary, it endorsed the "Overall Conception of Political System Reform" in principle, deciding to incorporate the basic content of the conception into the Central Committee's report to the Thirteenth National Congress for further discussion. 
The report at the Thirteenth National Congress, based on the reality of our country during the primary stage of socialism and the needs of socialist modernization, deeply analyzed the necessity and urgency of political system reform. It elucidated the goals, tasks, and principles of reform and proposed a blueprint for the political system reform in our country. 
2. Planning of the goals of political reform
The Thirteenth National Congress divided the goals of political system reform into long-term and short-term goals. The long-term goal of political system reform as stipulated by the Thirteenth National Congress was to establish a highly democratic, well-established legal system, efficient, and vibrant socialist political system. The short-term goal was to establish a leadership system conducive to improving efficiency, enhancing vitality and mobilizing enthusiasm in all aspects. Regarding the main content of reform, the Thirteenth National Congress proposed seven aspects of reform in the near term:
Firstly, to achieve party-government separation and strengthen the establishment of the Party's system. The key to political system reform is party-government separation. The Party's leadership is political leadership, that is, it leads in terms of political principles, political direction, major decisions, and recommending important cadres to state power organs. The main way for the Party to exercise political leadership over state affairs is to turn the Party's assertions into national will through legal procedures, and to drive the broad masses of people through the activities of the Party organization and the exemplary role of Party members, to realize the Party's line, guidelines, and policies. In order to achieve the separation of the party and government, it is necessary to adjust the organizational form and work institutes of the party, and to strengthen the establishment of the Party's system, and to enhance the whole Party's understanding of party-government separation. Only in this way can the desired objectives be achieved.
Secondly, to further delegate power. The phenomenon of excessive concentration of power not only manifests itself in the excessive centralization of power in the Party's leadership organs by administrative, economic, cultural organizations and mass organizations but also at the grassroots level to the superior leadership organs. This makes the leadership organs trapped in bureaucratism and unable to extricate themselves, and the grassroots lack autonomy, and the enthusiasm of the masses is hard to mobilize fully. The general principle of delegating powers established by the Thirteenth National Congress is: all things that are suitable for lower levels to handle should be decided and implemented by the lower levels.
Thirdly, reforming the government's work institutes. The large and bloated nature of government institutions, along with their many levels, unclear responsibilities and mutual buck-passing, is an important reason for the formation of bureaucratism.



Reforms must be carried out top-down in government institutions. The principles of the reform are streamline, unify, and efficiency. The Thirteenth Congress suggests that the State Council should immediately start formulating a plan to reform the central government institutions and implement it after approval by the First Session of the Seventh National People's Congress.
Fourth, reform the cadre and personnel system. The focus of the reform is to establish a civil servant system, i.e., to make laws and regulations and scientifically manage personnel exercising state administrative power and performing state official duties in the government in accordance with the law. At the same time, personnel should be categorized according to the principles of separating party and government, separating government and enterprises, and closely integrating and reasonably restricting management of people and affairs. The main categories include: leadership and office staff of Party organizations, managed by Party committees at all levels; leadership and office staff of state power organs, judicial organs, and procuratorial organs, managed by a similar civil servant system; mass organizations' leadership and office staff, and managerial staff of enterprises and institutions, managed by their respective organizations or units according to their respective constitutions or regulations.
Fifth, establish a consultative dialogue system. The consultative dialogue system is conducive to correctly handling and coordinating various different social interests and contradictions, and enabling the work of leadership organs at all levels to be based on listening to the opinions of the masses, accepting supervision and avoiding mistakes. The basic principle to establish consultative dialogue is to carry forward the good tradition of "originating from the masses and going to the masses," increase the openness of leadership activities, inform the people of major issues, and discuss major issues with the people. 
Sixth, perfect a number of systems of socialist democratic politics. These systems include: strengthening the People's Congress system; perfecting the multi-party cooperation and political consultation system led by the Communist Party; strengthening the construction of mass organizations; improving the election system; strengthening the systematization of grassroots democratic life; further perfecting the system of regional autonomy for ethnic minorities.
Seventh, strengthen the construction of the socialist legal system. Every aspect of the state's political, economic, and social life, every link in democracy and dictatorship, should have laws to abide by, laws that must be complied with, laws that must be strictly enforced, and violators must be pursued.
Since the 13th National Congress of the Communist Party proposed the blueprint for political system reform, China's political system reform has gradually advanced from partial reform to comprehensive reform with clear goals and steps.
On November 14, 1987, the newly elected Central Political Bureau held its first plenary meeting and discussed and passed the "Work Rules (Trial) of the Thirteenth Central Political Bureau," the "Work Rules (Trial) of the Thirteenth Central Political Bureau Standing Committee," and the "Work Rules (Trial) of the Thirteenth Central Secretariat." These three rules and the later work rules of the State Council further clarified the relationships among the Central Political Bureau and its Standing Committee, the Central Secretariat, and the Central Plenary Session. The Central Secretariat became an executive agency and no longer held decision-making powers. The Central Political Bureau Standing Committee regularly reported to the Central Political Bureau, and the Central Political Bureau regularly reported to the Central Plenary session. The frequency of the Central Plenary Session also increased from once a year to twice a year. At the same time, the functions, scope of work, and working methods of the Party Central Committee and the central people’s government were clarified, providing preliminary norms for the Party Central Committee and the highest executive organ of the state to form a reasonable structure in accordance with the requirement of separating party and governmental functions. This is an important step in the construction of inner-Party and national democracy.



At the same time, differential elections began to be implemented within the party. According to the method of differential election stipulated by the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, the 13th National Congress of the Party implemented differential elections with a representative of 20%, a central committee member of 5%, and an alternate central committee member of 12%. The result of the 13th National Congress of the Communist Party of China was that 10 candidates for the Central Committee failed to be elected, 16 were alternate members of the Central Committee, and 4 members of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection were not pre-elected. At the provincial level, differential elections have been implemented in the elections of standing committee members of provincial committees, directors and deputy directors of standing committees of people's congresses of provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities, as well as governors and deputy governors. In the provincial-level turnover election after the 13th National Congress, 11 directors of the Standing Committee of the People's Congress of provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities, 8 governors and chairmen of provinces and autonomous regions implemented a differential election, and 99 candidates recommended by the representatives of the people of 28 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities were listed as official candidates , Among them, 12 people were elected, including 4 directors of the Standing Committee of the People's Congress, 2 deputy directors, 5 deputy governors and deputy mayors, and 1 presiding judge of a senior court. This is unprecedented in the history of elections of people's power since the founding of New China, and it has caused a strong response in our country's political life.
According to the requirements of the separation of party and government functions and the principle of improving party leadership, the Party Central Committee's directly-affiliated institutions were reformed in 1988. The Central Committee of the Party originally had 26 directly-affiliated work units and institutions, 8 were abolished during the reform, 3 were transformed, 15 were retained, and 5 new ones were established. After adjustment, the Central Committee of the Party has 23 directly-affiliated work units and institutions. In the reform, attention was paid to clarify the responsibilities of the party's work department and the administrative department, straighten out the relationship between the party's work organ and the government organ, transfer the work that should be undertaken by the government department to the relevant government department, and no longer set up leadership groups and offices that overlap with the Central Committee of the Party and the State Council. Provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities have made corresponding rules, and reforms have been made in specific organizational forms and working methods. The party committee generally does not have a full-time secretary in charge of government work, abolished the counterpart department in the party committee office, streamlined party committee institutions, and reduced full-time cadres.
In enterprises, in accordance with the "Draft Law on State-Owned Industrial Enterprises of the People's Republic of China" passed by the First Session of the Seventh National People's Congress, enterprises implement a manager (manager) responsibility system, the manager is the legal representative of the enterprise, in the enterprise In a central position, leading the production and operation management of the enterprise, bearing comprehensive responsibility for the material and spiritual construction of the enterprise. The grassroots organizations of the Communist Party of China in enterprises guarantee the implementation of party and national policies and policies in the enterprise. This provides a legal basis for the separation of party and government functions in enterprises. After the implementation of the Enterprise Law, enterprises across the country have generally implemented the factory manager (manager) responsibility system, and the pattern of separating party and government functions in enterprises has basically formed.
3. The initiation of government institutional reform and cadre personnel system reform
According to the blueprint of political system reform designed by the 13th National Congress, government institutional reform and cadre personnel system reform were on the agenda. From March 25 to April 14, 1988, the first meeting of the Seventh National People's Congress was held, which approved the "Reform Plan of the State Council Institutions". Li Peng elaborated on the goals, policies and key points of government institutional reform in his "Government Work Report". He said: The long-term goal of government institutional reform is to gradually establish a full-fledged, reasonably structured, coordinated, flexible and efficient administrative management system with Chinese characteristics in accordance with the principles of separation of party and government, separation of government and enterprises, and simplicity, unity and efficiency. Achieving this goal requires long-term efforts. In the next five years, efforts should be made to create conditions to gradually straighten out the relationship between the government and enterprises, institutions and people's organizations, the relationship between government departments, and the relationship between the central government and local governments. 





The "State Council Institutional Reform Plan" determines that 12 ministerial-level institutions will be abolished, 9 new ministries will be established, and 32 will be retained. Thus, the former 45 are adjusted to 41, and Xinhua News Agency has been converted into an institution. In addition, the number of institutions directly under the State Council is adjusted from 22 to 19, the number of service institutions from 4 to 7, the State Bureau under the unified management of various ministries from 14 to 15, and the non-permanent institutions from 77 to 44. The number of streamlined personnel is about 20%.

Compared with the reform in 1982, the biggest difference in this institutional reform of the State Council is that it is carried out in accordance with the requirements of the political and economic system reform process, focusing on the transformation of functions, matching with the internal system construction of the government, and combined with the preparatory work of implementing the national civil service system. In practice, focusing on the transformation of functions, decomposing functions according to the principle of separating government from enterprises, transferring out the function of directly managing enterprises, and letting go of the functions of directly managing money and things, while strengthening functions such as decision-making, consultation, regulation, supervision and information that belong to the central government. At the same time, it has also strengthened the functions of social management that were originally undertaken by the party's departments and should be undertaken by the government departments. On this basis, the institutions are set up according to the new functions, and the personnel establishment is determined. According to the function, the departments that undertake the same or similar business are abolished, and their business is undertaken by one department; there is generally no corresponding professional organization in the comprehensive economic departments, and the industry management work is undertaken by the competent departments; only two levels of department and office are set up within the ministries to reduce the management levels within the departments. This reform of the State Council's institutions has promoted the transformation of the government's management of enterprises from direct management to indirect management, and has made a considerable push to reduce the overlap of functions and institutions in work, enhance institutional vitality, and improve work efficiency, laying a good foundation for further reform and local institutional reform.

The central government's institutional reform also requires corresponding connection with local reforms. Therefore, the State Council's Institutional Reform Office began preparatory work in August 1988. Prior to May 1986, pilot work for local institutional reform had been conducted in 16 medium-sized cities. In 1989, with the approval of the State Council, it was decided to carry out institutional reform pilot projects in Harbin, Qingdao, Wuhan, and Shenzhen, four planned cities, and nine counties including Ji City, Hebei, Yuanping, Shanxi, Zuozi Mountain, Inner Mongolia, Shangyu, Zhejiang, Hua County, Henan, Huarong, Hunan, Baoan, Guangdong, Qiongwei, Sichuan, and Dingxi, Gansu. After gaining experience in pilot reforms at different levels and of different types, the pilot was expanded in 1991. Through the pilot, not only has the pilot unit itself achieved certain results in institutional reform, but the thinking of local institutional reform has also become clearer. According to the pilot experience, the State Council intends to gradually promote local institutional reform, with the basic idea of sorting out relations, transforming functions, launching local institutional reform, including sorting out relations between the central and local governments, relations between local governments at all levels; rationally dividing powers, and changing the functions of local governments at all levels according to the requirements of separating the government from enterprises; and then striving to realize the scientification of administrative decision-making system, the perfection of administrative execution system, the rationalization of administrative supervision system, and the perfection of the operation mechanism of administrative management.

The establishment of a national civil service system is the key point of cadre and personnel system reform determined by the Thirteenth Five-Year Plan. According to the arrangement of the Thirteenth Five-Year Plan, the State has set up a Personnel Department as the national civil servant management agency. After the establishment of the Personnel Department, on the one hand, it began to formulate the National Civil Service Management Regulations, and at the same time, pilot programs were carried out in six departments including the Audit Office, the General Administration of Customs, the State Statistics Bureau, the State Taxation Bureau, the State Building Materials Bureau, and the State Environmental Protection Bureau. In 1991, Harbin and Shenzhen were selected to pilot the local civil service system. The pilot in the six departments of the State Council is to starting with job classification in conjunction with institutional reform. The determination of government functions is the basis of institutional setting and also the premise of establishing a civil service system. In the past, the functions were unclear, and everything was set according to people. Now with clear functions, people can be selected according to tasks, which is undoubtedly a huge progress. These six departments began to pilot job classification based on the "Three Determinations" plan from April 1989, and completed 2618 job surveys, analyses, evaluations and the drafting of job classification norms and job arrays by the end of June 1990.



An important aspect of the civil service system is the examination and recruitment and training system for civil servants. From 1987 to 1988, 13 departments including politics and law, industry and commerce, and taxation adopted the method of examination and recruitment based on provinces for supplementing civil servants. More than 1 million people across the country registered to take the test, and over 80,000 people were recruited. In January 1989, the Central Organization Department and the State Personnel Department issued the "Notice on Implementing the Examination and Assessment Method for Supplementing Staff in State Administrative Organs", requiring county and above administrative organs to implement examination and assessment methods for supplementing staff. The procedures include: issuing announcements, eligibility reviews, written exams, interviews, physical exams, assessments, and recruitments. The examination system has a history in China. The imperial examination system formed over thousands of years is the main way for China to select officials. The examination and recruitment system for civil servants is by no means a revival of the traditional imperial examination system, but an important reform of the past cadre selection system to meet the needs of modern social life. This method of open examinations and merit-based recruitment has had a positive impact on implementing competition principles in cadre personnel management, strengthening democratic supervision, preventing unethical behavior in employment, and ensuring the quality of recruited staff. 

Reforms to the personnel system of enterprises and institutions have also made significant progress.
