In May 1988, the Central Organization Department and the Ministry of Personnel formulated the "Several Opinions on the Introduction of a Competitive Mechanism to Reform the Cadre Personnel System in State-Owned Enterprises", requiring the introduction of a competitive mechanism into enterprise personnel management, and selecting enterprise operators through public tendering; the appointment of managers at all levels within the enterprise should also implement various forms of appointment system, appoint by level and choose the best. The enterprise has the right to appoint and dismiss, and the individual has the right to be appointed and to resign. In 1991, the Central Organization Department and the Ministry of Personnel issued the "Interim Provisions on the Management of Cadres Appointed by State-Owned Enterprises", which unified the provision of appointments, transfers, retirements, your treatment, further improving the cadre appointment system in enterprises.

By the end of 1990, the number of cadres appointed by enterprises across the country had reached 1.7 million, of which more than 90% were appointed from workers. Practice has proved that the implementation of the appointment system for enterprise cadres is relatively successful. Therefore, many institutions also use similar enterprise tendering methods to select leaders of their own units. The appointment system for professional and technical positions is generally implemented among scientific and technological cadres.

IV. Taking a New Path of Strengthening Party Building through Institutional Construction  

Whether China's reform and opening up and socialist modernization construction can reach the expected goals depends on many factors, but the most important one is still the status of the Chinese Communist Party as the ruling party. Since the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, the Chinese Communist Party has been firmly grasping the key link of strengthening the party's own construction while leading reform and economic construction. It has made great efforts to strengthen the party's ideological construction, political construction, organizational construction and style construction, and has gradually embarked on a new path of strengthening party building through institutional construction.

1. Completion of the New Round of Party Rectification

As early as the 12th National Congress, the Party Central Committee decided to start from the second half of 1983 and use 3 years to carry out a comprehensive rectification of the party’s style and organization in stages and batches.



From October 11th to 12th, 1983, the second plenary session of the 12th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) was held in Beijing. In accordance with the decisions of the 12th National Congress of the CPC, the meeting arranged a comprehensive reshaping of the party. The meeting resulted in a decision by the CPC Central Committee on reshaping the party (referred to as "Necessity and Urgency"). The decision analyzed the need and urgency for reshaping the party and proposed the overall objective and requirements for the party reshaping. These included guiding the work with Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought, relying on the revolutionary consciousness of all party comrades, using the sharp weapon of criticism and self-criticism correctly, implementing party discipline, revealing and resolving serious ideological, style, and organizational impurities within the party, fundamentally improving the party style, raising the ideological and working levels of the whole party, bringing the party closer to the masses, and striving to build the party into a strong core that leads the socialist modernization project.

The decision clearly stipulated that the reshaping of the party required unified thinking, rectification of the style of work, strengthening of the discipline, and purification of the organization. Specific explanations were provided as follows:

- Unified thinking involves further achieving high consistency in ideology and politics throughout the party and correcting all tendencies that violate the four fundamental principles and the party's line since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee.
- Rectifying the work style means promoting the revolutionary spirit of serving the people wholeheartedly, correcting all behaviors that exploit power for personal gain, and opposing irresponsible bureaucratic practices towards the party and the people.
- Strengthening discipline involves adhering to the organizational principles of democratic centralism, opposing patriarchal systems, factionalism, anarchism, and liberalism, and transforming the weak and loose state of party organizations.
- To purify the organization in accordance with the party charter by excluding members who persistently oppose or damage the party.

The decision prescribed that the reshaping of the party should be carried out from the central to grassroots party organizations, from top to bottom, in stages and batches. The reshaping of each unit of the party organization should also follow this top-down approach, starting with leaders and cadres, followed by party members and the masses. The fundamental method for reshaping the party is to carry out criticism and self-criticism, distinguish right from wrong, correct mistakes, and purify the organization. Throughout the process, ideological education should be strengthened, aiming to raise the ideological awareness of all party members. The decision announced the establishment of the Central Party Reshaping Work Guidance Committee.

According to the decision on reshaping the party and the guidance of the CPC Central Reshaping Guidance Committee, the comprehensive reshaping of the party proceeded in three phases. 

The first phase was carried out in central, national government ministries and commissions, as well as provincial, autonomous regions, municipalities, and major units of the People's Liberation Army. To strengthen the leadership of the first phase of the party reshaping, the Central Party Reshaping Guidance Committee and the Central Military Commission jointly dispatched 90 reshaping liaison groups with 850 participants and established ten guiding groups for reshaping the work at the central and state agencies. During this period, the Central Committee for Reshaping issued 11 notifications and other documents. These documents gave specific instructions on various issues such as studying documents on reshaping the party, fully listening to suggestions from non-party friends and the non-party masses, establishing two groups for reshaping and business work, comparing checks, making changes while reshaping, handling organizational procedures and party member registration, inspection summaries, and consolidating development reshaping, etc. These guidelines not only provided timely guidance for each stage of the first phase of reshaping but also played a significant role in all phases of reshaping the party.



The second stage was carried out in the party organizations of enterprises, institutions, colleges, scientific research institutions, etc., at the municipal and county levels. From February 28 to March 6, 1985, the Central Party Guidance Committee held the second stage Party Construction Conference, deploying the second stage of party rectification. Faced with several tendencies that disturbed construction and reform within the party and society at that time, the Central Party Rectification Guidance Committee emphasized in the notice that the key points for party rectification at the municipal and county levels should be to enhance the party spirit of party members, correct new unhealthy tendencies, ensure the smooth progress of reforms, and promote the continued healthy development of the political and economic situation. To grasp the basic situation of the second stage party rectification work in various places, the Central Party Rectification Guidance Committee sent seven inspection teams to understand the situation, find problems, summarize experience, and make suggestions.

The third stage was carried out in the grassroots party organizations in the vast rural areas. On November 24, 1985, the Central Party Rectification Guidance Committee issued a notice on the deployment of rural party rectification work, making comprehensive arrangements for the specific requirements, methods, and steps of rural party rectification work. Provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the Central Government sent 630,000 propagandists and liaison officers to help with party rectification in rural areas. From May to June 1986, the Central Party Rectification Guidance Committee held a symposium on party rectification work for secretaries of the party committees of provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the Central Government, further clarifying the fundamental guiding ideology of rural party rectification, requiring serious attention to resolving the serious issues of power-for-private-gain and serious violation of laws and discipline among party members and cadres at the district, township, and village levels, and effectively strengthening the construction of rural leadership teams.

By the spring of 1987, the national party rectification work that had lasted for three and a half years had basically ended. On May 26, Bo Yibo, deputy director of the Central Party Rectification Guidance Committee, made a report on "The Basic Summary of Party Rectification and Further Strengthening Party Construction", making a overall evaluation of party rectification. When summarizing the achievements of party rectification in various aspects, Bo Yibo specifically pointed out:

The achievements in unifying thinking mainly include: (1) All party members, from senior cadres to the masses, through serious and relatively systematic study of the party rectification documents, have clarified many vague understandings, deepened their understanding of the socialist construction with Chinese characteristics since the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Party, clarified the adherence to reform, opening up, activating the economy and vigorously developing the socialist planned commodity economy. It is the only way to build a rich, democratic, and civilized socialist country, and further enhanced the voluntary implementation of these Marxist-Leninist policies. (2) Through the education of completely negating the "Cultural Revolution", the majority of party members are clear that both factions in the "Cultural Revolution" were engaged in activities under the "left" theory of "struggling class struggle as the guiding principle" and "continuing the revolution under the dictatorship of the proletariat" and were wrong in general. This further eliminated factionalism and "leftist" toxins and laid a more solid ideological and political foundation for strengthening the unity of the party and inspiring the reform and innovation spirit of party members. (3) By universally carrying out education on party character, ideals, and purpose, the condition of bartered communist ideal and the idea of serving the people among some party members was changed, the ideological consciousness of the majority of party members was improved, and the ability to resist the erosion of capitalist and feudalistic decay views was strengthened.

The progress made in rectifying work style mainly includes: (1) Various places have tried hard to investigate some serious cases of party members violating laws and discipline, seeking private interests with power, and serious irresponsibility of bureaucratism, basically curbing new malpractices such as party and government cadres running businesses, and improving the party style to varying degrees. (2) It promoted the change in work of leadership organizations at all levels, bureaucracy has decreased, the idea of serving at the base level has been strengthened, many party member leaders in various regions and departments have taken the lead in going deep into the grassroots level, conducting surveys and research, and solving practical problems in construction, reform, and people's lives, thus improving the relationship between the party and the masses.



(3) During the party rectification in rural areas, financial affairs were generally sorted out. Party members and cadres took the lead in returning long-overdue public funds and public goods, and took the initiative in doing practical things for the public, which was welcomed by the peasants. 
The main achievements in strengthening discipline and purifying the organization are as follows: (1) Severe efforts were spent in eliminating the "three kinds of people" from the "Cultural Revolution" and those who have made serious mistakes. Comrades participating in the party rectification, despite all kinds of difficulties and resistances, conducted a lot of strenuous investigation and evidence collection work. On the basis of several cleansings that were carried out before the party rectification, which dealt with 400,000 people, a further action across the country (excluding Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region) purged 5,449 "three kinds of people" and 43,074 individuals who had committed severe mistakes. (2) The tradition of criticism, self-criticism, and strict internal party life was restored and carried forward, and members' concept of organizational discipline has been reinforced compared to the past. Some party organizations, formerly in a paralyzed or semi-paralyzed state, have clearly improved after restructuring. (3) Through member registration and organizational processing, a group of members with serious problems and those disqualified were addressed. With 33,896 people expelled from the party, 90,069 denied registration, 145,456 deferred registration, and 184,071 given party discipline punishments such as probation, dismissal of party positions, recommendation of dismissal from non-party positions, serious warnings, warnings, etc. (4) A number of problematic and loosely organized leadership teams were re-adjusted, about half of the team leaders above the county level have been replenished to varying degrees. With the adjustments and replenishment, the construction of leadership teams was advanced. With the advent of a group of middle-aged and young party members who are firm in party spirit, upright in work style, and lead the masses to resolutely implement the current party policies.

The most significant meaning of this party rectification in the history of party building is that it purged the "three kinds of people" (referring to those who followed Lin Biao and Jiang Qing's anti-revolutionary group during the "Cultural Revolution", those with serious gang ideologies, and smashing robbers) hidden within various levels of party organizations, eliminated the hidden dangers that affect unity within the party and disrupted the party's construction, and purified the party organization. 

Of course, while achieving certain results, this party rectification also had shortcomings: uneven development of party rectification with some units, including some higher and middle-level party and government bodies, failed to fully complete the four basic tasks of the party rectification. Some even did it casually, damaging the party rectification's reputation among the masses. Units that performed well in party rectification also left some issues in party style and other areas, needing resolutions in the future regular party building.

2. Arrival of a New Stage in the Building of Party's Cadre Team
Comrade Mao Zedong once said in discussing the importance of cadre team building: "After the political route is determined, cadres are the deciding factor." Mao Zedong paid the most attention to training party cadres in his life. Chen Yun once said that one of Mao Zedong's incomparable achievements from the Zunyi Conference to the victory of the Anti-Japanese War was the cultivation of a generation of people, including us and a group of "38-type" cadres.

After the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, the second-generation leadership of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, with Deng Xiaoping as the core, gradually found the path to building socialism with Chinese characteristics, forming a set of correct guidelines and policies, and initiating a new situation in the construction of socialist modernization. Deng Xiaoping did not become complacent due to this but extended his thinking to how to ensure the continuation of the cause pioneered by the older generation of revolutionaries.

As early as August 18, 1980, Deng Xiaoping first proposed that cadres should be "four modernizations" in a speech at an enlarged meeting of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party. On December 25 of the same year, Deng Xiaoping clearly proposed the "four modernizations" standard for cadres in the Central Working Conference with the title "Implementing Adjustment Policies, Ensuring Stability and Unity".



He said, we should ensure the rejuvenation, intellectualization, and professionalization of our cadre team under the premise of adhering to the socialist path, and gradually develop a sound cadre system to guarantee this. The three conditions of rejuvenation, intellectualization, and professionalization are proposed, of course, the first thing is to revolutionize, so it is necessary to adhere to the socialist path as a premise. 
On July 2, 1981, Deng Xiaoping gave a speech at a symposium for party secretaries of provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the Central Government, titled "The First Task of Old Cadres is to Select Middle and Young Cadres". After analyzing the importance of promoting middle and young cadres, he proposed to establish the goal and plan for training and selecting middle and young cadres. He said: I suggest, let's discuss, should we propose a 5-year plan? The best is four years, until 1985. As for the cadre issue, I suggest two plans: a five-year plan and a ten-year plan. The first five years should select about 50,000 people and put them on appropriate job positions for training. In these five years, our leadership members, bureau-level members, provincial, autonomous region, and municipality-level members, around 50 years old, around 40 years old, gradually reach a certain proportion, put forward a requirement. By the second five years, we have to reach which level of leaders (for example, at the provincial, city, autonomous region level, ministerial level), except for special circumstances, not to exceed a certain age.
In the opening speech at the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, Deng Xiaoping put the "four modernizations" of the cadre team at the forefront of current work. At this congress, "revolutionization, rejuvenation, intellectualization, and specialization" were written into the new party constitution approved by the 12th Congress as the goal of building a cadre team with Chinese characteristics.
The "four modernizations" construction of the cadre team is to apply the principle of combining morality with talent, being both red and professional, specifically to the cadre construction, which reflects the objective requirements of China's socialist modernization construction. Revolutionization means that cadres must support the political and ideological lines since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, speak the party spirit, and not speak the party line, adhere to the socialist road, and have a strong sense of cause and responsibility. Rejuvenation means, under the premise of revolutionization, to select a large number of outstanding middle-aged and young cadres to various leadership positions, so that the cadre team of party and state leadership organs at all levels forms a echelon structure, is full of vitality and maintains vigorous vitality. Intellectualization and professionalization require that leadership cadres must have a certain cultural level and knowledge level, be able to master and use modern natural science, social science, and management science knowledge, and scientifically lead and manage socialist modernization construction. This fundamentally changes the previous tendency in the selection standard of leadership cadres to weigh family background, party seniority, depth of experience.
To achieve the "four modernizations" of the cadre team, it is necessary to abolish the lifelong tenure of leadership cadres. This is a key point and also a difficulty. In this regard, the party and the country have taken the following four measures to abolish the tenure of cadres:
The first is to establish term system for cadre positions. The Constitutional Law of the People's Republic of China passed by the Fifth Session of the Fifth National People's Congress abolished the lifelong tenure of cadres in the form of a fundamental national law. The Constitution stipulates that the term of the highest statewide leadership position for each term is five years, and the number of re-elections shall not exceed two terms.



The second involves the establishment of a cadre retirement system. In 1982, the CPC Central Committee made a decision on "On the Establishment of a Cadre Retirement System," stipulating that those who serve as the main person in charge at the ministerial level in central and state organs, and at the provincial level, should generally not exceed 65 years of age for the primary position, 60 years of age for the deputy position, and not exceeding 60 years of age for those at the bureau-level. In special cases where a cadre has not yet reached retirement age but their health is poor, they may retire early. After a cadre retires, their political life treatment remains unchanged. In accordance with the spirit of this document, by the end of 1982, more than 7,260 veteran cadres from the central authorities and central state organs directly under the CPC Central Committee had completed their retirement procedures. In August 1982, at the Seventh Plenary Session of the 11th CPC Central Committee, Liu Bocheng, and Cai Chang resigned from leadership positions. In September 1985, at the Fourth Plenary Session of the 12th CPC Central Committee, Ye Jianying, Deng Yingchao, Xu Xiangqian, Nie Rongzhen, and other 64 old comrades requested not to serve as members and alternate members of the Central Committee; Li Jingquan, Xiao Jinguang, He Changgong, and other 37 old comrades requested not to serve as members of the Central Advisory Commission; Huang Kecheng, Wang Congwu, and other 30 old comrades will no longer serve as members of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection.

Deng Xiaoping, who advocated abolition of the lifelong system of leadership positions, has long hoped to gradually disappear from the political stage because he realizes that too much honor is a burden to himself, and an individual weighing too heavy is also a burden for the party and the state. Because many countries base their policies towards China on whether he is sick or dead, which to build a country's fate on one or two individuals' prestige is very abnormal and also very dangerous. In that case, any change in this person will cause instability, and if something goes wrong, it will be uncontrollable. Deng Xiaoping did not want this situation to occur after him. Therefore, as early as November 2, 1979, he said at a senior cadre meeting: I myself have this idea, if the party allows me to retire today, I will retire immediately. This is true, not falsehood.

On September 2, 1986, during a meeting with American journalist Wallace, Deng Xiaoping said, "I advocate abolishing the tenure system and promoting the establishment of a retirement system. You also know that during a conversation with Italian journalist Farachi, I said that I was ok working until 1985, which is now more than a year ago. I am considering when to retire. Personally, I hope to retire early."

In 1987, before the Thirteenth Party Congress, Deng Xiaoping formally proposed his desire to retire in order to practice the abolition of the lifelong system of cadre leadership positions. At this time, the CPC Central Committee repeatedly considered the opinions of Deng Xiaoping himself and within and outside the party, and decided that he would resign from other positions except for remaining as the chairman of the party and the state military commission. Since then, he has no longer interfered with the central daily work, realizing semi-retirement.



The third point is to reduce deputy positions and part-time positions. In August 1980, Hua Guofeng no longer concurrently held the position of Premier, and Deng Xiaoping, Li Xiannian, Chen Yun, Wang Zhen, and Wang Renzhong no longer concurrently held deputy premiers. In 1982, during the reform of the central and state council institutions, the number of deputy positions was reduced. The number of Vice Premiers of the State Council was reduced from 13 to 2. According to statistics from 38 departments and committees, excluding the concurrently serving ministers and directors, there are 167 principal and deputy ministers, and principal and deputy directors, a reduction of 338 from the original 505, a decrease of 67%; their average age is 58, which is 6 years younger than before; the number of cadres with university-level cultural standards has increased from 37% to 52%. According to statistics from 28 departments and committees, there were originally 720 department and bureau organizations, which has now been reduced to 488, a decrease of 32%; the original number of principal and deputy bureau directors was 2,450, which has now been reduced to 1,398, a decrease of 43%; their average age was originally 59 years old, which has now decreased to 54 years old; the proportion of cadres with university-level cultural standards has increased from 36% to 49%.

The fourth is to establish an advisory system. Deng Xiaoping proposed the idea of establishing an advisory system in 1981: in addition to the Central Committee, an advisory committee should be established, to "accommodate some old comrades". Advisors do not hold current positions, so this can free up positions for younger people. At the same time, being an advisor is also a position, and its rank is not lower than that of party committee members of the same level. It is better for old comrades to move their positions to this place. Of course, being an advisor is not just about comforting, but also has the role of "passing on and helping", which is "helping onto the horse, and sending a way". Deng Xiaoping's intention in this regard is deep, because China's leadership not only has the problem of aging, but also the problem of inheritance. To solve these two problems, establishing an advisory system is a good solution. The Central Advisory Committee was formally established in September 1982, and Deng Xiaoping was elected as the director of the committee.

The establishment of the Central Advisory Committee, at a critical juncture in history, has made a historic contribution to ensure the long-term stability of the Party and the country. After the establishment of the Central Advisory Committee, it has done a lot of effective work to assist the Central Party to maintain the unity of the party and social stability, and promote reform and opening up and modernization.

Deng Xiaoping estimated that the advisory committee should be abolished after another ten years, and at most not more than 15 years. The Central Advisory Committee, from 1982 to 1992, exactly ten years. Over the past decade, the cooperation and transition between the old and new cadres of the Party have proceeded smoothly. At the same time, the Advisory Committee has existed for two terms, and the members are old, and as a transitional measure, its mission has been completed. In view of this, the Central Advisory Committee proposed to the 14th Party Congress that there will be no Central Advisory Committee after the 14th Party Congress. The Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, after careful and sufficient discussion, decided not to set up the Central Advisory Committee of the Party and the advisory committees of provinces, cities, and autonomous regions.

The above measures have created favorable conditions for the selection of middle-aged and young cadres and the realization of the "Four Transforms" target for the Party's cadre team. The Central Committee of the Communist Party of China seized this opportunity and accelerated the "Four Transforms" construction of the Party's cadre team.



From 1984 to 1985, the central government carried out concentrated adjustments of leadership at all levels. Throughout this period of over one year, there were 47 newly appointed ministers, directors, and heads of direct bureaus under the Central Government and the State Council, and 80 deputy ministers, deputy directors, and deputy directors of direct bureaus, including almost a hundred young and middle-aged cadres newly selected. Before the leadership of the 81 departments under the State Council were adjusted, the average age was 56.6. After adjustment, this dropped by 5 years, and the proportion of those under 55 rose from 10% to 30%. The percentage of those with a college degree or more increased by 27.5%, reaching 71%. During the same period, the average age of the standing committee members of provincial, autonomous regional, and municipal party committees, as well as governors, chairmen, and mayors, dropped from 57 to 53. Those under 55 made up 90%, and those with a college degree or higher rose to 80%. During the same period, after readjustments, the leadership of the nation's 3000 large and medium-sized key enterprises formed a pyramid structure with officials in their 40s as the main body. According to statistics from 2900 of these enterprises, there were 18,000 leading officials, 20% of them under age 40 and 63% aged 41 to 50, with an average age of 45. Those with a college degree or above amounted to 74%, among which 89% of factory chiefs had a college degree or above, an increase of 40% from before the adjustment, while 81% of party secretaries with a college degree or above, a 70% increase from before the adjustment. In order to accelerate the process of rejuvenation of the cadres, a national congress of the party was convened in 1985. This meeting was designed to solve the problem of aging cadres. At this meeting, 131 elderly leaders withdrew from the main leadership bodies of the party, and 179 new leaders were elected at the same time. The newly elected Central Committee members and newly appointed ministers and provincial Party secretaries were generally over 50, with some just over 40. Deng Xiaoping said that this event amounted to an unprecedented transfer of power in the history of the Communist Party of China and warranted special documentation in the history of the party.

In view of the fact that a considerable proportion of old cadres at all levels will gradually retire from their current positions over a period of time, there would be a disconnection if there were not a necessary number of new people as a reserve force. To this end, the central government decided to establish a reserve cadre system, creating a reserve cadre corps composed mainly of outstanding young and middle-aged cadres under 50, especially around 40, and putting them to the test in practice. Those with excellent performance in their duties would be promoted and appointed in a timely manner based on their real work achievements and the further test of the organization and the public.

Through strengthening the "Four Modernizations" construction of the cadre team, our cadre team began to show a new look. Under the premise of revolution, a large number of young and middle-aged cadres took up leadership positions, forming a cadre team that is equipped in echelon, an effective combination of old, middle-aged and young people, and is both rich in experience and full of vitality. Its combat effectiveness and cohesion have been strengthened. Of course, there is still a long way to go in the "Four Modernizations" construction of the cadre team, and there is still much work to do, and there are many contradictions to overcome.

3. Correcting Various Malpractices within the Party

Party style is a concentrated reflection of the spirit of the party, directly related to the image of the party among the people, and to the prestige of the party among the people. Therefore, the central party paid high attention to various malpractices that emerged in the process of reform and opening up, and made consistent efforts to seriously address them.



First, it is prohibited for party and government cadres, and their children and spouses to conduct business and create enterprises, engaging in corrupt practices. After the Third Plenary Session of the 12th Central Committee, the focus of China's reform shifted from rural to urban areas, entering a stage of comprehensive reform. Economic development entered a new round of growth period, and a business boom emerged nationwide. Some party and government organs and their cadres got involved consciously or unconsciously, becoming a peculiar spectacle in economic life. Before the comprehensive rectification of companies in 1988, there were more than 470,000 companies registered in the country. Among the many companies, there were central-level companies established by various party, government, and military departments as well as national mass organizations; "princely companies" set up in various regions; and "surplus heat companies" run by retired cadres. Quite a few of these companies did not distinguish between government and business, traded for profit, and sought huge profits. Some companies were chaotic in operation and deviated from China's actual conditions to pursue high salaries and benefits; a few people exploited their power for corruption, theft, speculation, bribery, and accepting bribes. These actions severely disturbed the integrity of government and the establishment of a sound socialist economic order, aggravated the contradiction of social distribution injustice, and affected social stability.

As for the condition of party and government organs conducting business and creating enterprises, and the serious harm brought by it, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China has maintained a clear understanding from the beginning. On December 3, 1984, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council issued the "Resolution on Strictly Prohibiting Party and Government Organs and Party Cadres from Doing Business and Starting Enterprises." It clearly required that party and government leading organs at all levels, especially economic departments and their leading cadres, should correctly play the role of leading and organizing economic construction, adhere to the principle of separating duties and separating officials from business, uphold the style of being upright and just, and not allow them to use their power to operate business and start enterprises against party and state regulations for personal gain, or compete with the people for profit. The Central Committee required party and government leading organs and leading comrades at all levels to maintain a clear mind, adopt a distinct attitude, and resolutely eliminate corruption.

However, after prohibiting party and government organs and their in-service cadres from conducting business and creating enterprises, a new situation emerged where some leading cadres' children and spouses were involved in business and enterprises, which was unforeseen. After the Central Party Committee discovered this problem, on May 23, 1985, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council issued the "Decision on Prohibiting the Children and Spouses of Leading Cadres from Doing Business," stipulating that children and spouses of leading cadres at county level or above are not allowed to engage in business, except in state-owned, collective, and joint ventures. On July 9 of the same year, the General Office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the General Office of the State Council issued a "Supplementary Notice on Party and Government Cadres Not Holding Concurrent Posts in Economic Entities," making related provisions.

For a period of time, most of the enterprises organized by party and government organs were either closed down or were de-linked from party and government organs. Most party and government cadres involved in business returned to their roles or resigned from party and government leadership positions, but corruption is like a piece of wasteland, "wildfires can not burn them all, and when the winds of spring blow, they reappear." Some party and government organs and their cadres still adopted various ways to conduct business and create enterprises; some party and government cadres continue to hold concurrent positions in companies; some family members used the connections and influence of leading cadres to conduct business and create enterprises; some serious illegal acts in business operations and running enterprises, especially those involving some leading cadres, did not receive due resolution.

In order to curb the trend of party and government organs and party and government cadres conducting business and starting enterprises, on February 4, 1986, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council issued the "Regulations on Further Curbing the Practice of Party and Government Organs and Party and Government Cadres Engaging in Business and Starting Enterprises" It required all levels of party committees and governments to resolutely implement central regulations and strictly enforce prohibitions. Those who refuse to implement will be dealt with severely and held accountable accordingly. Discipline inspection commissions at all levels and industrial and commercial administrative management departments must closely cooperate with organization, personnel, auditing, banking, and judicial departments to supervise the implementation.

Through the implementation of the spirit of this document, the issue of party and government organs and party and government cadres conducting business operations and establishing enterprises has been initially solved. 

Second, investigate issues of party and government cadres accepting and soliciting bribes.



In the process of prohibiting party and government officials from conducting business and engaging in corrupt acts, the issue of bribery by party and government officials was also investigated and dealt with. When the commodity economy began to become more active, but administrative actions, market actions, and business actions were not yet strictly regulated through legal forms, corruption activities such as exchanges of power and money were most likely to breed and spread. In response to the new features of party discipline and clean government construction in the new situation, on June 30, 1987, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection issued the "Decision on Resolutely Investigating and Dealing with the Issue of Communist Party Members Accepting Bribes". The Decision pointed out: In recent years, the ugly behavior of accepting and soliciting bribes, which was common in feudal and capitalist societies, has spread in some areas and departments in our foreign economic activities. Such a situation has caused strong dissatisfaction both inside and outside the party, and domestically and internationally. This must be given high attention by the whole Party, decisive measures must be taken, and bribery and bribery violations must be severely dealt with. For this reason, the Central Discipline Inspection Commission made three decisions: (1) Communists, especially leaders, regardless of who they are, if they violate criminal laws due to bribery or bribe-seeking, they will be expelled from the party. Party members who solicit bribes in any way must voluntarily confess their problems, otherwise, regardless of the severity of the circumstances, they will be cleansed out of the party once they are found out. (2) Normal "kickbacks" in economic activities, no one is allowed to keep for any reason or excuse, all must be handed over to the state or the collective, and violators will be dealt with seriously according to party discipline and law. (3) All levels of party organizations, including disciplinary inspection agencies, must effectively strengthen the education, management, and supervision of party members, and never allow the Party's principles to be traded. Party members who have problems with solicitation and bribery must be resolutely investigated. If they are tolerated and not dealt with, the leadership responsibility of their party organization will be held accountable. After a period of effort, due to strong measures, the unhealthy trend of bribery and bribe-seeking has been basically stopped, but it has not been eradicated. Therefore, the Party Central Committee requires the whole party to persist in fighting this corruption phenomenon. 

Third, we must severely curb the unhealthy trend in the selection and appointment of cadres and the issue of going abroad. After the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, great achievements have been made in the selection and appointment of cadres. But there are also some problems, the most prominent of which are: some leading cadres do not abide by the party's principles and violate organizational and personnel discipline. Some of them choose people on personal likes and dislikes, grudges, or use people who are beneficial to themselves, or select people from the feudal clan concept and factional concept. Some, through various means, "go through the back door" to promote their children and friends; some give positions to send people, engage in transactions; some do not follow policy regulations, fight for grades and treatment for the cadres of their own system and unit, and upgrade their subordinate units; some cadres who do organizational and personnel work abandon their duties, do not speak of principles, and even use power for personal gains; etc. In order to control the problem of improper selection and appointment of cadres, the CPC Central Committee put forwarded eight rules for the selection and appointment of cadres on January 6, 1986: (1) Leading cadres must act as models in employing people according to party principles and uphold discipline in organization and personnel work. (2) The selection and appointment of cadres must strictly follow the procedure of democratic recommendation, broad consultation, proposing selection targets; organizational and personnel departments conduct inspections, the party committee discusses collectively, and then reports according to the authority of cadres management; the higher-level organization department conducts further inspections, and then proposes to the party committee for discussion and approval. (3) The selection and appointment of leading cadres must fully follow the mass line. (4) Before deciding to promote a cadre, a strict examination must be carried out in accordance with the moral and talent conditions required by the proposed position. (5) The selection of cadres must be decided by collective discussion of the party committee, not by individual decision. (6) The promotion of cadres should be based on the best among those who have been tempered in practice. (7) It is strictly forbidden to arbitrarily set up organizations, elevate organizational specifications, and increase the number of leading cadres. (8) Organizational and personnel departments at all levels must conscientiously perform their duties and serve as advisors and assistants to the party committee.



Beginning in early 1986, the Central Organization Department conducted a large amount of investigative research, proposing some ideas and principles regarding the establishment of a system for party and government officials to avoid conflicts of interest: First, job avoidance, for officials serving in party committees, government, Discipline Inspection Commission, public security, courts, and procuratorates, their spouses, children, and relatives must not have direct hierarchical relationships with the leaders, nor should they hold leadership positions in the offices, organizations, personnel, and supervision departments of the leaders, as well as the disciplinary inspection bodies at the same level. Second, public affairs avoidance, party and government leaders should not be involved in matters regarding their own appointments, dismissals, file management and transfer, and must not instruct or imply others to exert influence or interfere. Third, regional avoidance, the county (city) party secretary, mayor, secretary of the Discipline Inspection Committee, minister of the Organization Department, director of the Personnel Bureau, director of the Public Security Bureau, president of the court, and the chief prosecutor, should not be served by local cadres.

The malpractice of officials going abroad has been a specific form of corruption that has emerged in the process of China's reform and opening up. Since the reform and opening up, the number of people traveling abroad for private and public purposes has greatly increased in China. But there have also been malpractices, such as the overbundling of party and government officials going abroad, repeated inspections, rotations, and party and government officials replacing professional officials to go abroad. Some party and government officials have used inspections as a pretext to travel abroad, causing an increase in foreign exchange expenditures.

To curb this malpractice, on July 4, 1987, the CPC Central Committee and the State Council issued the "Several Provisions on Strictly Controlling the Issue of Party and Government Officials Going Abroad", declaring that all party and government officers who are not directly related to the work of going abroad must not be granted leave. Official business or professional personnel who can complete the task of going abroad should not participate, and party and government officials should not be allowed to participate. Party and government organs and other business leaders must not publicly or suggestively ask to join the group going abroad by enterprises and institutional units on the grounds of higher or lower relationships or some working relationships.

When the CPC Central Committee was improving the party's work style and building a clean government, it promoted the improvement of the party's work style by focusing on major and influential cases. In the Jinjiang region of Fujian Province, some enterprises manufactured a large amount of fake drugs and sold them to various places through various forms of bribery. On July 13, 1985, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection issued a public letter to the Jinjiang District Committee, requiring them to investigate and deal with this case according to party discipline and law, and report to the central authority.



On July 27, after the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection heard reports from the Fujian Provincial Committee and the Provincial Discipline Inspection Commission of the Chinese Communist Party, the involved parties were dealt with according to the law. The standing committee member and secretary of the Disciplinary Committee of Jinjiang County Committee, who participated in the manufacture and sale of counterfeit medicines and profited from it, were removed from their posts for investigation.

From early 1986 to April 1989, a few leaders of the Ministry of Railways and the Zhengzhou Railway Bureau exploited their positions due to the limited capacity of railway transport and tight carriage scheduling. They used various means to capitalize from the situation and committed corruption and bribery. Upon investigation, this case involved 48 cadres above the division level in Zhengzhou Railway Bureau of the Ministry of Railways, one deputy minister of the Ministry of Railways, 15 bureau-level cadres, and 19 department-level cadres. The total amount of criminal funds was more than 960,000 yuan. The Transportation Bureau of the Ministry of Railways violated regulations and illegally demanded and accepted a total of more than 760,000 yuan from shippers or subordinate units in various names. The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection dealt with this case seriously. The State Council revoked Luo Yunguang, the deputy minister of the Ministry of Railways who was involved in bribery and was responsible for his subordinates' corruption and bribery. The procuratorial organ initiated a criminal case against Luo Yunguang for bribery. The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection also decided to expel Xu Jun, the former director of the Transport Bureau, deputy directors Jia Shuang and Hu Jun, assistant director Wei Guofan (Bureau-level treatment), dispatcher Ma Mingshan (Bureau-level treatment) and former director of Zhengzhou Railway Bureau He Zhigui, party secretary Liu Demin, and deputy director Pan Keming. Their violation of criminal law was dealt with separately by judicial authorities.
  
From May 6 to June 2, 1987, a major forest fire broke out in the Greater Hinggan Mountains, causing considerable damage to national property and lives, with some losses impossible to calculate in financial terms. Yang Zhong, the Minister of Forestry, severely lost the party principles that party leadership cadres should have, and lacked a high degree of political responsibility for the party and the people's cause, committing serious bureaucratic errors and major dereliction of duty. Dong Zhiyong, the vice minister in charge of forest fire prevention, lacked the necessary responsibility for forest fire prevention work and committed serious bureaucratic and dereliction errors, and held significant responsibility for the Da Hinggan Mountains forest fire. With the approval of the CPC Central Committee, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection decided to remove Yang Zhong from the position of Party Secretary of the Ministry of Forestry. The State Council proposed to the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress to revoke Yang Zhong's position as Minister of Forestry and Dong Zhiyong's position as Deputy Minister, and asked Heilongjiang Provincial Government to conduct a thorough review.

The Central Committee of the Communist Party of China has educated the whole party through major cases, causing the whole party to receive a profound party style education and promote the formation of a party style issue where everyone manages together. However, the fight against corruption and promotion of integrity is a long-term struggle that runs throughout the entire process of reform, opening up, and modernization, so there is still a long way to go in this work.

Chapter 6 The Formation of the Third Central Leading Collective and the Preliminary Establishment of Deng Xiaoping's Theoretical Directing Position
1. Full rollout of renovation and a series of 'double-hand grab' guidelines

After the 13th National Congress of the Party, the Party led the people of the whole country to continue on the road of socialism with Chinese characteristics. The economic construction since the reform and opening up has achieved great achievements, mainly reflected in: the sustained and stable growth of the national economy, the gross national product, national fiscal revenue, and the average income of urban and rural residents have doubled; serious economic and social problems that have long plagued our country have begun to be resolved or found solutions; the vast majority of the 1 billion population live in moderate prosperity, some regions are moving towards a comfortable life, even in areas where moderate prosperity has not been fully achieved, people's lives have improved: the market supply has greatly improved, basically reversing the long-term serious shortage of consumer goods in the past. From 1984 to 1988, it was a leap forward in rapid development, the gross national product increased from 717.1 billion yuan to 1,492.8 billion yuan, showing the lively situation of promoting agriculture and industry, rural and urban, reform and development, and the comprehensive national strength stepped onto a new stage.

1. Full rollout of renovation



With the deepening of reform and rapid economic development, some deep-seated contradictions in the economic system gradually emerged. At the same time, there arose a tendency to purely pursue speed and ignore objective conditions in the process of reform and construction. In August 1988, under the circumstances of a not-so-relaxed macroeconomic environment, it was decided to push through with price reform, triggering a mass buying spree and causing social tremors. A series of unstable and conflicting issues appeared in the operation of the economy. These issues manifested as “four overs and one disorder," namely excessive social demand, too rapid industrial growth, excessive credit and money supply, excessive price increases, and economic disorder. In response to these problems, the Central Party Committee made timely decisions to regulate and reorganize, and to deepen reforms: curbing overheated economy; containing inflation; seriously adjusting economic structure, allowing for significant increase in the yield of main agricultural products such as grain, cotton, and oil; and establishing and improving necessary economic regulations, as well as a macro-control system and supervision system, actively promoting the establishment of a new order of socialist commodity economy. After about a year of regulation and reorganization, the trend of overly rapid economic development and the chaotic situation in the economic sector were reversed. 

With the deepening of reform and opening up, new trends and issues have emerged in social customs amidst the highlighting of deep-seated contradictions in the economic system. Under these circumstances, the Central Party Committee clearly put forward the principle of "grasping with both hands."
2. The era's demand for the principle of “grasping with both hands"
In the process of building a socialist modernization, why do we insist on the principle of "grasping with both hands"? This is not the result of subjective imagination by someone, but the embodiment of the objective law of China's socialist modernization construction. 

The report of the 13th National Congress of the Communist Party of China explicitly stated that "grasping with both hands" is the strategic principle of building socialism with Chinese characteristics. The so-called strategic principle has two implications: one is from the importance, it means holding the two civilized constructions together, relating to the fundamental direction and fundamental road of constructing with Chinese characteristics. Because only "grasping with both hands" can holistically develop material civilization and spiritual civilization to enhance China's overall national strength. Secondly, in terms of longevity, it refers to adhering to the two civilizations during the entire primary stage of socialism, rather than just sticking to it for a while or during a certain period. If the basic line at the primary stage of socialism remains unchanged for a hundred years, the principle of "grasping with both hands" must also remain constant. Adhering to "grasping with both hands" is a profound summary of the experiences and lessons of reform and opening up. 

For the purpose of promoting the development of social production forces, it is necessary to accelerate the pace of reform. This revolution will unfold across a considerably wide field and profound depth. It relates to the future of socialism, to the interests of hundreds of millions of people, and is an extremely complex mass exploration and innovative undertaking. This will not only cause significant changes in people's economic and political lives, but also induce great changes in people's lifestyles, ways of thinking, and mental states. Therefore, some problems and passive phenomena will inevitably appear. 

From the practice of reform and opening up, the problems we face can be roughly divided into three types: The first is that in the process of transitioning between the old and new systems, some new contradictions and problems will inevitably arise. The second is that some reformers do not accurately or fully understand the central government’s policies, or due to lack of experience and insufficient consideration, some deviations and mistakes appear in bold explorations. The third is a phenomenon where some people take advantage of the loopholes in the reform to make a fortune, engage in "official speculation," "private speculation," foster unhealthy tendencies, even break the law and order, commit economic crimes and other criminal activities. For the first two situations, we must proceed with caution and increase people's awareness, especially party members and cadres, through education, to ensure the healthy progress of reform and opening up.




In the third situation, we resolutely handle according to party discipline, political discipline, and legal discipline, especially for those serious economic crimes and other criminal activities. We must punish them severely according to the law, resolutely crack down, and never be soft. Practice has proven that the deeper the reform, the more we need to "grasp both hands", otherwise, reform cannot be carried out. 
In the process of opening up to the outside world, on the one hand, we have introduced advanced technology, advanced equipment, and some management experiences and methods that are in line with socialized mass production. On the other hand, it is difficult to avoid the accompanying undesirable impacts, such as the decay of foreign capitalism and the lifestyle, certain reactionary political views and sociological theories of the bourgeoisie may infiltrate, even flood in on a massive scale, causing serious harm to our social life and people's spiritual world. For example, in politics, Western bourgeois "liberalization", "democratization", and "multi-party system" political views might infiltrate, leading to bourgeois liberalization trends; in economics, the Western bourgeoisie's pursuit of profit, harm to others for personal gain, values of money worship, fraud, smuggling and drug trafficking, bribery and corruption, speculation and other behaviors might pour in, triggering economic crimes and other criminal activities; in terms of culture, obscene videos, photos, movies, yellow literature, books, music, and toxic sociological theories from overseas may be introduced, polluting people's spiritual world and corroding people's souls. For these, Deng Xiaoping had early foresight. He said that by implementing the open door policy, we opened windows, brought in fresh air, but also brought in mosquitoes and flies. How should we deal with this? closing the door, obviously, is not a solution. The only choice is to stick to reform and opening up, while opposing bourgeois liberalization and cracking down on all kinds of criminal activities.
Therefore, in the historical process of deepening reform and opening up, adhering to the "grasp both hands" principle is an important condition to ensure the vitality of the reform and opening up, it's also vital to ensuring that the reform remains on the correct path of development.
3. Proposal and elucidation of a series of "grasp both hands" guidelines
The "grasp both hands" guideline is an important strategy of governance experienced by the Communist Party of China in the process of reform and opening up. The so-called "grasp both hands" has several different levels of connotations: first, to construct material civilization with one hand and construct spiritual civilization with the other hand; second, to grasp reform and opening up in one hand, and the four cardinal principles with the other; third, to grasp reform and opening up in one hand, and crack down on economic crimes and other criminal activities with the other; fourth, to grasp the construction of two civilizations in one hand and construct democratic legal system with the other.
The "grasp both hands" guideline was generated, developed, and enriched in the practice of reform and opening up in our country. Deng Xiaoping, the chief architect of reform and opening up, was the first leader in the party to propose and emphasize this guideline.
After the third plenary session of the 11th Central Committee, while Deng Xiaoping was taking charge of setting strategies for reform, opening up, and modernization construction, he began to pay attention to the issue of "grasp both hands". On October 30, 1979, when he delivered a speech on behalf of the Central Committee to the Fourth Congress of Chinese Literature and Art Workers, he first proposed the idea of grasping the two civilizations together. He said: "Our country has entered a new era of socialist modernization. While we raise the social productive forces on a large scale, we also reform and improve the socialist economic system and political system, develop advanced socialist democracy and sound socialist legal system. While we build a highly material civilization, we also improve the scientific and cultural level of the whole nation, develop a noble and rich cultural life, and build a highly advanced socialist spiritual civilization."
On December 25, 1980, the central work conference was held in Beijing...



Deng Xiaoping made an important speech at this meeting, systematically expounded the relationship between material and spiritual civilization, and further proposed the concept of "emphasizing both hands". He said: "The socialist country we want to build, not only needs a high degree of material civilization but also a high degree of spiritual civilization. The more the party and the government implement various economic reform and opening-up policies, the more the party members, especially the senior leaders of the party, need to give high importance and put into practice the Communist ideology and Communist morality."
On March 27, 1981, the head of the Political Department of the People's Liberation Army of China reported to Deng Xiaoping that the army insisted on "emphasizing both hands". Deng Xiaoping was very pleased with this. He said: "There is one thing that has been done well recently, which is to highlight spiritual civilization. This area has made progress and must continue to be focused on."
With the development and depth of the reform and opening up, the criminal activities in the economic field have a tendency to spread. The Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council addressed this situation, conducted investigative studies, made the "Decision on Cracking Down on Serious Criminal Activities in the Economic Field" (referred to as the "Decision"), and began to investigate and punish economic crimes.
On April 10, 1982, the Central Politburo held a special meeting to discuss this "Decision". Deng Xiaoping made an important speech at the meeting, clearly proposing the problem of insisting on "emphasizing both hands" in the reform and opening up. He said: "We need to have both hands. One hand is to insist on the policy of opening to the outside world and invigorating the domestic economy, and the other hand is to resolutely crack down on economic crimes. Without this hand to crack down on economic crimes, not only will the policy of opening up to the outside world definitely fail, but the policy of invigorating the domestic economy will also definitely fail. With this hand to crack down on economic crimes, opening up to the outside world and invigorating the domestic economy can proceed in the correct direction."
It can be seen that Deng Xiaoping’s meaning of “emphasizing both hands” has developed further, not only referring to the simultaneous development of both civilizations, but also including the two hands of reform and opening up and cracking down on economic crimes, because this is related to the success or failure of the reform and opening up policy.
In order for the entire party to deeply understand the importance, necessity, and urgency of "emphasizing both hands", Deng Xiaoping repeatedly emphasized this policy.
On July 4, 1982, the Central Military Commission held a symposium, and Deng Xiaoping proposed four guarantees for adhering to the socialist system and doing a good job in modernization construction in his speech: the first is institutional reform, the second is good socialist spiritual civilization, the third is to resolutely crack down on economic crimes, and the fourth is to build the party well and rectify the party's organization and style. He emphasized: "We must insist on opening to the outside world and invigorating the domestic economy with one hand. However, in order to ensure that this policy is truly beneficial to the four modernizations construction and does not deviate from the socialist direction during its implementation, we must also have another hand, which is to crack down on economic crimes. Without this hand, there will be no restrictions."



"The four guarantees, these four things cannot be accomplished at once, they have to be done over a long period. We don't engage in campaigns, but with the progress of the four modernizations, we have to persist in the four guarantees, not to lose a day, and turn it into a regular work and struggle."
At the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China held in October 1982, under the guidance of Deng Xiaoping's theory of "grasping both hands", it was explicitly decided to grasp both civilizational aspects together, establishing it as a strategic guideline for the construction of socialist modernization to guide the work of the entire party. According to the "grasping both hands" guideline, the party strengthens the construction of spiritual civilization while developing material civilization, achieving certain results.

However, due to various subjective and objective reasons, China's spiritual civilization construction has not achieved the expected effects and has even shown signs of deterioration. This is specifically manifested in:
(1) Severe spread of corruption, with the unhealthy tendency within the party continuing to spread. The central government has taken measures to investigate major cases resulting in certain effects, but the situation has not been consolidated. The weakening of ideological and political work, along with the unchanged conditions of disjointed reforms, has led to a significant increase in illegal and disorderly behaviors by some party and government officials in exchanging power for money and using power for personal gains. Decadent behaviors such as extravagant eating and drinking, accepting bribes, cronyism, and soliciting personal favors have not declined, almost becoming the norm. This forgetfulness of the purpose of serving the people wholeheartedly has caused extreme dissatisfaction among the masses.
(2) Social morality continued to decline, and many members of society lost heart. Corruption and unhealthy practices within the party were not effectively curbed, severely affecting the party's and government's prestige and cohesion among the masses. Some regions did not crackdown on feudal superstitions, group gambling, prostitution, and pimping, and the once-rampant pornography recorded on videotapes and in publications caused serious harm to the minds and spirits of young people.
(3) Education and technology encountered worrying circumstances. Due to some difficulties and problems encountered in the reform of the education and technology system, and also due to the government's insufficient financial support for educational and technological affairs, the income of a large number of educators and technologists has been low for a long time, and the phenomenon of mental and physical mismatch continued and tended to expand. The education and research conditions did not see deserved improvements, seriously affecting the enthusiasm of intellectuals, with the increasing number of talents jumping ship in some areas. Under this influence, students' enthusiasm for study declined, "scraping a pass" became the mantra of some students, and rural areas saw students dropping out of school. China's education and technological affairs are once again facing a formidable challenge.

The Central Party quickly noticed the situation of one hand being hard and the other being soft. On September 23, 1985, Deng Xiaoping sharply criticized the mistake at the National Congress of the Communist Party of China. He said: "The construction of socialist spiritual civilization was proposed early on. The central government, local governments, and the military have done a lot of work, especially the emergence of a large number of advanced figures among the masses, which has a good influence. But looking at the whole country, the effect is still not ideal. The main reason is that the whole party has not paid enough attention... These years have seen production rise, but the toxins of capitalism and feudalism have not been reduced to the lowest possible level. Some bad things that had long vanished after liberation are also resurging."



"If we don't make drastic decisions to quickly change this situation, how can the superiority of socialism be fully demonstrated? How can we effectively educate our people and future generations? Without strengthening the cultivation of spiritual civilization, the construction of material civilization would also be destroyed and misguided. The success of our revolution and construction can't be achieved by material conditions alone."
To draw the attention of the whole Party, especially the central leadership, Deng Xiaoping once again discussed the issue of "Grasping Both Hands" at the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee on January 17, 1986. He pointed out that it is necessary to have "two hands" to achieve the four modernizations. Only one hand is not enough. The so-called two hands are one for construction and the other for legal system... We have made considerable achievements in economic construction, the situation is encouraging, this is our country's success. But what's the point of success in economy if the social atmosphere deteriorates? It can become a world of corruption, thievery, and bribery. Therefore, we cannot ignore the four insistences and dictatorship, which can ensure the smooth progress of our socialist modernization construction and effectively deal with those who sabotage the construction. He emphasized the need to promote spiritual civilization and improve the party’s conduct and social ethos from specific events; and emphasized that the higher the official, the more famous they are, the tighter their violations should be investigated and dealt with. The crimes of these people are harmful. Catching them and dealing with them will have a big effect, demonstrating our determination to overcome all obstacles in promoting spiritual civilization. He believes that if this matter is handled properly, it can truly promote reform and construction. This kind of determination, at least, requires ten years of struggle to restore the party's style and social ethos to the best times of the 1950s in the 20th century.
From the above situation, Deng Xiaoping made a huge contribution in the process of forming the party's strategic policy of "grasping both hands". In order to unwaveringly uphold the policy of "grasping both hands", he had a long struggle with various erroneous thoughts. Never compromise or give in on this major principle. In the process of struggling with erroneous thoughts, Deng Xiaoping also enriched and developed the strategic thought of "grasping both hands".
4. Gradual advancement of the "two-handed" policy in practice
The party's thoughts on "two-handedness" deepened with the reform and opening up, and continued to unfold in practice. All over the country, while focusing on promoting economic construction, they also began to strengthen "the other hand" in the field of ideology, culture, and other fields.
(1) The gradual development of socialist spiritual civilization construction. After the third plenary session of the Eleventh Central Committee, with the start of reform and opening up and the full deployment of socialist modernization construction, the Central Party Committee gradually put the task of socialist spiritual civilization construction on the agenda.
① The proposal of spiritual civilization construction thought. In March 1979, Deng Xiaoping's speech entitled "Adhere to the Four Basic Principles" at the party's theoretical work conference, proposed issues such as maintaining lofty revolutionary ideals, improving the moral level of the entire people, changing social ethos, and rectifying party style.



This has actually put forward some fundamental requirements for the construction of socialist spiritual civilization. In September of the same year, Ye Jianying first proposed the concept of socialist spiritual civilization in his speech at the celebration of the 30th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China. He said: "We must improve the education, science and culture, and health level of all our people while building a high level of material civilization, uphold lofty revolutionary ideals and revolutionary moral customs, develop a noble and colorful cultural life, and construct a high level of socialist spiritual civilization. These are important goals for our socialist modernization and necessary conditions for the realization of the four modernizations." This argument not only clearly proposed the concept of spiritual civilization, but also outlines the content of socialist spiritual civilization, including education, science, health, revolutionary ideals, revolutionary moral customs and cultural life, etc., clearly putting forward socialist spiritual civilization construction as an important goal and necessary condition for our country to realize modernization.

On 20th December 1980, at the Central Work Conference, Li Chang, one of the heads of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences at the time, wrote a letter to Deng Xiaoping specifically calling for the strengthening of the construction of socialist spiritual civilization. Deng Xiaoping wrote in his reply: Comrade Li Chang's letter raises a problem that deserves everyone's consideration. And proposed to send this letter to the comrades who participated in the Central Work Conference. On 25th December, Deng Xiaoping accepted Li Chang's suggestion in his speech at the conference and discussed the issue of building socialist spiritual civilization as an important topic, once again emphasizing its importance. He said: "The so-called spiritual civilization not only refers to education, science, culture (which is completely necessary), but also refers to communist ideology, ideals, beliefs, morals, discipline, revolutionary stance and principles, comrade-style relationships between people, etc." Here, the construction of socialist spiritual civilization has been summarized into two basic aspects, namely, the construction of scientific culture and the construction of ideological morality, thus making the connotation of spiritual civilization construction more clear.

In June 1981, the resolution on Some Historical Issues of the Party since the Founding of the Country, approved by the Sixth Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Party, made spiritual civilization one of the ten basic points of our country's socialist modernization construction, and for the first time in the form of a resolution of the Central Committee of the Party, defined the building of a "modern, highly democratic, and highly civilized socialist powerful country" as the Party's struggle program in the new historical period.

The gradual development of the construction of socialist spiritual civilization. In February 1981, nine units including the All-China Federation of Trade Unions, the Central Committee of the League, and the All-China Women's Federation jointly issued a proposal on the launch of civilized polite activities to respond to the call of the Central Committee to strengthen the construction of spiritual civilization, proposing to conduct civilized, polite, sanitary, orderly, moral and soul beauty, language beauty, behavior beauty, environmental beauty as content of the "five lectures and four beauty" activities among the people of the country, especially among young people. On February 28th, the Central Propaganda Department, the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Culture, the Ministry of Health, the Public Security Department jointly issued a notice on the launch of civilized polite activities. According to the notice, the civilized polite publicity and education activities with "five lectures and four beauty" as the main content were generally carried out throughout the country.

At the beginning of 1982, the General Office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China forwarded the report by the Central Propaganda Department on conducting in-depth "five lectures" and "four beauty" activities. In the spring of that year, in accordance with the deployment of the Central Secretariat, a "Civilized Polite Month for All" activity was launched throughout the country, focusing on improving environmental sanitation and solving the "dirty", "chaotic", and "poor" problems. In January 1983, the Central Propaganda Department and more than 20 other departments proposed that in the "five lectures and four beauty" activities, to launch an educational activity of "loving the motherland, loving socialism, loving the people", thus further enriching the content of spiritual civilization construction activities.

In September 1982, the 12th Party Congress summarized the understanding of the construction of socialist spiritual civilization by the Party since the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, and emphasized the construction of socialist spiritual civilization from a theoretical perspective.



The Twelfth Report proposes that "socialist spiritual civilization is an important characteristic of socialism and an important manifestation of the superiority of the socialist system", and determines that while building a high level of socialist material civilization, we should strive to build a high level of socialist spiritual civilization as a strategic policy for the modernization of socialism in our country.
According to the requirements of the Twelfth Congress to strive to build a socialist spiritual civilization, in March 1983, the CPC Central Committee and the State Council established the "Five Talks, Four Beauties, and Three Loves" activity committee in the central and various provinces, autonomous regions and municipalities for the leadership work of strengthening the "Five Talks, Four Beauties, Three Loves" activities, and set up corresponding offices. In this year, the activity of "Creating a Civilized City" began to rise in Sanming City, Fujian Province. In Baoding, Hebei Province, and other places, there were activities of the army and the people building civilized towns and streets.
