Resolving the issue of the return of Hong Kong and Macau through diplomatic negotiations and the "one country, two systems" approach is a major initiative by Chinese communists on the path of Sinicization of Marxism, and is a significant contribution made by the Chinese people to world peace and development. The successful practices after the return of Hong Kong and Macau have proven that "one country, two systems" is not only the most realistic way to achieve national reunification, but also the most important institutional guarantee for stability, prosperity, and development in the returned regions.

3. Promote the early resolution of Taiwan issue according to the "one country, two systems" principle.
In the late 1980s, the political situation in Taiwan underwent significant changes. With the lifting of martial law and localization of political power, the force of "Taiwan independence" gradually became more active. From the beginning of 1988 to 2000, Lee Teng-hui, through power strategies, suppression of dissidents, and consolidating his position, gradually abandoned the principle of one China and pursued a divisive policy of manufacturing "two Chinas." After 1993, the Taiwan authorities intensified their actions such as seeking "participation in the United Nations", carrying out so-called "holiday diplomacy", "dollar diplomacy", etc., deliberately creating "two Chinas", "one China, one Taiwan" in the international community. Especially in June 1995, with the permission of the United States, Lee Teng-hui visited the US and delivered a political speech at Cornell University, repeatedly emphasizing "Republic of China on Taiwan", and intensifying his international activities of creating "two Chinas". Meanwhile, Taiwan conducted continuous military exercises against mainland China, creating a tense atmosphere across the strait.

In face of the increasingly intensified secessionist activities by the Taiwan authorities, the Chinese government and the Chinese people have always maintained a high degree of vigilance, and have resolutely fought against secession and "Taiwan independence" from political, military, diplomatic, and public opinion perspectives. The anti-secession, anti-"Taiwan independence" struggle carried out by the Chinese people has powerfully hit the secessionist forces advocating "Taiwan independence" in Taiwan, helped the international community further understand the harmfulness of "Taiwan independence", and alerted the majority of Taiwan compatriots that "Taiwan independence" is a dead-end. The US government also made a commitment to continue the "one China" policy and stated that it does not support Taiwan independence.



Under pressure from all sides, the leader of Taiwan had to state: there is currently no need or necessity to immediately declare "Taiwanese independence".
Due to Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States, the second "Wang-Koo talks" could not proceed as planned, and negotiations at all levels between the two associations were forced to halt completely. In order to alleviate and improve cross-strait relations, the Taiwan Work Office of the Communist Party of China Central Committee, the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, and the Straits Exchange Foundation expressed their willingness to resume negotiations under the principle of one China. In September 1997, Jiang Zemin reiterated in his report at the 15th National Congress of the party that he solemnly urged the Taiwan authorities to start political negotiations with us as soon as possible. After several rounds of discussions, from October 14 to 19, 1998, Koo Chen-fu led the Taiwan Strait Exchange Foundation delegation to visit mainland China. Jiang Zemin met with Mr. and Mrs. Koo Chen-fu, Wang Daohan met with Koo twice, and they reached a four-point consensus, thus initiating the political dialogue across the strait and improving the atmosphere of cross-strait relations.
However, just as the knowledgeable individuals in mainland China and Taiwan were actively promoting the development of cross-strait relations, the Taiwan authorities chose to continue the path of destruction and confrontation. On July 9, 1999, Lee Teng-hui blatantly proposed the "two states theory", claiming that cross-strait relations are "state to state, at least special state to state". In the election held in Taiwan in March 2000, the KMT was defeated and DPP leader Chen Shui-bian was elected the new leader of Taiwan. Although he repeatedly claimed the "sincerity" and "goodwill" to restart the two-association dialogue and improve cross-strait relations at the beginning of his tenure, he chose to evade, obfuscate, and refuse the key issue of accepting the one-China principle. After that, he not only denied the existence of the "1992 consensus", deliberately obstructed the resumption of cross-strait negotiations, but also used various means to attempt to implement the "Taiwan independence" program in a gradual manner. On August 3, 2002, Chen Shui-bian made a televised speech to the 29th annual meeting of the "World Federation of Taiwanese Associations" held in Tokyo, Japan, bluntly claiming that "Taiwan is one country on one side of China across the strait", promoting the use of "referendum" to decide "Taiwan's future, fate, and current status", revealing his stubborn insistence on the "Taiwan independence" stance.
Whether it is the "two states theory" or the "one country on one side theory", both disregard the welfare of the Taiwanese people and lead Taiwan towards disaster. As soon as these remarks were made, they were firmly opposed by all the Chinese people, including Taiwanese compatriots. People from all over the country and overseas Chinese living abroad have strongly condemned the Taiwan authorities' separatist remarks and actions.
Although the Taiwan authorities have been promoting "Taiwanese independence" and separation activities, which have limited and obstructed the further development of cross-strait relations, various exchanges and cooperation between the two sides of the strait are irresistible. With the increase in exchanges between the people across the strait, Taiwanese compatriots have learned more about the situation in mainland China, and more and more people realize that Taiwan's development and prospects cannot be separated from mainland China. Economic and trade exchanges are the most active and vibrant factors in cross-strait relations. As of October 2002, Taiwanese businessmen have made more than 55,000 investments in mainland China, with a contracted Taiwanese capital of more than 60 billion US dollars. The total trade value between the two sides of the strait has reached more than 260 billion US dollars.



In this situation, the people of Taiwan urgently demand the realization of direct "Three Links." With mainland China and Taiwan both joining the World Trade Organization, mainland China has established more intimate economic relations with Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Macao. Undoubtedly, this trend will further enhance the common economic interests of people across the strait, promote the common development and prosperity of the strait economies, and become an important force maintaining and promoting cross-strait relations, as well as realizing national unification.

The process by which the Communist Party of China is advancing the cause of national unification clearly states: "Peaceful reunification, one country, two systems" is the basic policy for national unification. It represents the creative development of Marxist strategy thought by Chinese Communists on how to achieve national unity; the efforts of the Communist Party of China to promote peaceful reunification of the motherland represent the common interests and wishes of all Chinese people and compatriots at home and abroad; adhering to these basic policies and realizing full national unification as soon as possible is an unshakable belief of all descendants of China and an irresistible trend of historical development.

Fourth, establish a comprehensive foreign relationship pattern for the new century. Maintaining and developing independent and peaceful diplomatic thoughts is a new contribution the Chinese Communists have made to Marx's diplomatic thoughts in the 20th century. This idea has further enhanced the ability of the Chinese Communist Party to handle international affairs in its foreign dealings. The construction of an all-round and multi-level diplomatic relationship structure, the rapid development of various partnerships, and frequent diplomatic activities at the top level - all these are manifestations of the enhanced ability of the Communist Party of China to handle international affairs. All of these reflect a "newer" sense in which the Chinese Communist Party advances and develops Marxism's diplomatic thinking.

From a practical perspective, since the mid-1990s, Chinese diplomacy has mainly faced three tasks: first, responding to the various changes in international relations brought about by the trend toward multipolarity, and establishing an all-rounded, multi-tiered foreign relationship pattern for the 21st century; second, opposing all forms of hegemonism and power politics, maintaining world peace, and promoting a more just and equitable new international political and economic order, in order to safeguard the rights and interests of countries around the world, especially those of the majority of developing countries; third, dealing with the impact on China brought on by the trend of economic globalization and rapid development of high technology.

Under the leadership of the Party Central Committee with Jiang Zemin at the core, our country fully implemented the established basic foreign policies and enriched and developed their ideological connotations according to changes in the international situation and new practice. The independent feature of Chinese foreign policy is even more prominent. Its outstanding performances are: first, everything starts from national interests, always puts national sovereignty and security in the first place, and will not allow any country to interfere in our country's internal affairs. Second, adhering to our specific national conditions, we determine independently the areas and speed of opening up - persevering in expanding opening up, fully utilizing the various beneficial conditions and opportunities brought by economic globalization, while also maintaining sober understanding of potential risks, strengthening prevention, and realistically maintaining national economic security. Third, firmly upholding real non-alignment. China not only doesn't ally with any country, it also doesn't lead the flag in the world socialist movement and doesn't take the lead among developing countries. Fourth, respecting the diversity of the world and handling international affairs in the spirit of mutual respect and seeking common ground while reserving differences, to promote democratization in international relations.

Chinese diplomacy also shows new characteristics in form. One is that head-of-state diplomacy has played an unprecedented and irreplaceable important role. Chinese leaders have frequently appeared at important international occasions, which has expanded China's international influence and demonstrated an increase in China's international status.



Secondly, in the partnerships and cooperative relationships established between our country and other countries and regional organizations, a multi-level system of regular meetings, consultations, and dialogues has been widely established. This new mechanized operational method not only improves the effectiveness of bilateral and multilateral cooperation, but also helps to stabilize and further develop the relationships among all parties. Thirdly, the Communist Party of China focuses on practical results, exchanges governance experiences extensively with ruling parties and legal opposition parties around the world, and carries out cooperation, making party-to-party relations serve national development strategies and overall diplomacy, providing an important guarantee for the long-term stability and healthy development of national relations. 

At the turn of the century, our country has basically established a comprehensive, multi-level diplomatic relationship pattern. Since the reform and opening up, our country's diplomacy has been developing in this direction. In the second half of the 1990s, this work made considerable progress. When constructing an external relationship pattern for the 21st century, our country considered both relationships with major countries and developed countries, and relationships with neighboring countries and the vast number of developing countries; also paying attention to developing bilateral relations with various countries and actively conducting multilateral diplomatic activities; it attaches importance to relationships between governments of various countries and is keen to develop the relationship between the Communist Party of China and political parties in various countries around the world. Furthermore, it emphasizes conducting various forms of people-to-people diplomacy.

Stabilizing and developing relations with big countries and developed countries is of great significance for our country's socialist modernization, and for maintaining world peace and development. In the mid-1990s, our country's leaders proposed to actively strive to develop a new type of big country relationship mainly characterized by non-alignment, non-confrontation, and non-targeting the third party. Based on this principle, our country has successively established and developed a basic framework for bilateral relations for the 21st century with Russia, the United States, France, the United Kingdom, Japan and Canada, and the European Union.

China and the United States are the largest developing country and the largest developed country in the world, respectively. There have always been some contradictions and differences between China and the United States. Some differences may hardly be eliminated over a considerable length of time. However, regarding major issues concerning world peace and development, the two countries also share common interests. For this reason, although there are ups and downs in China-US relations, the overall trend is continuous development. Chinese leaders have consistently viewed China-US relations with strategic vision and long-term perspectives, insisting on basing the development of bilateral relations on the three China-US joint communiqués, and advocate dealing with differences between the two countries in the spirit of mutual respect, equal consultation, and seeking common ground while reserving differences. In October 1997, President Jiang Zemin made a state visit to the United States, and both sides declared that they would jointly strive to establish a constructive strategic partnership for the 21st century. The maintenance and development of healthy and stable relationships between China and the United States not only aligns with the fundamental interests of the people of both countries, but also contributes to the peace, stability, and development of the Asia-Pacific region and even the whole world.

China and Russia are each other’s largest neighbors. With the disintegration of the Soviet Union in 1991, China and Russia immediately established diplomatic relations, achieving a smooth transition from China-Soviet relations to China-Russia relations. The relationship between the two countries has since entered a new stage of mutual respect and neighborly friendship. In the second half of the 1990s, China-Russia relations made more noticeable progress.



In April 1996, President Yeltsin made a state visit to China. China and Russia signed a "Joint Declaration," announcing their "determination to develop equitable and trustful strategic partnership relations for the 21st century." In April 1997, President Jiang Zemin made a state visit to Russia, where both countries signed the "Joint Declaration on Multipolarization of the World and Establishment of a New International Order," expressing their willingness to strive together for a peaceful, stable, fair and rational new international political and economic order. In July 2001, President Jiang Zemin made a state visit to Russia, wherein the leaders of both nations formally signed the "China-Russia Good-Neighborly Friendship Cooperation Treaty," marking a significant milestone in their relations. China and Russia have become friendly neighbors with broad prospects for exchanges and cooperation in various fields.

Since 1991, relations between China and Western Europe have returned to normalcy, entering a stage of steady development. Frequent visits between Chinese and European leaders have vigorously promoted the development of bilateral relationships. In September 1994, during his visit to France, President Jiang Zemin proposed four principles for the relationship between China and Western Europe, expressing his willingness to develop long-term stable friendly cooperative relations for the 21st century. In 1997 and 1998, China established comprehensive partnership relations with France and the UK respectively. The European Union, as a significant regional organization, has adopted a series of measures conducive to the development of Sino-European relations. In 1998, the first summit between China and the European Union was held in London, and both sides issued a joint declaration, stressing China and the EU's willingness to establish long-term, stable, constructive partnerships for the 21st century. The EU then decided to raise its relations with China to the same level of importance as with the U.S., Japan, and Russia. With mutual efforts, cooperation between China and European countries in various fields all show promising prospects. 

China and Japan are neighbors across a strait. Since the normalization of diplomatic relations in 1972 and the signing of the Treaty of Peace and Friendship in 1978, Sino-Japanese relations have entered a new period of comprehensive progress with advancements made in all areas. In 1998, President Jiang Zemin paid a state visit to Japan, and both sides issued the "China-Japan Joint Declaration", announcing that China and Japan will establish a "friendly cooperation relationship dedicated to peace and development". At the same time, Japan formally acknowledged its aggression towards China, expressed deep reflection and apology, and jointly confirmed with China that a correct understanding and handling of history is an important basis for the further development of Sino-Japanese relations. The development of Sino-Japanese relations has been generally smooth, with continuous progress made in friendly exchanges and win-win cooperation in various fields, bringing important benefits to both countries, and making positive contributions to peace, stability, and development in the region and the world.

Developing friendly relations with neighboring countries, maintaining peace and stability, promoting common development are some of China's important diplomatic goals. At the beginning of the 1990s, China normalized its relations with all its surrounding countries. Since then, China's relations with its neighboring countries have continued to develop.



China has established diplomatic relations with Central Asian countries and established the "Shanghai Five" mechanism, as well as the "Shanghai Cooperation Organization" of six countries, including China, Russia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. It has also participated in the six-party talks with China, North Korea, South Korea, the U.S., Japan, and Russia aimed at establishing a peace mechanism on the Korean Peninsula, making significant contributions to maintaining peace and stability in the Korean peninsula and Northeast Asia.

The relationship between China and ASEAN is noteworthy. In 1996, China became a full dialogue partner of ASEAN. At the end of 1997, both sides issued the "China-ASEAN Summit Joint Declaration", defining the goal of establishing a neighborly and trustful partnership towards the 21st century and guiding principles of the bilateral relations. On disputed issues such as the South China Sea issue, China clearly stated its willingness to resolve relevant disputes through peaceful negotiations in accordance with internationally recognized laws and other principles and legal systems. After the outbreak of the Asian financial crisis, China provided aid to relevant countries through bilateral and multilateral channels, and kept its promise not to devalue the RMB, which was widely praised internationally. Since the 21st century, China's mutual and beneficial cooperation with ASEAN countries in various fields has been continuously expanding, playing an important role in promoting regional peace and stability.

Strengthening and developing friendly and cooperative relations with South Asian countries is an important part of China’s efforts to stabilize its surroundings. In November 1996, President Jiang Zemin paid a state visit to India. During his visit, he proposed a five-point proposition for China and South Asian countries to jointly build long-term and stable neighborly relationships for the future. The two countries decided to establish a constructive partnership for the future based on the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence. Subsequently, China and Pakistan also announced their joint efforts to build a comprehensive cooperative partnership for the 21st century. In early 2002, as soon as the new Afghan government was established, the Chinese government immediately recognized and supported it. The improvement and development of China's relations with South Asian countries has played a significant role in maintaining peace and stability in this region.

Active multilateral diplomacy is a prominent feature of China's foreign policy at the turn of the century. Since 1971 when China resumed its rightful seat at the United Nations, it has gradually participated in activities in all areas of multilateral diplomacy centered on the United Nations. By the mid-1980s, China had clearly included multilateral diplomacy as a major component of its independent and peaceful foreign policy. In the 1990s, China was increasingly active in the field of multilateral diplomacy, achieving noticeable successes.

Opposing hegemonism and power politics and protecting the interests of developing countries is an important principle followed by China in multilateral diplomatic activities. After the end of the Cold War, in response to the Western countries' interference in the domestic affairs of developing countries under various pretexts, China has always insisted on respecting national sovereignty and independence, non-interference in internal affairs, and principles of equality and mutual benefit, closely cooperating and mutually supporting with the vast number of developing countries, effectively resisting and confronting various bullying actions in international relations.



Since 1990, with the support of third-world countries, China has successfully defeated anti-China proposals put forward by Western countries ten times consecutively at the United Nations Human Rights Council. China supports and actively participates in the various initiatives conducted by organizations like the United Nations to promote dialogue between the North and the South and to boost South-South cooperation. China has established effective collaborative relations with the Group of 77 and participates as an observer in the Non-Aligned Movement.

Establishing a new international political and economic order is a major issue in contemporary international relations. As early as the late 1980s, Deng Xiaoping advocated for the establishment of a new international political and economic order based on the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence. After the Cold War, this issue became even more prominent. The Chinese government believes that the new international political and economic order should ensure sovereignty equality and non-interference in the internal affairs of all countries, guarantee equal rights to participate in international affairs and equal rights to development, especially protecting the development rights of the majority of developing countries. In March 1999, President Jiang Zemin delivered a speech during his visit to Switzerland, comprehensively explaining China's fundamental position on the establishment of a new international political and economic order.

In the 1990s, an important part of our country's multilateral diplomatic activities was the negotiations to join the World Trade Organization (WTO). Because of historical reasons, for some time after the establishment of New China, it did not participate in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Since beginning its reform and opening-up, in July 1986, the Party Central Committee decided to restore our country's status as a contracting party to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to suit the needs of the situation, and immediately established a specialized agency to organize foreign negotiation work. The negotiations of our country "restoring relations" and joining the WTO were always under the leadership of the Party Central Committee. Throughout the 15 years of negotiation, our country always adhered to three principles: that the WTO, as an international organization, is incomplete without the participation of China, the largest developing country; that China can only join as a developing country; that China’s rights and obligations to join the WTO must be balanced. After continuous efforts and difficult negotiations, China finally reached an agreement with the relevant parties. On November 10, 2001, the World Trade Organization’s Fourth Ministerial Conference held in Doha, Qatar’s capital, reviewed and approved China’s decision to join the WTO by consensus. China's admission greatly stepped towards the WTO becoming a truly global trade organization, and it had a significant impact on our country's economic system reform and economic development.

In the 1990s, China initiated and participated in a series of regional multilateral organizations with an open attitude. China clearly expressed its support for developing varied forms of regional dialogue and cooperation on the basis of equal participation, consensus through consultation, seeking common ground while shelving differences, and making gradual progress. It actively promoted the establishment of a multilateral trust mechanism with neighboring countries to maintain regional security and stability and promote regional economic development. In October 2001, the 9th Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Leaders' Informal Meeting was held in Shanghai. This was the highest-level and largest international conference ever held in China.



The successful holding of this conference has played a positive role in promoting economic recovery and development in the Asia-Pacific region. In the early 21st century, although the international situation has undergone drastic changes, the major trend of development has not changed. The 16th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, held in November 2002, pointed out: Peace and development are still the theme of the current era. Maintaining world peace and promoting common development is the common wish of the people of all countries and an irresistible historical trend. The development of the trend of world multipolarity and economic globalization has brought opportunities and favorable conditions for the world's peace and development. A new world war cannot be launched in the foreseeable future, and it is possible to achieve a peaceable international environment and a good neighboring environment for a long period. China will uphold the principle of maintaining world peace and promoting common development in line with an independent and peaceful foreign policy.

V. Actively promote military reform with Chinese characteristics

The focus of military struggle preparation is laid on winning local wars under high-tech and informational conditions, and strengthening the quality of army building. This is the new military strategic policy established by the party's central committee in the 1990s and into the new century, based on the changes in the trend of world military development. This strategic policy is a further development on the basis of the 1980s, it is more in line with the requirements of the science and technology background and military strategic development of the 1990s. 

1. Establishing a military strategic guideline under high-tech conditions
In the early 1990s, there were two significant changes in world military affairs: one was the end of the Cold War, and the collapse of the Warsaw Pact, one of the two major military groups; the other was the revolutionary development of high technology represented by microelectronics and information science in the military field. The first change makes large-scale wars less likely, and local wars are more probable. The second change has led to an ongoing military revolution, the war model of the pre-industrial era characterized by pouring steel will become a thing of the past, and the arms race characterized by high-technology and information is on rise. Under this trend, countries around the world are accelerating military reforms in an effort to establish a compact armed force that is of high quality, sufficient, and fitted.

Faced with the new situation, the new Central Military Commission, with Jiang Zemin at its core, made another major adjustment to China's national defense strategic policy in a timely manner. The expanded Military Commission meeting held at the beginning of 1993 decided to base our army's strategic policy on winning local wars under modern technology, especially high-tech conditions, accelerate the qualitative construction of the People's Liberation Army, and improve its emergency combat readiness. To implement the new strategic policy, the Central Military Commission also put forward two "fundamental changes" centered on the concept of "strengthening the military through technology", that is, transforming from dealing with local wars under general conditions to winning local wars under modern technology, especially high-tech conditions; in terms of military construction, transforming from a quantity-scale model to a quality-effectiveness model, and from a labor-intensive model to a technology-intensive model. This is the second adjustment of the national defense strategic policy made by our army after entering the 1990s.



High-tech requires high investment as a strong backing, while national construction also requires the military to "endure" and "tighten its belt for a few years". Faced with this contradiction, our country's defense research and equipment have for a long period of time taken a path of concentrating limited financial and physical resources to make breakthroughs in key areas, to ensure that we have the "ability to fight back" against any strong enemy once something happens. But the cost of doing this is that the pace of army equipment development slows down again, and the gap between our equipment level and that of developed countries in the world further widens.

After Jiang Zemin took office as Chairman of the Military Commission, the direct issue he faced was how to build our military to higher standards, to accelerate the pace of military construction, and to adjust military strategic guidelines in response to new situations and tasks.

In December 1990, not long after Jiang Zemin took office as Chairman of the Central Military Commission, he put forward the overall requirements for army construction under the new situation at an important military work conference held by the General Staff Department, namely: "Politically qualified, militarily tough, strictly disciplined, strongly supported, and good in style.". These five sentences constitute the fundamental direction of military construction in the new period and also cover the basic content of army construction. This is an inheritance and development of Deng Xiaoping's overall guideline and task of building a strong modern and regular revolutionary army proposed in 1981.

After the overall requirements for army construction were formulated, a major topic to be solved was to put forward new military strategic guidelines under the new situation. On this issue, Jiang Zemin proposed not long after taking office as chairman of the Military Commission: The ultimate goal of military strategy is governance. A country, a nation, to survive and develop, to stand firm in fierce international competition, cannot be without the correct military strategic guidelines.

So, in which direction should the new military strategic guidelines be adjusted? This was the direct problem faced by the new military commission. On this issue, on November 9, 1992, Jiang Zemin clearly stated at a military work conference that the international situation is developing rapidly, and we must closely observe and grasp the development and changes of the situation and determine our military strategic guidelines correctly.

Based on Jiang Zemin's idea, the Military Commission held a symposium on military strategic issues in December of the same year. After full consideration and discussion, Vice Chairman of the Military Commission, General Zhang Zhen, made a preliminary summary of the new military strategic guidelines in his concluding remarks at the symposium: We should base ourselves on being able to win a local war under high-tech conditions. After this forum, the General Staff organized multiple investigations in accordance with the intent of the Military Commission, and the Standing Committee of the Military Commission also went through multiple discussions, finally reaching a consensus.

In early 1993, the enlarged meeting of the Central Military Commission was held, at which Jiang Zemin, on behalf of the Central Military Commission, formally proposed the military strategic guidelines for our army under the new situation, that is, "to base the focus of military struggle preparation on winning a local war under modern technology, especially high-tech conditions.



"
2. Promoting military reform under the new situation with "Winning" and "No Degeneration" as the direction
Under the guidance of the overall requirements for military construction and the general policy of military strategy in the 1990s, the Central Military Commission led the whole army to carry out continuous and in-depth reforms in all aspects of army and national defense construction, with "Winning", "No Degeneration" as the direction, and "Quality military building" and "Science and technology strengthen the army" as the goals.

(1) Further strengthen the ideological and political construction of the army. The most important part of implementing the overall requirements for army building in the new period is to persist in the party's absolute leadership over the army, and put ideological and political work in the first place of all the work of the whole army.
After the 14th National Congress of the Party, the first decision made by the Central Military Commission was to reaffirm the promotion of the tradition of the old Red Army and adhere to the principle of the party commanding the gun. The education of insisting on the party's absolute leadership over the army was widely and deeply carried out throughout the army, which strengthened the consciousness and determination of the majority of officers and soldiers to obey the party's absolute leadership and adhere to the party's basic line.
After the Fifteenth National Congress of the Party, in accordance with the unified deployment of the Party Central Committee, the whole army carried out phase-by-phase study and education activities mainly on "learning, politics, and integrity" from top to bottom, and extensively carried out education activities on learning and practicing the "Three Represents" important thoughts. The Military Commission and the General Political Department have formulated a series of resolutions and regulations aimed at the "Opinions of the General Political Department on Strengthening the Education Management of Middle and High-Level Cadres in the Army", "Opinions on Implementing the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China's "Decision on Strengthening and Improving the Party's Style of Work", "Decisions on Several Issues Concerning the Construction of Political Thought in the Army under the Conditions of Reform, Opening up and the Development of the Socialist Market Economy", etc. The ideological and political work of the whole army revolves around ensuring the party's real mastery of the troops in thought and politics, continuously strengthening the consciousness and determination to listen to the party and follow the party, carrying out in-depth theoretical arming and patriotic dedication education, instilling a revolutionary outlook on life, respecting and loving the soldiers, and hard work education. The Outline of Grassroots Construction of the Army is fully implemented, and efforts are made to lay a solid foundation for troop construction.
From 1992 to 2001, the whole army held nearly 10,000 theory study classes of various types, and 85% of the cadres above the regiment level had been trained. The enthusiasm of the grassroots officers and soldiers was greatly enhanced in the competition and excellence activities, with 60,000 advanced companies and 3.6 million excellent soldiers emerging in the "Striving for Advanced Company and Excellent Soldier" activity. The strong ideological and political work guarantees the coordinated development and overall progress of the military construction.

(2) Reform the command structure of the Chinese People's Liberation Army. The military reform in the 1990s was multifaceted, marked by the establishment of the General Equipment Department, and all reforms were fully advanced. These reforms include the reform of our army's command structure marked by the establishment of the General Equipment Department; the reform of the education and training system aimed at "winning"; and the reform of our army's logistical support system marked by the joint logistics of the three services.



On April 5, 1998, the General Armament Department of the People's Liberation Army of China was officially established. This was a significant reform of our military command structure, changing from a tripartite structure to a four-department system. The establishment of the "General Armorment" signifies that under the guidance of new military strategic guidelines, the People's Liberation Army will place more emphasis on the research and improvement of weaponry than ever before. Weapons and equipment provide the material foundation for "victory", and the establishment of the "General Equipment" department is of great significance for strengthening the leadership of weapons and equipment research and production, unified management, and overall planning.

In order to resolve the contradiction between the actual needs of the military and the overall situation of national economic construction, Jiang Zemin, the chairman of the military commission, proposed a very incisive idea: to highlight the key points, to have something to do, something not to do, to rush and not to rush, and to accelerate the creation of several "killer moves" that frighten our enemies. Guided by this concept, after ten years of effort, our military has upgraded its main battle tanks, naval vessels, and combat aircraft; developed unique features in certain missiles and stealth countermeasures technology; and achieved notable achievements in the field of aerospace.

(3) Improvement of military education and training system and further reduction of troop numbers. The fundamental determinant of war's outcomes is people, and the quality of people is of paramount importance to the win or lose of modern wars, especially in high-tech localized wars. Since the 1990s, the entire army has implemented several powerful reforms to the military talent education and training system.

In order to cultivate important military talent, the Central Military Commission has made significant adjustments to the military academy system of the entire army. To meet the needs of winning local wars under high-tech conditions and cultivate talented personnel for a strong army of science and technology, five comprehensive universities have been newly established: the University of Defense Science and Technology, the Information Engineering College, the University of Science and Technology, the Naval Engineering University, and the Air Force Engineering University. The cultivation of military talents has also stepped out of the single-path model of the past, gradually forging a dual-path that includes self-training and reliance on national education. More than fifty higher education institutions, including Peking University and Tsinghua University, have undertaken the task of training officers for the military, sending large numbers of outstanding talents to the military each year.

According to statistics from 2002, there are more than 30,000 officers with doctoral or master's degrees in the entire army. In combat units, the percentages of leaders at the military, division, and regiment levels with at least a college education level are 88%, 90%, and 75% respectively, and the proportion of military officers with a college degree or above in the entire military is 71.8%.

Another important measure to build a quality military and a technology-strong military is to reduce the number of troops, taking the path of a lean military with Chinese characteristics. In September 1997, at the 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, Jiang Zemin announced: On the basis of reducing the number of troops by 1 million in the 1980s, China will further reduce the number of troops by 500,000 in the next three years. This major strategic decision is made according to the new changes in the international situation and the internal law of military construction.



The People's Liberation Army of China still has a total force of over 3 million (including civilian personnel) despite the drastic reduction of a million in force since 1985. This number is obviously still on the high side, but large-scale disarmament is restricted by various factors within and outside the military, and it is impossible to accomplish it in one go. It can only be done in a planned and phased manner. The reduction of 500,000 is a firm and prudent arrangement to reduce the number of troops and improve their quality. The secondary effects it brings will not merely be a reduction in numbers. Along with deepening reforms, the structure and quality of our army will climb to a new level, and overall combat effectiveness will inevitably be strengthened. By 2002, the total staff of the People's Liberation Army (including regular and reserve forces) remained within 2.5 million.
(4) All commercial activities of the military and armed police forces are cancelled. Since the reform and opening up, the army has been obedient to the overall situation of the country with economic construction at the centre, and has been living a tight life. To solve economic difficulties, the army and the armed police forces have widely carried out commercial and industrial production activities for a period. The majority of the funds obtained were used to improve the living, working, and training conditions of the troops. However, as time went on, some negative impacts gradually emerged, mainly distracting the attention of leaders at all levels and nurturing unhealthy tendencies.
Soon after Jiang Zemin assumed the chairmanship of the Military Commission, he pointed out that the army should eat the "Imperial Grain". As a result, the Military Commission took measures to gradually shrink and clean up the army's production and operation activities, and finally, according to its unified deployment, stopped all commercial activities in July 1998. Within the stipulated period, the military and armed police forces handed over or revoked thousands of commercial enterprises and trade companies. The troops fully implemented the orders of the Military Commission, reflecting the military's consistent good style of subordination to the overall situation and obedience to the ban.
After the military and armed police forces ceased all commercial activities, to ensure the living conditions of the troops, especially for the grassroots soldiers to serve the country willingly and to create good conditions for their devotion to national defence, the state allocated a huge amount of special funds for this purpose. The headquarters of the People's Liberation Army adhered to the use of funds tilted towards combat troops, border troops and grassroots units since the 90s of the 20th century, and invested more than 1.6 billion yuan, implementing supporting rectification projects for the living facilities of troops stationed in remote and difficult border areas. Many border posts and troops on plateaus and islands have moved into standard camps, ate fresh vegetables, had hot showers, and watched television. The non-operating agricultural sideline production of the troops has not been reduced, but strengthened. In implementing the "Vegetable Basket" project, over half of the regiments in the entire army achieved a self-sufficiency rate of 70% for major side dishes, and a considerable number of units basically achieved self-sufficiency for meat and vegetables. To improve the cultural life of grassroots soldiers, the headquarters also allocated special funds to greatly improve grassroots cultural facilities and promote the development of grassroots cultural activities.
(5) Strengthen the legal governance of the army.



In view of the new situations and problems brought about by the social environment of developing a socialist market economy to the construction of the armed forces, the military commission particularly emphasized the importance of governing the army according to law during the reforms in the 1990s. In addition to revising the traditional three major orders (namely, the internal affairs orders, disciplinary orders, and combat orders), the National People's Congress, the State Council, and the Central Military Commission have also formulated and promulgated a series of laws, regulations, and orders. These include specialized laws related to the army and national defense construction such as the National Defense Law, the Conscription Law, the Active Duty Officers Law, the Military Facilities Protection Law, and more; over a thousand military regulations such as the Conscription Work Regulations, the National Defense Traffic Regulations, the Command Headquarters Regulations, the Political Department Work Regulations, the Logistics Regulations, and Weapons Equipment Management Regulations were established. Over 2000 corresponding rules have been formulated by the four headquarters, various military services and major military regions.

After continuously completing the three five-year legal education plans, the entire army conducted the fourth five-year legal education in 2001. In the legal education, with a focus on military regulations, the entire army carried out extensive learning about legal knowledge. Many grassroots units of the troops also conducted legal consultation activities during the legal education, assisting the vast majority of officers and soldiers in resolving legal issues encountered in daily life, learning to use legal means to protect the lawful rights and interests of military personnel and their families, and enhancing their understanding of the legal system. At the turn of the century, the army and the construction of national defense basically could rely on laws and regulations to operate. Incorporating army construction into a track of legalization greatly ensured and promoted the modernization and standardization construction of the army.

In addition to the aforementioned reforms, the People's Liberation Army has also carried out a series of reforms including conscription system, officer service system, army housing system, military insurance system, and operational command system. Through these reforms, the overall military and political quality of the troops has been greatly improved.

3. Following the path of elite soldiers with Chinese characteristics under informatization conditions

Entering the 21st century, a series of new changes occurred in both international and domestic environments, and informatization has increasingly become prominent in the high-tech field, which is a significant feature of these changes. In response to this change, the Central Military Commission timely adjusted its military strategic principles, transferring from winning modern wars, especially high-tech local wars, to winning local wars under the conditions of informatization. At the same time, it proposed the construction and development goals of the military, referred to as "three offers, one role". This has further realized the advancement of the military strategic thinking of the Communist Party of China, formed the latest achievement of Marxist military thinking, and thus promoted this thinking to a new height in the new century and new stage.

Since the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe in the 1990s, the US's foreign policy has been attempting to dominate the world alone, which has sharply conflicted with efforts from many countries including China to multipolarize the world. For a period of time, due to the lack of effective constraints on the US in the world, the US acted almost recklessly worldwide. Statistics show that during this period, the number of times the US used force to intervene in other countries' internal affairs was twice as high as during the Cold War. The enhancement of its soft power also greatly exceeded the level of US-Soviet contention.



In recent years, with the rapid development of China, the United States has increasingly strengthened its encirclement and suppression of us in various respects. There exist contacts, cooperation, struggles, and compromises between China and the U.S. The rivalry between both parties extends to many aspects including politics, economy, military, and diplomacy.
Since the reform and opening-up, the high-speed growth of China's economy has not only brought tremendous progress to our country but also made significant contributions to the global economy, a consensus shared by the majority of countries today. However, not everyone is pleased by this, some hostile forces are always bent on obstructing China's development, laying out obstacles covertly and overtly. Concurrently, as the trend of economic globalization accelerates, the integration of various national economies is becoming increasingly quick, and mutual involvements in the business realm have become a global trend. With today's booming economy and technology, the extension of national interests is also actively expanding. In the agricultural age, the frontier of national interest was limited to the territory, the industrial age extended it to the ocean, it spread to the sky after World War II, and in the era of high technology, it has spread to space. In today's information era, it reaches even further into the electromagnetic fields. The expansion of the frontier of national interests demands the military's role to pavé along as well, providing a strong security guarantee and strategic support for the maximization of national interests.

The rapid changes in international and military situations have quickly drawn the attention of our military. As mentioned in an article in the "People's Liberation Army Daily" on January 1, 2002, "In the new year, we will continue to focus on joint operations in the information age, focusing on the basic theory of joint operations, especially foreign militaries' theory and practice of joint operations, strive to reflect the general rules of joint operations, and in combination with the actual situation of our military, propose countermeasures for joint operations, talent cultivation, joint operations training, etc., enhance the joint operations capability of our military". From the historical mission of national unity, entering the new century, the situation of national unity in our country is still not optimistic. The Taiwan independence forces are rampant on the island, continuously provoking the bottom line of my peaceful reunification. While making the utmost efforts to achieve peaceful reunification of the motherland, we also have to be ready for military struggle at any time.

These new era characteristics are posing higher demands on the functions of our military. At the expanded meeting of the Central Military Commission on September 20, 2004, the retired Chairman of the Military Commission Jiang Zemin pointed out: "We must have a broad perspective, foresight, and continuously innovate and actively cope with the severe challenges of the new military reforms worldwide. With the urgency of 'time waits for no one', we will promote the military reform with Chinese characteristics, to complete the dual historical tasks of mechanization and informatization construction, and unswervingly achieve the strategic goal of building an informatized military and winning informatized wars."

Hu Jintao, who had just taken over as chairman of the Military Commission at the same meeting, also asked the army to "continually improve the abilities of strengthening ideological and political construction in the troops, grasping the correct direction of troop building, leading military struggle preparations, leading troops to complete combat tasks under informatization conditions, pushing forward military reform with Chinese characteristics, promoting mechanized and informatized troop construction, and strictly governing the army and strengthening the normalization of troop construction".

The white paper on national defense released by China in 2004 officially announced: "The People's Liberation Army is based on winning local wars under conditions of informatization, emphasizing the strengthening of weapons and equipment construction, joint operations capacity building, and battlefield construction. Adhere to the idea of people's war, develop the strategy and tactics of people's war..."



Adapting to the requirements of integrated joint warfare, we must establish a modern warfare system that can fully exert the overall effectiveness of armed forces and national war potential." At this point, our army began the third transformation of military strategy in the new era, that is, from winning a localized war under the conditions of modern technology, especially high technology, to winning a localized war under informationized conditions. 
According to the requirements of this new military strategy, Chairman Hu Jintao, representing the Central Military Commission, promptly adjusted the historical mission of our army. On March 13, 2005, Chairman Hu Jintao delivered an important speech at the plenary meeting of the delegation of the People's Liberation Army at the Third Session of the Tenth National People's Congress, requiring the army to "provide an important guarantee for the party to consolidate its ruling position, provide a strong security guarantee for safeguarding the country's important strategic opportunities, provide a powerful strategic support for safeguarding the national interests, and play an important role in safeguarding world peace and promoting common development." The "three provides, one role," reflect the new requirements of the party's historical task for our army, adapt to the new changes in our country's security situation, reflect the new needs of the national development strategy, conform to the new trends in world military development, grasp the key issues concerning the construction of the army, further expand the functions and tasks of our army, clarify the development goals of national defense and army construction, raise the standards for military struggle preparedness, and enrich the guiding principles for the application of military power. Hu Jintao's important exposition, in line with the important thoughts of Mao Zedong, Deng Xiaoping, and Jiang Zemin on the historical mission of our army, is a major innovation in the party's military guidance theory, marking our party's understanding of the law of national defense and army construction in the new century and stage has reached a new realm.
The new mission given to the Chinese People's Liberation Army by the Party Central Committee and the Central Military Commission is of epoch-making significance. In the past, the Chinese Communist Party's understanding of the historical mission of the people's army was relatively general. It was generally considered that the army was the "strong pillar" of people's democratic dictatorship and the "great wall of steel" defending the motherland. But the new historical mission is no longer just based on political belief, it is based on the commanding heights of the times and comprehensively examines the functions and roles of China's armed forces from the needs of a broader and deeper era.
Although the four aspects covered by the new historical mission are not completely new points for the first time, they form a rigorous logical relationship as a whole for the first time in history. The party in command of the gun is the basic principle of the establishment of the people's army; Marxist state theory believes that the army is a major component of the state. On the basis of these two basic principles, in the state of people's democratic dictatorship, the armed forces must be firmly held in the hands of the ruling party of the working class and play an important role in its effective rule. Positive and negative lessons have repeatedly proved that if these two points are firmly grasped, the cause of socialism will develop forward. On the contrary, under the attack and temptation of internal and external hostile forces, the cause of the party and state is in danger of being toppled, and the interests of the people will be greatly hurt. When we face a complex international environment and a period of frequent domestic contradictions, it becomes particularly important for the army to provide an important force guarantee for the party to consolidate its ruling position.
China's modernization construction cannot be separated from a good international environment, especially in today's increasingly strong trend of global economic globalization, safeguarding world peace is also safeguarding its own development. In the past, our country's comprehensive national strength was not strong enough, so it particularly emphasized the need to seize the opportunity of peace to develop itself. Now, we have a certain foundation, the ability, and the necessity to rely on our own strength, to join all the forces that love and maintain peace in the world to create a peaceful and harmonious international environment.



The entrustment of the function of "playing a significant role in maintaining world peace and promoting common development" to our army by the Central Military Commission can be said to be timely.

Chapter Ten: The Formation of the New Great Project for Party Construction and the "Three Represents" Important Thought

The Party Central Committee, with Jiang Zemin at its core, has formed the important thought of the "Three Represents" through continual summary of experiences from vigorously advancing socialist modernization and the new great project for party construction. The important thought of the "Three Represents" further enriches and develops Marxist socialist construction theory and party building doctrine under new historical conditions. This thought is another significant achievement in the sinicization process of Marxism by the Chinese Communist Party. It fully reflects the new changes in international and domestic historical developments and the new requirements of the times, playing a crucial role in guiding all aspects of contemporary China's development. This is why the 16th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party officially established it as the guiding thought of the party.

I. Further clarify the overall objective and task of party construction, and continue to advance the new great project

Entering the 1990s, the Chinese Communist Party encountered a new condition, the socialist market economy, during the process of reform and development. Under such conditions, what kind of party should be built, how the party should be constructed, and what goals should be followed for party construction have become new topics for the Chinese Communist Party's own construction. In response to this, the third generation of central leadership, with Jiang Zemin as its core, creatively proposed the overall objective and task for party construction under socialist market conditions, based on Marxist principles of party establishment and the objective reality of China.

1. New requirements set forth by reform, opening up, and the development of the market economy for party construction

Combining the socialist system with the market economy is a great innovation, and it is also a new topic and problem. How to strengthen the party construction under socialist market economy conditions is an unprecedented endeavor and undoubtedly a new challenge for the Chinese Communist Party.

The fundamental problem that the development of a socialist market economy aims to solve is how to transform from planned to market-based. This transition inevitably leads to profound changes in all areas of society, including both the positive impacts and negative effects on party construction.

The positive impact of the market economy on party building is mainly manifested in: First, the market economy follows the basic law of value, emphasizing the principle of material interests, and insists on focusing on efficiency. Acting according to this law helps party organizations and party members to further establish a pragmatic ideological concept and work style, overcoming formalism, falsification, and detachment from reality. Second, the diversification of market entities, diversity of transaction methods, and value orientation of prioritizing efficiency and balancing fairness, help party organizations and members maintain and promote an energetic and hardworking spirit, overcoming the tendencies for conventionality and complacency.



Thirdly, the openness and fairness of market competition contribute to enhancing the democratic awareness of party organizations and party members, overcoming "monologism", and correcting the wrong practice of doing things arbitrarily. Fourthly, the unity and openness of the market system are conducive to party organizations and party members learning and drawing on the beneficial experiences from other regions and countries, overcoming closed and conservative thinking, and enhancing openness awareness. Fifthly, the market economy is a legal economy, where all kinds of market behaviors and the rights and responsibilities of market entities are regulated by laws and regulations. This regulation helps to strengthen the institutional construction thinking of party organizations and party members, and to overcome the tendency not to follow rules and regulations, and not to comply with party discipline. Sixthly, the market economy mainly regulates indirectly through the market, not emphasizing direct administrative intervention. This is conducive to properly handling the relationship between party and government, and overcoming the replacement of the government by the party.

The negative effects of the socialist market economy on party building are mainly manifested in: firstly, the market economy emphasizes material interests, and under the drive of material interests, people's world view, life view, and values can easily become distorted, breeding materialism, hedonism, and individualism. Some people may even lose their party principles, engage in power-money trading, and thus damage the image of the party. This makes the task of educating party members in ideals and beliefs, worldviews, life views, and values under the conditions of a market economy even more difficult. Secondly, the outstanding characteristic of the market economy in terms of activity is the lateral connection between market entities, which has strong spontaneity and dispersion. This can easily dilute party members' overall concept and organizational concept, breed decentralization and anarchism, and thus make the task of managing party members more difficult. Thirdly, the market economy is an open economy, which not only opens internally but also externally, connects the domestic and international markets, and participates in international division and competition as much as possible, in order to effectively allocate domestic resources and use international resources. This feature of openness, on the one hand, promotes rapid population mobility, and on the other hand, it is easy for foreign thoughts and culture to spread with the expansion of opening up. This brings instability to the party membership and difficulties to the work of unifying party members' thoughts.

The socialist market economy is a double-edged sword for party building, with both opportunities and challenges. Facing these opportunities and challenges, the Communist Party of China must adapt to the new requirements of the changing situation, clearly propose the overall goal and tasks of party building suitable for the requirements of the socialist market economy in practice, so as to strengthen its own construction with the development of the times and enhance its ability to control the market economy, and consolidate its ruling position.

2. Further clarification of the overall goal and task of party building
Clarifying the overall goal and task of party building is the primary issue of ruling party construction. After the Communist Party of China came to power, it carried out long-term explorations to establish correct party building goals. After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, with the shift of the focus of the party's work, it proposed to build the party into a strong core leading the socialist modernization drive, thus defining the direction of party building during the entire socialist historical period. After the Fourth Plenary Session of the Thirteenth Central Committee, the party central committee, led by Jiang Zemin and in accordance with Deng Xiaoping's political instruction of "focusing on party building", seriously summarized the experience and lessons of party building since the reform and opening up, and actively explored new ways to strengthen party building under the conditions of a socialist market economy, clearly defining the overall goal and task of party building.



The overall goal and task of the party's construction is gradually formed in the practice of strengthening and improving the party's construction by the central leadership collective with Jiang Zemin at the core. In August 1989, the central government issued a notice on strengthening the construction of the party, requiring party committees at all levels to resolutely solve the urgent problems in the current party construction in accordance with the requirements of the party's basic line, so that the party could withstand the test of governance, the test of reform and opening up and the development of commodity economy, as well as the test against peaceful evolution. In March 1990, the 13th Central Committee's Sixth Plenary Session emphasized in the decision on strengthening the connection between the party and the masses that now, our party, and the country are at a critical period of historical development. The relationship between the party and the masses, and the relationship between cadres and the masses are generally good. But in recent years, some party members and cadres have also seen serious corruption phenomena that are disconnected from the masses, which all comrades in the party must remain highly vigilant and persist in fighting against. In 1992, the 14th Congress of the Party highlighted the tasks of learning Deng Xiaoping’s theory of socialism with Chinese characteristics, strengthening party construction, strengthening relations between the party and the masses, strengthening the construction of grassroots organizations, and persevering and improving democratic centralism in line with the needs of a socialist market economy. 

To implement the tasks of party construction proposed by the 14th Congress, and make party construction compatible with the reform of the socialist market economy system, the 14th Central Committee's Fourth Plenary Session held in September 1994 made the "Decision on Several Major Issues of Strengthening the Party's Construction" (referred to as the "Decision"). The "Decision" clearly put forward the total goal and task of the new great project of party construction, that is, "building the party into a Marxist party that is armed with the theory of socialism with Chinese characteristics, serves the people wholeheartedly, is fully consolidated ideologically, politically and organizationally, can withstand various risks, and always takes the lead in the times". According to this general goal and task, the "Decision" required to focus on solving the central link of the party's organizational construction while continuing to carry out central deployment on ideological construction and style of work. In particular, three issues needed to be addressed: First, persist and improve democratic centralism, paying special attention to system construction; Second, strengthen and improve the construction of the party's grassroots organizations; Third, cultivate and select leaders who are both morally upright and professionally competent especially young cadres. Paying attention to system construction is an important feature of the "Decision" passed at this meeting.

In September 1997, the 15th party congress summarized the new experience of party construction and further summarized the overall goals and tasks of party construction proposed at the 14th Central Committee's Fourth Plenary Session as: "Building the party into a Marxist party that is armed with Deng Xiaoping’s theory, serves the people wholeheartedly, is fully consolidated ideologically, politically and organizationally, can withstand various risks, always takes the lead in the times, and leads the entire nation in building socialism with Chinese characteristics." The congress called on the entire party to strengthen party construction in ideologically, organizationally, and behaviorally according to the general goal of the new grand project of party construction, continuously improve the leadership level and steadily increase the ability to resist corruption and risk, and lead the people to complete new historical tasks with a new look and stronger combat power.

3. Preliminary implementation of the overall goal and task of party construction
After the Fourth Plenary Session of the 14th Central Committee, party construction gradually started in various aspects such as ideology, politics, and organization according to the requirements of the overall goals and tasks.

In terms of ideological construction, the 14th Congress of the Party established the guiding position of Deng Xiaoping's theory of socialism with Chinese characteristics in the entire party and proposed the strategic task of arming the entire party with this theory. In 1993 and 1994, after the publication of the first, second, and third volumes of Deng Xiaoping's Selected Works, the central government immediately issued a notice requesting the entire party to organize serious learning.



From the end of 1993 to May 1994, the central government successively organized 175 leaders from various departments of the party, government, and military, as well as some experts and scholars, to participate in four batches of theoretical seminars for provincial and ministerial leaders at the Central Party School, conducting diligent study of the "Selected Works of Deng Xiaoping". In order to further advance the training of cadres, in May 1996, the central government formulated the "National Cadre Education and Training Plan for 1996-2000", giving comprehensive arrangements for strengthening the ideological and theoretical education of cadres.
In the process of conducting theoretical learning throughout the Party, a complete set of study systems has been gradually established. This includes mechanisms like regular party school training for party committee members at the county level and above, study sessions of the party committee's central group, and more. In addition, organizations at all levels have adopted various forms such as organizing lecturer groups for tutoring and conducting theoretical seminars, to promote widespread learning. These measures have stimulated the enthusiasm of the vast number of Party members and cadres for learning theory, and promoted the improvement of the Party's theoretical level.
In terms of improving the democratic centralist system, after the 14th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, the CPC Central Committee gradually strengthened the building of the party's democratic centralist system in response to the problems of insufficient democracy and centralization within the party. In terms of safeguarding the democratic rights of party members, democratic channels within the party have been unhindered and expanded, allowing party members to participate more in party affairs. By establishing effective mechanisms, it is ensured that grassroots party members can timely reflect their opinions to higher party organizations through lower party organizations. Based on fully listening to the opinions of party members and lower party organizations, collective wisdom is gathered to continuously advance the scientific and democratic decision-making process. 
In rural grassroots party organization construction,  in 1990, the Central Organization Department held a meeting in Laixi, Shandong, establishing the core leadership role of the party branch in the village-level organization. In 1992, the Central Organization Department held a meeting in Zhangqiu, Shandong, summarizing and promoting the experience of "law-based establishment, rule of law village governance, democratic management", pushing the rural grass-roots organizations with the party branch as the core onto the track of standardization and institutionalization.
In terms of the construction of grassroots Party organizations in state-owned enterprises, in December 1996, the Organization Department of the CPC Central Committee, the Central Policy Research Office, the State Economic Trade Commission, the State Commission for Economic Reform, the All-China Federation of Trade Unions and other agencies held a joint meeting on the construction work of state-owned enterprises in Beijing.



In January 1997, the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) issued the "Notice on Further Strengthening and Improving the Party Building of State-owned Enterprises", which clearly specified the goals, policies, and principles of the building of party organizations in state-owned enterprises. In line with the spirit of this document, party committees at all levels, in the process of establishing a modern corporate system, uphold the party's political leadership over enterprises, play the central political role of enterprise party organizations, adhere to the policy of fully relying on the working class, and explore new pathways and methods for party building work centred around enterprise reform and development, achieving notable results and accumulating new experiences.

In terms of party building in urban streets, in June 1995, some street-level cadres from 16 provinces and cities across the country met in Tianjin to discuss how to enhance the construction of urban grassroots party organizations, and exchanged their experiences. A year later, based on a comprehensive understanding of various aspects, the Central Organization Department issued the "Opinions on Strengthening the Construction of Street Party Work" on September 3, 1996, demanding that the construction of Street Party Work should start from the characteristics and realities of urban work under the new situation, focus on improving urban management, social services, maintaining social stability and developing the street economy, strengthening the construction of the leadership team, and enhancing the quality of cadres, augment the cohesion and fighting power of the party organization, fully play the vanguard and exemplary role of party members, and serve the healthy development of the construction of material and spiritual civilization in urban socialism. In line with this spirit, cities across the country gradually established a network system for the street community party organization work, making the street community party organizations increasingly play an important role in enhancing the building of spiritual civilization and mass ideological and political work, improving comprehensive social security, strengthening the connection between the party and the masses, and elevating the quality of residents and the level of urban civilization.

In terms of party building in non-public economic organizations, this period also saw further strengthening. In areas where the non-public economy is relatively developed, party organizations have been gradually established in some foreign-invested and private enterprises, and the cohesion of party organizations and the role of Communist Party members as pioneers and role models are also well embodied in these enterprises. In September 2000, the Central Organization Department issued the "Opinions on Strengthening the Party Building in Individual and Private and Other Non-Public Economic Organizations (Trial)" based on extensive investigations, research, and summarizations of practical experiences across the country. According to this document, by June 2001, the number of party organizations established in non-public enterprises nationwide had grown to 44,000.

At the same time, the CCP Central Committee also proposed a series of new ideas and requirements for the party building work in organs, schools, research institutes, and other departments, which greatly strengthened the construction of grassroots party organizations under new historical conditions.

While strengthening the construction of grassroots party organizations, party organizations at all levels also generally strengthened the building of party member teams. According to the principles of "upholding standards, perfecting structures, developing prudently, and ensuring quality", a constant inflow of advanced individuals from various fronts have been introduced into the party member teams, thus bringing fresh blood into the party organizations. The cohesion and creativity of the party organizations have been continuously enhanced.

4. Uphold and improve democratic centralism, and strengthen the construction of the party's internal democratic system
Democratic centralism, the combination of centralism on the basis of democracy and democracy under centralized guidance, is the application of Marxist epistemology and mass line in the party's life and organization building.
